The Afghan Government ordered the Red Cross to end its activities on Oct. 8, 1982, Mr. Kurz said.

headline: I.B.M. Remains Cautious on 1986
abstract: Lingering troubles in the economy have prompted the International Business Machines Corporation to continue a cautious approach in 1986, company officials said today at the annual shareholders meeting.   ''The U.S. economy continues to show only moderate growth and has yet to emerge from the long year-and-a-half period of disappointing corporate profits and capital investment, now compounded by uncertainty over tax reform legislation,'' John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s president and chief executive officer, said. I.B.M. stock fell a bit after his remarks but rebounded later to close at $161.125, up $1.625.

headline: SOVIET, IN FIRST DETAILED ACCOUNT, TELLS OF RAGING BLAZE AT REACTOR
abstract: The Soviet party newspaper Pravda today published the first detailed account of the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine. It said an explosion on the night of April 25 touched off a raging blaze that eventually reached inside the reactor and released radioactivity.   The newspaper described desperate efforts by ''brave, bold'' firefighters to put out 100-foot-high flames while their boots sank in molten bitumen, or asphalt. It reported that ''there were some panic-stricken individuals,'' although it said most of the thousands of people who work at the plant and live nearby remained calm and orderly.

headline: PRESIDENT BEGINS TRIP TO INDONESIA
abstract: President Reagan declared today that the United States must be willing to defend its values and its citizens ''unflinchingly'' in the face of terrorism.   In remarks at a brief rest and refueling stop at Andersen Air Force Base in Guam, Mr. Reagan continued to focus on terrorism as he once again pledged resolve in combatting such attacks.   In his speech for American servicemen and their families at the Pacific base, Mr. Reagan said:   ''Many of you are thousands of miles from your own homes, and as beautiful as Guam is, I know you must miss familiar sights and sounds, and above all, your families and friends.'' 'Willing to Sacrifice'    ''Yet, you're willing to make that sacrifice, willing because you've understood all along what recent events have once again made clear.

headline: EX-AIDE TO ARAFAT, NOW A FOE, SAYS P.L.O. HAS A FORTUNE IN BANKS
abstract: A former aide who now opposes Yasir Arafat, responding to reports abroad that the Palestine Liberation Organization is going bankrupt, was quoted this week as saying the P.L.O. has amassed a fortune in bank accounts in Lebanon, Jordan and Switzerland.   The former aide is Col. Saed Musa, who since 1983 has headed a dissident faction based in Damascus that opposes Mr. Arafat's leadership of Al Fatah, the mainstream movement that is the considered the most important guerrilla group in the P.L.O.   Colonel Musa told the Beirut magazine Al Shirra that the P.L.O. had $500 million in a bank in Amman, Jordan, alone. He played down reports in the Western press that the P.L.O. is going bankrupt. ''I know,'' he said, ''because once I was a member of the Arafat entourage.''

headline: PURCHASERS' SURVEY FINDS GAINS
abstract: The pace of economic activity has picked up markedly this month, following a sluggish April, a closely watched business survey showed yesterday.   The National Association of Purchasing Managers, whose monthly Report on Business provides one of the first glimpses of overall economic conditions, said that gains in new orders, employment and an increase in inventories, the first such rise since February, helped push the purchasing managers' composite index up by more than 11 percent from April, to a seasonally adjusted 54.4 percent.

headline: DIPLOMATS SAY LIBYA IS DISTURBED AT A LACK OF SUPPORT FROM SOVIET
abstract: The Libyan Government is disturbed at what it considers a lack of support from the Soviet Union as Libya's confrontation with the United States grows more critical, according to Western and Soviet-bloc diplomats.   Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, is one of the Soviet Union's largest arms clients, and 5,000 to 6,000 Soviet-bloc military advisers are reported to be stationed here.   But the diplomats said the Russians did not pass on satellite data or other intelligence from Soviet ships in the Mediterranean as clashes unfolded between the United States Sixth Fleet and Libyan forces in and around the Gulf of Sidra three weeks ago.   At an antiaircraft missile site along the gulf, nearly 300 Soviet advisers refused to leave their underground bunkers despite Libyan appeals for help in putting up new launching pads during the incidents, the sources said. The only Russian to die during the clashes was a soldier who had a heart attack while playing soccer near Tripoli, an informed East-bloc source said.

headline: Texas Air's Plea Rejected
abstract: The Department of Transportation, citing concerns about the Texas Air Corporation's recent sale of popular air-shuttle routes to Pan American World Airways, today rejected Texas Air's plea that it be allowed to take immediate control of Eastern Air Lines.   The Department of Transportation, however, said that it would expedite its review of the $676 million merger agreement between Texas Air and Eastern by dropping lengthy hearings and oral arguments.

headline: A More Valuable Lira Is Planned for Italy
abstract: The Bank of Italy has announced plans for a new lira to be worth a thousand times more than the currency is now.

headline: 52 Vietnamese Rescued
abstract: A West German rescue ship picked up 52 Vietnamese refugees today, including a 17-day-old baby from a fishing vessel adrift in the South China Sea, the relief agency Cap Anamur said. The relief ship, the Cap Anamur II, rescued 77 refugees in a similar operation two days ago.

headline: INSIDE STATE GUEST HOUSE, VERY LITTLE OF FLAVOR OF JAPAN
abstract: The seven leaders at the economic summit conference are meeting in a state guest house that stands as a monument to Japan's capacity for well-crafted imitation.   The Akasaka Detached Towers, as it is formally known, is a replica of the Versailles Palace, down to its tapestries, gilded staircases and exuberantly painted ceilings. It is about as uniquely Japanese as a hamburger stand and apparently about as inviting. ''Unlivable'' is how Emperor Hirohito is said to have described it more than 60 years ago when he was Crown Prince.

headline: CONTRAS EXPECTING SHOWDOWN ON FEUD
abstract: A long-brewing power struggle among senior Nicaraguan guerrilla officials is expected to lead to a decisive confrontation in the coming week at a meeting of the top rebel leadership in Miami, according to several rebel officials here.   Rebel leaders and American officials who monitor the guerrilla movement say the meeting will be the most far-reaching effort so far to reorganize the leadership of the anti-Sandinista guerrillas in an effort to expand their political appeal and military effectiveness.   The meeting appears to be the culmination of a long and politically damaging debate within the rebel movement over political objectives, and it appears to reflect a power struggle among top rebel leaders. The debate has gathered force at a time when the Reagan Administration is asking Congress to renew American military aid to the Nicaraguan guerrillas.

headline: MEDIATION RESUMED IN RAIL STRIKE
abstract: Federal mediators sought today to end a railroad workers' strike in the Northeast that could harden Congressional resistance to President Reagan's proposed sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.   The strike against three small railroads owned by Guilford Transportation Industries has disrupted freight and passenger service for nearly a month in parts of the Northeast, including New York.   Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of New Jersey, the chairman of the House subcommittee overseeing the Conrail sale legislation, said the Guilford strike raised additional questions about the Conrail proposal.

headline: INDIA REBEL CHIEF TO END 20-YEAR-OLD INSURGENCY
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in a step enhancing national unity, won an agreement today from the leader of an insurgent guerrilla group to end a 20-year rebellion in mountainous northeast India.   This evening the guerrilla leader, Laldenga, head of the Mizo National Front, formally renounced the insurgency and made plans to take over as the Chief Minister of the territory of Mizoram, heading a coalition with Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party.   The Mizoram accord was widely seen as a political gain for Mr. Gandhi, even though it was not likely to have any immediate effect on the rebellion of other guerrilla groups in the northeast or on other secessionist movements in India.

headline: REGIONAL BANKS WARY OF ROLE IN LOAN PACKAGE
abstract: Small and midsized banks will again balk at participating in a financial rescue of Mexico if such a bailout involves providing significant amounts of new loans, the banks indicated yesterday.   But they added that, as in 1982, they would probably give way to pressure from the big banks and the Government to participate.   ''Do we want to give new money to Mexico? Of course not,'' said Clarke W. Miller, an executive vice president of the Bank of Boston. ''I don't think anybody is enthusiastic about it. The better questions are, 'Will we end up having to give money to Mexico, and what are the implications if we don't?' ''

headline: TREASURY SECURITIES MIXED
abstract: Prices for Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday as the credit markets awaited the release later this week of Government reports on retail sales and producer prices for fresh signals on the direction of the economy.   Following sharp declines on Monday, prices for long-term issues slumped for much of the day but rallied somewhat in a brief flurry of dealer buying just before the close of the Chicago futures market. By the end of trading in New York, the price for the Treasury's 7 1/4 percent bond due in 2016 was 94 10/32, up 6/32, to yield 7.74 percent.   In the intermediate-term market, the price for the 7 3/8 percent note due in May 1996 was 95 17/32, up 7/32, to yield 8.04 percent, and the price for the 7 1/2 percent note due in 1991 was 98 9/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.90 percent. The two-year 7 1/8 percent Treasury note ended the day at 99.21, unchanged from Monday, to yield 7.31 percent.

headline: Israeli in Disguise Learns the Anguish of an Arab
abstract: In March a Jerusalem newspaper assigned a Jewish reporter to spend six weeks circulating here and in Tel Aviv disguised as an Arab.   The account by the Arabic-speaking reporter, Yoram Binur, published last month in the newspaper, Kol Hair, provided sobering insights into the attitudes of some Israeli Jews toward Arabs, and the nature of relations between the two groups. The article has been widely discussed in Jewish and Arab circles.   To blend in, Mr. Binur, 31 years old, grew a stubbly beard - ''about the same length as Yasir Arafat's,'' he said in an interview. He draped a black-checked Arab headdress around his neck and carried a copy of the Arabic newspaper Al Fajr with a picture of Mr. Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, on the front page. In his pocket he kept a pack of Farid cigarettes, a brand sold only in East Jerusalem, the city's predominantly Arab sector.

headline: THAI CHIEF WON'T ENTER ELECTION
abstract: Thailand's Prime Minister, Prem Tinsulanonda, announced today that he would not run for a legislative seat in the election on July 27.   The decision does not rule out another term for Mr. Prem, a former general who has survived two coup attempts as he moved the country toward a more democratic system.

headline: Goldome Selects Vickers & Benson
abstract: Goldome, the Federal savings bank based in Buffalo, may have considered a couple of New York agencies but when push came to shove it decided on the Vickers & Benson Companies, Canada's biggest agency, which is in Toronto, a mere 95 miles away.   Additionally the bank, whose budget is in the $7 million to $8 million area, hired Faller, Klenk & Quinlan of Buffalo, for out-of-home media and decided on keeping Computer Marketing Services of Rochester, which has been doing its direct marketing for years.

headline: Intervention Accord Seen
abstract: Japan and West Germany have agreed to intervene in currency markets to keep the yen from climbing further, according to traders and press reports here.   At the Tokyo summit meeting of seven industrial nations this week, both Japan and West Germany made it clear that they regarded the yen, up 40 percent since last September, as too high in relation to the dollar.

headline: UNC Offerings
abstract: UNC Resources is selling $120 million of debt securities, equally divided between 10-year notes and 20-year convertible subordinated debentures, through the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. The 11 1/2 percent notes are offered at a price of 95.741 to yield 12.25 percent, while the issue of 7 1/2 percent debentures is offered at par. Each debenture is convertible into the company's common stock at $15.40 a share. The debentures and notes are rated B-3 by Moody's and B by S.&P.

headline: 4 Die in Air Force Crash
abstract: A United States Air Force jet tanker trying to land at Howard Air Base near Panama City crashed into a hill early today, killing all four crew members, officials reported.

headline: Sullivan Seeks More Pressure
abstract: The Rev. Leon Sullivan, the Philadelphia minister who developed the code of conduct for doing business in South Africa that has been endorsed by scores of American companies, said yesterday that he had asked the companies to step up their opposition to South Africa's racially discriminatory policy of apartheid.   Mr. Sullivan said had called on American companies to engage in what he called corporate civil disobedience - by refusing to fill out documents that the Government might use to control the movement of blacks, for example - and to provide legal support to employees who challenge laws on racial segregation at beaches, theaters, schools, hospitals and in housing.

headline: U.S. DOCTORS IN SOVIET FACE A 'BATTLEFIELD'
abstract: For the last two weeks, Moscow Hospital No. 6, a nine-story brown-brick building on the outskirts of the city, has been the center of a desperate effort to treat the most seriously afflicted victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.   Soviet and American doctors and an Israeli specialist, using equipment and drugs airlifted from around the world, have raced against the killing effects of radiation exposure in an attempt to save the lives of 33 men and 2 women who spent the first hours after the April 26 accident within yards of the damaged reactor.   One of the American physicians, Dr. Robert Peter Gale of the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles, said that as of Wednesday evening 7 of the 35 had died of radiation and 28 remained alive. Higher Figure Reported    Tonight, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in a nationally televised address that the death toll had risen to 9 - 2 killed in the original explosion and 7 who have died since of radiation. He said that ''as of today'' 299 people had been hospitalized with radiation disease of varying degrees. That figure was 95 more than reported by Soviet officials last week.

headline: General Mills
abstract: General Mills Inc. has no plans to spin off any of its businesses in the manner proposed by Dart & Kraft Inc., which said Thursday that it would split into two companies, a General Mills spokesman said.

headline: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS WIN SOLID VICTORY IN NATIONAL VOTE
abstract: The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez won a solid victory in national elections Sunday, according to nearly complete offical returns.   Based on returns early today from 96 percent of the ballots cast, the Interior Ministry said the Socialists had won 184 of the 350 seats in the Congress of Deputies, a drop from the 202 they held before the election but 8 more than they needed for the majority that a spectrum of rightist, leftist and centrist parties tried to deny them.   The showing of the Socialists, who have been in office for four years, was a victory for the charismatic Mr. Gonzalez, a 44-year-old politician known for his pragmatism. In rallies and television spots during the campaign, he had asserted that Spain needed to consolidate the left-of-center course he has set for the nation. Benefit Seen for Ties to U.S.  Mr. Gonzalez had called the elections four months early to take advantage of the momentum he expected after his victory in a referendum in March that kept Spain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: Advertising; Cinzano Line Moves
abstract: The advertising for the Cinzano line, which since last September has been marketed by the Paddington Corporation, is going to be done by Berenter Greenhouse & Webster. The former agency was McNamara, Clapp & Klein. The line is made up of both vermouth and Asti-Cinzano.

headline: BRITISH FIND BOMB IN A BAG BEING TAKEN ONTO EL AL JET
abstract: A carefully concealed bomb was discovered this morning at Heathrow Airport in a bag carried by a woman who was about to board an El Al flight due to leave for Tel Aviv with about 340 passsengers.   Scotland Yard said later it was ''highly likely'' that if the device had gone off it would have destroyed the Boeing 747, killing everyone aboard.   The woman, who was not named, was still in custody this evening. But the head of the Yard's antiterrorism branch, Comdr. George Churchill-Coleman, said it appeared she had carried the bomb ''in all innocence,'' having been duped by an Arab man who dropped her off at the airport. ''We believe she did not know she had explosives,'' the officer said.

headline: REAGAN SAID TO ASK SOVIET TO ACT ON SUMMIT
abstract: President Reagan sent a message to Mikhail S. Gorbachev two weeks ago calling on the Soviet leader to reschedule a meeting between the two countries' Foreign Ministers to work out arrangements for a summit meeting this year, a high-level Administration official said Saturday night.   The official said there had been no response from the Russians to the message, which was delivered to the Kremlin by Arthur H. Hartman, the American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, who returned to Moscow earlier this month after extended consultations in Washington.   Mr. Reagan, returning today from a weekend at Camp David, Md., declined to give details of his proposal to Mr. Gorbachev. As he entered the White House, Mr. Reagan said of his message to the Soviet leader, ''We just correspond - private correspondence.''

headline: Commercial Building Ebbs
abstract: Los Angeles will top all cities in the United States in nonresidential construction this year with about $3.87 billion of work, but there will be scant growth in the market for industrial, commercial and office buildings, according to a survey by the Chicago Title Insurance Company.   The largest percentage increase will be in New York City, where volume will be up 12.8 percent, to $1.61 billion, from 1985's total of $1.42 billion, the company said.

headline: NAKASONE WINS AN ACCORD ON ELECTIONS, AND HIS STOCK RISES
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone won an important victory today when leaders of Japan's governing party ended weeks of political wrangling and agreed to hold elections in both houses of Parliament this summer.   At a daylong meeting, leaders of Mr. Nakasone's Liberal Democratic Party agreed to hold an extraordinary parliamentary session, a prerequisite for the simultaneous elections.   Such a ''double'' election will not only offer the Liberal Democrats a chance to regain a clear majority in Parliament. Diplomats and others here say it also signals a turnabout in Mr. Nakasone's political fortunes only a short time after he appeared to be in serious trouble.

headline: A FORMER PREMIER IS SEEKING A COMEBACK IN SPANISH VOTE
abstract: The former Prime Minister, Adolfo Suarez, rose before a cheering crowd crammed into a small theater here.   ''In these last four years, the Socialists have been arrogant,'' he said of the Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. ''They have been autocratic. And no other party can take away votes from them better than we can.''

headline: Hijacked Plane From Taiwan Starts Its Flight Back Home
abstract: A Taiwan cargo jet that was flown to China by a defecting pilot arrived in the southern Chinese city of Canton from Peking today on the first leg of its trip back to Taiwan.

headline: IRISHMAN IS CONVICTED IN THATCHER HOTEL BOMBING
abstract: A man accused of heading an Irish Republican Army terrorist cell was found guilty today of setting a bomb that killed five people and seriously wounded 30 in an assassination attempt on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Cabinet in 1984.   The convicted man, Patrick J. Magee, was identified as the principal in one of the boldest plots against the British Government, a devastating explosion that ripped through the Grand Hotel in Brighton as Prime Minister Thatcher slept in one of the rooms early on the morning of Oct. 12, 1984.   Mr. Magee, identified as a 35-year-old Irishman, was also accused with four others of plotting an elaborate ''bomb calendar'' of I.R.A. terror in which long-term automatic timers were to detonate 16 explosions on consecutive days last summer in London and seaside tourist hotels, according to police investigators.   The jury members were still considering those charges at the Old Bailey this evening when the court ordered them to be sequestered in a hotel and to resume deliberations Wednesday.

headline: Malaysian Crisis Ends In State of Sabah
abstract: A yearlong political crisis in the Malaysian state of Sabah was resolved this week when the state's ruling party was made part of a national coalition.

headline: 'I FELT MYSELF BEING PULLED OUT, TOO'
abstract: ''There was a big bang, and then the man beside me was blown out along with his seat,'' a passenger aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 840 said today, describing the explosion aboard the Athens-bound plane.   ''I felt myself being pulled out, too, and I hung on to my wife's seat beside me,'' said the passenger, Ibrahim al-Nami, a 29-year-old Saudi.   Four people were sucked out of the plane after the blast tore a hole in the Boeing 727's fuselage, hurtling them to their deaths near the town of Argos, 120 miles southwest of Athens.   A reporter in Argos, Georgios Seraphim, said a shepherd saw the bodies falling from the sky.

headline: FRANCE ACTS TO EXPEL 4 MORE LIBYANS
abstract: France said today that it was expelling four Libyans from the country because their activities were likely to ''trouble public order.''   The French Interior Ministry announced the expulsions in a terse communique that provided no details on the Libyans' identities or the activities they planned to carry out.   Agence France Presse reported tonight that the four men, all between the ages of 20 and 25, boarded a regular Libyan commercial flight to Tripoli. The agency said the four were carrying regular, not diplomatic, passports.

headline: DURABLES ORDERS UP 0.4% IN MAY
abstract: Factory orders for big-ticket durable goods, after declining for three consecutive months, rose a slight four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department said today. But the increase came exclusively from a surge in demand for military equipment.   It was the first increase since a six-tenths of 1 percent rise in January. Orders for durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, had fallen six-tenths of 1 percent in February, 2.7 percent in March and nine-tenths of 1 percent in April.

headline: Control of Walker
abstract: The Reichmanns of Canada, who own 80 percent of the Gulf Canada Corporation, will take control today of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the oil and liquor producer, sources close to the family said.

headline: Advertising; Shearson Shifts Ads To Color
abstract: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS' television advertising is about to blossom into living color.   This will mean quite a change from the plain, stark white-on-black type that the brokerage firm has been using for three years. It was the first TV campaign created by McCann-Erickson for Shearson, and it used the firm's brief pithy comments on matters of import, generally financial, to present Shearson to individual investors as being intelligent, serious and professional.   That format is still being used, and the purpose is the same. But the target audience has grown. The acquisition of Lehman Brothers, the investment bankers, two years ago meant that corporate leaderships, as well as governments, have to be impressed by the advertising.

headline: Walker Backs Transcanada
abstract: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., as expected, yesterday endorsed a $3 billion takeover bid from Transcanada Pipelines Ltd., Canada's largest pipeline operator. The oil and liquor producer said its directors had agreed to recommend that stockholders accept Transcanada's $26.39-a-share offer.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Alaska Mutual Bancorp., Anchorage, said Joseph C. Miller had resigned as president. Barry L. Hulin was named his successor.    * Brunswick Corp., Skokie, Ill., which serves worldwide markets in marine power, recreation, defense-aerospace and industrial areas, elected Lieut. Gen. Eugene F. Tighe Jr., who serves as president of an international security consulting conern that bears his name, to its board.

headline: U.S. NAVY WARNS OFF IRANIAN VESSEL
abstract: A United States Navy ship came to the aid of an American merchant vessel in the Gulf of Oman Tuesday during an encounter between the freighter and an Iranian patrol boat, Pentagon officials said today.   The Navy destroyer, which was in the area at the time, warned the Iranians ''to stand clear to insure freedom of navigation of the United States merchant ship,'' a Pentagon statement said.   The Iranians complied, and there was never any threat of hostilities, officials said.   As the Pentagon officials spoke, the Iranian foreign minister issued a statement warning that Iran would not tolerate any United States intervention in the Persian Gulf.

headline: DISCOVERY IN WEST BERLIN: ARAB SUSPECT VISITED LIBYA
abstract: A Jordanian arrested on suspicion of involvement in the explosion in a West Berlin discotheque made at least one visit to Libya after moving to the city in 1975, according to a well-placed official source close to the investigation.   The discovery that the suspect, Ahmed Nawaf Mansour Hazi, had visited the North African country was one of ''several indications'' that he might have had ties to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government, according to the source.   The Reagan Administration has linked Libya's mission in East Berlin to the organizing of the explosion April 5 in the discotheque. The blast killed an American soldier and a Turkish woman and left 230 others burned and wounded. The terrorist attack was cited in justifying the American air raids against Tripoli and Benghazi on April 15.

headline: Kaiser Outlook
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that it expected losses from its aluminum division to widen in the second quarter, reflecting the negative impact of a mill fire at a fabrication plant, higher scrap metal costs and a less favorable product mix. However, the company said it expected third-quarter results to be better than those of both the first and second quarters.

headline: Monetarist Hue To Advisers
abstract: TREASURY SECRETARY JAMES A. BAKER 3d has recruited a new chief economist, a position of some consequence. It is the second-highest ranking economist position in the Government, after Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: S.E.C. Cites 2 Executives
abstract: The Worldwide Ventures Corporation and two senior executives were charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with falsifying the company's business activities and financial prospects from 1982 through 1985.   According to the S.E.C. complaint, filed in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York, Worldwide did not have any substantial business operations but issued press releases about a planned hotel in the Poconos and other enterprises.

headline: Ausimont Begins Public Offering
abstract: Ausimont Compo N.V., Waltham, Mass., a diversified international chemical company, yesterday began the public offering of three million common shares at a price of $27.75 a share through underwriters led by Wertheim & Company.   Proceeds from the sale, estimated at $78 million, are expected to be used by the company to finance its pending purchase of certain fluorine chemical operations from Allied-Signal Inc., as well as providing additional working capital, a company spokesman said.   The stock, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, finished at $28.25, up 25 cents.

headline: Regular Financings Are Scheduled
abstract: Treasury financing this week consists of the regular auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills today, followed on Wednesday by the regular monthly sale of two-year notes.   Late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at 6.21 percent and the six-month issue was at 6.29 percent. Securities dealers offered the new two-year notes on a when-issued basis at 7.24 percent.   Yields for tax-exempt bonds increased last week, but remain low enough so that many local governments are eager to reduce their interest expenses by refunding high-interest bonds sold earlier in the 1980's with the proceeds of new issues. According to data from Salomon Brothers Inc., refunding issues accounted to about $5 billion of the nearly $10.8 billion of bonds sold in April. Of the $11 billion of bonds offered so far in May, about $6 billion have been for refundings.

headline: Real Estate; Luxurious New Hotel At Taft Site
abstract: WHEN the redevelopers of the old Taft Hotel announced two years ago that they would convert the 60-year-old structure at 51st Street and Seventh Avenue into Executive Plaza, a mixed-use residential and commercial building, they said the new hotel to be included would have 270 moderately priced rooms.   But when the Grand Bay Hotel at Equitable Center, as the new hotel will be called, opens later this year, it will have fewer rooms, more luxury appointments and higher rates to match. The Equitable Center, whose main component is the new 54-story Equitable Tower erected by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, is just north of the hotel on Seventh Avenue.   The Grand Bay will take up the first seven levels of Executive Plaza, the complex being carved out of the former Taft Hotel by a development partnership that includes Arthur G. Cohen Properties, the Goodstein Development Corporation and J. I. Sopher & Company. That team has been joined by Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc. to build the new hotel.

headline: REFUGEES' PLIGHT AFTER CHERNOBYL PERPLEXES KREMLIN
abstract: Among the major problems facing Soviet authorities in the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster is the future of tens of thousands of people displaced by the accident.   According to Soviet accounts, 92,000 people were evacuated from towns and villages in an 18.6-mile zone around the damaged reactor in the days and weeks after the accident. Most left with nothing, apparently expecting to return after a few days.   In addition to those compelled to leave their homes near the Chernobyl reactor at the town of Pripyat, untold thousands have left Kiev, 70 miles south of the reactor, and other cities and towns, either because of the advice of authorities or on their own. Many of these have settled with acquaintances or in temporary homes across the Soviet Union, waiting for reassurances that it is safe to return.

headline: GREETING MANNEQUINS ON THE STAIRS
abstract: MANNEQUINS are an integral part of store design these days. ''The image of the store has a lot to do with the kind of mannequins it buys,'' said Ralph Pucci of Pucci Manikins in lower Manhattan.   Take, for example, The Limited, a woman's clothing store on Madison Avenue that is supposed to be the trend-setter for The Limited's nationwide chain. It has set out to create a whimsical atmosphere for its stores.

headline: LOTUS GIVES PRESIDENT CHIEF EXECUTIVE TITLE
abstract: The Lotus Development Corporation yesterday named Jim P. Manzi, its president, to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Mitchell D. Kapor, the company's 35-year-old founder, who will continue as chairman.

headline: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP
abstract: Construction spending rose for the third consecutive month in February, with the strongest gains concentrated in the home-building business.   The Commerce Department said today that the 1.2 percent February increase carried the seasonally adjusted annual rate of total construction outlays to $360.5 billion from January's $356.1 billion.

headline: 2.1% RISE IN MACHINE TOOL ORDERS
abstract: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 2.1 percent in March from February's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. Industry analysts attributed the small increase to the nation's sluggish industrial growth and uncertainty about how proposed changes in tax legislation will affect capital spending.   The trade group said that new orders for machine tools were $214.8 million in March, up from $210.4 million in February.

headline: RUMANIA TO LET 1,000 EMIGRATE, STATE DEPT. SAYS
abstract: Rumania has told the United States in recent weeks that it will allow more than 1,000 people to emigrate, the State Department said today.   The announcement came on the eve of President Reagan's annual decision on whether to extend trade benefits to Rumania for another year.   Officials said that based in part on the stepped-up emigration, and the release from prison of fundamentalist Protestants, the State Department has recommended that Mr. Reagan extend for another year the lower import tariffs that obtain under what is called most-favored-nation treatment, the arrangement for trade with most countries. Crackdown on Evangelicals    Several members of Congress, angered at a crackdown on Christian evangelical groups, have called for revoking the trade benefits.

headline: NEWS? ONLY IF ROOM 159 SAYS IT IS
abstract: The Union Building here, designed by Sir Herbert Baker and built in a brown stone that suggests solid power, is the seat of the nation's executive authority - South Africa's equivalent of the White House, and more.   When he is here and not in Cape Town, the legislative seat, President P. W. Botha works out of offices in the Union Building, as do some other Government leaders.   These days, after the emergency decree imposed last Thursday, the building - or rather, one room in it - has taken on added significance. The room, No. 159, vaulted and paneled and chandeliered, has become the font of official information.

headline: Advertising; Xerox Winner Seen as Bates
abstract: For the Xerox Corporation the search for a new agency that began in late March is over at last. And the winner of the $40 million account is Ted Bates Advertising, New York, according to a reliable source.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 26, 1986
abstract: International    President Reagan will work to reduce farm quotas, subsidies and other trade barriers when he is at the Tokyo summit conference, according to senior Administration officials. They have said before that agriculture was emerging as an issue there.  [ Page 33. ]    Tiffany will open a store on Bond Street in London and then will move on to other European cities. The jeweler is owned by investors and managers who bought it from Avon two years ago.  [ 35. ]

headline: Loan Arranged In Northwest Deal
abstract: Ten Japanese banks and one French bank have arranged a $500 million loan to help Northwest Airlines acquire Republic Airlines, according to Northwest officials. The remaining $384 million needed for the acquisition, which was announced in January, will come from a public securities offering or public sale of the debt, the officials said.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Broadcast Music Inc. has named Frances Preston executive vice president and chief operating officer.    * Coleco Industries, West Hartford, Conn., said its chief financial officer, David J. Ruggles, had resigned.    * New York Life Insurance Co. has elected Lee M. Gammill Jr., Edward C. Walsh and William F. Yelverton senior vice presidents.

headline: Kinder-Care Deal
abstract: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Pioneer Western Corporation, a financial services company, from Kansas City Southern Industries for about $65 million.

headline: EVACUATED TO NEW A-SITE
abstract: Some of the people evacuated from the danger zone around the Chernobyl nuclear power plant have been temporarily resettled next to another Ukrainian nuclear station still under construction, a Moscow paper has disclosed.   The paper, Moskovskaya Pravda, said in Tuesday's issue, just received in the West, that 144 newly completed apartments in the settlement of Neteshin, next to the Khmelnitsky station, had been placed at the disposal of the evacuees.

headline: Europe Air Rules Shift
abstract: The European Court of Justice ruled today that price regulation of French airlines violates the European Community's founding treaty. The decision could accelerate deregulation of Europe's airline industry.

headline: U.N. CHIEF AND WIESENTHAL DENY DEFENDING WALDHEIM
abstract: A United Nations spokesman denied today that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had made a statement attributed to him about his predecessor, Kurt Waldheim, who is running for the Austrian presidency.   At issue is a quotation in a memorandum drafted by Mr. Waldheim's son, Gerhard, in defense of his father's wartime activities. The senior Mr. Waldheim denied charges that he had been involved in war crimes when he served as a German Army lieutenant in the Balkans during campaigns against Yugoslav partisans and the deportation of Greek Jews.

headline: NEW RUSSIAN IN CAPITAL: YURI VLADIMIROVICH DUBININ
abstract: When a local Spanish winery invited Yuri V. Dubinin to the annual Pamplona running of the bulls two summers ago, Mr. Dubinin, then Soviet Ambassador to Spain. accepted with enthusiasm.   Faithful to tradition, he donned an open shirt and a ''panuelico,'' the red handkerchief that demonstrates solidarity with the young men who run with the bulls. At a welcoming ceremony at City Hall, he charmed officials of the medieval hill town, telling them in Spanish that he knew about bullfighting from reading Ernest Hemingway, a popular author in the Soviet Union.   But the personal affability of Mr. Dubinin, 55 years old, who was named ambassador to Washington today, contrasts with his professional demeanor in his advocacy of Soviet foreign policy.

headline: PRETORIA ORDERS CURFEWS IN AREA OF BLACK UNREST
abstract: The South African authorities, invoking the nation's emergency decree, imposed a curfew and other prohibitions tonight on segregated black townships in 13 areas in the restive Eastern Cape, the Government Gazette reported.   The prohibitions included a ban on possessing T-shirts emblazoned with the names of 47 anti-apartheid groups, including student and community organizations. The curfews were the first known to have been ordered under the emergency decree.   The measures followed frequent assurances by official spokesmen that violence in the country had lessened since the emergency decree - the harshest in the country's recent history - was announced a week ago. The reasons for the curfew were not explained.

headline: Mack Trucks
abstract: As part of a continuing cost-reduction and restructuring effort, Mack Trucks Inc. announced a program to cut at least 10 percent of its 3,500 nonunion workers. The company, based in Allentown, Pa., said the cuts would be made through layoffs, induced retirements and resignations. Walter C. Meck, executive vice president of finance, said he could not determine how many layoffs would be needed.

headline: Earthquake in Peru Kills 5 and Hurts 30
abstract: An earthquake jolted the ancient Incan city of Cuzco today, killing 5 people, injuring at least 30 and sending panicked residents racing from crumbling homes into the streets, authorities said.

headline: HOLIDAY FOR THE WALLET: CHEAPER GAS FOR JULY 4
abstract: Contrary to the usual trend as the Fourth of July holiday draws near, the average retail price of gasoline around the country has fallen nearly 2 cents a gallon in the last two weeks, and may continue to fall through the holiday weekend.   Oil industry analysts said that prices had fallen because the widely anticipated surge in motorists' demand for gasoline - which prompted a substantial buildup this spring in gasoline production and inventories - has failed to materialize.   Retail gasoline prices had risen steadily through the late spring after falling to about 90 cents a gallon in late April. Today, at less than $1 a gallon, prices remain about 28 cents a gallon below the level of a year ago.   ''People at every level are beginning to worry about moving their product,'' said Daniel Lundberg, a gasoline industry consultant, referring to refiners, distributors and gasoline marketers. ''That's why prices are dropping.''

headline: U.S. EMBASSY AIDE WOUNDED IN YEMEN
abstract: An American communications officer at the United States Embassy in Yemen was shot from a passing car yesterday as he drove home from church in Sana, the capital, the State Department reported.   In other attacks, the British manager of an American-owned subsidiary of Black & Decker, the tool maker, was shot and killed yesterday by a hooded gunman at his home near Lyons, France, and a bomb exploded early today in the building that houses the American Express office there, starting a fire and slightly wounding a passerby.   Also yesterday, an explosion in Vienna shattered the office entrance of Saudi Arabia's state-run airline.   The police in Heidelberg, West Germany, meanwhile, reported that the unoccupied automobile of an American serviceman and a Canadian military van had been heavily damaged in separate arson attacks.

headline: Ex-Boesky Officer Starts Up a Firm
abstract: Stephen J. Conway, former president and chief operating officer of the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation, announced yesterday that he was stepping out on his own in the competitive world of investment banking.   Mr. Conway, who is 39 years old, has formed S. J. Conway & Company and has brought in two men he met in Harvard Business School, Stephen J. Swain, 37, and Nigel Denscombe, 36, as managing directors. William S. P. Cotter, 50, an associate director, rounds out the team.

headline: SUMMIT IN TOKYO: THE GLOBAL MONEY MARKET AND THE WAY IT WORKS
abstract: Advances in telecommunications and computer technology have played a pivotal role in the emergence of today's international financial system. The new technology has knit trading centers around the globe into a single international market. It has also encouraged the development of new financial products, accelerated the pace of trading and added to its volatility. In recent years, the following four technologies have been most important:   Telecommunications. Satellites, transoceanic cables, microwave stations, and fiber optics have made it almost as easy to deal with banks on the other side of the world as it is to deal with banks across the street. Multinational banks and brokers have set up private lines that link their currency trading rooms into intercontinental networks that allow them to match a New York bank with one in London or Tokyo if the price is better than one offered locally.

headline: TAX BILL'S MAIN THRUST SEEMS INTACT
abstract: Key senators and many lobbyists said today that they expect the Senate to make changes in the Finance Committee's tax-revision bill but to approve intact its fundamental approach.   Support for keeping the deduction for Individual Retirement Accounts seemed to be gaining, they said. ''I think we have a good chance of winning this fight,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.   Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican majority leader, said the full Senate would take up the tax bill after June 3, when several states are holding primary elections and many senators will therefore be out of town. ''The tax bill continues to gain momentum,'' he said.

headline: SWEDES SEEK PALME CASE CLUE IN '76 ASSASSINATION IN U.S.
abstract: The Stockholm police are reliably understood to have asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to open its files on a 10-year-old assassination of an opponent of President Augusto Pinochet of Chile in hopes of finding leads on the killing this year of the Swedish Prime Minister, Olof Palme.   The only known connection between the Palme case and the assassination of Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean Ambassador to the United States who was blown up in a car in Washington in 1976, was supplied by an American citizen named Michael Vernon Townley. Mr. Townley eventually confessed to having conspired against Mr. Letelier on behalf of the Chilean secret police.   Mr. Townley, who eventually testified as a prosecution witness in the case against three Cubans charged in the assassination, was reported in 1979 to have told the F.B.I. that he had received orders from his Chilean sponsors to make an attempt on Mr. Palme's life at a 1976 meeting in Madrid of Social Democratic parties.   The Swedish Prime Minister was cooperating in that period with Mr. Letelier and others in efforts to make an international pariah of the Pinochet regime. He had also been active in making Sweden and other Scandinavian countries a haven for Chilean political refugees.

headline: Late Rally Limits Dow's Loss to 1.37
abstract: Stock prices fell again on Wall Street yesterday, but thanks to a late rally in blue-chip issues the final totals were not as bad as they could have been.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell almost 25 points on Tuesday, and had been down as many as 21 points yesterday, finished with a loss of only 1.37 points. It closed at 1,829.61.   Robert Stovall of Stovall/21st Advisers said the equities market yesterday remained closely aligned with the bond market, which continued to struggle. Of particular concern to both markets, he said, were statements by the Federal Reserve'schairman, Paul A. Volcker, expressing concern about growth in the nation's debt, and indicating that the decline in interest rates in the United States may have gone far enough.

headline: Bonn Has Secret Talks With Albania on Ties
abstract: West Germany said today that it had held secret talks with Albania on establishing diplomatic ties and indicated that the two sides had resolved a 40-year stumbling block over Albanian demands for war reparations.

headline: Ex-Treasury Aide Joins Nomura Securities
abstract: Nomura Securities International Inc., the giant Japanese securities house, appeared to bolster its case for designation as a primary dealer of government securities yesterday when it announced that John J. Niehenke, former deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury for Federal finance, had been named senior vice president in its United States Goverment securities department.   Officially, Mr. Niehenke will be in charge of marketing Treasury obligations to foreign investors. But his contacts at the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, charged with designating primary dealers, are likely to be as important as his experience in the debt markets.

headline: U.S. DISREGARDED WARNINGS OF ALLIES, ITALIAN SAYS
abstract: A senior Italian official said this morning that the United States carried out its attack against Libya against the advice of virtually all the European allies.   The official also said he feared the American retaliation might unleash a new ''spiral of violence'' across Europe.   But the official also said that President Reagan's envoy, Vernon A. Walters, had made a ''strong'' case for American action in a meeting late last night with Prime Minister Bettino Craxi.

headline: PENTAGON REPORT IRKS STATE DEPT.
abstract: The State Department assailed the Defense Department today for issuing a report expressing skepticism that the Contadora negotiations in Central America will produce a verifiable peace treaty.   In an unusually direct criticism of another agency, Charles E. Redman, a State Department spokesman, said the Pentagon study, which was distributed to members of Congress and to reporters, ''has no standing as a United States Government document.'' He said it was ''an internal Department of Defense study written under contract and released without authority.''   The White House, seeking to avoid involvement, denied there were any differences between State and Defense.

headline: ISRAELI HELD IN U.S. ARMS PLOT CARRIED OFFICIAL INTRODUCTION
abstract: A retired Israeli general, charged by the United States with conspiring to sell $2 billion in American-made weapons to Iran, was empowered by Israel to hold talks with foreigners on arms sales, a senior Israeli military official said today.   But the official said the permit issued the retired officer, Brig. Gen. Abraham Bar-Am, was a standard ''to whom it may concern letter'' issued to scores of Israeli arms merchants. The official said the letter did not grant the right to negotiate weapons sales or to put agreements into effect -acts that required an additional permit signed by the Defense Minister.

headline: Stocks Continue Down; Dow Falls 14.76 Points
abstract: Stock prices declined for the second consecutive session as Wall Street, after ignoring weakness in the bond markets of late, decided once again to move in tandem with the credit markets.   Yesterday's action in the equities market, however, was a classic example of how bond prices can sometimes have an impact in a roundabout way. Traders said the credit markets first caused a decline in the value of stock index futures, and this in turn dragged down the price of stocks late in the session.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 5.64 points on Friday, lost another 14.76 points, to 1,861.95, yesterday. The blue-chip index was about 9 points higher midway through the volatile session, which ended with several big brokerage firms unloading stocks in favor of the heavily discounted index futures.

headline: Consumer Debt Rise Is Slowed
abstract: Americans took on $4.97 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in February, the smallest monthly increase in eight months, the Government reported today.   The Federal Reserve Board said consumer debt grew at an annual rate of 11 percent in February, compared with a 17.2 percent rate in January, when debt increased by $7.66 billion.

headline: Tenneco Job Cut
abstract: Tenneco Inc. will cut its work force by about 700 employees at its corporate headquarters and several of its Houston-based subsidiaries, officials said. The company eliminated 470 jobs in mid-March in its oil exploration and production unit; the additional cuts by midsummer will bring the employee reduction to about 1,200.

headline: CONSENSUS OF EXPERTS: THE ACCIDENT ISN'T OVER
abstract: American technical experts widely believe that the graphite core of the crippled Soviet reactor is still burning but say the chance that molten nuclear fuel will burn through the reactor's foundation and explode violently is remote.   At the same time, reactor construction experts expressed doubt yesterday that the Russians would be able anytime soon to build a concrete catchment under the reactor to contain nuclear fuel if it did melt through the basement of the Chernobyl unit, or to otherwise encase the plant in concrete.   The consensus among experts is that the accident is not yet over: that inside the reactor is a mass of up to 2,000 tons of molten nuclear fuel mixed with concrete, steel, fuel cladding, graphite and anything else that the hot radioactive core chewed up as it began to slump from the accident.   There is no nuclear fission, or chain reaction, the experts said, because it requires a specific engineered configuration and a way to trap neutrons -both of which have been lost. Most of the radiation has already been released, they said. #5,000 Degrees in the Molten Mass What is left instead is the enormous decay heat of the reaction, 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit in the molten mass. Also left is the heaviest radioactive elements from the nuclear core, since the lighter and more volatile fractions have already escaped with the initial explosion and graphite fire, the experts said.

headline: City Developer Shuns Limelight
abstract: Marshall Rose, chairman of the Georgetown Group, the real estate development company involved in the effort to build a new Madison Square Garden, dislikes the limelight.   ''I'm just not used to publicity,'' he said yesterday.   During the course of his career, however, the former lawyer and accountant has attracted attention. In the early 1970's, he served as president of the Arlen Realty and Devlopment Group as well as president of its Korvette discount chain subsidiary.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: Assets of the nation's 361 money market mutual funds fell $169.9 million, to $224.50 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Envoy to Panama Delivers a Note on Policy
abstract: The United States Ambassador delivered a formal clarification of American policy toward Panama today, but he refused to characterize the statement. The action followed reports implicating Panama's army chief in criminal activities.

headline: Market Place; Hospital Issues Struggling On
abstract: STOCKS of hospital management companies have failed to climb aboard the bull market bandwagon this year. This was borne home anew to investors yesterday when Humana Inc., an industry leader with a steady string of profit gains over the past decade, traded at a 52-week low of 24 3/4 before closing at 25 1/4, down 1/8.   This followed a 2 5/8-point loss for the stock last week after the company said it expects to report a decline of 5 to 10 percent in earnings per share for its third fiscal quarter, ended May 31. If current trends continue, it added, fourth-quarter earnings also will be down from a year earlier.

headline: Israel Names Chief Banker
abstract: The Israeli cabinet named Michael Bruno today as the governor of the Bank of Israel, the country's central bank. He replaces Dr. Moshe Mandelbaum, who was forced to resign in the wake of a bank shares scandal.

headline: RURAL MEXICO SEES THE U.S. AS A MAGNET
abstract: At one point or another, it seems, virtually every able-bodied man and some of the women in this small village deep in the mountains of southern Mexico has journeyed north and slipped across the border to spend a season or longer as an illegal worker in California.   Braving the border crossing to find work as a gardener, construction worker or maid in Los Angeles or as a field hand in California's agricultural regions is a way of life here, an essential economic principle of survival.   ''Have you heard if there is any work there?'' Elias Hernandez, the storekeeper here, asked an American visitor recently. ''I might go if there is work.''

headline: Report Links Waldheim To Nazi Hostage Deaths
abstract: A 1948 United Nations War Crimes Commission report says Kurt Waldheim was responsible for the deaths of hostages held by the Nazis in World War II, according to an article in the current issue of Newsweek magazine.   The magazine article cautioned that the report was not a finding of guilt, but said the commission did say it was ''satisfied that there is, or will be at the time of trial, sufficient evidence to justify prosecution.''

headline: Safeway Stock Up on Rumors
abstract: Shares of Safeway Stores Inc. surged $3.875 yesterday, to $51.50, in heavy trading amid rumors that the Haft family of Washington would soon make a tender offer for the nation's No. 1 supermarket chain.   Market sources said the Hafts had asked the Wall Street firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert to raise money for a takeover, but Drexel officials could not be reached for comment.

headline: ADMINISTRATION CHALLENGES PLAN BY RIGHTS PANEL
abstract: The chief White House spokesman today took issue with a draft report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic people or women.   The spokesman, Larry Speakes, said, ''The Administration's position is that we support the minority set-aside program.''   These programs require the Government to set aside specified percentages of money or work for businesses owned by women or members of minority groups. Federal agencies awarded more than $5 billion in contracts under such programs last year.

headline: Times Fills Ad Positions
abstract: The New York Times yesterday named Tim Maby director of classified advertising. Lance R. Primis, senior vice president for advertising, announced the appointment.

headline: PATENTS; Breath Test Can Keep Car at Curb
abstract: A BREATH tester called the Soberlizer, which prevents a car's ignition from starting if a driver has had too much to drink, was patented this week. Its manufacture is planned in the fall.

headline: LEADERS IN TOKYO SET TO DENOUNCE ACTS OF TERRORISM
abstract: Advisers to the heads of the leading industrial democracies produced draft statements on nuclear safety and international terrorism in an all-night session, and President Reagan was described today as ''extremely pleased'' with the efforts to address the two issues here.   Reagan Administration officials said that, barring last-minute snags, Mr. Reagan and the six other leaders were expected to approve the drafts at the first plenary session of the Tokyo summit conference later this morning. The declarations were to be issued this afternoon.   The officials said some parts of the terrorism statement were still being ironed out this afternoon. The Japanese Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, said at a news conference that there seemed to be ''a convergence of views'' but that some work remained on the wording.

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Appoints Head for Yellow Pages
abstract: Martin Daniels has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Yellow Pages. Mr. Daniels, 52 years old, has been with the division for seven years.   In another bit of news, the unit has also picked up five new accounts, which add up to several million in billings. They are Merrill Lynch, Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance, KIS One-Hour Photo, Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, and Wang Laboratories' Value Added Resellers.

headline: Kennedy Faults Arms Move
abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said in the first televised session of the Senate today that President Reagan's decision to stop observing the limits of the 1979 arms treaty was the worst mistake of his presidency. For the United States to repudiate the treaty now will hurt it more than the Soviet Union, Senator Kennedy said, because the Russians would have had to dismantle 600 additional missile launchers and five additional submarines under the treaty.

headline: Anheuser-Busch
abstract: The San Miguel Corporation is negotiating to sell its Hong Kong brewery to Anheuser-Busch Inc., the world's largest brewer, both companies said. No price was disclosed in either company's statement, although Manila newspapers have said that San Miguel is asking about $165 million for the brewery.

headline: MEXICAN JITTERS DISCOUNTED
abstract: Jitters went through the big money center bank stocks last week when Mexico seemed to be about to default on interest payments on its $95 billion in bank debt. As stock prices fell in the early part of the week, the big bank issues seemed to lose more than the general market.   But not to worry, say some analysts, the Citicorps and Chases of the world are better prepared to handle a Mexican crisis than they were in 1982. Most of the big banks have reduced Latin loans as a percentage of their capital and, in addition, the third world countries have shown that they can keep relatively current on their interest payments.

headline: People
abstract: * Robert Cox has joined Young & Rubicam as group creative director and senior vice president. Mr. Cox was previously executive vice president, director of creative services at Needham Harper Worldwide.    * Barbara Gans Russo has been promoted to senior vice president, associate creative director of the Bloom Agency, New York.

headline: WORLD BANK AND I.M.F. HIT BY WALKOUT ON PAY
abstract: Employees of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank - including several hundred professional economists earning upward of $100,000 tax-free - walked off their jobs today in a wage dispute.   The nearly 8,000 employees, encompassing professionals and clerical workers, were protesting decisions of their government shareholders to freeze salaries.   For the institutions' technocrats who lunch on cote de veau and Cotes du Rhone at subsidized prices, the strike culminated a personal encounter with the austerity measures they often recommend for debt-burdened developing countries.   At a crowded midday meeting of the World Bank staff association in the floral courtyard of the 19th Street headquarters, a senior British-born economist said the issue was both pay and the professional independence of the staff. ''Who do we work for -political appointees or the people of the world?'' he asked to loud cheers and applause.

headline: PARAGUAY REGIME BUFFETED BY UNREST
abstract: Paraguayan opposition groups have begun taking to the streets to challenge the country's long-ruling dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner. The Government has been swift to respond, denouncing ''subversive agitators'' and sending policemen and paramilitary thugs to club and tear-gas demonstrators. But over the last two months more than a dozen protest marches have nonetheless taken place.   ''Something very fundamental is taking place here,'' an opposition leader said, adding that the Paraguayan police had not had to use tear gas since 1969. ''People are still scared but they're no longer intimidated by fear. They're regaining control of the streets.''

headline: Gorbachev Comment Retracted by Reagan
abstract: President Reagan said tonight that he ''must have goofed'' two days ago in linking ing Mikhail S. Grobachev with Fidel Castro, Muammar el-Qaddafi, and Yasir Arafat.   Although Mr. Reagan made the comparison on Monday in a speech before Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies, the President spoke far more warmly tonight about the Soviet leader during his nationally televised news conference.

headline: Broken Hill Offer Allowed
abstract: A court ruled today that Robert Holmes a Court's $1.48 billion offer for control of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company could proceed, ending months of legal wrangling over the bid.   The Supreme Court of the state of Victoria removed an injunction blocking the offer after ruling that the bid for Australia's largest company did not violate Australian takeover laws.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD PACKAGING
abstract: WITH the exception of the toothpaste pump and a few other eyebrow-raising packages to hit supermarket shelves over the last few years, innovations in consumer packaging have traditionally come from cosmetics companies. Long ago they recognized that unusually shaped mascara wands, see-through tubes for lipsticks, and other new packages can boost market share in the absence of a new product formula.   ''For many years, they were leading the dance,'' said Benjamin Miyares, executive editor of Food and Drug Packaging News. ''The food companies were hesitant to get involved in innovative packaging.''

headline: Automatix Settlement
abstract: Automatix Inc., a designer and maker of factory robots, said it had settled a complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. began an investigation after the company announced in March 1984 that it was correcting its financial statements for three quarters of 1983. By agreeing to a consent decree, which was announced Tuesday, Automatix did not admit any wrongdoing, but is enjoined from filing inaccurate reports in the future.

headline: A Founder of Giorgio Tries a Solo Venture
abstract: Ever since she was a little girl growing up in New York, Gale Hayman has had a passion for fragrances.   At the age of 10, she bought small vials of perfume at a Woolworth's for 15 cents each. Mrs. Hayman said she loved that perfume so much that she wore it all the time, even when she went to sleep.   Ultimately, Mrs. Hayman transformed her fascination with perfumes into a multimillion-dollar business, creating Giorgio, one of the leading lines of fragrance products for men and women. The line, marketed through Giorgio Inc., produced more than $100 million in sales last year, with the fragrance itself selling at about $150 an ounce.

headline: What Tax Proposals Mean
abstract: AFTER months of uncertainty, a clearer picture of the direction of tax policy is coming into focus on Capitol Hill, providing investors with a better insight into the potential dangers and opportunities of everything from tax shelters to bank accounts.   While the Congressional debate on overhauling the Federal income tax is far from over, and the final outcome is still not certain, individuals now have proposals from both the Senate and the House to help guide their investment decisions.   The package unanimously approved last month by the Senate Finance Committee headed by Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon differs in important detail from the bill passed by the House of Representatives last December. And it is likely to be amended during debate on the Senate floor this month. Under the House bill, for example, an individual's contributions to a 401(k) employee retirement plan would reduce dollar-for-dollar the amount of tax-deductible contributions he or she could make to an Individual Retirement Account. Under the Senate committee bill, no I.R.A. deduction could be claimed by a taxpayer who is covered by a pension plan. But interest earned on I.R.A. contributions could still grow tax-free until withdrawn.

headline: Aquino Gives Insurgents 6 Months to Hold Talks
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the leaders of the Communist insurgency had not yet responded to her offer to hold talks and that she would give them about six months to do so.   Interviewed on the Government television station on the eve of the arrival of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mrs. Aquino also said she hoped American expressions of support for her new Government would translate into ''massive'' aid.

headline: SANCTIONS ARE CALLED A SAFEGUARD
abstract: The leader of a high-level Commonwealth study group on South Africa warned this weekend that imposing economic sanctions against that country was the only way to protect Western investments there.   ''The choices before the West are very stark now,'' said Malcolm Fraser, the former Prime Minister of Australia, who was co-chairman of the Commonwealth's Eminent Persons Group that last week completed a seven-month study of South Africa's crisis.

headline: Treasury Focus on Short-Term Bills
abstract: Treasury financing this week is confined to the short-term bill market, with no note auctions expected until the middle of the month.   In advance of today's regular auction of new three- and six-month bills, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 6.31 percent while the six-month issue was at 6.43 percent. Before Thursday's auction of $9.25 billion of new one-year bills - an issue the Treasury sells every four weeks - the outstanding one-year issue was bid late Friday at a rate of 6.49 percent.   To raise cash needed to continue Government operations until its cash balance is restored by midmonth tax receipts, tomorrow the Treasury will auction $5 billion of special 15-day cash management bills. The bills are sold in minimums of $1 million, and non-competitive bids are not accepted.

headline: Bonds Slide in Profit Taking
abstract: Bond prices tumbled again yesterday, as traders took profits in the face of an increasingly uncertain outlook for interest rates.   ''There have been a lot of very large sell programs from some go-away investors who have decided to sell out, go to the sidelines and reassess the situation,'' said A. Craig Coats Jr., a managing director in charge of the government securities department at Salomon Brothers.   As was the case on Thursday, the bulk of the selling occurred among longer-term issues, which because of their maturity are generally viewed by traders as highly speculative instruments.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 30, 1986:

headline: Sperry Still Silent
abstract: The Sperry Corporation's board reportedly met in a long session yesterday to discuss the Burroughs Corporation's hostile takeover bid, but Sperry made no comment about what actions it would take. Since the takeover effort began a week ago, analysts have expected Sperry to take some kind of defensive action, or seek another merger partner. So far, however, Sperry has said nothing publicly about the $70-a-share bid, the second Burroughs has made for the company in a year.

headline: U.S. CARRIES OUT A DISPUTED A-TEST
abstract: The United States carried out its second nuclear test of the year today, an action that was widely expected to spur the Soviet Union to resume its testing.   The Soviet Union has not conducted a nuclear test since it adopted a self-imposed moratorium Aug. 6. The United States has detonated nine nuclear explosions since that date.   In Moscow, the official Soviet press agency Tass denounced the test today as a ''dangerous destabilizing step'' that cast doubt on American reliability as a negotiating partner.  [ Page A8. ]  Test Had Been Postponed The test, which had been postponed twice, was planned for Tuesday, the same day President Reagan met with the departing Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, to discuss a proposed summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Officials said the postponement was the result of technical problems and winds that could have carried any accidential radiation leaks toward populated areas.

headline: CURB ON LOANS TO SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank, has decided to end all lending to borrowers in South Africa until the system of racial separation known as apartheid is dismantled.   A committee of the board of directors of the BankAmerica Corporation, the bank's holding company, reached that decision on June 2, ratifying a proposal by the bank's management, a spokesman said. There has been no formal announcement of the new policy, however.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, said it would increase aluminum beverage-can body stock prices by about 7 percent on shipments beginning July 1.    * Collins Foods International, Los Angeles, said it had agreed to sell its 111 Kentucky Fried Chicken stores in southern California to Naugles Inc. of Fullerton, Calif.

headline: 1,000 Sikhs Arrested In Punjab in 2 Days
abstract: Nearly 1,000 Sikh militants have been arrested in the Punjab in two days of largely peaceful protests marking the second anniversary of an army raid on the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' holiest shrine, the authorities reported today.   Meanwhile, the state government withdrew all paramilitary policemen from the Golden Temple, where they have been since April 30, when a second raid on the shrine was conducted to flush out terrorist suspects there.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TAIWAN IS SEEKING HIGH-TECH GROWTH
abstract: Five years ago, at an age when many successful American executives turn their thoughts to golf, C. H. Li retired from his $100,000-a-year job as research director for Honeywell Inc. in Minneapolis and started work at a fraction of the salary in Hsinchu, the city that officials here like to call Taiwan's Silicon Valley.   Mr. Li, now 65 years old, keeps his golf swing in shape at a course that nestles against the hills outside Hsinchu. But recreation has to be squeezed in between the duties the Chinese-born American has taken on as director of a sprawling development zone known as the Science-based Industrial Park, where 59 companies are at work in a venture that could decide the fate of this island's economy.   ''This is the future of Taiwan,'' Mr. Li said recently, gesturing beyond the picture windows of his office toward the low factory buildings that have sprung up since the Government established the park in 1980, off Taiwan's main cross-island freeway 55 miles south of the capital, Taipei.   The Government's goal was to attract a number of high-technology industries with inducements that include venture capital and low-interest loans, accelerated depreciation, a variety of ownership plans and substantial tax incentives.

headline: MULRONEY 'FURIOUS' AT REAGAN APPROVAL OF LUMBER TARIFFS
abstract: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who has spoken of his friendship with the United States, today unleashed a barrage of criticism at President Reagan, accusing him of engaging in ''pure protectionism'' against Canada.   Mr. Mulroney's Government sent a rare protest to Washington and threatened to retaliate against American imports because of the stiff tariffs that Mr. Reagan approved Thursday on certain Canadian lumber products.   ''We are looking at options of retaliation,'' the Secretary of State for External Affairs, Joe Clark, said. ''We don't want to get into that, but this action leaves us no alternative.''

headline: APPLE TO ELIMINATE 600 OF ITS DEALERS
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. is cutting off 600 dealers, a move that will reduce the number of stores authorized to carry Apple products in the United States by about 23 percent.   The cuts were announced in letters mailed out last Thursday to the affected dealers. Before the cuts, Apple had 2,600 dealers.   Apple's move is the latest by computer makers to help shore up dealers, who are going through a shakeout caused by a slowdown in growth in computer sales and an overabundance of computer stores. Computer manufacturers are becoming concerned that if the dealers are not healthy, the manufacturers will also be hurt in the long run.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 18, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The economy grew at an annual rate of 3.2 percent in the first quarter, a figure that was higher than many analysts had expected. Economists, noting the weakness shown by other indicators such as industrial output, said the G.N.P. figure should not be interpreted as a sign of a robust economy.  [ Page A1. ]    An expansion of the authority to issue tax-exempt bonds was approved by the Senate Finance Committee. President Reagan and House tax writers had sought restrictions on such bonds.  [ D1. ]

headline: SENATE TAX BILL: HOW SUPPORT GREW
abstract: Late Tuesday afternoon, the Senate clerk will call the roll - ''Mr. Abnor, Mr. Andrews, Mr. Armstrong'' - and one senator after another will vote ''aye'' on one of the most sweeping legislative measures to come before Congress in years. No one will be surprised if, when the roll call is over, the vote approving the tax-revision bill is 100 to 0.   The overwhelming Senate support is a testament to many factors:    * To the tenacity of President Reagan in standing behind tax-revision legislation in the face of advice from important aides, as recently as six weeks ago, that the cause was hopeless.    * To the strategy devised more than a year ago by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and his deputy, Richard G. Darman, of giving powerful committee chairman a personal political stake in moving a tax bill, and then in forcing Congress into the position where lawmakers had no choice but to vote up or down on ''tax reform.''

headline: U.S. ENVOY IS CALLED INTRUDERS' TARGET IN SWEDEN
abstract: A bodyguard to the United States Ambassador, fearing an assassination attempt, opened fire Tuesday night on two armed men he discovered in the grounds of a mansion near here where the Ambassador was a guest at a dinner party.   The guard, a Stockholm police officer assigned to the Ambassador, chased the men across the estate grounds, firing three shots, but failed to apprehend them, according to the Swedish police.   ''We are assuming that the men were attempting an assassination of the U.S. Ambassador,'' Police Inspector Sven Lilja said of the search for the two men, who did not fire their weapons.

headline: ITALIAN COALITION IS VICTOR IN SICILY
abstract: Italy's governing coalition won an overwhelming majority in Sicilian regional elections today, while the opposition Communist Party lost ground.   The five governing parties won two-thirds of the total, a slight increase from their share in recent elections, according to vote totals made public today.   Prime Minister Bettino Craxi , a Socialist who leads the centrist coalition that is Italy's longest lasting postwar Government, called the results ''a vote for and a sign of stability.''

headline: BONN IS CRITICIZED OVER 'STAR WARS'
abstract: The Soviet Union lodged a formal protest with the Bonn Government today over an accord covering West German participation in the Reagan Administration's missile-defense research program.   The Foreign Ministry, in a statement, said Moscow's Ambassador in Bonn repeated ''known Soviet objections'' to the space-defense program, the Strategic Defense Initiative, in a meeting with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.   The statement said Mr. Genscher told the Ambassador, Vladimir S. Semyonov, that the accord, which was signed Thursday in Washington, limited participation in the program to research projects by West German companies and research institutes. He also said it involved no public funding.

headline: EXECUTIVES CHANGES
abstract: * A. H. Belo Corporation, Dallas, which owns several newspapers, radio and television stations, announced that Dealey D. Herndon had been elected to the board of directors for a three-year term.    * BMW A.G., the Munich-based automobile and motorcycle manufacturer, announced that Gunter Kramer, chief executive officer of BMW of North America Inc., had been named to its board of management, export sales, by its supervisory board.

headline: Advertising; Overseas Ad Spending Is Revised Upward
abstract: Because of the ''explosion'' of dollar spending in Europe brought on by changes in exchange rates, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and director of forcasting at McCann-Erickson, yesterday dramatically revised upward his estimate of what overseas ad spending will be this year. Although he originally, in December, called for 9 percent growth, now he thinks it will be 26.9 percent, to $78.3 billion.

headline: CHALLENGE ON OIL ACCOUNTING
