abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, the big oil-and-gas drilling company, said yesterday that it might take a $300 million charge against earnings for its third fiscal quarter because of the interplay between lower oil prices and oil and gas accounting standards.   Such a charge would wipe out Petro-Lewis's net worth. The company's apparent goal is to get the Securities and Exchange Commission to relax its accounting rules.   A. Clarence Sampson, the chief accountant for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said he would recommend temporary changes in the accounting standards that would enable oil companies such as Petro-Lewis to avoid having to take big write-downs.

headline: Telenet Moves Billings To J.W.T. in the West
abstract: Telenet, which provides data communications products and services, has hooked up with J. Walter Thompson, San Francisco.

headline: Sri Lanka Approves Plan for Councils
abstract: The Cabinet approved a plan today that is intended to resolve the island's ethnic conflict, which has claimed more than 3,000 lives in the last three years.   The Government's Information Department said in a statement that the plan included the creation of elected provincial councils to which power would be passed.   Tamil guerrillas have been battling Government troops in a campaign for autonomy for Tamil areas in the north and east of the island.

headline: Advertising; All-Female Agency Wins Lotion Account
abstract: Lotas, Minard, Patton, McIver, the new, all-female ad agency that has taken up residence in the Chrysler Building, has just announced its first client, S. C. Johnson, which has assigned it Curel, a moisture lotion for the derma.

headline: The Senate Plan And Tax Liability
abstract: Average reduction in income tax liability for various income classes in 1988 tax year.

headline: Companies Move to Fill Ginnie Mae's Shoes
abstract: Participants in the mortgage securities market may soon be faced with two new versions of mortgage pass-through securities to fill the void left by the Government National Mortgage Association. That agency, known as Ginnie Mae, has stopped selling commitments for new pass-through certificates.

headline: Allied-Signal Switches To Homer & Durham
abstract: Allied-Signal Inc. of Morristown, N.J., is switching its $4 million corporate account to Homer & Durham from Doyle Dane Bernbach.

headline: Guerrillas in Ecuador Seize a High Official
abstract: The Government said today that guerrillas had seized a member of a constitutional tribunal.   Interior Minister Luis Robles said the official, Enrique Echeverria, was kidnapped Tuesday by a group known as Guerrillas for a Free Homeland.   The rebels said Dr. Echeverria would live only if President Leon Febres Cordero was put on trial.

headline: G.M. Plastic Van
abstract: The General Motors Corporation plans to build a front-wheel-drive plastic-body mini-van for sale later this decade by Chevrolet and Pontiac dealers, a spokesman said today. The vehicle will be assembled in Framingham, Mass., where G.M. now builds the Chevrolet Celebrity and Oldsmobile Ciera.

headline: BRITAIN REPORTEDLY DECIDES TO DISSOLVE ULSTER ASSEMBLY
abstract: The British Government has decided to dissolve the Northern Ireland Assembly because it failed to bring together the province's Roman Catholics and Protestants, official sources said today.   The decision, made at a meeting of senior ministers in the Cabinet's Overseas and Defense Committee, signals the collapse of the seventh initiative in 14 years to establish a political bridge between the two sides in Ulster to end the sectarian violence.   The sources said the assembly would be dissolved by an order in council, a procedure that allows the Government to act without recourse to Parliament.

headline: AN AUSTRIAN O.S.S. MAN IS LINKED TO WALDHEIM
abstract: Austria's first postwar Foreign Minister said today that he hired Kurt Waldheim as his personal secretary in 1946 on the recommendation of a member of his staff who had worked for the American Office of Strategic Services and who would later become the son-in-law of Allen W. Dulles, head of the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1950's.   Karl J. Gruber, 78, a former anti-Nazi resistance leader who served as the Austrian Foreign Minister from 1946 to 1953, said the recommendation came from the Foreign Ministry's young first secretary, Fritz Molden, heir to an Austrian publishing empire. Mr. Gruber said Mr. Molden gave Mr. Waldheim a strong recommendation after checking Mr. Waldheim's background with the four Great Powers, including the United States. At the time, Austria was under Allied occupation.   ''Molden investigated him and found no material on him, nothing, nothing,'' Mr. Gruber said in a telephone interview from Washington. He added that Mr. Molden ''soon became the son-in-law of Allen Dulles and so had the opportunity to do a thorough investigation.''

headline: AROUND THE TABLE
abstract: The Schedule (All times are local. Tokyo time is 13 hours ahead of New York time.)

headline: REACTION IS MIXED
abstract: The head of Haiti's provisional Government announced late Saturday night that presidential elections would be held in 17 months, and the reaction today included both praise and criticism.   It was unclear whether the announcement on national television would end the wave of protests that spread across the nation last week.   Today, for the second day in a row, no demonstrations were reported. But tension remained high, and a group of outspoken Haitians involved in politics, labor and human rights continued to demand a change in the structure of the provisional Government and threatened more protests.

headline: STRIKING GOLD IN A CANADIAN COURT
abstract: THIS is a tale of how one small company wrenched one of the planet's richest gold mines from a giant competitor. The characters are the stuff of a good bad movie: There are the pair of rumpled prospectors who became millionaires by turning up gold in Canada's limitless ''moose pasture,'' the Vancouver stock promoter whom comedian Joey Bishop called the ''Jewish Howard Hughes,'' and the seventyish Maryland widow who discovered that a hunk of forest she had reluctantly paid taxes on for years had overnight become Canada's hottest mining prospect.   One conclusion is certain: ''Strange things'' are done ''by the men who moil for gold,'' as the poet Robert Service once wrote.   In this instance, International Corona Resources Ltd., the little guy, took giant Lac Minerals Ltd., one of Canada's most aggressive mining operations, to court to complain about being misused. Last month, after one of the biggest judgments in Canadian history, Corona walked out of a Toronto courthouse with a smile and a $3 billion gold mine.

headline: 9.9% DROP IN MACHINE-TOOL ORDERS POSTED IN APRIL
abstract: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 9.9 percent in April from March's level, according to a report that will be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.   Industry analysts attributed the decline to the nation's sluggish industrial growth and uncertainty about how proposed tax legislation would affect capital spending.   The trade association said that new orders for machine tools fell to $193.5 million in April, from $214.6 million in March.

headline: SOVIET SEEKS STATUS IN GATT
abstract: Faced with falling foreign trade volume and declining oil prices, the Soviet Union has recently made public its interest in becoming an observer at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.   At an unusually candid news conference here recently, Mikhail Pankine, who heads the Soviet Foreign Ministry's Department for International Economic Organizations, said Moscow viewed it as ''essential'' that it be granted such status, and be allowed to observe a new round of world trade talks expected late this year or early next year.   But diplomats here, headquarters of the 90-member GATT, which works to expand and liberalize world trade, say there is little chance that the Soviet Union would gain such observer status anytime soon. They said industrialized nations such as the United States and the European Economic Community would block the consensus decision needed for Soviet membership or observer status, for political as well as economic reasons.

headline: U.S. Reaffirms Japan Chip Dumping
abstract: The Commerce Department, in a victory for the American semiconductor industry, said today that it had determined that Japan has been dumping computer memory chips in the United States at below production costs.   The department said it was upholding a preliminary decision that Japanese exports of the computer chips were violating United States trade laws.   The decision provides for the imposition of stiff tariffs for importing the chips, known as 64-kilobit dynamic random access memory components, or 64K dynamic RAM's. Based on the preliminary ruling, the Japanese companies are being required to pay a fee into a special account equal to the margin by which their product falls below ''fair value'' as determined by the Commerce Department.

headline: BRAZIL PLANS TO EXTRADITE CHINESE
abstract: Brazil's Supreme Court has granted a United States request for the extradition of a Taiwan national wanted on charges of murdering a prominent Chinese-American journalist in California 18 months ago.   The family and friends of the slain journalist, Henry Liu, who was 52 years old, have said he was assassinated for political reasons after he published a critical biography of the Nationalist President, Chiang Ching-kuo. The Taipei Government has denied involvement in the case.

headline: THE PRIORITY IN TOKYO: RESTORING SOME UNITY
abstract: The American bombing of Libya on April 15 has transformed the agenda for the summit conference of the seven leading Western industrial powers.   In the last few days, officials of the Reagan Administration and diplomats and spokesmen for the other governments involved have said in a series of interviews that restoration of a semblance of unity - especially but not exclusively on terrorism - has become the overriding priority for the conference, which opens in Tokyo on Sunday.   ''We simply cannot afford to leave there in the same state of disarray we found ourselves after the air raids,'' said Lord Lever, an international economist and a former British Cabinet member, who has been involved in the planning for the conference. Stresses Are Noted    He argued that in a sense both the economic questions with which these annual gatherings are designed to deal and the political issues that have always intruded would have to be viewed, this time, ''in terms of the stresses that are seriously weakening the alliance.''

headline: RARE MOMENT FOR A GLOBAL ECONOMY
abstract: IN a single week, the Japanese fretted that the yen had climbed too high, Federal Reserve Board chairman Paul A. Volcker thought aloud about the dollar collapsing, and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d berated West Germany for not cutting taxes and interest rates more. Meanwhile last week, the Senate Finance Committee nearly blocked President Reagan's attempt to widen trade with Canada, and the acrimony over protectionism in agriculture reached the point where the Common Market's ambassador to Washington called American charges ''hogwash.''   ''The trade atmosphere is very difficult,'' said Lawrence B. Krause, international economist at the Brookings Institution. ''Indeed, one could call it foul.''   Countries fear this kind of posturing and turmoil almost as much as the worldwide recession it can lead to. But now they have what Mr. Baker calls a ''golden opportunity'' to calm things down.

headline: Enron Combines Its Pension Plans
abstract: The Enron Corporation, the new name for the company created by the merger of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and Internorth Inc., said it was combining the two companies' pension plans in a move that will yield $130 million after taxes. Formed last July, Enron, based in Omaha, is primarily engaged in the transmission and sales of natural gas in North America.

headline: U.S. GROUP ACCUSES ZIMBABWE OF REPRESSION
abstract: A report issued today by an American committee of lawyers asserts that over the last three years, Zimbabwe's Government has committed a wide range of human rights violations against its political opponents and other people in the south of the country.   The report, issued by the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, charges that Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government has engaged in a systematic campaign of terror and repression against the minority Ndebele-speaking people of southern Zimbabwe. Many of the report's assertions, which include torture, murder, arbitrary arrest and indefinite detention, have been made in the past by Amnesty International.   A spokesman for the Zimbabwe Government, Justin Nyoka, declined to respond to repeated telephone requests for comment on the charges. In the past, the Government has denounced similar contentions by Amnesty International. Mr. Mugabe has described the rights group as ''Amnesty Lies International.''

headline: BOEING'S VENTURE
abstract: To the Editor:   Robert Reich ignores the realities of the commercial jet airframe market. This is a luxury that Boeing cannot afford. Contrary to Mr. Reich's assertion, the Japanese venture does more to strengthen Boeing's position than to weaken it.

headline: 1,000 Protestants Riot In Northern Ireland
abstract: About 1,000 Protestant youths rampaged through a provincial Ulster town, attacked the police and stoned property early today, the authorities said.   Ten police officers were wounded and at least eight people arrested in a widespread night of violence against security forces in the province, a Belfast police spokesman said.   The police casualties all were in Portadown, 25 miles southwest of Belfast, where 1,000 youths roamed the streets in five hours of rioting that began Saturday night and lasted until 3 A.M. today, the police said.

headline: MORTGAGE LOAN PARTNERSHIPS
abstract: MORTGAGE loan partnerships, a little-known category of limited partnerships, may be suitable for investors looking for higher-than-average returns in tax-deferred accounts. Since such partnerships, however, offer more risk than the more common selections for Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh accounts, they should be carefully considered before purchase. Thus, while they may not be an appropriate last-minute choice in the few days remaining for 1985 I.R.A. investments, mortgage partnerships may be attractive to some investors planning 1986 contributions.   These income-oriented limited partnerships have a special appeal for tax-deferred retirement accounts because earnings would not immediately be subject to taxation. However, the 38 funds now on the market are also open to all investors seeking regular income plus equity participation.

headline: NEW LOOK PAYS OFF FOR FORD
abstract: The early returns are in, and the Ford Motor Company's $3 billion Taurus gamble appears to be paying off.   Introduced in the last days of last year after extensive delays, the European-looking Ford Taurus and its sister model, the Mercury Sable, are keeping two factories going at full tilt. Ford sold 99,500 of the midsized cars through May 10 and has orders for 120,000 more.   ''I think you have to call the Taurus program an unqualified success, except for the delays in getting it to market,'' said David Healy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: New Witco President
abstract: The Witco Corporation, a maker of specialty chemicals and petroleum products, said yesterday that Thomas J. Bickett, 47 years old, its executive vice president had become president and chief operating officer, succeeding William J. Ashe, who retired after 34 years with Witco. Witco announced the move in January but had not said when it would take effect.

headline: DOLLAR HITS LOW AGAIN VS. THE YEN
abstract: The dollar weakened further yesterday even though the West German central bank reportedly joined the Japanese in trying to stem the dollar's steady decline.   The dollar set another postwar low against the yen in Tokyo, falling to 167.35 yen, from 170.25 on Friday. In New York trading, the dollar ended at 167.30 yen. It also fell to a five-year low against the West German mark in European trading and a four-year low against the Swiss franc.

headline: Paris Seeks to Tighten Pretoria Trade Curbs
abstract: France said today that it would push for new European trade sanctions against South Africa at a meeting of Western European foreign ministers in Luxembourg on Monday.   The French Secretary of State for Human Rights, Claude Malhuret, said in a radio interview in Senegal that France favored such trade restrictions after the South African Government's declaration of a nationwide state of emergency.

headline: REAGAN ASKS VOTE FOR SAUDI MISSILES
abstract: President Reagan told Republican Congressional leaders today that a Senate vote later this week on the sale of missiles to Saudi Arabia would ''have a profound effect'' on United States relations with Arab states.   At stake in the vote, White House officials and Republican leaders emphasized, was nothing less than Mr. Reagan's influence among the less militant Arab countries and his leadership at home. ''The President's leadership is on the line, particularly as far as Republicans are concerned'' said Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, after the Republican legislators met with Mr. Reagan.   Senator Dole said: ''We're all running around the country praising Ronald Reagan for his great leadership, his 68 percent approval rating. And if we really believe what we say, then we ought to be with him on a critical issue like this.''

headline: Mohawk Sells Five Divisions
abstract: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation said it had completed the sale of five domestic divisions to a new private company formed by the New York venture capital firms of J.H. Whitney & Company and   Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe. Under the terms of the agreement, Mohawk, which manufactures computer and communications systems, will own 10 percent of the newly formed company and receive royalties over a 10-year period.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 18, 1986
abstract: International    Mexico President Miguel de la Madrid replaced Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog, amid reports of sharp differences within his Cabinet over Mexico's response to its latest foreign debt crisis. Gustavo Petricioli, director of the Nacional Financiera, a state-owned investment bank, was named to replace him.  [ Page D1. ]    The European Community wants to open trade-freeing talks covering agriculture and services as early as September, but they warned that the United States must also be ready to make concessions. The Administration welcomed the European stand.  [ D2. ]

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS'S NET SOARS
abstract: The American Express Company, the financial services conglomerate, reported yesterday that its net income more than doubled in the first quarter, bolstered by sharply higher profits at its securities brokerage subsidiary, Shearson Lehman Brothers.   American Express said net income was $321 million, a record for the company, compared with $151.6 million a year earlier. Earnings per share jumped to $1.40, from 67 cents, and revenues increased 37.3 percent, to $3.61 billion from $2.63 billion.

headline: 14 Killed in Sri Lanka In Fighting in North
abstract: Fourteen people were killed today in battles between Government troops and Tamil separatist guerrillas in the Jaffna district in northern Sri Lanka, security sources said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Illinois Tool Works has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $100 million of debt securities through Morgan Stanley & Company.    * Tuscon, Ariz., is offering $52 million of double-A-rated general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 7.90 percent for bonds due in 2015 through Bankers Trust. Yields on bonds with shorter maturities range from 4 3/4 percent in 1987 to 6 1/4 percent in 1991, 7.20 percent in 2001 and 7 3/4 percent in 2005. For longer maturities, a bond due in 2010 is offered to yield 7.80 percent.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Upjohn Shifts Are Indicated
abstract: The Upjohn Company has made some changes with its proprietary drug assignments that it has not announced yet.

headline: Agency Given Information
abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, in a statement issued today, said it had been provided information by the Soviet Union ''confirming the accident'' at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Ukraine.   The agency, which represents 112 nations under the auspices of the United Nations, said the information it received reported ''the partial destruction of structures'' and ''damage to buildings'' housing the reactor.

headline: TAX AMENDMENT HOPES DIM
abstract: Senators and lobbyists seeking changes in the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan are growing increasingly skeptical that they will be able to muster enough support on the Senate floor to push through major amendments.   More than two dozen amendments are expected to be proposed when the landmark legislation comes up for debate Wednesday. But some sponsors - including Senators Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, and Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota - are considering not calling for a vote after their amendments are debated for fear of suffering a major defeat and spoiling any chance for change in later negotiations with the House of Representatives.   ''At this point, it looks pretty clear that virtually no amendment is going to succeed on the floor,'' said Jonathan W. Fleming, an aide to Senator Cranston who is working on a Cranston-Boschwitz amendment to preserve preferential treatment for capital gains.

headline: A Top Arbitrager Is Won by Merrill
abstract: A top risk arbitrager has resigned from the Chemical Bank to join Merrill Lynch & Company, taking his staff with him.   In another illustration of what Wall Street has come to call ''gang hiring,'' Merrill said it had hired away from Chemical Timothy L. Tabor, a successful arbitrager, along with the two other executives in Mr. Tabor's unit, Ted Scott and Spencer Lambert. Mr. Tabor will immediately become director of risk arbitrage at Merrill with the two other executives reporting to him, the brokerage firm said.   To make room for Mr. Tabor, Merrill said it was promoting Thomas Burnett to the newly created position of director of international equity trading. Mr. Burnett will be responsible for overseeing the coordination of Merrill's trading activities of foreign stocks in New York, London, Tokyo and Toronto.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PANAMA GENERAL ACCUSED BY HELMS
abstract: Senator Jesse Helms said today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the army commander and strongman of Panama, was ''head of the biggest drug trafficking operation in the Western Hemisphere.''   Senator Helms, a North Carolina Republican who is a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, was the first American public official to affirm on the record published reports about what has been described as General Noriega's connection to drug traffic and other illegal activities. The first of the reports appeared in The New York Times on June 12.

headline: Ex-Bank Aide in Guilty Plea
abstract: Wayne Liang, formerly a marketing director for Chinatown's failed Golden Pacific National Bank, has pleaded guilty in Federal court in Manhattan to conspiring to have the bank make and conceal an illegal campaign contribution to the ''Cranston for President Campaign'' in 1983.   Rudolph W. Giuliani, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said there was no indication that Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, was aware of any illegality or impropriety in connection with the contribution.

headline: Fund, C.D. Yields Off
abstract: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds on the whole slipped lower for the week ended yesterday.   The Bank Rate Monitor's national index has now expanded to survey 100 of the largest-asset institutions in the nation's 10 largest metropolitan areas. The addition to the index of five new markets - Washington, Houston, Dallas, San Francisco and Boston - where there is a great deal of aggressive pricing has raised the average national yield on some accounts, thus affecting the index. The yield for a six-month certitifcate of deposit is 7.33 percent, while an average yield for a bank money market account is 6.68 percent.

headline: Data Bank: April 20, 1986
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: A MODEL AND A MURDER: ITALY'S HIGH LIFE ON TRIAL
abstract: Ever since she was a teen-ager in South Carolina dreaming of a modeling career, Terry Broome has wanted to be famous. Now she is photographed every day in a Milan courtroom, where she has admitted killing an Italian playboy and has spelled out the details of her cocaine addiction and her love affairs.   Miss Broome, 28 years old, faces possible life imprisonment for shooting Francesco D'Alessio, a member of a wealthy horse-breeding family, who she says insulted her repeatedly and treated her obscenely.   Her trial, which began last week, attracted many journalists and spectators, and it had to be moved to a larger courtroom. Aside from its prurient appeal, the trial has attracted much attention because it casts a shadow of scandal on some high-living and well-connected social circles. It also touches on a more general concern about the increasingly widespread use of cocaine by affluent young people in Italy.

headline: Wisconsin Bond Yields Range From 4.6% to 8%
abstract: While a number of large issues sensitive to fluctuations of interest rates have not yet been priced because of unfavorable market conditions, there is an ample supply on the competitive calendar.   Among the competitive issues yesterday was a $247.8 million tax-exempt offering of Wisconsin general obligation bonds that were priced through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Morgan Grenfell Plans Public Offer
abstract: Morgan Grenfell Holdings Ltd. said that it plans go public, listing its shares on the London Stock Exchange. The merchant bank said a letter would be sent to its existing shareholders soon and a further announcement would be made then.   A Morgan Grenfell spokesman said the bank could be looking to raise about $:100 million, or about $154 million, to help finance its international expansion program, including its fast-growing securities business.

headline: G.M. INCENTIVE PLAN
abstract: The General Motors Corporation will offer a new auto sales incentive program Sunday, with the centerpiece a prevailing loan interest rate of slightly more than 8 percent, WWJ radio in Detroit reported today. The program will contain as many as three interest rate programs on cars financed through its in-house credit subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

headline: Nortek Makes Offer
abstract: Nortek Inc., the Providence, R.I., textile manufacturer, said today that it has offered to purchase all of the outstanding shares of the Universal-Rundle Corporation for $27 a share in cash, or an estimated total of $42.7 million.

headline: PINOCHET IS IN NO HURRY TO RELAX AN IRON GRIP
abstract: In a country where most people are too law-abiding to display their graffiti skills, one scrawled phrase has stood out recently on a number of buildings: ''Halley, carry Pinochet away with you.''   Downtown, in the offices of one of Chile's many political parties, all theoretically illegal, hangs a photocopy of a newspaper front page for Feb. 26 on which the headline announcing the departure of President Ferdinand E. Marcos from the Philippines has been altered to read, ''Pinochet Resigned and Went Into Exile.''   But those who write or post such things and those who spend most of their waking hours analyzing Chilean politics consider it unlikely that Gen. Augusto Pinochet could be so easily removed after 12 years as Chile's ruler.   The explanation for that belief may lie in the other Halley-Pinochet line making the rounds in Santiago: As the comet began its movement away from Earth in its 75-year cycle, the 70-year-old President bade it farewell with the words, ''Until next time.''   While there is continuous public debate in Chile, with encouragement from the United States, about the possibility of freely electing a new president in 1989 or sooner and reinstituting all the trappings of democratic pluralism, General Pinochet himself has given no sign that he finds such ideas appealing.

headline: LOFT CONVERSION EXTENDS BOUNDARY OF COBBLE HILL
abstract: In some minds the cut of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway off Hicks Street represents something of a boundary for the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. It is in fact the boundary of the Cobble Hill Historic District.   In a housing sense, however, boundaries can be stretched. That is what seems to have happened in a new loft conversion under way on Tiffany Place - 70 condominium apartments in the first conversion of a manufacturing building in the mixed industrial and residential area just to the west of the expressway. The building will be known as One Tiffany Place.

headline: Big Block of Flick Shares Is Planned
abstract: The biggest flotation of shares in West German history was announced today when Deutsche Bank gave details of plans to sell the former Flick conglomerate's industrial core to the public.

headline: Market Place; Cray Soars; Doubts Rise
abstract: CRAY RESEARCH INC., the nation's leading manufacturer of supercomputers, has shown rapid growth over the last few years - and its stock has reflected this. Many investors, however, wonder how far the stock can go in an increasingly competitive environment.   Cray, which is based in Minneapolis, reported revenues of $142 million in the first quarter, up 19.3 percent from $119 million a year earlier. Net income amounted to $30.9 million, or $1 a share, compared with $30.8 million, or $1.02 a share, in the corresponding three months of 1985. Earnings were flat, the company said, because of ''significantly higher operating expenses, much of which were tied to personnel increases.''

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Bank of Tokyo Trust Company announced that Boris S. Berkovitch, who retired as vice chairman of J. P. Morgan & Co. and its subsidiary Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. of New York in March, had been elected to its board of directors.

headline: ANSWERS EMERGING ON SENATE TAX BILL
abstract: As more details of the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan emerge, new questions have been raised by individuals trying to grasp the impact of the sweeping proposal.   The plan is still being drafted by committee staff members. But in recent days aides and Treasury officials have provided some specifics of what the final document will include.   The tax bill, unanimously approved by the committee two weeks ago, is expected to reach the Senate floor early next month after Congress returns from its Memorial Day recess.   Here are answers to some of the latest questions about the tax plan:   Q. Why does support for the Senate committee's bill seem to be so much broader among businesses and other interest groups than for the House version?

headline: Both Iran and Iraq Cite Gains In Fighting in Their Gulf War
abstract: Iran said today that its forces had inflicted 4,000 casualties on the southern front and Iraq contended that it had captured 17 enemy positions in the rugged mountains on the northern border.   Iranian forces advanced more than a mile along the Fao-Basra highway in an overnight attack in which 4,000 Iraqis were killed or wounded and many were captured, according to a military communique quoted by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency.

headline: TRENDY MOSCOW MALL DRAWS SHOPPERS AS WINTER DEPARTS
abstract: With the arrival of warmer weather and the reappearance of sidewalks buried for months under ice, Muscovites have shed their fur hats and abandoned the shelter of their apartments.   One of their favorite destinations is a downtown shopping mall that is the Soviet Union's answer to American urban developments like the South Street Seaport in New York or the Faneuil Hall area in Boston.   The mall is on the Arbat, an old shopping street. Until last summer, when it was turned over to pedestrians, it was clogged with traffic and had a series of unexceptional shops.

headline: BRACING FOR THE TAX CHANGE SWEEPSTAKES
abstract: RADICAL tax changes seem all but certain in 1986, and the only question is what shape the final legislation will take. Because the House and Senate tax plans contain widely differing provisions, a number of people are simply refusing to make any investment decisions until the Congressional conferees emerge with a finished product.   But many financial experts say that a passive approach is the wrong way to go. Among the strategies they suggest are these:    * Selling certain appreciated stocks now, so that profits can be taxed at the current favorable rate on long-term capital gains;    * Reinvesting the proceeds in tax-exempt securities, such as tax-free money market funds or short-term municipal bond funds;    * Purchasing tax-favored investments such as universal life insurance policies;    * Holding onto existing tax shelters instead of trying to unload them in the secondary market.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: IT'S A HAPPY TIME FOR THE MOTORIST
abstract: Plentiful gasoline, at sharply lower prices, will make this Memorial Day weekend, the traditional start of the peak summer driving season, one of the least worrisome for motorists in recent years, according to oil industry experts and motoring groups.   Nationally, all grades of gasoline now average 92 cents a gallon at the pump, according to Lundberg Survey Inc., an oil industry consulting firm. That price is 2 cents higher than the low of 90 cents a gallon, reached in late April. However, it remains far below the average $1.21 a gallon at the beginning of the year.

headline: INVESTING; AN UNCERTAIN TIME FOR TAX-EXEMPTS
abstract: IN recent weeks, tax-exempt bonds have been held hostage by two forces: the likelihood of tax revision and the threat of higher interest rates.  ''We are finding an awful lot of people in America are real confused about tax reform, and don't know what to do,'' said Guy Wickwire, a vice president of Fidelity Investments in Boston and portfolio manager of the Fidelity High Yield Municipal Bond Fund. ''Consequently, they are doing nothing.''  And many investors fear that interest rates may head higher and cause a plunge in bond prices.

headline: I.R.A. BOMB IN ULSTER KILLS A MILITIAMAN
abstract: An Irish Republican Army bomb killed an off-duty militiaman today and Protestant radicals attacked the homes of four police officers on the ninth day of violence against a British-Irish agreement.   The off-duty member of the Ulster Defense Regiment was killed in County Tyrone near the border with the Irish Republic when a booby-trap bomb blew up a trailer he was repairing.

headline: Justice Dept. Backs RCA's Sale to G.E.
abstract: The Justice Department today endorsed the General Electric Company's proposed purchase of the RCA Corporation for $6.28 billion, raising no objections to the two companies' overlapping electronics business.   The combination, which still faces approval by the Federal Communications Commission, would be the largest non-oil acquisition in American history. RCA is the parent of the National Broadcasting Company.

headline: The U.N. Today: April 10, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for Disarmament and Development Conference - 11:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: GRUMMAN OFFICIAL TO GET PRESIDENCY
abstract: The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday that it had named John O'Brien an executive vice president, and said he would be named president on Aug. 1, when George M. Skurla, the current president, is scheduled to retire.   Mr. O'Brien, 55 years old, is president of Grumman's Data Systems division.   The company was recently restructured into 10 operating divisions. ''This is a transition year,'' Mr. O'Brien said, ''and we have had some pains, but we are seeing a major benefit of encouraging entrepreneurship and moving into other markets.'' Two of them, he said, were data systems and electronic test equipment.

headline: U.S. FAILS TO HEAL NEW ZEALAND RIFT
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand met today but failed to reach agreement on saving the 35-year-old alliance between their countries from collapsing later this summer over differences on nuclear policy.   Unless there is an unexpected shift by Mr. Lange's Government, this would mean the virtual end of the three-way Anzus alliance, between Australia, New Zealand and the United States, which has been in effect since 1951. Legislation on Ship Visits    The treaty will not be formally abrogated but the United States has already served notice that if New Zealand enacts legislation barring visits by nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships as scheduled in August, Washington will no longer be bound by the treaty to come to New Zealand's defense.   After a meeting with Mr. Lange this morning, Mr. Shultz told reporters that they had been unable to reconcile their differences.

headline: OPPOSITION IS SEEN ON DETROIT LINKUP
abstract: Yesterday's announcement that The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News had agreed to merge came as no surprise to newspaper analysts who have watched them wage a costly competitive war.   By merging production, advertising and circulation operations, while retaining separate news departments, the two newspapers could quickly become very profitable after years of losses.   But some experts in newspaper antitrust law predict that the proposed Free Press-News joint operating agreement, known in the industry as a j.o.a., will prompt a fierce legal challenge. They say competing suburban newspapers and unions are likely to oppose the merger on the ground that the resulting mega-daily would represent an economic monopoly that would thwart suburban competition and eliminate jobs.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 9, 1986
abstract: The Senate Tax Plan    President Reagan will actively seek Congressional support for the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision plan, White House officials said.  [ Page A1. ]  The tax-rate structure outlined in the committee's plan is neither as low, nor as simple, as advertised. Upper-income individuals would find that some of their income would be taxed at a rate of 32 percent, or higher.  [ D4. ]  All the committee members got favorable treatment for their constituents. Senator Moynihan, who backed the chairman, Bob Packwood, at every turn, got all he asked for.  [ D4. ]    A number of trade and industry groups are protesting some provisions of the plan. The bill would significantly alter planning for retirement, especially affecting I.R.A.'s. Real estate experts said the bill would discourage investors from putting money into real estate deals. For business meals and entertaining, only 80 percent of the expenses would be deductible, a proposal that drew complaints from the service sector. Tax-exempt financing for pollution-control facilities would end. Some venture capitalists said less would be invested in small, entrepreneurial companies because the preferential treatment for capital gains would be ended. Consumer lenders, however, said borrowing patterns would not change much even though interest deductions would be less valuable.  [ D5. ]

headline: CAMPAIGNING STARTS IN JAPAN FOR JULY 6 VOTE
abstract: Official campaigning began today for parliamentary elections that may determine whether Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone can defy political odds and stay in office beyond this year.   The elections on July 6 will be something of a rarity. For only the second time in postwar Japan, voters will select both houses of Parliament on the same day, a scheduling twist that the the Prime Minister hopes will stimulate the turnout to the governing party's advantage.   Whatever the results, they are unlikely to alter basic Japanese policies, which emphasize economic growth at home and alliance with the United States on most international matters. Barring an electoral cataclysm, Mr. Nakasone's Liberal Democratic Party is all but certain to retain the power it has held since 1955.

headline: ATHENS REPORTER FILES LIBEL SUIT IN '83 DISPUTE
abstract: A reporter here filed a libel suit today against the publisher of Greece's largest newspaper, a week after the Athens prosecutor charged the journalist with threatening terrorist acts against the paper.   The developments added another twist to a three-year-old legal battle involving charges by the newspaper that the reporter is a spy for the Central Intelligence Agency and charges by the reporter that the newspaper is controlled by the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence service.   The reporter, Paul Anastasiades, a Cypriot journalist based in Athens, sued the publisher, the editor and three staff members of the left-leaning daily Ethnos for defamation of character and perjury.

headline: Pennsylvania Bell Offering at 8 3/4%
abstract: The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania is offering $275 million of 8 3/4 percent debentures due 2026 at a price of par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The 40-year debentures, which are refundable after five years, are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P. and yield about 1.22 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

headline: Most Yields Fall Again
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts declined for the week ended yesterday. But money market mutual funds rose.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, the average yield for six-month certificates of deposit fell 4 basis points, to 6.80 percent, while the average yield of bank money market accounts, which compete directly with money market mutual funds, lost 2 basis points, slipping to 6.26 percent.

headline: U.S. TO ASK FARM TALKS IN TOKYO
abstract: President Reagan will urge participants at the Tokyo economic summit conference next week to work toward a reduction of quotas, subsidies and other barriers to world trade in farm goods, according to senior Administration officials.   ''President Reagan is going to raise these issues there,'' Clayton K. Yeutter, the President's special trade representative, said in an interview today.   Concern over the long-intractable issue of protectionism in farm trade and the taxpayer cost of supporting farmers both in the United States and Europe has produced a ''quasi-crisis situation'' in just the last few weeks, he said. ''To me that's good,'' he said, ''because people respond to crises.''

headline: BONNER SAYS SAKHAROV FILMS ARE K.G.B.'S WORK
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner said today that recent films purporting to portray the views of her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, were part of a disinformation campaign by the K.G.B.   Miss Bonner said at a news conference here this afternoon, ''In recent years the world has only received false information about him.'' She said many of the untruths could be found in the dispatches of official Soviet press agencies.   Miss Bonner singled out the Soviet journalist Victor Louis as the ''acme'' of disinformation. Mr. Louis, who often appears to reflect official thinking in Moscow, said Thursday that Miss Bonner's behavior in her six-month stay in the West posed an ''obstacle'' to Dr. Sakharov's return to Moscow from internal exile in Gorky.

headline: Advertising; Southwestern Aims At the Yellow Pages
abstract: High above the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 43d Street on a 53-foot-by-96-foot billboard where Sergio Valente long held sway, workmen are putting the finishing touches on the latest tweek of New York Telephone by the guys from Southwestern Bell.   The words are already there, ''Our new Yellow Pages is about to give your walking fingers a hand.''   Anyone in New York who can see or hear must be aware that Southwestern Bell, which already claims to be the world's largest publisher of Yellow Pages directories, is prepared to take advantage of the relaxed atmosphere following divestiture by entering markets where it thinks it can do better than the indigenous publisher.

headline: New Battles Erupt In Beirut Suburbs
abstract: Gun battles went on unabated today in Beirut's southern suburbs between Palestinians in three districts and militiamen of the Shiite Moslem movement Amal, who surround the areas.

headline: CALAMITY HIGHLIGHTS OLD REACTOR-DESIGN DEBATE
abstract: The Soviet nuclear disaster has brought to the fore a debate regarding reactor design that began almost a half century ago during the development of the University of Chicago ''pile'' that produced the world's first chain reaction.   The discussion concerns how best to slow neutrons in the reactor sufficiently to sustain a chain reaction. When a uranium atom is split it ejects neutrons at such high velocity that they are unlikely to split other atoms. Unless the neutrons are slowed, or moderated, a chain reaction cannot occur.

headline: Poland Indicts A Solidarity Figure
abstract: A military prosecutor has indicted Tadeusz Jedynak, a Solidarity underground leader, on a charge of plotting to overthrow Poland's Communist system by force, according to a published report.

headline: Economic Scene; Need for U.S. Leadership
abstract: THE annual economic summit conferences of the seven major industrial democracies -the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - have increasingly been dominated by political events.   Last year's reunion in Bonn was swamped by emotions stirred up by President Reagan's visit to the Bitburg military cemetery, at which some S.S. troops were buried. It now looks as though this year's economic summit conference, to be held in Tokyo from May 4 to 6, may be overwhelmed by debates over how to deal with international terrorism following the United States air attack on Libya and the refusal by France, and Spain as well, according to a member of the Spanish Cabinet, to let the American planes use their airspace.   President Reagan has said that at Tokyo he will press for stronger joint action against Libya and terrorism. France's denial of its airspace to American planes, he added, was ''a subject that must be discussed.'' Mr. Reagan said some European nations were already talking about ''a wider-based and more all-out effort'' against Libya.

headline: Market Place; Western Union Maneuvers
abstract: FOR months, Drexel Burnham Lambert worked to devise a plan to restructure the Western Union Corporation. In mid-March, the blueprint for getting the communications company back on its feet was announced. Western Union's banks applauded the proposal, which is subject to approval by the company's debt and stock holders, but it has generally received a cool reception on Wall Street.   That's why, Wall Street sources say, it was not surprising when Drexel officials earlier this month asked Victor Palmieri, New York investor and bailout specialist, if he would like to try his hand at turning the company around.

headline: Punjab Police Chief Vows 4-to-1 Vengeance
abstract: Punjab's new police chief vowed today over the body of a slain policeman to take four lives for every police officer killed by Sikh extremists.   The pledge came as Sikh separatists killed two people near the holy city of Amritsar, bringing the death toll from extremist violence in the northern state to 120 in five weeks.

headline: DOW PLUNGES 28.50 IN HEAVY SELLING
abstract: Stock prices plunged yesterday, with prices hurt by sell programs that began after Prime Computer projected a 25 percent drop in first-quarter earnings.   The Dow Jones industrial average was off about 35 points in late afternoon and ended with a drop of 28.50 points at 1,790.11. The decline was the biggest since March 21, when the Dow fell 35.68, to 1,768.56.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 13, 1986
abstract: Markets    The S.E.C. charged a Wall Street merger specialist with operating an insider trading scheme that brought at least $12.6 million in profits over five years. The commission, in its largest insider case ever, said a managing director of Drexel Burnham Lambert bought and sold stock and stock options in 54 companies.  [ A1. ]    Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell by a point or more as securities dealers found that demand from domestic investors for last week's new issues was very weak.  [ D1. ]

headline: New Phelps Dodge Chief
abstract: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that its 56-year-old president, G. Robert Durham, had been named to the additional post of chief executive.

headline: BAKER SAYS THAT U.S. HAS NO DOLLAR TARGET
abstract: The Reagan Administration has no target for the dollar's international value but did discuss the importance of ''stability'' in the yen-dollar rate at recent meetings in Tokyo, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today.   Mr. Baker, responding to questions at a Senate hearing, said the dollar's decline had been ''orderly'' and had created no financing problems for the Treasury. ''We have not experienced any difficulty in placing Government securities, in financing the operations of the U.S. Government, and we don't anticipate any difficulties,'' he added.   When Mr. Baker, an architect of the dollar's lower value, said the Administration did not have a target for the currency, the dollar moved sharply higher. Traders said the comments might represent a softening in the Administration's desire to see the dollar fall.  [ Page D17. ]  Volcker Unhappiness The dollar also gained strength when Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve's chairman, was quoted by Reuters as saying the dollar's fall against the yen ''doesn't make me happy.''

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN PERSONAL SERVICES
abstract: TIME is money, the adage goes. And a growing number of people, particularly in two-career families, are willing to spend some money to buy some time.   They have given rise to a whole new personal services industry whose practitioners will, for a fee, do just about anything that needs doing. They will plan wardrobes or buy theater tickets. They will visit homes and offices to give massages or hold one-on-one exercise classes. They will prescreen baby sitters, plan parties, even buy gifts and send them to the right people at the right time.

headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; HUNTING FOR RICHES IN THE ATTIC CHEST
abstract: NEARLY everyone has run across old stock or bond certificates in a trunk in the attic, among the belongings of a deceased relative, or even at a garage sale. But how to determine if they are treasure or trash? Going through the safe of my late father, I found stacks of obsolete certificates, mainly Canadian mining stocks, and embarked upon a quest to determine whether they had financial, collectible or simply sentimental value.  There are many reasons why a certificate may be obsolete - the company may have changed its name, gone into bankruptcy, or merged with another entity, to name a few. Many people mistakenly consider securities worthless if they are not among the financial listings in the newspaper; in fact, many small but active issues are not quoted on a regular basis. If the issuer has been through a name change, the surviving company may be listed and the old certificates have value.

headline: SALES TAX PROVISO IN SENATE BILL
abstract: The Senate agreed today to allow people who live in states with little or no income tax to deduct a portion of their state and local sales tax payments on their Federal tax returns.   The measure would also require taxpayers to list on their tax returns the Social Security numbers of dependents at least 5 years old for whom they claim a personal exemption. This would vastly increase the number of small children who would need Social Security identification.   With the main elements of the landmark tax-revision bill apparently in place, the Senate reached a unanimous agreement tonight to take a final vote on the legislation Tuesday afternoon. No one doubts that the measure, reducing income tax rates and disallowing many deductions and other tax preferences, will pass and will be sent to a conference with the House of Representatives.

headline: 3-State House Vote On Trade Bill
abstract: Following are the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House approved sweeping trade legislation calling for sharp import curbs. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the bill; a ''no'' vote was a vote against the bill; an ''xxx'' denotes a member not voting.

headline: IN COLOMBIA VOLCANO STIRS MORE TROUBLE
abstract: Isolated white and pink crosses, each marked with the fateful date of Nov. 13, 1985, now stand in silent protest against the fury of nature on the vast and desolate mudbank where about 22,000 people lie buried.   Nearby, solitary scavengers wander among the few abandoned homes that somehow survived the onslaught of water, stones and mud released by a volcanic eruption. And here, too, there is now silence.   Armero, a once-prosperous town of 40,000 inhabitants, is no longer. Survivors of Colombia's worst natural disaster have been scattered to towns near and far to try to rebuild their lives and families.

headline: WALDHEIM PLEDGES FIGHT AGAINST BIAS
abstract: Kurt Waldheim, holding his first news conference since his election as Austria's President, said today that his victorious election campaign had been devoid of appeals to anti-Semitism and he promised to oppose discrimination against Jews.   He also said he welcomed a proposal that a commission of historians investigate his war record, and he called on Yugoslavia to release documents touching on his German Army service.   ''I welcome all efforts in this regard because they can only help me in clarifying the situation,'' Mr. Waldheim said of the proposal for a panel of military historians to study his war years in Greece and the Balkans. The proposal was made this week by Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi-hunter.

headline: Survey Sees Outlay Dip
abstract: Caught in a sluggish economy, American companies say their projected spending for new facilities and equipment in 1986 will be slightly less than what they spent in 1985, according to a survey by McGraw-Hill Economics, a unit of Data Resources Inc.   The companies projected outlays of about $384.5 billion this year, down five-tenths of 1 percent from actual spending in 1985.

headline: Talking Business with Prestowitz of Commerce Dept.; Trade Friction With Japanese
abstract: For nearly five years Clyde V. Prestowitz, counselor to the Secretary of Commerce, has been the chief coordinator on issues related to Japan and has built a reputation as one of the sternest critics of Japanese trading policy.   Before joining the Administration, Mr. Prestowitz was a graduate student at Keio University in Tokyo, worked for multinational companies and started his own international consulting company.   He has announced that he is leaving his post to join the Woodrow Wilson Center of the Smithsonian Institution and do some writing and lecturing. Q. What is the source of the Japan frictions? A. The U.S. is the world's leading industrial and technological power, and Japan is second. Japan has been reducing the U.S. lead and has overcome it in some areas. That inevitably brings frictions, which both sides have been struggling to contain.

headline: Unocal Job Trims
abstract: A continuing drop in oil prices has prompted the Unocal Corporation to try to pare its work force with an early retirement offer that it expects to attract about 1,000 of the 1,600 eligible workers.

headline: Market Place; A.M.A. to Own Fund Manager
abstract: MOVE over Dreyfus, Vanguard Group and Fidelity Investments. The American Medical Association is going into the mutual fund business. The A.M.A. plans to acquire the stock of PRO Services Inc., a mutual fund management company based in Blue Bell, Pa., for $3.5 million in cash and $500,000 in notes.   PRO Services, whose name will be changed to AMA Advisers Inc., is the investment adviser to four no-load mutual funds with net assets totaling $166 million and to one closed-end investment company. Fund shareholders are scheduled to vote July 15 on the transaction.

headline: MEXICO DRUG PROFITS FLOWING TO U.S.
abstract: Mexican drug traffickers have deposited billions of dollars in United States banks and other financial institutions in recent years, a significant part of their illicit profits, according to public documents and American law enforcement officials.   Documents in one case now being tried in San Antonio show that 40 banks, ranging from tiny Texas border banks to some of the nation's largest, were used to hide profits by a Mexican ring reported to have imported some $125 million of marijuana into the United States.   Financial institutions are generally not prohibited from accepting criminal-related funds provided all large cash transactions are reported to the Federal Government. Officials Criticize Banks    Federal law enforcement officials said few United States banks knowingly handle transactions linked to drugs or other illegal activities. But the officials criticized banks for too easily accepting what turn out to be drug-related deposits.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: Sperry gave in to Burroughs's advances. It agreed to be acquired for $76.50 a share, or $4.8 billion, creating the second-largest computer company after I.B.M. The price is well below the $80 a share Sperry was hoping to command and not much above Burroughs's previous offer of $75. Burroughs had started the bidding at $70 a share early in May, coupling it with a tender offer that angered Sperry into threatening a self-tender. But Sperry apparently was unable to find a more generous partner, and thus was forced to reward the persistence of W. Michael Blumenthal, the former Treasury Secretary and Burroughs's chairman.   Burroughs is hoping Sperry's mainframes will give it the added clout it needs to challenge I.B.M. But some analysts - and users - say the merger of two such incompatible computer lines could mean less attention for each line and could drive many customers to I.B.M.

headline: LETTING COMPUTERS TRACK AESTHETICS
abstract: UNTIL two years ago, Lawrence Levine, the administrator of Chemical Bank's 1,600-piece art collection, tried to keep track of the inventory on hundreds of handwritten, and often illegible, lists. Now the location of any piece of art, and its value, purchase date, media, artist, dealer, framer and dimensions, are available at the touch of a button. ''The computer will give me all the art in the London office - or all the art on the seventh floor of the Lexington Avenue office,'' he marvels.

headline: Economic Scene; MILITARY COSTS AN ISRAELI ISSUE
abstract: PRIME MINISTER SHIMON PERES, in the midst of controversies here over the purported misconduct of Israel's intelligence services at home and abroad, stressed in an interview the most positive of his administration's accomplishments: the sharp drop in Israeli inflation.   From an annual rate of more than 500 percent during the first half of 1985, the inflation rate has fallen to between 15 and 20 percent.   ''I don't know of any other country that could have achieved it,'' Mr. Peres said. ''We hope to bring it down to 6 percent by the end of the year.''

headline: QADDAFI IS ABSENT FROM OBSERVANCE
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi failed to appear tonight at what Libyan officals had said would be his first major public appearance since the April 15 American air raids on this country.   Instead, Colonel Qaddafi, puffy-faced and with bags under his eyes, delivered a rambling hour-and-50-minute speech broadcast over the Government-run television and from loudspeakers on public buildings. There was no official explanation for the change in plans. More than 30 Western journalists, including representatives of the major American newspapers, wire services, magazines and television networks were invited here to witness Colonel Qaddafi's appearance.

headline: Wood Gundy Merger Is Off
abstract: In a surprise announcement, Wood Gundy Inc. and the Gordon Capital Corporation, two major Canadian securities companies, said yesterday that they were calling off a merger that they had announced publicly just three weeks ago.   The short statement, released late yesterday in Toronto, said that ''the parties have been unable to reach a mutually satisfactory agreement.''

headline: SPERRY'S SKILLED AND DOGGED PURSUER
abstract: W. Michael Blumenthal, the chairman of the Burroughs Corporation, loves to negotiate. He has studied the art of negotiating, and practices his skill whenever he can, even, on occasion, entertaining friends by trying to negotiate discounts at restaurants.   All of Mr. Blumenthal's practice paid off this week, when his lengthy and determined negotiations finally led to the Sperry Corporation's $4.8 billion agreement to merge with Burroughs. Whether it was working out the intricate provisions of the securities that Burroughs will use to pay for the deal, or the tax treatment of the compensation packages for Sperry executives, Mr. Blumenthal was intimately involved.

headline: REALIZING A DECADES-OLD DREAM; THE IRRESISTIBLE LOGIC OF TAX REFORM
abstract: THE Senate Finance Committee has been forced by the inexorable logic of comprehensive income taxation to report out a real tax reform bill. Apparently, the trade-off of tax preferences for lower tax rates was irresistible.  At first, though, the committee followed its usual practice of handing out tax favors having no rhyme or reason other than to help favorite constituents. But it soon found that it was losing too much ground and that there was no place to stop. It then reversed gears and went in the opposite direction, promoted by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, and others, of broadening the tax base and using the increased tax revenues to cut rates. That's something that many of us have been advocating for years, and we heartily endorse it.  The howls of the special interests reflect the true nature of comprehensive tax reform. The elimination of tax preferences hurts the few, while the rate reductions help the majority who pay taxes on all or most of their income. The result is that individuals and businesses with the same income will pay more nearly equal taxes. Equity will be better served, and the huge economic distortions created by the present system will be reduced.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: A May 25 article about bottled water omitted a major national distributor.

headline: Retirement: Plan Ahead For Income
abstract: AS people prepare to retire, they usually cover the basics. They learn about their pension, their Social Security benefits, their coverage under a company health plan and the role of Medicare. But there is much more that individuals should consider in planning for retirement, the experts say.   As retirement approaches, many people look at their four walls as a profit center. Sell the house, the theory goes, and buy another more convenient, smaller one or buy a condominium and receive a tax advantage under current laws.   Certainly a home lived in for 10 to 20 years or more has probably gained a lot in value. However, some persons live in houses that are not too big for their needs.

headline: ATTITUDE OF THE LIBYANS: ONE OF PASSIVE WAITING
abstract: There is about the residents of this capital a sense of being playgoers passively watching an unfolding drama.   As much of the American Sixth Fleet steams from Spanish ports across the Mediterranean for possible renewed actions against this desert country, many Libyans wait with a blend of aloofness, apprehension, even fatalism, but little action.   There were no rallies today, no angry speeches, no ringing jingoism on television. Most shops closed as usual on a Thursday afternoon in preparation for the Moslem sabbath Friday.

headline: MURDOCH OFFERS PRINTERS A $17 MILLION PLANT
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born newspaper publisher, offered Friday night to give printing unions his abandoned plant in central London as a way of settling a dispute with them over his move to a computerized site in January, when he dismissed nearly 6,000 workers.   Union leaders reacted cautiously today to the unexpected offer, but they did not reject it altogether. ''It can certainly be part of a settlement,'' said Brenda Dean, general secretary of the Society of Graphical and Allied Trades, the main printers union. ''But this offer alone will not end the dispute.''

headline: Careers; 'Survivors' Syndrome' In Layoffs
abstract: WHEN the Occidental Petroleum Corporation recently announced the dismissal of 2,000 employees, the move was the latest in a series of cutbacks by many companies that have resulted in a lot of unemployed middle managers.   Much has been said about the plight of people who lose their jobs in corporate downsizing, but what about those who are still on the payroll?   These employees often experience ''survivors' syndrome,'' marked by feelings of anxiety, distrust, fear and insecurity, according to L. Marshall Stellfox, a partner in the Goodrich & Sherwood Company, a human resources consulting firm.

headline: A COMPETITIVE LIABILITY; RIDDING WALL STREET OF A SHORT-TERM BIAS
abstract: AMERICA'S growing problems with international competition are too often blamed on the usual suspects: high labor costs, unfair trade practices and the overvalued dollar. The role of our financial system is overlooked. It shouldn't be. By favoring short-term, high-return deals at the expense of riskier, long-term investments, the capital markets discourage investment in the companies and technologies that we need to compete in world markets.  The capital markets' short-term bias, which has developed over the past decade, robs industry of the capital it needs to move new technologies out of the lab and into the market. Investors' time horizons are now out of step with the incubation periods of critical new technologies. At the same time, financial deregulation has spurred rapid - often chaotic -change just when key industries need stable financial relationships. Unless we address these problems, they will sap our system of the long-term capital vital to future competitiveness.

headline: JOHN PAUL, ISSUING FIFTH ENCYCLICAL, ATTACKS MARXISM
abstract: Pope John Paul II issued the fifth encyclical of his papacy today, denouncing Marxism and other forms of philosophical materialism as ideologies that portray ''God as an enemy of his own creature.''   In the 141-page document brimming with references to Satan and to the coming of the third millennium, John Paul sought to focus the attention of Roman Catholics on the Holy Spirit, the mysterious third person of the Trinity whom Christians revere, along with the Father and the Son, as the one God.   The encyclical, ''Dominum et Vivificantem'' (''The Lord and Giver of Life''), is a highly personal revery by John Paul on one of the richest but most elusive concepts of the Christian faith - in the Pope's words, the ''hidden God'' who is the Holy Spirit. Harsh Critique of Modern World   But John Paul, as is his habit, used these reflections to undergird a harsh critique of the modern world, with ''its signs and symptoms of death,'' and of ideologies he sees as destroying a spiritual vision of humanity.   He underscored the importance he ascribed to his message by issuing it as an encyclical, which is the most formal teaching instrument of the papacy.

headline: Technology; Tripping Up Enemy Radar
abstract: IN World War II, the German military, concerned that its U-boats' jutting snorkels might be vulnerable to detection by Allied radar, applied a radar-absorbent coating to the snorkels to make the U-boats far more difficult to detect.   In the last few years, such technology has enjoyed major advances, promising to make planes and missiles much harder to see on enemy radar. The Northrop Corporation is using such technology, which has come to be known as Stealth, in a bomber, drones and a tactical cruise missile. The Lockheed Corporation is using it in a fighter plane, and General Dynamics is adopting it for a cruise missile.

headline: World Bank Asks Increase
abstract: World Bank policy makers agreed Friday to seek to nearly double the level of loans the bank makes to debt-burdened developing nations, to $21.5 billion a year by 1990.   The plan may require the bank to seek a multibillion dollar increase in its capital reserves as early as next year, the outgoing bank president, A. W. Clausen, told a news briefing.

headline: MISSILE BACKERS ARE RE-ELECTED IN NETHERLANDS
abstract: The Prime Minister of the Netherlands, facing what polls had predicted would be a narrow defeat in parliamentary elections, carried his center-right coalition to triumph today.   The victory by Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers removed the possibility that there would be a reconsideration of the Netherlands' wrenching decision to deploy 48 American ground-launched cruise missiles in 1988.   The elections turned in large part on the issue of Mr. Lubbers's efforts to trim the welfare state and stimulate economic growth.   But at the same time, the vote was widely seen as a personal victory for the 47-year-old Prime Minister, a millionaire businessman who in the last four years has emerged as the dominant figure in Dutch politics.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Marion Laboratories, Kansas City, Mo., to Rolf Werner Rosenthal for the angina medication Cardizem.

headline: Earthquake Rattles Greece
abstract: A strong earthquake measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale jolted eastern Greece today, but there were no reports of injuries or damage. A spokesman for the Athens Seismological Institute said the quake was centered in the Aegean between the islands of Euboea and Chios, about 80 miles northeast of Athens.

headline: Ford Splits Stock, Raises Dividend
abstract: The Ford Motor Company announced a 3-for-2 stock split, raising the number of shares outstanding to 270 million from 180 million.

headline: BOMB KILLS 11 IN A CHRISTIAN ENCLAVE NEAR BEIRUT
abstract: A car bomb exploded in Lebanon's largest Christian town today, killing at least 11 people, wounding 100 others and setting several buildings ablaze.   A Christian radio station, the Voice of Lebanon, said hospitals in the town, Junieh, were overflowing with casualties. Several calls for blood donations were made.

headline: BIRTHDAY GALA FOR SAKHAROV AT TOWN HALL
abstract: It was a birthday party to remember. There were offerings of roses and lilacs, music and poetry by Russian emigre artists, a gift from Afghan insurgents and a cake with 65 candles.   Then everyone last night at the Town Hall auditorium in New York joined in singing ''Happy Birthday'' to Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and rights advocate. The occasion was a tribute to the banished physicist on his 65th birthday today.

headline: INDIA COURT AWAITING BHOPAL SUIT
abstract: Like its counterparts in the United States, the hulking Tis Hazari courthouse in Old Delhi is a place of human woe. Some 50,000 people, wearing suits or wearing rags, are said to enter its portals each day seeking justice.   Ask any lawyer or citizen in the bustling building about Indian courts, and the biggest complaint is the same. They talk of delays in adjudicating cases - not just years, but decades.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 28, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   General Committee - 9:45 A.M.

headline: ADVERTISING; Minority Recruitment
abstract: Among black advertising agency executives the poor performance of general agencies in minority recruitment in the professional area is a continuing cause for concern.

headline: Virginia Housing Mortgage Bonds
abstract: The Virginia Housing Development Authority is offering $93.7 million of residential mortgage bonds with a maximum yield of 7.55 percent for an issue due in 2012 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   Yields on shorter-term maturities range from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.70 percent in 1991, 6.70 percent in 1996 and 7.30 percent in 2002. The financing also included 7 1/2 percent bonds due in 2007 at a price of par. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

headline: RENEWING TRADITIONAL VALUES
abstract: The wallflower is becoming the belle of the ball. A decade-long debate over what is wrong with American business and how to cure it has produced a surprising model for success: the family business.   As old as America itself, the family business is being rediscovered as the embodiment of the management practices and business values needed to help the nation's industries regain their competitive edge.   The best family companies have long cared about product quality, treated employees with respect and focused on more lasting concerns than the next quarter's results. These values, business critics say, are exactly what Japan has cultivated and the United States has generally neglected.

headline: SHULTZ HAS PRAISE FOR SOVIET COURAGE AT CHERNOBYL
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today praised the Soviet people for showing courage and sacrifice in the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.   Mr. Shultz spent an hour in his office with three bone marrow specialists -Robert Gale, Paul Terasaki and Richard Champlin - who had gone to the Soviet Union to treat victims.   ''I was impressed and inspired by Dr. Gale's descriptions of the courage and sacrifice with which his Soviet colleagues and the Soviet people as a whole, have sought to cope with the effects of the accident,'' Mr. Shultz said in a written statement after the meeting. ''The United States stands ready to lend a hand in any way we can in helping the Soviet Union recover from the tragedy.''

headline: PERU SAYS TROOPS MAY HAVE ERRED AT JAIL
abstract: The Government has acknowledged that the military may have used excessive force in retaking one of the three prisons where imprisoned guerrillas rioted last week.   A communique Saturday night from the press office of President Alan Garcia said the Government ''guaranteed'' that the guilty would be punished. It said the military command had been ordered to begin the necessary investigations.   At the same time, the Government expressed support for the armed forces, which it said had ''loyally complied with their obligation of service to the nation and obedience to the constitutional Government.''

headline: Missouri Begins $385 Million Offer
abstract: Missouri is offering $385 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, which submitted the winning bid yesterday.   Yields on the triple-rated issue range from 4.25 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.90 percent in 1991, 6.90 percent in 1996, 7.40 percent in 2001 and 7.50 percent in 2005 through 2010.

headline: END OF GIMBELS IS REPORTED NEAR
abstract: The owner of Gimbels, after six months of searching for a buyer who would continue to operate the two Manhattan outlets as department stores, has given up and will sell both properties to a real estate developer, according to parties close to the negotiations.   By the end of the year, the Gimbels name, a force in retailing for 140 years, will apparently disappear.   While no contract has been signed, Batus, the current owner, has narrowed the field of prospective buyers to one company, the London and Leeds Corporation, which is expected to pay more than $130 million for the flagship operation on West 33d Street and the chronically weak outlet on East 86th Street.   According to brokers and analysts, the stores will be closed before the end of the year and the sites redeveloped, which will put 5,000 employees out of work. Gimbels has already canceled all orders for merchandise for the New York stores, as well as for the rest of the Gimbels chain.

headline: Morgan Securities Unit Expects a Challenge
abstract: David W. Fisher, the freshly named president of J.P. Morgan Securities Inc., a new subsidiary of J.P. Morgan & Company, takes a modest view of the unit, saying it ''really isn't a very big deal.''   That might come as something of a surprise to Morgan's top executives, who created the nation's 16th-largest securities firm by providing the unit with $250 million in equity capital.   And Mr. Fisher's opinion would also be contested by the brokerage industry, which is committed to keeping commercial banks and their subsidiaries out of the investment banking business.

headline: PATENTS; 24-Hour Time Release In Drug Dosage System
abstract: A controlled time-release dosage system for drugs and vitamins, which can keep them at work for as long as 24 hours, was patented this week by Choong-Gook Jang for the Tech Trade Corporation, New Brunswick, N.J.  Bioenergy Inc., Mr. Jang's employer, also in New Brunswick, has been using the process under license to produce time-release pellets for several years under patent 4,590,062.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S SPEECH AT JERSEY SCHOOL
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech by President Reagan today to the graduating class at Glassboro High School in New Jersey, as made public by the White House:   In June of 1967, President Johnson flew from the White House to Glassboro - just as I have done today - to hold a summit meeting with Soviet Premier Kosygin. The meeting was scheduled to last one day. But the two men talked for more than five hours, then held a second meeting two days later. If you were to research the meeting in your school library, you would find that U.S. News wrote, ''Among the problems they discussed were some of the world's biggest: Vietnam, the Middle East, and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.''   Today, historians have concluded that the Glassboro summit was not, in fact, one of the most momentous - no major breakthroughs were made or agreements reached. Nevertheless, the two men met. They were frank. They worked to understand each other and to make themselves understood. In this alone, I would submit, they taught us a great deal.   This brings me to the international scene and our relations with the Soviet Union. It is important to begin by distinguishing between the peoples inside the Soviet Union and the Government that rules them. Certainly we have no quarrel with the peoples - far from it. Yet we must remember that the peoples in the Soviet Union have virtually no influence on the Government.

headline: Capital Outlay By May Stores
abstract: The May Department Stores Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, will spend $2 billion between 1986 and 1990, the largest capital spending program in the company's history, shareholders were told yesterday at the company's annual meeting in St. Louis.   Thomas A.
