abstract: President Reagan's approval rating from the American people matches the highest level he has ever recorded, a New York Times poll shows, even though support for the bombing of Libya last month has slipped a bit from what it was immediately after the attack.   Sixty-eight percent of the public approves of his handling of the Presidency, according to a telephone poll of 1,099 adults taken April 29 through May 1. Twenty-one percent disapproved, and 11 percent had no opinion.

headline: Amoco Plans Cuts
abstract: The Amoco Corporation plans to cut about 400 people from the work force in its staff departments by the end of the year, the company announced. Each department will develop its own timetable for staff reductions, but the cuts, which will not be across the board, will be made between now and Dec. 31.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * Mort Scharfman has been named senior vice president/creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach, San Francisco.

headline: GROUP REVIEWING NATO POLICIES
abstract: Allied disarmament experts met today to begin what is expected to be a long effort to forge a new approach to the control of conventional arms.   North Atlantic Treaty Organization sources said a high-level task force, set up last month, held its first meeting with arms control experts from all 16 member countries under the chairmanship of Deputy Secretary General Marcello Guidi.

headline: TEST FOR NAKASONE
abstract: Whatever its long-range economic and diplomatic impact, the Tokyo summit conference has caused immediate political troubles for Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.   A successful meeting, however Japanese politicians and newspapers ultimately define it, had been widely regarded as critical to Mr. Nakasone for any hope he may entertain to stay in office after his term expires next fall.   Thus far the conference has not gone the Prime Minister's way. It could produce serious consequences for him and his ruling Liberal Democratic Party if he goes ahead with plans to dissolve Parliament's decision-making lower house and hold national elections late next month.

headline: U.N. CHIEF SUGGESTS U.S. CONTRIBUTION BE CUT
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, stating that ''no single country should be in a postion in some way to threaten or to blackmail the United Nations,'' suggested today that the United States should pay less of the United Nations budget.   As the General Assembly met today to discuss ways to slash this year's budget following drastic cuts in the United States' contribution, Mr. Perez de Cuellar told reporters, ''The United States should reduce its contribution to, I don't know, 20 or even 15 percent and then some other countries should increase their contribution.'' The United States currently is assessed 25 percent of the regular United Nations budget of $830 million.   Responding to questions at the annual luncheon of the United Nations Correspondents' Association, the Secretary General suggested that each of the five permanent members of the Security Council, which have veto power, should pay equal shares of the budget to create what he called a ''fair and honest'' system.

headline: LEADING INDICATORS CLIMB 1.5%
abstract: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday in response to signs that economic activity is strengthening and is likely to continue to improve.   ''The market has been nervous about prospects for the economy,'' said one trader, who added that ''yesterday's data was enough to tip the scales'' toward lower prices and higher interest rates.   He referred to a monthly report by purchasing managers that showed a strong increase in business conditions in May, as well as the Commerce Department's report of a larger-than-expected 1.5 percent increase in the index of leading economic indicators in April. Investors Wary    Signs of a stronger economy have made traders and investors wary, because they expect that the improving business activity may put upward pressure on interest rates and dissuade the Federal Reserve from any additional moves to reduce short-term rates.

headline: Machiavelli
abstract: To the Editor:   Before Pickens there was Machiavelli. (''History's First Takeover Expert,'' Forum March 2.)

headline: BONNER STARTS HER JOURNEY BACK TO SOVIET
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner left the United States tonight to return to her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, and their life in internal exile in the Soviet Union.   Miss Bonner, 63 years old, ended her nearly six-month stay in the United States for medical treatment by boarding a 7:15 P.M. flight to Paris.   ''I feel a great sadness parting with my mother, children and grandchildren,'' she said at a news conference at Logan International Airport. ''I want to return to him, but it is extremely sad and extremely difficult for many reasons.

headline: U.S. Cites a Deadline To Companies in Libya
abstract: United States officials stepped up the pressure today for American companies with oil interests in Libya to leave the country, saying that a deadline was approaching.   President Reagan called on these companies to leave when he imposed additional economic sanctions on Libya last January, but he gave them time to disengage in order to prevent a windfall to Libya.

headline: CNW-Douglas
abstract: The CNW Corporation said it had agreed to pay $52.4 million in cash to acquire Douglas Dynamics Inc., a Milwaukee-based manufacturer of snowplows.

headline: URANIUM MINING Vs. GRAND CANYON
abstract: Until recently uranium mining seemed about as promising a business here on the Colorado River plateau as grazing steers in Central Park, but the discovery of some rich uranium ore deposits along the border of the Grand Canyon National Park is changing that.   Several mining companies, including one owned by the French Government, have been lured to the area by deposits five or six times richer in uranium content than ore from the handful of old mines, built in the days of the American uranium boom before the Three Mile Island nuclear accident, that are still operating.   In the last few years nearly a million acres of high, sage-covered land have been staked out in 45,000 uranium claims between the Grand Canyon in northern Arizona and the Utah state line. The area, totaling some four million acres of wild and empty space, is known as the Arizona Strip. Four mines are already in operation, with several more planned.

headline: Advertising; Time Inc.'s Real Estate Magazine
abstract: THE upstarts have had their turn.   Now let's see if the old pros still have the touch.   On Friday, Time Inc. began mailing out 150,000 copies of a controlled-circulation magazine named New York/New Jersey/Connecticut Real Estate. The concept came from Andrew Heiskell, the 70-year-old retired chairman of the corporation, while the actual creation was supervised by Otto Fuerbringer, 75, who has been involved in the creation of a number of new magazines - but not TV-Cable Week - since stepping out of the managing editor's job at Time magazine in 1968.

headline: NICARAGUAN LEADER IN OFFER ON ARMS
abstract: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua was prepared to seek ''concrete agreements on arms control'' in an effort to resolve a deadlock over a Central American peace treaty.   The proposal appeared to be the first substantive Nicaraguan statement on a key aspect of the proposed treaty that deals with limits on weapons and military manpower in the region.   ''The purpose of the proposal is not to disarm Nicaragua, but for all Central American nations to reach an agreement on what weapons we can reduce, limit, regulate and omit,'' Mr. Ortega said.   He called the proposal ''a point of departure'' for discussions about ''armaments and maneuvers, bases and advisers.''

headline: CHANGE IN DATA CODING OF COMPUTERS EXPECTED
abstract: The National Security Agency has decided to replace the coding system widely used by Government agencies, companies and banks to protect their most sensitive computer data, according to Government and computer and banking industry officials. The new system, which is being developed by the intelligence agency, will be sharply different.   The move apparently arises out of fears by the N.S.A., the nation's largest intelligence agency, that the current system for making computer data unintelligible to eavesdroppers is growing increasingly vulnerable to cracking by foreign governments, terrorists and sophisticated thieves.   While N.S.A. officials refuse to discuss the change publicly, they have told industry officials in recent weeks that the new system, which will be phased in at Government agencies and corporations beginning in January 1988, will use a variety of new codes whose distribution will be tightly regulated by the agency. The new system would be incompatible with the current one, involving different procedures and different encoding equipment.

headline: U.S. SAYS MANY SEIZED ARE TOWNSHIP LEADERS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the single largest group of detainees in South Africa were local township leaders from citizen associations and youth groups.   They also said the other major targets had been middle-level officials of the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front, the Soweto Youth Congress and the Azanian People's Organization, and many trade union and church leaders.   Administration officials and private human rights groups estimate that the South African Government has so far jailed 2,000 to 4,000 people.   These officials said that the number was rising as the Government-imposed state of emergency continues, but that they had not received reports of abuses of the detainess ''on a massive level.''

headline: JUSTICE DEPT. OPPOSES NORTHWEST-REPUBLIC DEAL
abstract: The Justice Department said today that it continued to oppose the proposed merger of Northwest Orient Airlines and Republic Airlines, asserting that the transaction would stifle competition.   In 29 pages of comments, the department said it had found serious antitrust problems with combining the two airlines' operations, especially at the airport in Minneapolis, which both Northwest and Republic have made an important hub. The two airlines between them have 51 of the 63 gates at the Minneapolis airport.

headline: A.M.C. Says Suits Top $1.8 Billion
abstract: The American Motors Corporation has notified stockholders that pending lawsuits involving personal injury in Jeep CJ accidents total more than $1.8 billion. The amount sought by plaintiffs consists of $1.2 billion in punitive damages and $640 million in compensatory damages.   The disclosure was made in the company's annual 10-K form filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A.M.C. did not say how many cases were pending.

headline: IS FOOD IRRADIATION SAFE?; THE F.D.A.'S GAME OF 'GENETIC ROULETTE'
abstract: ONE would think, after the accidents at Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, that the Government would have developed a healthy skepticism about nuclear technologies. Apparently, it has not.  The lessons from these accidents and numerous others were swept aside by the Food and Drug Administration recently, when it issued a final rule legalizing the irradiation of fresh fruits and vegetables and tripling the dose currently used on spices. The agency acted without demonstrating the safety of eating irradiated foods and with apparent disregard for the inherent dangers of using huge quantities of radioactive materials.

headline: Daiwa Fills Adviser Post
abstract: Owen B. Butler, who retired last month as chairman of Procter & Gamble, has been named a senior adviser at Daiwa Securities America, the Japanese-based securities firm announced yesterday. Takuro Isoda, Daiwa America's chairman, said that Mr. Butler would consult with Daiwa executives on developing a long-term strategy for the firm in its growing United States operations. Mr. Butler retired from Procter & Gamble after more than 40 years at the giant consumer products company.

headline: Top Canadian Official Resigns Post
abstract: The Industry Minister in the Conservative Cabinet of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney resigned today in the face of accusations of conflict of interest raised by the political opposition and the press.   The Industry Minister, Sinclair Stevens, had been under attack in the House of Commons for two weeks after it was disclosed that his wife, Noreen, arranged a $2 million business loan on his behalf from a Toronto business executive with links to a company getting financial assistance from Mr. Stevens's Department of Regional Industrial Expansion.

headline: MARCH TRADE GAP $2 BILLION WIDER
abstract: The nation's overall trade deficit widened by $2 billion in March, to $14.5 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. The deficit in trade with Japan set a record.   The sharp deterioration surprised many analysts and gave the Administration fresh ammunition with which to argue at the coming economic summit conference in Tokyo that America's trading partners need to take steps to help redress the trade imbalance.   The latest figures are also expected to intensify pressure on Congress to pass legislation to protect American industries. Steel, textile and footwear groups issued statements today deploring their loss of market to foreign producers.

headline: Holders Vote At Dow Jones
abstract: Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Wall Street Journal and Barron's magazine, approved, as expected, anti-takeover measures that give directors substantially more leeway to combat a hostile bid. One provision staggers the election of directors to prevent a rapid change in the composition of the board.

headline: Short-Lived Reprieve For Airline Attendant
abstract: An airline flight attendant, Ashgan Attia, told friends she felt reborn when she survived a hijacking that left 60 people dead in Malta last November.

headline: ON EVE OF SENATE TAX DEBATE, JOCKEYING BEGINS
abstract: Senators from both parties jockeyed for position today as the Senate prepared to begin debate Wednesday on tax-revision legislation.   Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and the assistant leader, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, urged other Republicans at a lunch meeting to hold the line against any significant amendments to the tax measure that the Finance Committee approved last month.   ''It appears we're going to run this bill all the way through pretty much the way it is,'' said Senator David F. Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota.

headline: Patents; Electronic Translations Of Complete Sentences
abstract: An electronic translator, invented for a Japanese company, translates a complete sentence into another language.

headline: SANDINISTAS SAY CLOSED NEWSPAPER BACKED U.S.
abstract: The Government said today that it had ordered the indefinite closing of La Prensa, the only opposition newspaper in the country, because the paper had sought ''to justify United States aggression.''   The newspaper's editors said they would appeal the decision, calling it ''a black moment for the people of Nicaragua.''   Soon after ordering the closing of La Prensa, Sandinista leaders issued an announcement that laws restricting civil liberties would be enforced ''with full vigor.''   The paper was ordered shut late Thursday. Its editors, in a statement issued today, said they would appeal the order to the Nicaraguan Supreme Court.

headline: TRADERS UNCERTAIN, WITH RATES MIXED
abstract: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as credit market participants waited for developments in the domestic economy or overseas that would cause rates to rise or fall.   Treasury bonds were the strongest sector. The bellwether 7 1/4 percent issue due in 2016 rose about 7/8 point, to 96 2/32, yielding 7.50 percent. Officials of Japanese securities firms said the demand for Treasury bonds in Tokyo was strong after trading ended in New York on Wednesday night, and this helped lift prices in New York trading yesterday.

headline: 9 7/8% Sonat Notes
abstract: Sonat Inc., a diversified energy company, yesterday began offering $200 million of 9 7/8 percent notes at a price of par, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.

headline: Grey and Romann Shun Rush Toward Mergers
abstract: The sudden mega-merger craze has suddenly made not being acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi or anyone else a sellable quality.   In The New York Times today, both Grey Advertising and Romann & Tannenholz have both bought space.

headline: U.S. Bank in Spain Bombed
abstract: A small bomb exploded early today at a Citibank branch in this central Spanish city, causing damage but no casualties, the police said.

headline: Anitec Image Plan
abstract: The Anitec Image Technology Corporation said it had tentatively agreed to acquire substantially all the assets of Allied-Signal Inc.'s Sinclair and Valentine division for undisclosed terms. Anitec, which has annual sales of about $120 million, said Sinclair and Valentine, maker of printing ink, has annual sales of about $170 million.

headline: TOP G.M. FIVE EACH GOT OVER $1 MILLION
abstract: Roger B. Smith, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, collected $1,852,850 in salary, bonus and stock-option profits in 1985, a year that saw all five top executives of the company earn more than $1 million.   Because G.M. has a second bonus plan in which payouts are made only every other year, it is not clear how much Mr. Smith actually earned for 1985, including deferred bonus. In 1984, this separate, long-term bonus added $750,000 to Mr. Smith's compensation, reflecting several years of accumulated long-term bonus.

headline: Merger of Ohio Utilities Excites Centerior Chief
abstract: He has spent the last 37 years with the same company, but next week Robert M. Ginn will start working for somebody else. Mr. Ginn is not exactly upset about the change, though. He spent the better part of a year working to bring it off.   ''It was 50 weeks ago that John Williamson approached me at lunch about this,'' Mr. Ginn said. ''We were confident that it would go through, but we have been getting anxious, because the team is ready and raring to ago.''

headline: New Hampshire
abstract: New Hampshire is offering $60 million of capital improvement bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation. Yields range from 4.10 percent for bonds maturing in 1987 to 5.80 percent in 1991, 6.70 percent in 1996, 7.15 percent in 2001 and 7.30 percent in 2005 and 2006.

headline: AQUINO URGES SELF-RELIANCE FOR ASIA
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino urged leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations today to look to the organizations's own shortcomings before blaming the developed nations for all of the region's economic woes.   Mrs. Aquino's unexpectedly pointed remarks were followed later in the morning by a speech in a similar vein by Vice President Salvador H. Laurel, who is also the Philippine Foreign Minister.   At a meeting expected to concentrate on complaints against protectionist trade legislation in the United States, a theme sounded by Thailand and Malaysia, Mr. Laurel instead put forward specific suggestions for better economic cooperation among the association's nations: Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei and the Philippines.   The ministers from the regional association are to meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz later this week. At the regional association's last ministerial meeting in Bali in April, Mr. Laurel was reported to have annoyed Mr. Shultz with demands for large increases in aid to Manila. Today he acknowledged being disappointed with the results of the Bali meeting and of the economic summit meeting that followed in Tokyo.

headline: People
abstract: * Donald H. Rice has been named chairman of Fahlgren Swink & Nucifora, the Atlanta division of Fahlgren & Swink, Cincinnati.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday: Memorial Day. Tuesday: None. Wednesday: None. Thursday: Leading Indicators...April.   Friday: Merchandise Trade Balance...April; Agricultural Prices...May; New-Home Sales...April.

headline: COMMON MARKET IN PACT ON TERROR
abstract: Cabinet Ministers from countries of the European Community agreed today to step up their exchange of information on terrorism with the United States and other nonmember nations.   A statement issued by the ministers from eight of the 12 Common Market nations said the agreement reflected recognition that nations must work together to effectively fight terrorism.   The United States officials, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, William Webster, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Robert Oakley, director of the State Department's counterterrorism office, also met with some of the ministers, including Home Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain.   Mr. Hurd told a news conference that the American officials ''suggested in a very courteous and understanding way that it would be valuable if there was a procedure which doesn't now exist for contacts between the Common Market and the United States Administration.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S SPEECH ON CHERNOBYL ACCIDENT
abstract: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's television address tonight on the Chernobyl nuclear accident, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:   Good evening, comrades.   As you all know, a misfortune has befallen us - the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant. It has painfully affected Soviet people and caused the anxiety of the international public. For the first time ever we encountered in reality such a sinister force as nuclear energy that has escaped control. So what did happen? As specialists report, the reactor's capacity suddenly increased during a scheduled shutdown of the fourth unit. The considerable emission of steam and subsequent reaction resulted in the formation of hydrogen, its explosion, damage to the reactor and the associated radioactive release.   It is yet early to pass final judgment on the causes of the accident. All aspects of the problem - design, projecting, operation and technical -are under the close scrutiny of the Government commission.

headline: JUDGE QUESTIONS CLEARING UNIT'S ROLE IN COLLAPSE
abstract: In a heated finale to the failure of the Volume Investors Corporation, a commodities brokerage firm that went into receivership last year, a Federal district judge has suggested that the Comex Clearing Association may have been partly responsible for the collapse by permitting gold market trading to become disorderly.   Comex Clearing processes transactions and helps maintain the financial viability of clearing firms on the Commodity Exchange, where Volume Investors operated.   The suggestion, by Judge Kevin T. Duffy, at a hearing last month, came amid a bitter dispute between lawyers for the clearing association, which may lose up to $9 million because of Volume's failure, and Volume's court-appointed receiver, over how much the receiver and his lawyers and accountants will be paid.

headline: Magazine Rate Talks Backed by N.W. Ayer
abstract: Although for years the print media have generally adhered to their rate cards while broadcast rates were negotiable, a growing number of multidivisional advertiser companies have been pushing hard recently to get better deals from the print media, particularly magazines. This has brought a statement from N.W. Ayer, the country's oldest agency.

headline: Afghan Rebels Say Vital Base Has Fallen
abstract: Soviet and Afghan soldiers were reported today to have destroyed a key Moslem rebel base near the Pakistan border, but the United States State Department said the rebels were still holding their own.

headline: AQUINO SEES PROGRESS IN CEASE-FIRE ATTEMPTS
abstract: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she had already sent emissaries to talk with Communist insurgents and that progress was being made in some areas in trying to reach a cease-fire.   Holding her first news conference in more than two months, Mrs. Aquino showed a quiet confidence in the performance of her Government, despite divisions within its ranks.   In a wide-ranging session with foreign reporters, she displayed a detailed command of the issues and a sense of assurance about the priorities and timetable she had set for herself.   ''My Government is a popular government. it has credibility,'' she said.

headline: LATE RALLY LIFTS BOND PRICES
abstract: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose as much as 1 1/4 points yesterday, but only after prices moved erratically as bond traders continued to slavishly follow developments in the oil markets.   When the May oil futures contract rose to yesterday's peak price of $12.45 a barrel, the bellwether 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due in 2016 fell to as low as 120, down about 1 1/4 points from the previous day. But later, as oil prices declined to the closing price of $11.52, the Treasury bond market recovered, and the 9 1/4 percent issue ended New York trading at 122 14/32, up nearly 1 5/32 points, to yield 7.38 percent.   ''I expect attention will continue to be focused on oil until the market is convinced that oil prices have bottomed and stabilized,'' said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc.

headline: F.H.A. Back In Business
abstract: The Federal Housing Authority resumed processing applications for Government-insured home mortgages today after President Reagan signed legislation ending the agency's three-week shutdown.   The F.H.A.'s acting head, Silvio DeBartolomeis, notified the agency's field offices and major lenders to resume processing applications, which have been pouring in at a rate of 10,000 a day during the hottest real estate market of the decade.

headline: SINCLAIR RESEARCH SOLD
abstract: Sir Clive Sinclair, whose computer empire was once valued at $197 million, sold his company to a rival concern today for $7.3 million.   Under the terms of the sale of Sinclair Research to Amstrad Consumer Electronics, Sir Clive can no longer market computers under his own name.   Sir Clive, 45 years old, had been honored by Queen Elizabeth for his role in bringing inexpensive home computers to Britain. At one time, his Spectrum model was the world's top-selling microcomputer and his products still hold 35 percent of the British market.

headline: Afghan Demonstrators Protest Ouster of Karmal
abstract: At least eight protests, most of them student demonstrations broken up by the secret police, have been held in Kabul in support of the former Afghan Communist Party leader, Babrak Karmal, Western diplomats said today.   They quoted witnesses from the Afghan capital as saying the latest rally was held Tuesday and that the police beat up and hauled away two busloads of high school girls who chanted: ''Death to Najibullah! We want Karmal! Out with the Soviets! We want an Islamic Government!''

headline: C.I.A. REVAMPS ITS HANDLING OF DEFECTORS LIKE YURCHENKO
abstract: A senior C.I.A. official said today that the agency had made major changes in its procedures for handling defectors like Vitaly S. Yurchenko, the high-level Soviet official who fled to the West last year and then returned to Moscow.   The official, Robert M. Gates, disclosed the new approaches at his confirmation hearing for deputy director, the No. 2 post in the Central Intelligence Agency. At the hearing, senior members of the committee from both parties criticized the Reagan Administration's policy of providing covert aid to guerrilla movements around the world.

headline: Saga's Board Opposes Offer
abstract: The Saga Corporation said today that its board had recommended that shareholders reject the $34-a-share offer from the Marriott Corporation.   ''The board of directors believe there is a reasonable likelihood that a higher price than the Marriott offer can be obtained for Saga's shares if the board pursues other available alternatives,'' Charles A. Lynch, Saga's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.

headline: MAY 21-31 AUTO SALES DOWN 10.9%
abstract: Sales of domestically produced automobiles fell 10.9 percent in the May 21-31 period from the final 10 days of the month last year, the seven major manufacturers reported here today. Sales of light trucks in the period were stronger, however, up 7 percent from the comparable period last year, bringing total light-vehicle sales, including cars and light trucks, to 416,936, a decline of 6 percent from 1985.   For the entire month of May domestic car sales were off 2.6 percent and light-truck sales rose 8.1 percent. Importers had a relatively stronger showing, with car sales of 258,939, up 7 percent, and light-truck sales of 76,302, up 7.6 percent. Import companies increased their share of the domestic market to 26.7 percent, from 25.9 percent in April and 24.9 percent in May 1985.

headline: Nynex in Pact for Tel-Optik
abstract: The Nynex Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Tel-Optik Ltd. for $10 million, making Nynex a joint partner in a $600 million project to develop the first privately financed trans-Atlantic telephone cable system.

headline: MOSCOW NEWS SESSION: BRIEF AND NOT TO POINT
abstract: The Soviet Union's recent inclination for holding Western-style news conferences and its traditional desire to control information collided today at a briefing on the Chernobyl nuclear accident.   The briefing hall at the Foreign Ministry press center was jammed with hundreds of reporters, dozens of Western diplomats, including several ambassadors, and more than a dozen television cameras.   A panel of senior officials and nuclear experts, including the head of a Government commission set up to investigate the accident, seemed poised to answer questions that have accumulated in the 10 days since an explosion ripped off the roof of the nuclear power plant in the Ukraine, spewing radioactive material into the atmosphere.

headline: The U.N. Today: May 13, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Committee for General Assembly Special Session on Critical African Economic Situation - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. >TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: NL TO BUY BACK UP TO 32% OF STOCK
abstract: NL Industries, a chemicals and energy-services company, yesterday announced a sweeping restructuring program that includes a sale of 20 percent of its profitable chemicals business to the public and the repurchase of up to 20 million, or 32 percent, of its common shares. At a minimum, NL said, it would buy 15 million shares, or 24 percent.   As part of the repurchase program, the company said it had agreed to buy 2.6 million shares of the 5.3 million shares held by Coniston Partners, the investment group that last month made a bid to acquire 60 percent of the company. NL said Coniston could sell its remaining shares in the general repurchase program. Coniston, in turn, withdrew its offer.

headline: Hong Kong Bank Fraud
abstract: A Hong Kong financier accused of conspiracy to defraud a bank of more than $66 million was remanded in custody after a brief court appearance today. Simon Yip, who returned last week from San Francisco in the custody of Hong Kong officials, was expected to enter a plea next week to 46 criminal charges linked to the near collapse of the Overseas Trust Bank last year, his lawyer said. Mr. Yip headed the now defunct Dominican Finance Ltd. and was honorary consul of the Dominican Republic. The bank was declared insolvent last June and taken over by the Hong Kong Government at a cost of $255 million.

headline: S.E.C. ACCUSES REVLON OF MISLEADING INVESTORS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged that Revlon Inc. misled investors during its takeover battle with Pantry Pride last fall by not promptly disclosing friendly buyout talks with two investment companies.   The cosmetic company, which was bought by Pantry Pride for $1.74 billion after one of last year's most protracted takeover battles, signed an S.E.C. consent order agreeing to comply with the disclosure provisions of the securities laws.   The effect of the agency's action, said Gary Lynch, director of enforcement at the S.E.C., should be that companies trying to defend themselves from hostile takeovers by seeking a ''white knight'' will be more forthcoming about complying with disclosure rules.

headline: Swiss to Send a Bill to U.S.
abstract: A Swiss Government spokesman said today that the Americans would be billed for bomb damage to the Swiss ambassador's residence in Libya. ''Whether they will pay is an open question,'' he said. He did not say how much money it would cost to repair the Tripoli residence, damaged in the air strike Monday.

headline: INSIDER PLEADS GUILTY IN $12.6 MILLION STOCK CASE
abstract: Dennis B. Levine, a 33-year-old former Wall Street investment banker, yesterday settled Federal charges that he earned $12.6 million through illegal insider stock trading. He pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to four felony counts and agreed to cooperate in a continuing investigation of insider trading on Wall Street.   Mr. Levine also agreed to settle civil charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission last month. To do so, he will turn over almost all his estimated wealth of $11.5 million, will be barred from working in the securities business and is permanently enjoined from further violations of securities laws.   ''He's going to lose pretty much everything he has,'' said Charles M. Carberry, the Assistant United States Attorney in charge of the case.

headline: Harcourt's Theme Park
abstract: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. has closed Circus World, which it bought for $18 million, and plans to reopen it in December with a baseball theme. The 847-acre park near Haines City, Fla., will get a $7 million face lift, the publishing company said. Attendance at Circus World had dwindled.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: SOVIET ANNOUNCES NUCLEAR ACCIDENT AT ELECTRIC PLANT
abstract: The Soviet Union announced today that there had been an accident at a nuclear power plant in the Ukraine and that ''aid is being given to those affected.''   The severity of the accident, which spread discernable radioactive material over Scandinavia, was not immediately clear. But the terse statement, distributed by the Tass press agency and read on the evening television news, suggested a major accident.   The phrasing also suggested that the problem had not been brought under full control at the nuclear plant, which the Soviet announcement identified as the Chernobyl station. It is situated at the new town of Pripyat, near Chernobyl and 60 miles north of Kiev.

headline: POLL SHOWS CONFUSION ON AID TO CONTRAS
abstract: Americans are uncertain about which side the United States is backing in Nicaragua and only one out of four supports President Reagan's request for $100 million in aid to the rebels who are trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   With the approach of another key vote by the House of Representatives on the President's proposal, majorities of those polled accepted his argument that Nicaragua is a risk to American interests, but opposed his remedy of $100 million in aid.   Only 38 percent knew that Washington was supporting the guerrillas and not the Government. That confusion extended to the nature of Nicaragua's Government, which is aligned with the Soviet Union; just 20 percent said it was Communist, 19 percent said it was a right-wing dictatorship and 49 percent said they didn't know. Nicaraguan Threat Perceived    Nevertheless, after questions about the Reagan aid plan had been asked, a more defined image of Nicaragua seemed to emerge. Fifty-nine percent of the 1,601 adults interviewed by telephone from April 6 through 10 answered yes when asked if they thought the Nicaraguan Government would provide the Soviet Union with military bases, and 56 percent agreed that Nicaragua constituted a threat to the security of other Central American countries. The survey's margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.

headline: Keeping A Cool Head With Futures
abstract: THE futures and options markets often seem to be a place where a sort of financial alchemy overtakes the normal laws of physics. You can pay a Volkswagen-sized downpayment, but drive away with a Ferrari, and yet, if you turn your head, even for a moment, the Ferrari may turn into a heap of scrap metal.   Futures and options are ephemeral creatures. With a share of stock, you have bought an interest in a corporation that can usually be held as long as you like. With a bond, you have bought the right to receive a steady rate of return, often for years or decades. With a future or option, though, you have latched onto a perishable commodity that requires constant attention, a steady flow of decisions and the kind of cool head that the smaller investor is notorious for losing when tensions build.   In short, futures and options are probably the most volatile, risky and complex products that the individual can invest in outside of Atlantic City. On top of that, options and futures commissions tend to be significantly higher than those for other investment products, such as stocks. So the cost for changing one's mind can be high.

headline: GREEN PARTY ASKS BREAK WITH NATO
abstract: The antinuclear and environmentalist Green Party has ended a four-day congress with agreement on a national election program that demands West Germany's immediate withdrawal from NATO and the abolition of nuclear energy.   Emboldened by a surge of popular support that followed the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, the party's radical wing, the so-called fundamentalists, controlled the congress.   The congress, which was held in Hanover and ended Monday, laid down the party's strategy for elections scheduled for January. It came against a backdrop of fierce clashes between the police and antinuclear demonstrators at an uncompleted reprocessing plant at Wackersdorf near the Czechoslovak border. On Sunday, 132 policemen were reported wounded by protesters, who hurled ball bearings and gasoline bombs.

headline: CATERING TO THE 20-MINUTE SHOPPER
abstract: ONE businessman's disaster, to paraphrase a cliche, is another's opportunity.   Some 130,000 neighborhood gas stations have gone belly-up in the last dozen years. Countless old factory buildings are shuttered, and numerous parcels of once-valuable land remain vacant.

headline: Local Costs Unchanged Last Month
abstract: Consumer prices in March remained essentially unchanged from February in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area as a sharp decrease in energy prices was offset by an increase in costs for shelter, restaurant meals and medical care, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.  ''Because of the lower gasoline and fuel oil prices, the news on inflation in March is pretty good,'' said Jesse Benjamin, assistant commissioner of the bureau. He added that the 5 percent drop in energy prices in March was the largest one-month decline in the eight years the bureau has been compiling such statistics. In February, the index for energy dropped 2.6 percent.

headline: OBSTACLES TO CHANGE IN JAPAN
abstract: Japan, the trading colossus that has spectacularly reshaped itself in the last 40 years, is now being urged to do something it has rarely done: enact sweeping changes without a clear-cut ultimatum from the outside world.   As Japan sells more and more goods abroad - with its trade surpluses growing ever larger - its trading partners around the globe feel threatened in their home markets and shut out in Japan itself. Amid this mounting hostility, a spate of blue-ribbon reports have recommended that Japan start relying on domestic spending and imports for economic growth rather than on exports.   It is by no means clear that Japan has the political will or the popular mandate to make such changes on its own. The proposals being discussed face obstacles deeply rooted in Japanese ways. The proposals would require sacrifices from many Japanese who only now are beginning to enjoy the fruits of years of hardship. And they would radically alter the credo of postwar Japan - that the nation must export to survive.

headline: TIME PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 16% OF ITS SHARES
abstract: Time Inc., the giant magazine and cable company, yesterday authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million shares of its stock, or 16 percent of Time's total 62.9 million shares outstanding.   Time's stock rose $2.875 a share yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at an all-time high of $90.125 a share.   In making the announcement, Time also said its board had authorized, as expected, the sale of up to 20 percent of the stock of its wholly owned cable subsidiary, American Television and Communications.   Joseph Fuchs, a vice president and media analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, echoed the views of others on Wall Street in perceiving the news as yet a further defensive move against any possible takeover bid.

headline: Texas Bank Cites Talks
abstract: Daniel C. Arnold, chairman and co-chief executive officer of the First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., said today that the Houston bank holding company had held ''exploratory'' talks with Frank Cahouet, the former chief executive of the Crocker National Corporation. Mr. Arnold said, however, that the discussions had been held in a ''very preliminary way,'' in order ''to see if there could be an area of mutual interest.''   Mr. Arnold also said that no discussions had taken place about the possible retirement of James A. Elkins Jr., the 67-year-old senior chairman of the board and co-chief executive.   The bank's comments, released in a statement today, were in response to a June 16 Business Week article, which quoted unnamed banking regulators and analysts who questioned the financial status and current management of First City.

headline: Trade Gap for Soviet
abstract: The Soviet Union ran a trade deficit of $8.3 million with Western countries last year after a surplus of $2.3 billion in 1984, Tass, the official press agency, said today. The Soviet Union's trade performance improved during the last quarter of the year, however, following a deficit of $1.46 billion for the first nine months. Total trade with non-Communist industrial countries fell to $51.9 billion, from $56.2 billion in 1984, the press agency said.

headline: SOVIET PROMISES A CHERNOBYL ACCOUNTING
abstract: The Soviet Union has promised a detailed accounting of the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant at an international forum this summer, probably in July, according to a senior American nuclear official.   Soviet officials made the commitment at a meeting last week in Vienna of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the American official, Harold R. Denton, director of reactor regulation at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said today.   While the Russians provided frustratingly few technical details of the Chernobyl disaster at the Vienna meeting, information gleaned from ''hall talk'' with Soviet officials confirmed earlier indications that the reactor was being used in experiments when the accident occurred, Mr. Denton said.   Soviet officials have given no indication of what those experiments might have been. Some Western experts suspect that the reactor was being used to produce plutonium for weapons.

headline: EXITING GRACEFULLY FROM A MUTUAL FUND
abstract: GETTING into mutual funds is easy enough, but getting out is another story. ''Most shareholders just don't understand the tax consequences of mutual funds,'' said Glenn O. Head, chairman of the First Investors Management Company, Inc., which manages mutual funds. ''They don't realize that, when they pick up the telephone to switch money from one fund to another, it's considered a taxable sale.'' However, a little strategic planning can minimize Uncle Sam's share of the take and smooth your exit, say the experts, whether you are selling a few shares to lock in profits or checking out of your fund altogether.   For example, investors who request telephone switching privileges within a fund group may also want to open an account with the company's money market fund. That way, they can switch shares from their equity or bond fund to their money market fund and then write a check against the balance. This ''lets you get your hands on the cash a week or two faster'' than it typically takes a mutual fund to process the paperwork and mail the check, which must then clear your local bank, said John Markese, research director at the American Association of Individual Investors.

headline: Israel Studies Bank Scandal
abstract: The Cabinet in Jerusalem announced today that a committee of ministers ''will address itself'' to the report of a commission that inquired into a 1983 bank shares scandal.   The commission's recommendations included the dismissal of the governor of the state bank and the heads of four major commercial banks whose shares crashed on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange in October 1983.

headline: Young & Rubicam Lands Kodak Canada
abstract: Young & Rubicam, which picked up Kodak's consumer electronic products in the United States in February, yesterday was named agency for all Kodak Canada's consumer products.

headline: Economic Scene; Chernobyl's World Impact
abstract: THE disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear generating plant in the Soviet Union and the spread of radioactivity over other countries provide fresh proof of just how vulnerable the American and world economy has become to unpredictable shocks.   In New York the stock market plunged, with analysts attributing part of the record 41.91-point drop in the Dow industrial average to fears that the accident would inflict a devastating blow on the United States nuclear industry, although utility stocks recovered somewhat yesterday. Worldwide prices of grain, livestock, cotton and other commodities have shot up in response to anxiety that radioactive fallout might create shortages in the Soviet Union and other countries.   This could be the greatest shock to hit the world economy since the oil price explosion caused by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries during the 1973-74 Arab-Israeli war. In a sense, the current shock from the Chernobyl disaster is itself traceable to the oil price explosion, which gave additional impetus to many countries to try to replace petroleum with nuclear energy.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * American Continental Corp. is offering $25 million of 12 percent senior debentures due in 2001 at par through Offerman & Co.    * American Southwest Financial Corp. is offering $150 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs; the four-part offering consists of obligations backed by Federal National Mortgage Association pass-through securities; yields range from 9.24 percent for an issue with an estimated average life of 3.3 years to 10.61 percent for an issue with a life of 18.25 years.

headline: CHERNOBYL CLOUD PASSES, BUT CHILL IN ITALY LINGERS
abstract: Marcella Senni, a secretary and mother of four, found that the Soviet nuclear disaster had complicated birthday plans for her 13-year-old daughter.   Giulia, the daughter, wanted to go to the beach. But, Mrs. Senni said, ''a mother called to say the sand was radioactive.''   A trip to the country was also vetoed because the children would have to sit on ground as contaminated as the sand.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aeronca Inc., Charlotte, N.C., said its board had determined that an unsolicited $5-a-share offer made by Fleet Aerospace Corp. on May 21 was inadequate and should be rejected.    * Cipher Data Products Inc., San Diego, said it had agreed to acquire 90 percent of Optimem Inc., a maker of optical disk drives, from Xerox Corp. for $6.3 million in cash and a $3 million note and future royalties.

headline: Norway Rig Plan
abstract: A complex rescue plan, involving the raising of six oil rigs, has been proposed to save Norway's slowly sinking Ekofisk oilfield platforms in the North Sea, the field's operator, Phillips Petroleum, said. The operation, to be carried out this summer pending Norwegian approval, is expected to cost $205 million.

headline: Mesa Plans Cut In Oil Output
abstract: Mesa Limited Partnership, the unit formed last year to manage the oil and gas assets of the Mesa Petroleum Company, said Friday that beginning June 1 it would reduce its oil production by up to 20 percent.   T. Boone Pickens, the oilman and general partner, said he expected oil prices to rise to $20 a barrel by the end of the year, up from its current $15.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Comdisco Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $250 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011, with plans for another offering of $100 million of senior notes due in 1994.    * Duke Power Co. has filed for $600 million of debt securities and $150 million of preferred stock.

headline: Resignation At Iroquois
abstract: Iroquois Brands Ltd., a food and beverage company that weathered the arrest last year of its chairman and chief executive on cocaine possession charges, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, James P. McCaffrey, had resigned. His duties will be assumed by Terence J. Fox, Iroquois's 48-year-old chairman and chief executive.   Less than a week ago, a Hartford court agreed to drop the charges against Mr. Fox in two years if he is not convicted of a crime in that time. Mr. McCaffrey, 52, said his resignation was not related to the case.

headline: WRITER, EXILED BY MAO, NOW GETS TOP CULTURE POST HE DIDN'T WANT
abstract: A writer who spent 17 years in internal exile after one of his early works displeased Mao Zedong was appointed Minister of Culture today.   In his new position, Wang Meng will be partly responsible for judging what Chinese and foreign works should be published here.   Mr. Wang, 51 years old, said several months ago that he had used ''every possible occasion'' to persuade top Communist Party officials that he did not want to succeed the retiring minister, Zhu Muzhi. But the party hierarchy, led by Deng Xiaoping, evidently decided that appointing a victim of past repression to the culture post would be a powerful signal of its intention to persist with more relaxed policies toward the arts that have been resisted by party conservatives.

headline: S.E.C. CUTS STOCK LIST IN INQUIRY
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday delivered to Judge Richard Owen of Federal District Court in Manhattan the names of nine stocks on which it plans to build its insider trading case against Dennis B. Levine, a former Wall Street merger executive.   The list, requested by Judge Owen after a hearing yesterday, seemed to suggest that the S.E.C. was conceding for the present that it had no evidence to show that Mr. Levine had engaged in illicit dealings in 54 separate stocks as originally charged.   The list, delivered late yesterday, was not immediately available. It was understood to consist only of stocks in which the S.E.C. contends that Mr. Levine had a direct knowledge because he personally worked on takeover projects relating to them.

headline: Reagan Fills Treasury Job
abstract: President Reagan said yesterday that he would nominate Michael R. Darby, an economics professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy. If confirmed by the Senate, Dr. Darby, 40 years old, would succeed Manuel H. Johnson Jr., whom the President appointed to the Federal Reserve Board. Dr. Darby, who earned a   B.A. degree from Dartmouth College and M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Chicago, has been a member of the U.C.L.A. faculty since 1973.

headline: Pacific Stereo To Be Bought
abstract: U.S. Electronics Group Inc., a chain of 30 stereo and video stores based in Aurora, Colo., said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the Pacific Stereo Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month. The agreement is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court, and by the shareholders of Pacific, a closely held company that was once the world's largest retailer of brand-name stereo equipment.

headline: Strawbridge Receives Offer
abstract: Strawbridge & Clothier, one of the nation's few remaining large independent operators of department stores, yesterday faced its second takeover threat in a year. The Berry Acquisition Company, headed by Ronald Baron, said it would offer $60 a share, or a total of about $240 million, for at least 4.1 million shares, or about two-thirds of the company.

headline: Patents; Cap for Pen or Pencil
abstract: Eugene L. Heyden of Spokane, Wash., has invented a retractable cap to protect the tip of a pen or pencil and prevent marking such things as shirt pockets. Patent No. 4,595,307, granted to him this week, says that the sheath folds upon itself and can be re-extended. The inventor says the device can also provide insulation for an electrical instrument.

headline: Tesoro Loss Increases
abstract: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, a diversified energy company, said today that it lost $54.1 million in its second fiscal quarter, a big increase from the $4.4 million it lost in the comparable quarter last year. Revenues fell 41.8 percent, to $369.2 million, from $634.1 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 22, 1986
abstract: The Economy    Banks lowered their prime lending rates by half a point, to 8 1/2 percent, the lowest level since 1978. The action followed the Federal Reserve's cut in its discount rate to 6 1/2 percent. The prime rate mainly affects small and middle-sized businesses, but also is the benchmark for some consumer loans and third world debt.  [ Page A1. ]  Representative Schumer made public a list of banks with relatively low interest charges on credit card purchases.  [ D10. ]    Manuel H. Johnson is likely to become the Fed vice chairman, a White House official said. A new vice chairman would succeed Preston Martin, whose spot on the board, sources say, is expected to be taken by William E. Gibson of Republicbank.  [ D1. ]

headline: U.S. BOMBS, MISSING TARGET, STRUCK FARMS NEAR AIR BASE
abstract: More than a dozen bombs and missiles from the American air raids early Tuesday appear to have missed an air base and hit two farms about two miles away, according to evidence seen by reporters on visits to the farms today.   Adding to scores of civilian casualties in other civilian areas reportedly hit, the evidence raises questions about the accuracy of the American pilots and the political benefit resulting from the raid, Western diplomats here said.   In another development, Libyan officials said that a bomb that failed to explode when it was dropped by American warplanes blew up tonight in a residential district, wounding a man and two boys. The officials said the man lost his right hand and was badly wounded in the chest and arms. They said the boys were only slightly hurt.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's 360 money market mutual funds rose $2.34 billion, to $226.85 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: TALLEY ASSAILS BID
abstract: Talley Industries criticized an acquisition offer of $24.25 a share from a group led by American Investment Partners.

headline: PERES REAFFIRMS PLAN TO OUST AIDE
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres today affirmed his intention to dismiss Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, increasing the chances that Israel's coalition Government will soon collapse.   Speaking at the opening of the Labor Party convention in Jerusalem, Mr. Peres said that ''the Finance Minister has to be fired'' - but could remain in the Cabinet in another capacity - because of insults that Mr. Modai, a senior member of the Likud bloc, directed at the Prime Minister. Mr. Peres got a standing ovation for his declaration.   Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader, said Mr. Peres's statement was ''very serious,'' adding, ''I'm afraid it brings near the end of the national unity Government.''

headline: Trade Aids For Mexico Suggested
abstract: Mexico could lessen its dependence on oil and in turn improve the United States-Mexico border economy if it adopted free trade measures, trade representatives told members of the International Trade Commission last week.   By shedding protectionist curbs as part of its proposed entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Mexico could increase overall trade, as well as so-called twin-plant production, which is the country's second-largest source of foreign capital. Mexico relies on oil sales for about 70 percent of its foreign earnings, according to the Government.

headline: SRI LANKANS LAMENT LOSS OF A LINGUISTIC BRIDGE
abstract: Bombs have come to Colombo, bringing fear, heightening wariness between ethnic groups and shattering the confidence of a cosmopolitan city that was once a model of progress and development for southern Asia.   But the people of Colombo also say the new climate of violence, in which an airliner has been destroyed, a train bombed and several public buildings damaged, may be only the latest and most traumatic stage of a process of alienation that has been going on in this Indian Ocean port for 30 years.   ''Even if the ethnic Tamil-Sinhalese conflict were settled tomorrow,'' a Sinhalese resident said, ''this city would remain deeply divided.''   The reason, both Sinhalese and Tamils say, is that Government policies, especially the Official Language Act of 1956 by which Sinhala replaced English as the official tongue, split residents along ethnic lines and eroded the linguistic link that might have made the separation less complete.

headline: Sara Lee Debentures Have a Sinking Fund
abstract: The Sara Lee Corporation, in its first public domestic offering of debentures in 15 years, is selling $175 million of 8 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures due 2016 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   Rated double-A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the debentures may not be refunded with lower-cost borrowings for 10 years, but are subject to retirement from a 4 percent mandatory sinking fund beginning in 1997.   The debentures have an average life ranging from 22.4 years to as little as 14.7 years, if the company exercises its option to increase the sinking fund payments.

headline: THE WORST EFFECTS WILL EMERGE SLOWLY
abstract: THE history of the 20th century is a confirmation of the wisdom that the impossible is always possible. Whether in the destruction of Challenger or in the meltdown at Chernobyl, the seeds of disaster were planted long before the event, and the repercussions will be felt long after.   What are the likely environmental and health effects of Chernobyl? For a few in the immediate vicinity who were heavily exposed to radiation, it could mean death within days, weeks or months, depending on the extent of exposure. For those with less severe - but still critical - exposure, it could mean a bone-marrow death that could occur in weeks to months. Fluid replacement, antibiotics and stringent sterile precautions may save many in this group.

headline: Advertising; Bologna International Loses 4 Co-Founders
abstract: Four of the co-founders of Bologna International, a health care ad agency, in 1980, have left to found Girgenti, Hughes, Butler & McDowell.   And some of the business is following from the old shop just as it did when the four and William Bologna left William Douglas McAdams Inc. Then it was Key Pharmaceuticals.

headline: Mulroney Trade Plea
abstract: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney tonight urged Canadians to support the removal of trade curbs with the United States. Broad-ranging trade talks between the two nations are set to begin Tuesday in Washington.

headline: NATO Backing Plans On Chemical Weapons
abstract: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has tentatively approved the Reagan Administration's plans for production of chemical weapons, but opposition was voiced by several NATO countries concerned that the project could damage East-West relations and set back talks on a global ban on chemical arms.   The allied clearance came Friday, at the end of two days of meetings of NATO delegates, who adopted American goals for 1987 that call for the production of binary chemical weapons to replace the aging stocks of nerve gas stored in the United States and West Germany.

headline: Oil Ends Slightly Down After Rising Above $16
abstract: The futures price of the major American crude oil broke through the $16-a-barrel barrier for the first time in nearly three months yesterday, but later fell back to the $15-a-barrel range, posting a slight loss for the day.   Oil analysts said that crude oil prices, which last week broke above $15 a barrel for the first time since February, had reached another point of resistance and, at least for now, lacked the strength to breach it.   West Texas Intermediate crude oil, the domestic benchmark, finished the day at $15.77 a barrel, down 9 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It had reached $16.13 a barrel during the morning, its highest mark since closing at $16.47 a barrel on Feb. 13.

headline: Visiting Russian in U.S. Calls Jamming Counterproductive
abstract: Vladimir Posner, the Soviet commentator now touring the United States, said today that he regarded Soviet jamming of some Western radio broadcasts as ''counterproductive.''   He said in an appearance at the American Enterprise Institute, a private research group, that in his ''very personal evaluation'' the jamming of Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe, two American-financed stations broadcasting from Munich, East Germany, attracted undue attention to the programs.   Mr. Posner is in the United States to make public appearances and to arrange a Soviet-American television program June 22 involving people in Boston and Leningrad to be aired in the two countries.

headline: CROATIAN WAR CRIMINAL SENTENCED TO FIRING SQUAD
abstract: Andrija Artukovic, an 86-year-old Croatian nationalist extradited from California, was convicted and sentenced to death today for ordering mass killings and deportations when he was an official in a Nazi-supported Government from 1941 to 1945.   Mr. Artukovic, who lived for more than 35 years in Long Beach, Calif., before he was deported in February, had to be helped to his feet by guards. He heard the verdict and the sentence of the court without any show of emotion. The sentence of death by firing squad can be appealed within two weeks.

headline: Woolworth P.L.C. Gets Improved Bid
abstract: Dixons Group P.L.C. sweetened its hostile bid to acquire another British retailer, Woolworth Holdings P.L.C., to the equivalent of $2.9 billion. Woolworth, a variety store chain, was spun off from the F. W. Woolworth Company of the United States in 1982.

headline: Washington Suburban Bonds
abstract: The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, a Maryland-based entity whose bonds are known as ''wash tubs,'' is offering $172.7 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.45 percent for bonds due in 2011 through 2016, underwriters led by Citibank announced.   For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 5.80 percent in 1991 to 6.75 percent in 1996, 7.25 percent in 2001 and 7.40 percent in 2006. The high-grade bonds, rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's, are backed by user fees from the district's water and sewer system, and are general obligations of Montgomery and Prince Georges Counties.

headline: C.D. Yields Off Slightly
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts fell slightly, while the average yield on money market mutual funds was unchanged in the week ending yesterday.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor national index, the average yield on a six-month certificate of deposit fell two basis points, to 6.82 from 6.84.

headline: G.M.'S SPUTTERING OPEL UNIT
abstract: Adam Opel A.G., the sturdy West German subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, used to be called the money machine.   But Opel, the linchpin of G.M.'s European activities, has been sputtering lately and G.M. officials are revamping the big European operation to nudge it back to profitability.   Last year, the division, G.M.'s second largest after the domestic United States unit, lost $372.1 million, about $80 million more than in 1984. The widening loss came despite fast-selling models that helped G.M. dramatically widen its European market share last year to 11.4 percent, from 9.6 percent as recently as 1982. Seeming Contradiction    The seeming contradiction in results arises because Europe's Big Six auto makers - Volkswagen, Fiat, Peugeot, Renault and the European units of Ford and G.M. - are all strugglng for shares of a relatively flat automobile market. That has translated into vicious price discounting and ballooning advertising budgets, both of which have depressed profit margins and left many of the majors losing money.

headline: COPTIC DUSK IN CAIRO: THE FAITHFUL AND THE WARY
abstract: Every day at dusk, riot policemen block off all the dirt alleys that lead to the Church of St. Demyana, an unpainted concrete building surrounded by crumbling apartment houses.   Once it is dark, and especially after midnight, the believers and the curious arrive, often by the thousands. They come hoping to see a glow atop St. Demyana's that the Coptic Church has identified as an apparition of the Virgin Mary.   ''We are here to maintain security,'' Sayed Abdel Halim, the local police chief, said as his men shouted ''Yallah!'' - ''Hurry up!'' - at passers-by and beat bamboo canes against their riot shields to reinforce the message.

headline: POLICE SAY FIANCEE WAS A DUPE
abstract: The police said today that they had arrested a man wanted for questioning about a bomb found Thursday in a woman's luggage at Heathrow Airport.   The police said the woman, who is pregnant, told them the man took her to Heathrow to board an El Al flight for Israel and gave her the bag with the bomb in it before he kissed her goodbye.   The man, Nezar Hindawi, who a former employer said is Jordanian by birth, was arrested at a London hotel and did not resist. Timed to Explode After Munich    The woman, Anne-Marie Murphy, who was arrested at Heathrow, has told the police that she did not know she was carrying a bomb. She had cleared airport security without difficulty. But El Al's security guards said Miss Murphy, who is Irish, looked different from the others checking in for Flight 016 to Tel Aviv, and they took extra care with her luggage. In previous news reports she had been described as looking Middle Eastern.

headline: S.E.C. Approves Utilities' Merger
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously approved the proposed merger of two Ohio-based utility companies, the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and the Toledo Edison Company, which would become subsidiaries of a single holding company, the Centerior Energy Corporation, which, with assets of more than $9 billion, would rank among the top 20 utility companies.   The transaction is the first merger of such utilities in years.

headline: Swedes Guard Envoy After Intruder Incident
abstract: The United States Ambassador, Gregory Newell, apparently unfazed by police concern that two men might have been stalking him, made a festive visit to his family roots in Dakarna Province today. He was carefully escorted by police bodyguards on the lookout for the two men who were chased from a private estate where the Ambassador was dining Tuesday after guards found them lurking with guns.

headline: 29.74 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,853.03
abstract: The stock market continued its recent surge yesterday as blue-chip issues lifted the Dow Jones industrial average by more than 29 points, to within 3 points of its highest close.   In the last three trading days, the Dow has risen nearly 78 points. With yesterday's 29.74-point climb, it closed at 1,853.03, ending slightly below its record close of 1,855.90 last April 21.   Analysts said that the market continued to follow bond prices, reflecting investor optimism over the direction of interest rates in the near term.

headline: TEXTS OF THE STATEMENTS ADOPTED BY LEADERS OF 7 INDUSTRIAL DEMOCRACIES
abstract: Following are the official texts of the statements on international terrorism, nuclear accidents and political issues that were adopted here today by the leaders of seven industrial democracies:   Terrorism We, the heads of state or government of seven major democracies and the representatives of the European Community, assembled here in Tokyo, strongly reaffirm our condemnation of international terrorism in all its forms, of its accomplices and of those, including governments, who sponsor or support it. We abhor the increase in the level of such terrorism since our last meeting, and in particular its blatant and cynical use as an instrument of government policy. Terrorism has no justification. It spreads only by the use of contemptible means, ignoring the values of human life, freedom and dignity. It must be fought relentlessly and without compromise. A Continuing Fight    Recognizing that the continuing fight against terrorism is a task which the international community as a whole has to undertake, we pledge ourselves to make maximum efforts to fight against the scourge. Terrorism must be fought effectively through determined, tenacious, discreet and patient action combining national measures with international cooperation. Therefore, we urge all like-minded nations to collaborate with us, particularly in such international fora as the United Nations, the International Civil Aviation Organization and the International Maritime Organization, drawing on their expertise to improve and extend countermeasures against terrorism and those who sponsor or support it.

headline: AS RIVALS MERGE, I.B.M. WAITS IN WINGS
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation's acquisition of the Sperry Corporation could prompt Sperry customers to abandon the company's products for those made by the International Business Machines Corporation, several users said today.   The users said they fear that the Sperry line of mainframe computers would not get full attention in the merged companies and might even be phased out eventually by Burroughs.   A group of 17 Sperry users in New England, led by Connecticut Natural Gas, sent a letter last week to the chairmen of both Burroughs and Sperry warning that ''the potential for erosion of the Sperry user base will increase dramatically'' in the event of a merger.   The New England users, as well as others, are seeking assurances that Burroughs will continue to support the Sperry computer line fully. ''It's of the utmost importance to our members to receive assurances by word and action from Sperry and Burroughs that the product line will not only continue but will be enriched and expanded,'' said Martin Litzky, the president of USE Inc., a group of Sperry customers.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: New York State and California yesterday offered two large new bond issues totaling $600 million, through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank. Underwriters said that demand for the new bonds was very strong, with heavy buying by institutional investors.

headline: Dome's Lenders Accept Extension
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said its 54 lenders had agreed to at least a five-month extension of an interim plan to defer a substantial amount of principal and interest payments on $5.3 billion (Canadian) of a $6.27 billion debt. The plan is effective immediately and scheduled to end next Oct. 28 or Feb. 28, 1987, if extended.

headline: SOVIET STATEMENT ON CHERNOBYL
abstract: Following is the text of a Soviet Government statement today on the Chernobyl nuclear accident, as distributed in translation by the official press agency Tass:   Throughout May 10, work to eliminate the consequences of the breakdown continued at the Chernobyl atomic power station. The temperature inside the reactor went down substantially as a result of the taken measures.

headline: CALIFORNIA OIL SUIT IN LEGAL SETBACK
abstract: In a setback for the state of California, a Federal district judge has ruled that the latest in a series of antitrust lawsuits charging eight oil companies with conspiracy and price-fixing must be decided in Federal court.   The latest suit charges the Chevron Corporation, the Unocal Corporation, the Mobil Oil Corporation, Texaco Inc., the Exxon Corporation, the Exxon Company U.S.A., the Shell Oil Company and Shell California Production Inc. with fraud, breach of contract and conspiracy to depress the price of crude oil pumped from state-owned lands in Long Beach, Calif., from 1980 to 1985.   The charges are similar to those in an earlier case that charged most of the same defendants with conspiring to fix the price of the heavy California crude from 1971 to 1977. United States District Judge William P. Gray dismissed most of the charges in the original suit last June after 10 years of pretrial testimony.

headline: 2D REACTOR WORRIES U.S. AIDES
abstract: United States officials said today that they were concerned that cooling problems at a second nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl complex in the Ukraine could result in a further release of radioactivity into the atmosphere.   The officials said the sister reactor to the one involved in the accident more than a week ago had been shut down. But Harold R. Denton of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that this unit retained sufficient heat to cause problems in the next few days.

headline: Most C.D. Yields Off
abstract: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds generally fell in the week ended yesterday, extending the decline to a ninth consecutive week.   The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed the average yield for a six-month C.D., at 6.83 percent, off two basis points from 6.85 percent from last week. The average yield for a bank money market account also declined two basis points, to 6.38 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.

headline: Dingell on Japanese Trade...
abstract: It is likely to take a vote on the floor of the House to resolve a contest between two powerful committee chairmen over the best way to retaliate against countries such as Japan that do not give American exporters a fair shake in telecommunications.   The Energy and Commerce Committee's chairman, John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, got his panel to clear a bill that would use the Federal Communications Commission as the instrument of reprisal.

headline: BRITAIN CITES 'EVIDENCE' OF LIBYAN ROLE
abstract: Britain said today that it had ''firm evidence of direct Libyan involvement'' in the kidnapping of two British teachers who were killed in Lebanon in reprisal for the bombing raid by American F-111's flying from British bases.   A statement by Sir Geoffrey Howe, the Foreign Secretary, stopped short of charging the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi with having ordered the execution of the hostages, whose bodies were discovered Thursday outside Beirut. But it said the British Government ''had good reason to believe'' the hostages, Philip Padfield and Leigh Douglas, ''were in Libyan hands.''   The term ''Libyan hands'' might be taken as meaning either the hands of terrorists directed by Libya or Libyan nationals, an official said, interpreting the Foreign Secretary's statement. Asked whether the statement meant Libya had control of the hostages this week at the time of the bombing raid or, subsequently, their murder, the official replied that he could not be that specific. But he said what the authorities here knew was more than enough for them to hold Libya responsible for their fate.

headline: New Air Links To Japan Due
abstract: An administrative law judge recommended today that Portland, Ore., and Dallas-Fort Worth be given nonstop airline service to Japan under an agreement signed last year with Japan. John M. Vittone, the judge, also urged that Delta Air Lines operate between Portland and Tokyo and American Airlines between Dallas-Fort Worth and Tokyo.

headline: Manila Palace Closed After Burglars Break In
abstract: Officials closed the presidential palace to the public today because of a break-in by burglars who apparently searched the rooms of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda.   ''We don't know yet what items were taken, but we found many items not in their usual places,'' said Rosemary Prieto, the palace administrator.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 23, 1986
abstract: The Economy    A wide-ranging revision of U.S. trade laws was approved by the House despite stern warnings from President Reagan, who criticized the bill as ''protectionist legislation.'' The bill would require the President to take more vigorous action against countries that subsidize exports to the U.S. but hinder American goods from entering their home markets. Mr. Reagan told a retailing group that the measure ''could plunge the world into a trade war.'' The bill, which also limits the President's discretion on trade matters, was passed 295 to 115, with 59 Republicans supporting the measure and just four Democrats opposing it. The Senate has already begun hearings on its version of trade legislation.  [ Page A1. ]  Canadian and U.S. negotiators ended the opening round of free-trade talks.  [ D4. ]    Factory orders for durable goods fell 0.8 percent in April, for the third monthly decline in a row. Commerce Secretary Baldrige attributed the drop to a 26.9 percent decline in military orders, but private economists called the results a big disappointment.  [ D1. ]

headline: JUNE VOTE ON CONTRA AID SET
abstract: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he has scheduled another vote on military aid to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government for the week of June 9.   Mr. O'Neill, a Democrat of Massachusetts, made his commitment as Republican leaders in the House acknowledged that they would not get the 218 signatures they needed on a special petition that would force a separate vote on military aid to the rebels, known as contras, by May 12.

headline: Sri Lanka Town Swept By Reservoir's Water
abstract: A reservoir holding nearly five billion cubic feet of water burst from its earthen embankment today, and 100 people may have been killed, the police said. The state radio said up to 20,000 families were left homeless.

headline: Fraud Bill Draws Fire
abstract: A majority of Securities and Exchange Commission members said today that they opposed a provision of a bill that would require outside auditors of companies to report to the Government their suspicions of fraud.   The bill, sponsored by Representative Ronald Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, would require independent auditors of a company to report to the S.E.C. or any other Government agency any suspicions they have that managers of their client companies have committed fraud.

headline: Sale by Hercules
