abstract: Hercules Inc. said it had sold its 13 percent interest, or about 5.6 million shares, of Erbamont N.V. to Montedison for about $125 million. Montedision, based in Italy, is the principal shareholder of Erbamont, an international pharmaceutical company in Stamford, Conn. Hercules said it had received its Erbamont shares in 1983 in exchange for its 50 percent interest in Adria Laboratories, a joint venture pharmaceutical company of Hercules and Montedison, and as compensation from Montedison in connection with the formation of Himont Inc.

headline: Advertising; G.M. Puts Stress on Efficiency
abstract: The General Motors Corporation, which spent $978 million last year for advertising worldwide, wants to use the clout of those dollars across media lines and national boundaries to get the lowest prices from the media.   Roger B. Smith, chairman of the world's biggest automobile manufacturer, disclosed his intentions today as keynote speaker at the 30th world congress of the International Advertising Association.   A record crowd of more than 1,400 was at Chicago's downtown Hyatt Regency for the first American gathering in 22 years.   And since the members of the audience were all advertising people -some of whom were listening to Mr. Smith, thanks to simultaneous translations into Japanese, Korean and Spanish - most were familiar with the moves already being taken at G.M. The company has brought in Phil Gurascio, an agency media heavyweight, from one of its shops in an all-out attempt to get multiple-title magazine publishers to hammer out new favorable volume and frequency discount deals for the auto giant.

headline: Phillips and Polygram Deal
abstract: Phillips International and Polygram International, two pioneers of the compact disk industry, said yesterday that they had formed a new company that would develop software for a new generation of compact disk systems. The new systems, called   Compact Disk Interactive, would integrate audio, video and text functions in an interactive format.

headline: European Boom Seen In TV Ads
abstract: CONSIDERING that John M. Eger's specialty is worldwide communications and considering the boom times that are being forecast, no wonder he is leaving CBS Worldwide Enterprises with hopes of wallowing in the expected pools of gold.   As for himself, the 46-year-old senior vice president is forecasting annual double-digit gains in both broadcasting and advertising in Europe alone for the next 20 years. So it does look like a man who also wears the hat of chairman of the Global Media Commission of the International Advertising Association and was once a White House adviser on telecommunications policy is in a position to capitalize on such credentials.

headline: Penalty Seen For Bank Leu
abstract: Bank Leu International, the Bahamian subsidiary of a Swiss bank, may be forced out of Nassau's Association of International Banks and Trust Companies, the leading trade group, because of its admitted involvement in the Dennis B. Levine insider trading case on Wall Street, according to bankers in the Bahamas.   Last week, the association forced Richard Coulson, a senior officer of Bank Leu Internatinal, to withdraw as the proposed new chairman of the offshore bankers group.

headline: The U.N. Today: June 20, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

headline: HOW 401(K)'S HURT LOWER-PAID WORKERS
abstract: THERE is a quick way for the Senate Finance Committee to raise billions of dollars in tax revenue: End the popular middle-income tax shelter known as the 401(k) plan.   This voluntary-savings arrangement has exhibited a remarkable resiliency in Congress. Scheduled for elimination in last fall's Treasury proposal for tax revision, the plans survived in the House tax reform bill with a proposed cap on employee contributions of $7,000. Then the Senate Finance Committe voted earlier this month to raise that limit to $12,000, ignoring the acid observation of its chairman, Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, that the ''tax code is not designed to let the elegant live very exquisitely when they retire.''

headline: DEBT-MIRED MEXICO SEEKS A WAY OUT
abstract: A rescue plan for Mexico was hurriedly formulated in light of that nation's $97 billion in foreign debt, the dramatic drop of the peso and the drop in the price of oil, its major hard currency generator. Discussions on ways to solve the debt problem had been under way for months, but the crisis was precipitated but the plunge of the peso, which fell 30 percent in six days. The rescue package would require Mexico to sign a letter of intent with the I.M.F., promising to take steps to expand its economy. In return, Mexico would get $6 billion in new, one-year loans, including some from the I.M.F. and the World Bank.   Some of the loans would have to come from commercial banks in the United States, and the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said lenders should be lenient. But many commercial bankers, seeing their problem loans mount up, say they are reluctant to throw good money after bad and will require some guarantees beyond the letter of intent with the I.M.F.

headline: U.S. OFFICIALS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER CHARGES AGAINST PANAMANIAN
abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials expressed concern today about evidence that the army commander of Panama was involved in drug trafficking and money laundering and was linked to the killing of a political opponent.   Members of Congress and the Administration said they had been aware for some time of the charges against the commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who is viewed as the leader of Panama.   Asked to comment on a report Thursday in The New York Times on the activities of General Noriega, Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said, ''These are serious charges, but they have been around a long time.''   Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he expected the Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs of the House Foreign Affairs Committee to investigate the charges against General Noriega.

headline: TEXT OF ECONOMIC DECLARATION ISSUED AT END OF TOKYO SUMMIT CONFERENCE
abstract: Following is the text of the Tokyo Economic Declaration issued today by the leaders of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada at the conclusion of their three-day summit meeting:   [ 1 ]  We, the heads of state or government of seven major industrialized countries and the representatives of the European Community, meeting in Tokyo for the 12th Economic Summit, have reviewed developments in the world economy since our meeting in Bonn a year ago and have reaffirmed our continuing determination to work together to sustain and improve the prosperity and well-being of the peoples of our own countries, to support the developing countries in their efforts to promote their economic growth and prosperity and to improve the functioning of the world monetary and trading systems.   [ 2 ]  Developments since our last meeting reflect the effectiveness of the policies to which we have committed ourselves at successive Economic Summits in recent years. The economies of the industrialized countries are now in their fourth year of expansion. In all our countries the rate of inflation has been declining. With the continuing pursuit of prudent fiscal and monetary policies, this has permitted a substantial lowering of interest rates. There has been a significant shift in the pattern of exchange rates which better reflects fundamental economic conditions.

headline: DOW RETREATS 14.63
abstract: The stock market was mixed yesterday, with blue-chip stocks getting the bulk of the selling pressure, as investors began doubting that the Federal Reserve Board intended to reduce the discount rate.   After the market closed for the day, however, those fears proved unfounded as the rate the Fed charges on loans to financial institutions was cut a half-point, to 6 1/2 percent.   After setting records in the earlier part of the week, the Dow Jones industrial average was ripe for profit taking and responded by declining 14.63 points, to 1,840.40. Even with that drop the Dow gained 50.22 points for the week.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: THE SELLING OF FATHER'S DAY
abstract: Signs abound of the new importance being attached to the role of the father, from the sharp rise in fathers attending hospital births to the increased time that American fathers are spending with their offspring.   So do the signs that it is selling at the cash register. With Father's Day falling tomorrow, sales of such items as cuff links and tie pins, traditional Father's Day presents, jumped 50 percent at Tiffany's from the period a year ago. Wallach's in White Plains also reports that business has increased. Bill Cosby's book, ''Fatherhood,'' now leads The New York Times best-seller list. And last week saw the introduction of a national publication called Fathers magazine.   While the holiday, celebrated on the third Sunday in June, still has nothing like the oomph of Christmas, it is not Flag Day either (which, for those who may not have noticed, happens to be today).

headline: How the Proposals Compare with Current Law
abstract: President Reagan has supported the basic principles of the House bill passed last December but opposes several of the specific elements. He wants a top individual tax rate of no more than 35 percent; a personal exemption of no lower than $2,000 for lower- and middle-income taxpayers, and more favorable business depreciation rules. After passage of the Senate Finance Committee tax bill early Wednesday morning, the President said he believed he could support that bill but has some ''questions'' about unspecified elements. Current lawfor 1986 House bill Senate Finance Committee bill INDIVIDUAL TAX RATES: 14 rate brackets from 11% to 50% Four rate brackets: 15%, 25%, 35%, 38% Two rate brackets: 15%, 27% EXEMPTIONS: Self, spouse, dependents $1,080 $1,500 for those who itemize deductions; $2,000 for non-itemizers For all but wealthiest taxpayers, $1,900 in 1987 and $2,000 in 1988 STANDARD DEDUCTIONS: Single returns $2,480 $2,950 $3,000 Joint returns $3,670 $4,800 $5,000 Heads of households $2,480 $4,200 $4,400 INDEXING FOR INFLATION: Adjusting tax-rate brackets and increasing personal exemptions and standard deductions for inflation Yes Yes Yes PERSONAL DEDUCTIONS:   Mortgage interest Fully deductible Deductible for first and second homes Deductible for first and second homes Other personal interest Deductible Limited to $20,000 over investment income Deductible only up to the amount of investment income Medical expenses Deductible above 5% of adjusted gross income Deductible above 5% of adjusted gross income Deductible above 10% of adjusted gross income Charitable contributions Deductible Fully deductible for itemizers; non-itemizers allowed deduction for contributions over $100 Deductible only for itemizers State and local income taxes Deductible Deductible Deductible Other state and local taxes Deductible Deductible Property taxes deductible, but sales taxes not deductible Two-earner deduction Yes No No Miscellaneous itemized deductions (such as union dues) Deductible Lumped together with employee business expenses and deductible only above 1% of adjusted gross income Repealed OTHER INDIVIDUAL ITEMS:   Earned income credit Yes Increased and indexed Increased Child care credit Yes Yes Yes Unemployment compensation Taxed if adjusted gross income more than $12,000 ($18,000 if married) Taxed Taxedurtailed Workers' compensation Not taxed Not taxed Not taxed Entertainment expenses Deductible 80% deductible 80% deductible Business meals and travel expenses Deductible 80% limit on business meals; no limit on business travel expenses 80% limit on business meals; no limit on business travel expenses Income shifting to children through trusts Permitted Curtailed Curtailed RETIREMENT:   Individual Retirement Accounts $2,000 tax-deferred contribution permitted each year $2,000 tax-deferred contribution permitted each year; contribution must be reduced by amount of 401(K) contribution Deduction repealed for individuals covered by other pension plans; however, income earned in account from existing and future contributions will continue to be tax-deferred Corporate pensions Tax deferred Tax deferred Tax deferred 401(K) plans Annual tax-deferred contribution up to $30,000 Annual tax-deferred contribution limited to $7,000 Annual tax-deferred contribution limited to $5,000 Social Security Generally not taxed Generally not taxed Generally not taxed FRINGE BENEFITS:   Health insurance Excluded from taxable income Excluded from taxable income Excluded from taxable income Group life and legal insurance Excluded from taxable income Excluded from taxable income Excluded from taxable income CAPITAL AND BUSINESS TAXES Corporate tax rates Graduated up to 46% Graduated up to 36% Graduated up to 33% Dividend relief $100/$200 exclusion Exclusion repealed, 10% dividend-paid deduction Exclusion repealed Depreciation Accelerated Cost Recovery System, allowing fast write-offs Partly indexed with investment incentives Accelerated Cost Recovery System, with faster write-offs except for real estate Investment Tax Credit 6% to 10% Repealed Repealed Capital gains 60% excluded from taxation 42% excluded from taxation for individuals Taxed as ordinary income for individuals; taxed at 28% for corporations Interest income/expense Fully taxable/deductible Fully taxable/deductible Fully taxable/deductible OIL INDUSTRY:   Percentage depletion Yes Phased out with stripper exception Yes Immediate deduction of intangible drilling costs Yes Most Yes FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS:   Special bad debt deduction Yes Retained for smaller banks Yes Deferral for life insurance investment income and annuity income Yes Yes Yes MUNICIPAL BONDS:   Public purpose Tax-exempt Tax-exempt Tax-exempt Private purpose Tax-exempt Some taxed Some taxed (Source: House of Representatives; Senate Finance Committee)

headline: Bid for Hispanic Stations Rejected
abstract: An investor group that includes the former United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, and the Hollywood executive A. Jerrold Perenchio has dropped its bid for Los Angeles television station KMEX and four other Spanish-language stations. ''We made an offer which was turned down,'' said Robert Cahill, the executive vice president of Chartwell Partnership Group, Mr. Perenchio's principal business.

headline: WEST GERMANY TO INVESTIGATE ROLE OF OTHER COUNTRIES IN BERLIN BLAST
abstract: The West German Government appointed a panel today to evaluate the possibility that foreign governments had some involvement in a bombing at a discotheque here that killed an American soldier and a Turkish woman.   A Foreign Ministry statement issued in Bonn said the action was taken in reaction to reports of possible Libyan involvement in the attack early Saturday at the club, which was frequented by United States soldiers. French Expulsion of Libyans   Bonn's decision was made a day after France announced it was expelling two Libyan diplomats who it said were in touch with people believed to be planning attacks against American targets. In another sign that France is willing to take firmer action to combat terrorism, President Francois Mitterrand last week reversed his opposition to closer coordination of intelligence exchanges with allied governments.

headline: CHIEF IS OUT AT UNITED ARTISTS
abstract: In a shake-up that startled Hollywood executives, the United Artists Corporation said that Jerry Weintraub was no longer its chairman and chief executive. Mr. Weintraub had joined the company five months ago.   The company's statement gave no explanation for his departure, and executives did not return telephone calls. Mr. Weintraub was said to be out of the country.   Sources in the industry said the move was apparently the result of disagreements between Mr. Weintraub and Kirk Kerkorian, the controlling shareholder of United Artists.   In a telephone interview yesterday, Stephen D. Silbert, Mr. Kerkorian's lawyer, said that Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. Weintraub had ''philosophical differences.'' Mr. Silbert would not elaborate.

headline: U.S. MAY SELL OFF URANIUM PLANTS
abstract: The Administration is considering selling the plants that process uranium for the nation's nuclear power utilities, according to officials.   Several said they would even consider giving away much of the business - a Federal monopoly - to stem the Government's losses from running it.   ''I think the Department of Energy and the Administration would be interested in selling the whole shebang if they could,'' said Thomas Gale Moore, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. As for giving the business away, Mr. Moore said, ''I would consider it among the options if that's the best you can do.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. is issuing 100 billion lire of 10 1/4 percent bonds in the Eurolira bond market. The bonds, due 1993, have a minimum price of 99 1/4 through Istituto Bancario San Paolo Di Torino.    * Calton Inc. is offering $50 million of B-2/B- rated 12 1/4 percent notes due 1996 at 100 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: QUEMOY (REMEMBER?) BRISTLES WITH READINESS
abstract: For Americans who remember the period, this cluster of islands off the China coast belongs somewhere between British troops seizing the Suez Canal and Nikita S. Khrushchev banging his shoe at the United Nations.   In August 1958 heavy shelling by the Chinese Communists threatened to draw the United States into China's civil war. But in the years since the 1960 Presidential campaign, when the islands figured prominently in the race between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon, the names of Quemoy and Matsu (about 150 miles farther up the coast) have largely receded from the American consciousness.   But on the islands, particularly those in the Quemoy group, barely a mile and a half from the mainland at their closest point, time has in many respects stood still. What has changed are the Nationalist fortifications, which have turned the cratered wasteland of a generation ago into one of the most expensively defended stretches of real estate anywhere.

headline: Journalists Denounce Pretoria's News Rules
abstract: The Foreign Correspondents' Association protested today against the Government's restrictions on news reporting, saying they had progressively become among the world's strictest since the state of emergency was declared last week.

headline: Dow Rises by 8.18; Many Stocks Decline
abstract: The prices of blue-chip stocks advanced yesterday, but the bulk of the market was lower as Wall Street turned in its second consecutive session of mixed prices and dull trading.   And with trading volume slowing to its worst level since the middle of April, speculators seemed to keep themselves occupied chasing takeover and other rumors. The day's juiciest speculation involved American Brands, which rose 3 3/4, to 91, in heavy trading while other tobacco stocks were declining in price.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which eked out a small gain on Friday, rose 8.18 points yesterday, to close at 1,843.75, thanks to a late afternoon surge that coincided with an improvement in the bond market.

headline: Paraguay Police Break Up Political Rally
abstract: Witnesses said the police used riot sticks and tear gas to disperse a political rally Sunday, and a member of a television crew filming the event reported that journalists were beaten and their equipment wrecked.   The rally, which witnesses said was attended by about 1,000 people, was held in front of the home of Domingo Laino, exiled leader of the opposition Authenic Radical Liberal Party.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: The U.N. Today; April 30, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND

headline: Advertising; Survey Shows Drop In Client Payments
abstract: The trend of larger advertisers decreasing their compensation to their ad agencies is continuing, according to an Association of National Advertisers Survey.   One of four members changed their form of compensation during the last three years, generally to decrease the amount the agency got, according to a report read at a recent workshop by William M. Weilbacher, an advertising management consultant.

headline: GREEK INACTION ON LIBYA UPSETS U.S.
abstract: The United States is disturbed by Greece's unwillingness to carry out the European Community restrictions against Libya that Athens joined in unanimously adopting on Monday, Western diplomats said today.   The differences are viewed by diplomats as the first major shadow cast over what was apparently a reconciliation between Greece and the United States, which was capped by a visit last month by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. The Libyan issue was discussed this evening by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and the American Ambassador, Robert V. Keeley, at a meeting held at the American's request.

headline: CAR BOMB KILLS 11 IN EAST BEIRUT IN WORST WEEK OF WAR IN MONTHS
abstract: An especially powerful car bomb exploded in Christian East Beirut today, killing 11 people, wounding 84 and setting several buildings afire, the police said.   As has been the case in almost all such terrorist attacks in this country in recent years, no group took responsibility. Car bombs have been a scourge of the Lebanese civil war and have killed more civilians than random bombardment of residential areas.   The bombing raised to 64 the number of Lebanese who have died and to 243 the number of those wounded in the last three days of bloodshed.

headline: PATENTS; PROCESS ADVANCES CIRCUIT BOARDS
abstract: Printed circuit boards are regarded as the heart of all electronic gear.

headline: Mortgage Aid Bill Is Passed
abstract: The House gave final Congressional approval today to emergency legislation reviving the Federal Housing Administration's authority to insure home mortgages.   ''My guess is that we will be back in business on Monday,'' said Silvio J. DeBartolomeis, the F.H.A.'s acting administrator.

headline: 'ANTI SOVIET HYSTERIA,' RUSSIAN TERMS REPORTS
abstract: A high Soviet official today accused Western journalists of exaggerating the Chernobyl nuclear disaster ''to whip up anti-Soviet hysteria.''   At the same time, the official press agency Tass made public a letter from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to six world leaders criticizing continued American nuclear testing.   Mr. Gorbachev's letter said that the Soviet Government reserved the right to resume nuclear tests but that it was ''in no hurry'' to do so.   The events seemed to indicate a Soviet desire to go on the offensive after five days of harsh worldwide criticism for the Kremlin's refusal to provide detailed information about the disaster at the Chernobyl reactor, about 70 miles from Kiev, which spread a cloud of radioactive debris over much of Europe. After four days of terse official statements on the Chernobyl matter, the Soviet Government today offered no new information.

headline: Chernobyl Death Toll Now Put at 26 by Soviet
abstract: A Soviet health official said today that 13 of the 19 people who received bone marrow transplants after getting massive doses of radiation in the Chernobyl disaster had died.   First Deputy Health Minister Oleg P. Shchepin said the death toll from the disaster, including the two deaths on the night of the explosion, was now 26, an increase of one.

headline: New Chairman Named For Troubled Enterra
abstract: Stanley P. Gold, who heads an investment firm owned by the Roy E. Disney family, has been named chairman of one of the firm's latest investments - the Enterra Corporation of Radnor, Pa.   Mr. Gold's firm, Shamrock Holdings Inc., has business interests that include real estate, a major agribusiness company, broadcasting stations and ranching properties.   The Enterra Corporation is an energy company with a woeful recent string of losses. But Mr. Gold sees value in it, since Shamrock, beginning late last year, has acquired a 23.5 percent interest in Enterra.

headline: RUMORS SPUR SAFEWAY STOCK
abstract: Safeway Stores stock jumped $2.625 in heavy trading yesterday, to $50.50, as market rumors spread that the nation's biggest supermarket chain was considering several defensive steps to fight off a possible takeover move by the multimillionaire Haft family of Washington.   Herbert H. Haft, the 65-year-old chairman of the Dart Group Corporation, majority owner of a chain of bookstores and car-parts outlets, announced last Thursday that a group he headed owned 3.6 million Safeway shares, or a 5.9 percent stake, and might try to buy the San Francisco-based company.   How serious the prospect might be was difficult to determine because in two earlier takeover situations, involving the Jack Eckerd Corporation and the May Department Stores Company, the Hafts sold their stock back to the companies at a profit.

headline: Alamito Rejects Bid by Ventana
abstract: In a major setback for the Ventana Electric Company, the Alamito Company ended its merger agreement with Ventana because it has found an offer from Osceola Energy Inc. more favorable to shareholders.

headline: Market Place; Suggestions on Mutual Funds
abstract: TWO observers of the booming mutual fund industry expressed optimism yesterday over prospects for the stock market and also suggested specific funds for investors.   ''I'm very bullish over the market outlook for the next 12 months,'' said Norman Fosback, the editor of the Mutual Fund Forecaster in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. ''Our total return projection of 17 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index translates into a target of 2,100 for the Dow Jones industrial average.''   Total return consists of price appreciation plus reinvested dividends. Yesterday, the Dow fell 4.85 points, to 1,880.20.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET TO PAVE WAY TO SUMMIT
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will probably meet in Washington in the second half of May to prepare the way for a summit meeting that could be held in July, Reagan Administration officials said today.   The decision to proceed with summit planning came against a background of recriminations between the two countries in recent months. American officials said they hoped the decision might indicate a more constructive relationship.   The officials said Mr. Shultz and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the national security adviser, met for breakfast this morning at the State Department with Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the departing Soviet envoy, to discuss a date for the Shultz-Shevardnadze meeting.

headline: ADVERTISING; People
abstract: * John H. Glorieux and Tim M. Pollak have been promoted to executive vice president and Christine E. Jones Lawrence to senior vice president of Young & Rubicam, New York.

headline: Dow Off 2.42; Trading Slows
abstract: Share prices were mixed on Wall Street yesterday and trading volume declined sharply from the level reached Friday, when the stock market was rallying on hopes of lower interest rates.   Despite glum economic news that produced an early upturn in the bond market, equities investors were taking profits and protecting themselves from this Friday's ''triple witching hour.''   Wayne Stevens, executive vice president of Chicago's Duff & Phelps, said investors were torn between the beneficial and detrimental effects of the weak economy.

headline: May Awaits Reply
abstract: The May Department Stores Company, which is offering $66 a share for the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, took no apparent action yesterday despite the passing of a 9 A.M. deadline for a formal response to its $2.7 billion bid.

headline: CHINA'S PROUD SPACE PROGRAM
abstract: Most Americans think of China as the land of the bicycle.   Late next year, they may have to adjust that image, if, as proposed, a United States-built communications satellite is launched into space aboard a Chinese Long March-3 rocket from a space center set in the hilly woodlands of southern Sichuan.   If the launching succeeds, a second privately owned United States satellite will follow in 1988.   According to Chinese officials, up to nine other nations have shown interest in similar deals.   The memorandum of agreement announced last week by Teresat Inc. of Houston and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation, an agency of the Astronautics Ministry, came against the background of uncertainty in the United States space industry following four major launching failures in the past 16 weeks, including the loss of the space shuttle Challenger Jan. 28.

headline: THE ART OF SELLING TO THE VERY RICH
abstract: NOBODY buys one of Gerry Grinberg's watches to get unbeatably accurate time. Mr. Grinberg admits it: You can get as good time on an $18 watch as you can on one of his hand-carved, $13,000 gold Piaget beauties or one of his diamond-studded $1 million watches.   Yet, especially over the last few years, he has been selling more and more of these wristwatches.   ''The reason has been here since civilization started,'' he said. ''People want to show their station in life. To the Egyptians, station was how many things they put in their tombs. In England in the 1700's, it was the big castles. Now it's by acquiring products like beautiful watches.''

headline: FRANCE SET TO PRESS IRAN ON HOSTAGES IN LEBANON
abstract: The French Government is ready to put pressure on Iran, through increased arms sales to Iraq, if the Iranian Government does not help to secure the release of seven French hostages being held in Lebanon, according to officials here.   The officials said France was evolving a new strategy toward Iran intended to both improve the tense relations between the two nations and secure the release of the hostages.   Disclosure of the French strategy comes after the killing on Thursday of two Britons and an American held hostage in Lebanon.   The officials said the strategy included a willingness to make some conciliatory gestures toward Iran but also increased support of Iraq if Iran remains unresponsive to French pleas for the hostages' release.

headline: DOW SLUMPS 24.92 ON PROFIT TAKING
abstract: A severe bout of profit taking on Wall Street yesterday sent stock prices down sharply in heavy trading.   ''The bond market really got hit,'' said Michael Sherman, head of the investment policy committee at Shearson Lehman Brothers. ''People are saying this is the last discount rate cut. This created a lot of profit taking in the bond market and it spilled over into the stock market.''

headline: MOTIVES ARE UNCLEAR IN MOVE TO EMBARRASS
abstract: Poland's assertion this week that the United States learned about plans to impose martial law in 1981, but withheld it from Solidarity is the latest Polish attempt to embarrass the Reagan Administration. There is agreement among diplomats and others that it is the most serious.   When the United States offered powdered milk for Polish children after the Chernobyl nuclear accident, the Polish Government, in accepting the offer, offered to send 5,000 sleeping bags to the homeless in New York.   Then, three days after Zbigniew Bujak, an underground leader, was captured last Saturday, Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman, suggested that United States diplomats had known the whereabouts of the fugitive.

headline: RADICAL SURGE ON CAMPUSES SHAKES SEOUL
abstract: A surge of campus radicalism, much of it anti-American in tone, has caused deep concern among both Government officials and opposition politicians who worry that the students may be beyond their control.   Demonstrations at universities, long a South Korean tradition, have been marked recently by an unusual degree of violence, as militants have rushed at riot policemen with gasoline bombs and sticks, and officers have fired back with tear gas. In the last few weeks, several people on both sides have died, including two policemen and a young demonstrator who had set himself on fire as a protest.   Government officials accused the students of echoing the language of Communist North Korea, and they warned of crackdowns if the violence persisted. Last Friday Home Minister Chung Suk Mo announced that riot troops would be sent onto campuses whenever an extremist group known as Min Min Tu called a demonstration.

headline: Geers Gross Wins Pie Fillings Account
abstract: Geers Gross Advertising is going to be doing advertising for the pudding and pie fillings of the Comstock and Thank You divisions of Curtice-Burns of Rochester. There will be $3 million in fillings billings, thank you.   Comstock and Thank You, which account for about half of the pie filling market, were formerly represented by two different agencies, Hicks & Greist and Young & Rubicam, Detroit, respectively.

headline: INSIDER ACCUSATIONS YIELD 5 GUILTY PLEAS
abstract: Dennis B. Levine pleaded guilty to Federal charges that he used inside information to make $12.6 million in illegal profits. And he settled S.E.C. civil charges by agreeing to return nearly $11.5 million. In addition, Mr. Levine, a former investment banker who was accused of insider trading while at several firms, agreed to cooperate with a widening inquiry into the pervasive but ambiguously defined Wall Street practice of leaking information. Mr. Levine, who traded through the Bahamian subsidiary of a Swiss bank, was accused of using such information to trade in the stocks of companies involved in takeovers.   Three other young Wall Streeters, and one of their customers, also pleaded guilty to Federal charges in a separate insider trading case. A fifth man, accused of stealing some of the information that was purportedly used in the trades, pleaded not guilty.

headline: Hartford National
abstract: The Hartford National Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the First New England Bankshares Corporation of Taunton, Mass., and its subsidiary, First Bristol County National Bank. Hartford National said it would exchange common shares valued at $88.1 million for all 2,077,746 shares of First New England subject to an adjustment based on the market price of Hartford National stock before closing.

headline: Morocco a Model For Baker Initiative
abstract: Ahmed, a ragged youth who pushes a wheelbarrow on a building site here, has never heard of James A. Baker 3d. But in his own way he is involved in a project that symbolizes the Treasury Secretary's proposed strategy for easing the debt burden in developing nations.   The Meknes building site, part of a World Bank project for replacing shantytown slum dwellings with modern apartment buildings, reflects the bank's belief that grinding poverty is itself an obstacle to economic development.   But the project also illustrates Morocco's role as a test of reforms like those urged by Mr. Baker as a way to bring hope to the third world's millions of impoverished people and head off the danger of loan defaults.

headline: New Mexico Bond Demand Is High
abstract: Strong investor demand for an $85 million issue of New Mexico severance-tax revenue bonds was noted yesterday, despite an announcment by Moody's Investors Service last week that it had lowered the triple-A rating of New Mexico's severance-tax bonds to double-A. The bonds are rated AA+ by S. & P. Since the bonds are backed by severance-tax collections from contractors who mine the state's natural gas, oil, coal and other minerals, Moody's felt that lower energy prices and diminished expectations for the mining sector could reduce margins of protection for bonds payable solely from severance taxes.

headline: FEBRUARY NEW-HOME SALES FELL
abstract: Sales of new homes fell an unexpected 3.8 percent in February despite the lowest mortgage interest rates of the decade. But sales are picking up, housing industry officials said, with the beginning of the spring home-buying season.   New single-family homes sold at a seasonably adjusted annual rate of 685,000 units in February, down from 712,000 in both January and December, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline was the largest since a 6.5 percent drop in October, and it left sales only 1.3 percent above the pace of February 1985.

headline: REAGAN TO ACCUSE SOVIET OF SENDING ARMS TO MANAGUA
abstract: White House officials said today that President Reagan, in a campaign to try to win Congressional approval of new aid for Nicaraguan rebels, would charge this week that the Soviet Union has resumed direct arms shipments to Managua.   The officials said United States intelligence sources had information showing that a Soviet freighter delivered a large cache of military supplies to Nicaragua in early May.   Attempts to reach the spokesman at the Nicaraguan Embassy in Washington were unavailing. The spokesman was in Nicaragua, according to the person who answered the phone, and no one else could respond.

headline: Duchess of Windsor Names Pasteur Institute in Her Will
abstract: The Duchess of Windsor has named the Pasteur Institute as main beneficiary of her fortune, including her famed jewels, her lawyer said today.   Suzanne Blum, the lawyer, said the will stipulated the research center would inherit all money remaining after donations to other charities.

headline: New Zenith Tube
abstract: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said that it had developed a high-resolution flat picture tube that does not distort images or reflect background light.

headline: Tri-Honda Auto
abstract: Korey, Kay & Partners considers itself the first beneficiary of megamerger fallout. Its new account is the Tri-Honda Auto Dealers Association, which should spend in the $4 million to $6 million range. The account came loose from its former agency, Needham Harper Worldwide, because it was merging with Doyle Dane Bernbach, long the agency for Volkswagen, certainly a competitive auto company.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * ARA Services Inc., Philadelphia, a management services organization, named James Ksansnak senior vice president and a member of the executive council.    * Hi-Shear Industries, North Hills, L.I., a maker of space and military ordnance equipment, said S. Gerard Benford had joined it as vice president and chief financial officer.

headline: RESORTS STOCK UP SHARPLY
abstract: The stock of Resorts International Inc., which owns a casino in Atlantic City and other valuable properties, soared yesterday after the death of its chairman, James M. Crosby. Wall Street perceives that the company will now be up for sale, analysts said.   The class A common stock jumped $17.625 a share, to $67. It was the sixth-most-active stock on the Americn exchange, with 427,600 shares changing hands. Class B voting common stock closed at $69, up $16.875.

headline: 79 Jews Leave Soviet in May
abstract: The Soviet Union allowed 79 Jews to emigrate in May, the agency helping them resettle said Thursday. The number of Jewish emigrants was 72 in April and 53 in March, according to the agency, the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration. Last year, 1,140 Soviet Jews were allowed to emigrate; in 1979, 51,330 Jews left the Soviet Union.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Vacations in Paradise, a time-share group for Paradise Island, in the Bahamas, to I. Goldberg & Partners.    * Goldin-Feldman, maker of fine furs, to Arnell/Bickford.

headline: Chief Resigns Post At Beker Industries
abstract: Beker Industries, a phosphate fertilizer company now in bankruptcy proceedings, said yesterday that Erol Y. Beker, president and chief executive, had resigned but would become vice chairman.   The company named Perry B. Duryea Jr., who is 64 years old, to take over Mr. Beker's duties.   Mr. Duryea served as Speaker of the New York State Assembly from 1968 through 1974 and its minority leader from 1966 through 1968 and again from 1975 through 1978. He has been a director of Beker since 1976, the company said.

headline: Article 661486 -- No Title
abstract: Basic telephone rates for homes and small businesses will rise by $1 a month on Sunday. But as local rates increase, some long-distance rates are falling.   The rise is the second installment of a $2-a-month local charge ordered by the Federal Communications Commission.   As a result, residential customers of New York Telephone, for example, will see their average phone bill increase 3.3 percent, to $31.49 a month. Customers of New England Telephone will see their average bills increase 4.7 percent, to $22.50.

headline: FLEET NATIONAL BANK INDICTED
abstract: A grand jury investigating corruption at the state mortgage agency today indicted the Fleet National Bank and three top bank officials on fraud charges.   Fleet is the largest bank in Rhode Island and the third-largest financial institution in New England.

headline: Viacom Acts to Thwart Unfriendly Takeovers
abstract: In a move that would offer protection from an unfriendly takeover, Viacom International said yesterday that it planned an offering of securities that could raise as much as $530 million.   The diversified media company, which has been the subject of takeover reports for months, said it may use the proceeds in part to buy back its own shares. However, it did not specify how many.

headline: DOW UP IN SLUGGISH TRADING
abstract: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday on Wall Street, but trading remained sluggish as investors grappled with a host of potentially bothersome factors like tax revision, government refinancings and the economy.   Hugh Johnson, stock analyst and economist with the First Albany Corporation, said many investors are now worried that ''all the good news is behind us.''   ''People are searching, struggling to make the case that the stock market is going to move higher,'' Mr. Johnson added.   The Dow Jones industrial average, after losing nearly 13 points on Wednesday, did move higher yesterday, but the 10.91-point gain, to 1,786.21, left many analysts unimpressed.

headline: Honda Increases '86 Prices Again
abstract: The Honda Motor Company, citing the continued strengthening of the yen against the dollar, issued its fourth price increase on cars since the 1986 model year began. Honda said it would raise suggested base retail prices by an average 2.3 percent, or $238, on a typical Honda car, effective immediately.

headline: SAFEWAY SAYS IT PREFERS TO REMAIN INDEPENDENT
abstract: Safeway Stores, operator of the biggest chain of supermarkets in the country, yesterday spurned the idea of a takeover by Herbert H. Haft, a Washington multimillionaire, saying that the huge chain preferred to remain independent.   Peter A. Magowan, chairman of Safeway, said without elaboration that there were ''significant additional values'' in the company and that ''the best interests of stockholders will be served by Safeway remaining an independent company.'' 'All Appropriate Action'    Safeway, he said, has ''no intention of letting anyone usurp those values from our stockholders and will take all appropriate action to protect the interests of our stockholders.''

headline: MARTIN'S POSTS AT FED FILLED
abstract: The White House today announced its intention to nominate H. Robert Heller, a West Coast bank economist, to fill a vacancy on the Federal Reserve Board and to designate Manuel H. Johnson as vice chairman.   Mr. Heller, 46 years old, would fill the unexpired term of Preston Martin, which runs until 1996. Mr. Martin resigned from the board when his four-year term as vice chairman expired at the end of April and he was unable to obtain an Administration commitment that he would eventually succeed Paul A. Volcker as Fed chairman.   Mr. Johnson joined the board in February after having served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy.   Although Mr. Heller, a senior vice president at the Bank of America, had long been one of the three or four top candidates, it had appeared in recent weeks that the governorship would go to William E. Gibson, chief economist at the Republicbank Corporation in Dallas.

headline: NEW TAX LAW: MANY ITEMS ALREADY SET
abstract: The Senate's expected approval of its sweeping tax-revision plan would effectively seal many major provisions into any final package enacted into law by Congress.   Although the House and Senate tax bills differ on numerous critical issues, many other provisions are identical. These range from repeal of the two-earner marriage deduction and income averaging to retaining deductions for most state and local taxes other than sales taxes.   The next step will come when the two legislative bodies try to resolve their differences in a conference committee. When House and Senate negotiators meet, they almost never disturb provisions of the two bills that are the same. It would be highly unusual if the common tax-revision elements were not part of what the conferees eventually recommend for passage by both chambers and ultimately for President Reagan's signature.

headline: OPEC MAKES LITTLE PROGRESS
abstract: OPEC ministers appeared at a standstill today, as continuing strategy disputes and the American bombing raids in Libya derailed the group's efforts to find a formula for stabilizing oil prices.   Reacting to the lack of progress in the talks, which began Tuesday in the Hotel Inter-Continental here, crude oil prices on New York and London futures markets continued to decline.   After the oil ministers held a brief meeting this morning, a spokesman for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries told reporters that they would hold bilateral talks through the afternoon to sound out possibilities for compromise on production. The spokesman said the ministers were seeking a cumulative production ceiling of about 14 million to 14.5 million barrels a day, down from more than 17 million barrels, to balance supply and demand more closely and lift prices.

headline: SYRIA TERROR LINK CITED BY ITALIAN
abstract: Italy's Interior Minister said today that Italian judges had obtained ''concrete evidence'' that Syria was one of the sources of international terrorism.   The Minister, Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, made his comments after signing an agreement with Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d providing for cooperation between Italy and the United States in the fight against terrorism.   ''Unquestionably, the magistrates have obtained concrete evidence to believe that one of the sources of terrorism is definitely Syria,'' Mr. Scalfaro said at a joint news conference with Mr. Meese.   But Mr. Scalfaro declined to offer details of the evidence, and Mr. Meese declined to discuss the matter at all.

headline: Commercial Paper Due In Australian Dollars
abstract: The growing market in the United States for debt securities denominated in foreign currencies passed another milestone yesterday when the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced plans to begin selling commercial paper denominated in Australian dollars.   Officials at Morgan Guaranty and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, which will help sell the paper, said it was the first domestic issue of foreign-currency commercial paper to be sold here.

headline: OPEC STILL AT IMPASSE OVER PRODUCTION CUTS
abstract: A majority group of OPEC ministers failed today to persuade a stubborn minority to accept a moderate cut in the organization's production of crude oil in hopes of bolstering prices to about $17 to $20 a barrel by the year's end.   But the minority, including Libya, Iran and Algeria, continued to resist the proposal, insisting instead that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries make dramatic cuts in production, to propel the price of crude oil to $28 a barrel.   Ministers said they would continue their discussions on Saturday, but some delegation members said the sides appeared to be making little progress toward agreement.

headline: Washington Issues Priced
abstract: A $206.3 million financing by Washington, D.C., was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company with a maximum yield of 8.209 percent for general obligation bonds with a final maturity in 2005.   For shorter maturities, yields range from 4.75 percent in 1987 to 6.50 percent in 1991, 7.75 percent in 1996 and 8.12 percent in 2000. In addition, a 7 percent bond due in 2006 is offered at a price of 89 1/4, to yield 8.095 percent.   The bonds, backed by the full faith and credit of Washington, D.C., are rated Baa by Moody's and A by S.& P.

headline: Revere Copper Gets New Offer
abstract: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. said that it had received a $20-a-share acquisition proposal, worth $174 million, from a New York investment management firm. Revere, which makes aluminum and brass products, was formed in 1928 by the consolidation of six companies, one of them founded in 1801 by Paul Revere.

headline: SHULTZ DENOUNCES APARTHEID, SAYING: 'IT MUST GO SOON'
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that ''Western interests - moral, strategic, economic and political - will suffer'' if apartheid in South Africa is not soon ended peacefully.   ''Apartheid is wrong,'' he said. ''It robs the blacks of South Africa of their fundamental human rights. It drains the country of its human potential, and it threatens the security and economic prospects of an entire subcontinent.

headline: Bomb Kills 2 on Teheran Bus
abstract: A small bomb exploded under the front seat of a Teheran double-decker bus today, killing the driver and the conductor, the national press agency Irna reported. The agency described the explosion as the work of the Mujahedeen Khalq, a Paris-based opposition group.

headline: Continued Cuts At British Rail
abstract: Britain's state-run railway company, British Rail, said it could cut as many as 5,000 mechanics' jobs in the next three years as part of a restructuring program. It said this was in addition to cutting 2,650 mechanics' jobs, a move planned for this period.   The National Union of Railwaymen said the cuts were the most savage upheaval in railway workshops since the 1960's, and rejected British Rail's argument that the cuts were the result of a reduced need for maintenance on modern rolling stock.

headline: SHELL OFF 6.8%
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits increased 29.5 percent over those of a year ago.   The Sun Company, another large oil company, reported that earnings rose 14.9 percent. However, the Shell Oil Company, the nation's seventh-largest oil concern, said that its quarterly profits slumped by 6.8 percent.   Oil analysts said that the variance in the three earnings reports reflected the difference in the way the precipitous decline in crude oil prices during the first quarter affected different kinds of oil companies.

headline: SENATE PUTS BUDGET EFFORT AHEAD OF TAX REVISION
abstract: The Senate voted today, 72 to 24, to delay voting on a tax bill until President Reagan and Congress have agreed on a budget for the next fiscal year.   The vote was meant both as a prod to the White House to start negotiating on the 1987 budget and as an expression by some Senators that there should be no tax legislation at all this year.   Earlier, in a decision of primary importance to business, the Senate Finance Committee approved the main elements of a new system of depreciating the cost of capital goods such as equipment and machinery. The proposed system, which faces further debate by the full Senate and which is much more generous than depreciation rules approved by the House of Representatives last year, would affect the taxes paid by most large businesses in America.

headline: CONSUMERS POWER
abstract: The Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., said today, as expected, that it would convert its idled Midland nuclear plant to a natural gas-fired facility by 1990 if it could secure approval of the Michigan Public Service Commission and Federal officials. The conversion would cost an additional $500 million when complete. Work on the troubled Midland plant was suspended in July 1984 when the company was unable to finance completion of the project after investing more than $4 billion.

headline: 15 Blacks Die in Unrest Across South Africa
abstract: Fifteen more blacks were reported today to have been killed in political turmoil sweeping South Africa, amid growing signs that the Government will take tough new steps to crack down on the unrest.   The pro-Government newspaper Die Burger said the Government was set to make key decisions in the next few days on how to handle June 16, the anniversary of widespread protests that broke out in 1976.

headline: Jewish Body Releases Waldheim Document
abstract: The World Jewish Congress yesterday produced a copy of the United Nations War Crimes Commission document that accused Kurt Waldheim of being a war criminal who should stand trial for murder and putting hostages to death.   The secret file, made public at a news conference, said the independent United Nations body considered that there was ''sufficient evidence to justify'' Mr. Waldheim's prosecution at the end of World War II on those charges.

headline: Trade Plan Wins in Panel
abstract: Trade legislation intended to open overseas markets to the American telecommunications industry cleared a committee hurdle today. The 33-to-2 vote in the House Ways and Means Committee was seen as a rebuff to the Reagan Administration.

headline: Economic Scene; Austrian Seeks A New Balance
abstract: AUSTRIA's new Chancellor, Franz Vranitzky, the 48-year-old former Finance Minister in the Socialist Government, intends to reshape his nation's economic policy in response to the election to the presidency of Kurt Waldheim, the candidate of the conservative People's Party.   Mr. Vranitzky, once a star basketball player on the Austrian national team, described himself in an interview here as an admirer of the approach to taxation advocated by Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, himself once an outstanding forward on the New York Knicks basketball team.   Mr. Vranitzky said Austrian corporate tax rates should be cut and exemptions eliminated; he means to start that process in the year ahead. But he said it would take longer to bring down individual income tax rates because of the big budget deficit, which now amounts to 4.7 percent of gross national product - about the same ratio as the United States budget deficit to G.N.P. The Austrian Chancellor has a plan for bringing the deficit down to 2.8 percent over the next five years by across-the-board cuts in Government spending.

headline: Consumer Borrowing Up Sharply
abstract: Americans increased their short-term installment debt at a 9.1 percent annual rate in April, up from a revised 6.8 percent rate in March but down from the 11.8 percent credit growth rate in the first quarter of 1986, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   Consumer installment credit outstanding at the end of April increased by a seasonally adjusted $4.15 billion from March, to $555.09 billion, after a revised $3.09 billion gain in March, the Fed said.

headline: Market Place; Oil Industry's Brighter Side
abstract: AT a time when depressed industry conditions have forced some energy-related companies to cut or even reduce dividend payments, the refining and marketing part of the oil business has emerged as a shining star. In past years, these so-called downstream operations typically were far less important than the ''upstream,'' or production side, as profit centers.   ''Refining and marketing is now the driving force behind many oil companies,'' Eugene L. Nowak, senior energy analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds, said Friday. ''It is the one area of the business showing continued strength and improvement.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 19, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The Federal Reserve's main lending rate was cut half a point, to 6 1/2 percent, the lowest level in nearly eight years. The widely expected action followed a similar move earlier this week by the Bank of France, which said it was the first step in a round of internationally coordinated interest rate reductions by the major industrial countries. The Bank of Japan announced that it would cut its lending rate to 3 1/2 percent from 4 percent on Monday.  [ Page 1. ]    Further votes on a tax-revision bill were postponed by the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Senator Bob Packwood said he feared that continuing to vote on separate provisions ran the risk of killing the bill. He did say that he thought a bill could be worked out in private negotiations.  [ 1. ]

headline: Taiwan Proposes Date For Talks on Jet
abstract: Officials of Taiwan's national airline proposed today that talks begin on Monday with China over the return of a Taiwanese Boeing 747 cargo jet and crew flown to Canton by a defector.

headline: Court Backs Baldwin Plan
abstract: The Indiana Rehabilitation Court has approved the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's plan to guarantee the benefits and increase the interest rate on some $1.3 billion of annuities issued by three Indiana insurance subsidiaries of the Baldwin-United Corporation.   The plan was chosen Friday over one offered by Kaufman & Broad Inc. of Los Angeles.

headline: MEXICO'S LOSS OF ASSETS IMPERIlS DEBT PLAN... AS ITS GOVERNMENT BUYS BACK SOME LOANS
abstract: When the Senate Foreign Relations Committee takes up the issue of Mexico's economic situation on Tuesday, a major focus is expected to be the huge amount of funds that have left the country.   Many bankers and American officials say that Mexico's ability to pay its $98 billion debt and receive new loans is threatened unless it can recover some of the more than $50 billion in holdings that Mexicans are estimated to have transferred abroad.   ''Obviously they can't service the debt, the assets are abroad,'' said Rimmer de Vries, senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. He estimated that Mexicans have transferred a minimum of $50 billion out of their country in the last decade and that this capital flight has become both a ''symptom and a source'' of Mexico's debt problem.

headline: Bonn Denies Dollar Pact
abstract: West Germany has made no formal agreement with Japan to intervene jointly on currency markets to support the value of the dollar, a spokesman for the Finance Ministry said today. He denied reports in the German and Japanese press that such an accord had been struck.

headline: A POLISH RIDDLE: HIT-AND-RUN THRUSTS
abstract: For three days, an official in the Interior Ministry's press office has been asked to provide details of a statement this week by a Deputy Minister, Gen. Wladyslaw Pozoga, that Polish emigres are being trained as terrorists in New Jersey.   The press official was asked to say where in New Jersey this training was going on. Today he telephoned a foreign correspondent and said he could not provide the information because the case was under investigation.   When asked, ''What case and what investigation?'' he said he was not empowered to tell.   This pattern of dramatic disclosure followed by hedging has emerged here as the Polish Communist Party prepares to hold a convention this weekend, the first since the rise of the Solidarity movement in 1980.

headline: LAWMAKERS PRESS STATE DEPT. FUND CUTS
abstract: Congressional leaders from both parties brushed aside criticism from the Reagan Administration today and said they would push ahead with deep cuts in budget requests for both foreign aid and embassy security programs.   They said that the criticism was particularly unwelcome, and unfair, because President Reagan has refused to consider any revenue increases to help reduce the budget deficit and to finance Government programs.   Representative William H. Gray 3d, the Pennsylvania Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said he had an angry, 15-minute conversation last week with Secretary of State George P. Shultz on budget matters while the Secretary was traveling in Asia. According to Mr. Gray, he told Mr. Shultz: ''You want more money, you tell your President to bring it by.''

headline: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST UP 5.6%, TO RECORD LEVEL
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 18.4 million shares, or 5.6 percent, in the month ended June 13, to a record 349.8 million shares. The previous high of 331.4 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 253 million shares.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange fell 2.4 million shares, to 30.6 million shares. The record of 33 million shares was set last month.   A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: Advertising; 'Register' Book As Ad Medium
abstract: There is a preoccupation among creators of advertising media about reaching the swells, the upscale, the affluent, the possessors of moneybags.   Well, just guess who is going to get you into the homes of a select group of all of the above.

headline: MID-MAY CAR SALES EDGED DOWN 2.4%
abstract: Sales of new domestically built automobiles edged downward by 2.4 percent in the May 11-20 selling period from the corresponding period last year, the major auto makers reported today.   However, sales were very strong in the comparable 1985 period. In addition, the latest 10-day results, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, indicate a strong annual selling rate of 8.6 million units, above what most analysts have been predicting for domestic sales this year.

headline: TOUR BOOKINGS TO CARIBBEAN RISE ALONG WITH AMERICANS' FEAR OF EUROPE
abstract: Richard Steck is an executive for the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, which operates out of the sprawling port here on sparkling Biscayne Bay.   ''Until the beginning of this week we thought there was probably some increase in business that could be attributed to nervousness about what was going on in Europe and the Middle East,'' Mr. Steck said.   Now, he said, after the United States bombed Libya on Monday and terrorists responded with a spate of attacks in Europe and the Middle East, ''our phones have really been ringing.''   On Tuesday, the day after the United States air strikes, he said, ''we had 200 more calls than normal.''

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The Deficit Looms Larger - Back in February, the Office of Management and Budget estimated the 1986 deficit at roughly $202 billion. The Congressional Budget Office put the figure at $208 billion. But Gert Von Der Linde, economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, says it will be higher. Current patterns of revenue-gathering and spending, he says, suggest a deficit of $222.6 billion for fiscal 1986, which ends on Oct. 1.   Nearly all sources of Government revenues are behind expectations, says Mr. Von Der Linde. The outlook for revenues from taxes is dimming, especially if wages grow slowly and corporate profits fall. The outlook has worsened recently, he says, as tax uncertainties - including the possibility of a lower marginal tax rate in 1987 - encourage individuals and businesses to defer income until next year.

headline: TOKYO POLICE SET TO DEFEND SUMMIT
abstract: Across a wind-skimmed courtyard the other day, police officers fought police officers near the front steps of a baroque state guesthouse modeled after the Palace of Versailles.   The police, 1,100 men and women plus two attack dogs, took turns assaulting one another and defending themselves, their weapons of choice alternating among bare hands, rubber knives and toy guns. Several officers, posing as visiting heads of state, subjected themselves to mock assassination attempts, ducking for safety behind human shields as shots rang out.   The backdrop of the wedding-cake guesthouse, called the Geihinkan in Japanese, gave the exercise a faint backlot air. But the police could not have been more deadly serious.

headline: Climber Killed in Swiss Alps
abstract: A Belgian was killed and two Frenchmen were seriously injured when seven climbers fell 650 feet on the Grand Combin mountain in southwest Switzerland today, the police said. The climbers were roped together in two separate groups and were just beneath the peak of the 13,000-foot-high Grand Combin when one slipped. He pulled his group with him and they crashed into the climbers below them.

headline: Mexicans Seek Japanese Loan
abstract: The Mexican Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, has started a four-day trip to Japan for talks expected to center on debt, oil and Japanese investment, the official Notimex news agency said today. Angel Gurria, Mexico's director of public credit and chief debt negotiator, is accompanying him.

headline: New Toyota Plant
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation held a ground-breaking ceremony for a new assembly plant here.

headline: ALLIED DIPLOMATS DEFY EAST GERMAN CONTROLS
abstract: Diplomats from the United States, Britain and France defied an East German demand today that they show their passports while crossing from East to West Berlin or back again. But other diplomats complied with the measure, which the West has denounced as an attack on Berlin's delicate postwar status.   The American mission in West Berlin scheduled a meeting Wednesday with a representative from the Soviet Embassy in East Berlin to discuss the looming test of wills over the East German attempt to alter obscure - but symbolically important - diplomatic practice in the city.   Western diplomats said they had little doubt that Moscow had assented to the latest East German move.

headline: TAX BREAK FOR PHILLIPS KEPT IN BILL
abstract: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to keep a special tax exemption for one oil company in the tax-revision bill that seems almost certain to be passed this week.   The measure would exempt the Phillips Petroleum Company from paying an excise tax on money it plans to withdraw from the company pension plan. Phillips would use the money to help pay debts accumulated in fighting off hostile takeover bids in 1984 and 1985.   The Senate voted, 74 to 13, to defeat an amendment offered by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, that would have eliminated the special rule for Phillips. The exception, if it becomes law, would save Phillips $106 million in taxes over the next five years, according to staff experts.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN CAMPING; CAMPGROUNDS THAT DOUBLE AS CLUBS
abstract: BRIAN and Lynne Marriott first stayed at campgrounds in 1983, when they drove to Florida from their home in York, Pa. They were not impressed. Rowdy behavior by other campers interrupted their sleep, and running water and a coin-operated laundry were often the extent of amenities. ''The price of a night's stay was no real indication of quality,'' said Mr. Marriott, an engineer in his early 40's.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: A Trade Deficit Dip -The nation's trade deficit remains large, despite the weaker dollar. But Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., says that before the year is over, it will narrow enough to brighten the outlook for economic growth.   ''Last year, the trade deficit cost the economy about two percentage points of real growth,'' he said. This year, an improvement in exports and ''a better picture for imports by Labor Day'' should ultimately contribute about one percentage point to his estimate of 3.5 percent real growth in gross national product from the fourth quarter of 1985 to this year's fourth quarter. That would be up from 2.1 percent last year. Mr. Sinai's estimate for the 1986 trade deficit is $139.9 billion, down from $148.5 billion in 1985.

headline: SECURITY AGENCY SCANDAL SPLITTING ISRAEL'S CABINET
abstract: A new showdown appears to be shaping up between the Labor Party and the Likud bloc, this time over the scandal involving Shin Beth, the domestic intelligence agency.   The Labor Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, has found himself facing rising demands within his party that the Cabinet order a commission of inquiry to find out to what extent political figures were involved in the Shin Beth affair. Four members of the agency have been given immunity in the case, which involves the killings of two Palestinian bus hijackers in 1984.   The Likud leader, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, opposes any further inquiry in the case, saying President Chaim Herzog's decision to to grant immunity to the head of Shin Beth and three of his deputies brings the matter to a close.

headline: Leader of Strike at Base Is Slain in Philippines
abstract: Gunmen today shot to death the Filipino leader of a recent strike at a United States air base.   The union leader, Remegio Simbillo, 44 years old, was shot in the back and head after the assailants forced his car to stop near his home.   Mr. Simbillo had reported receiving death threats shortly after settlement of a strike that kept Filipino employees at Clark Air Base and nearby Subic Naval Base off the job for 11 days.

headline: DIGITAL PROFITS UP 85.7% AS NEW PRODUCTS EXCEL
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation, benefiting from its revamped computer line, said yesterday that earnings in its third fiscal quarter soared 85.7 percent on a 14.2 percent increase in revenues. Digital's earnings were higher than analysts had expected and are exceptional when compared with the flat or lower earnings that many of its competitors have been or are expected to report.   Two of those competitors posted widely different results yesterday. Profits at the Burroughs Corporation dropped 65.7 percent in the latest quarter, while Wang Laboratories reported an increase of 25.9 percent.

headline: SEOUL STUDENTS AND POLICE CLASH
abstract: Students and policemen clashed with gasoline bombs, stones and tear gas on at least four Seoul campuses today in an intensification of violence three days before the anniversary of a 1980 protest against martial law.   At Yonsei University near downtown, about 500 students were chanting ''Down with imperialism!'' and other anti-Government slogans when 500 riot police entered the campus.

headline: BankAmerica's Dividend View
abstract: Officials of the BankAmerica Corporation said today that the troubled banking company would have to see sustained strong earnings before reinstituting its stock dividend, which was eliminated in January.   At a heavily attended annual shareholders meeting here, officials of the bank declined to predict when the dividend would be restored.

headline: WALL ST. BUYS INTO THE ACTION
abstract: Wall Street firms have raked in hundreds of millions of dollars as advisers in takeovers in recent years, and some have even dabbled in corporate buyouts themselves.   Now, however, lured by the prospect of huge returns, they are pouring more and more of their own capital into buying companies. Typically, they put up a small amount of money - about 10 percent - and borrow the rest, in a transaction known as a leveraged buyout.   These are some of the more active players in the leveraged buyout field:    * Morgan Stanley & Company, which has raised $476 million, from its own capital and other investors, to finance buyouts, and has already completed nine as a participant. The firm aims to participate in as many as 30 investments over the next 30 months, said Donald Brennan, head of Morgan's leveraged buyout unit.

headline: 9 1/2% Ralston Issue
abstract: A $300 million issue of Ralston Purina Company 9 1/2 percent debentures due in 2016 was offered yesterday at a price of 97.60 to yield 9.75 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Company. The debentures, which are not refundable for 10 years, are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P.

headline: BEING A BLACK BOBBY MEANS HEARING 'I'M SORRY'
abstract: Sgt. Andrew Simons, a London police officer with nearly 10 years' experience, never wears his uniform when he is traveling to or from work. About 95 percent of black policemen here, he estimates, feel the same inhibition.   Riding in uniform on the subway or a public bus, he would expect to be accosted by hostile questioners wanting to know what a black thought he was doing in a police uniform. ''White people never approach you,'' he said over coffee in the canteen of the station house on Saville Row, where he is assigned to a squad supposed to keep prostitutes out of the center of London.   ''It's young black males in the 15-to-25 age group. You get a few standing around and you start thinking about a punch-up any minute,'' he said.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS NAME 4 LEADERS TO HOLD TALKS WITH GOVERNMENT
abstract: The Salvadoran leftist guerrilla movement formally accepted an offer today to reopen peace talks with the Government and said its most senior commanders would attend the meeting.   In an official communique, the rebel Democratic Revolutionary Front and Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front said that they would send a four-member delegation to the talks and that they wanted the meeting to be held in San Salvador, the capital.   The rebels said they would be represented by their two top military commanders, Joaquin Villalobos and Leonel Gonzalez, as well as by the two leading civilian politicians in the rebel alliance, Guillermo Manuel Ungo and Ruben Zamora.

headline: EXPORT-CONTROL LIST DEBATED
abstract: The House of Representatives, prodded by frustrated exporters, is about to take a knife to the ever-growing list of sensitive products that need a special Government license before they can be shipped abroad.   This list of more than one million products has ''definitely grown in the last 10 years,'' said the man in charge of enforcing export controls, Paul Freedenberg, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for trade administration.   Covered by 450 pages of Federal regulations, the controls affect sales of everything from the most sophisticated semiconductors to chemicals used in making ice cream.   So wide is their swath that it is now estimated that up to 30 percent of exports of manufactured goods cannot leave the United States without a Government license.

headline: Extension Vote On Bank Rules
abstract: The House voted today to extend for 90 days the authority of Federal regulators to merge a failed bank with at least $500 million in assets with a healthy bank in another state.   The bill, approved by voice vote, also would continue authority that lets the Federal Home Loan Bank Board inject capital in the form of i.o.u.'s into troubled thrift units to avoid having to close them.

headline: G.E. Is Marketing $500 Million Notes
abstract: The General Electric Company is offering $500 million of 7 1/8 percent notes at 99.80 to yield 7.20 percent to maturity in three years through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   The notes, rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P., are not callable. They yield about 17-hundredths percentage point more than three-year Treasury securities.

headline: REAGAN'S BOND PLAN IS REBUFFED
abstract: The Senate Finance Committee today rejected President Reagan's proposal to limit the kinds of tax-exempt bonds that states and municipalities can issue. Instead, it voted for an expansion of bonding authority.   The decision was the latest in what has become the committee's daily routine of approving, in the name of tax reform, measures that would cost the Government revenue.   Later, the panel decided to tighten somewhat the ability of American multinational corporations to reduce their taxes by claiming credits against the taxes they paid to foreign governments. The rules adopted by the committee, however, were not nearly so strict as those proposed by Mr. Reagan and would also be much more generous than rules approved by the House of Representatives last December in its tax-revision bill.

headline: Ammirati Gets Cruise Account
abstract: The Norwegian Caribbean Lines, looking for a proper berth for its $10 million to $15 million advertising account, has chosen the facilities at Ammirati & Puris (which also handles advertising for BMW).

headline: Computers By Tandon
abstract: The Tandon Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives that reported a $135 million loss last year, said it would seek a way out of its difficulties by selling its own brand of personal computers in the United States before the year is out. The company already makes computers for sale by other companies.

headline: People
abstract: * Brian Meredith has been named executive vice president/creative director for the Earle Palmer Brown Co., Philadelphia.    * Dr. Kenneth A. March is returning to Sieber & McIntyre, Chicago, as an executive vice president.

headline: Advertising; B.B.D.O. Gets Apple Computer
abstract: BATTEN, BARTON, DURSTINE & OSBORN has won the shootout with Chiat/Day for the domestic business of Apple Computer, reported to bill $50 million.   So ends a two-and-a-half-month confrontation in which the strategic thinking and actual advertising of both agencies on an assigned project were evaluated by the agency.   In both areas, said Bruce Mowery, advertising and sales promotion manager, B.B.D.O. ''seems to be most appropriate for the direction we will be taking in the future.

headline: The U.N. Today: June 11, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: COMPUTER CHIP INDEX DECLINES
abstract: A closely watched indicator of the health of the semiconductor industry declined in May for the first time in nine months, providing some of the first statistical evidence that the recovery in the computer-chip business has stalled.   The index, known as the book-to-bill ratio, declined to 1.10 for the three months ended in May, compared with a revised figure of 1.17 for the three months ended in April, according to Michael J. Stark, semiconductor industry analyst with Robertson, Colman & Stephens in San Francisco. Previously the index, which represents the ratio of incoming orders to outgoing shipments, had climbed for eight consecutive months.

headline: Mellon Backed On Thrift Unit
abstract: Legislation was signed today to allow the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh to buy a bankrupt Maryland thrift institution and begin commercial banking operations in Maryland.   ''This is just one more hurdle we've jumped over for the purchase of Community,'' Gov.

headline: PRICE GOAL REVISED FOR G.M.'S SATURN
abstract: Officials of the General Motors Corporation confirmed today that the upcoming Saturn line of cars would not attempt to compete with the cheapest imports.   Instead, Saturn's president, Richard G. LeFauve, said the cars would emulate the Japanese practice of offering small cars with a relatively high level of standard equipment -and higher price tags.   ''We're going to give people more car for the price,'' he said. Nevertheless, he said the Saturn cars would be ''on the low end of the price scale.''

headline: 15-Second ABC Ads
abstract: The ABC-TV Network announced yesterday that it will take free-standing 15-second commercials starting next September.

headline: SHARP SHIFT IN TAX POLICY
abstract: The overhaul of the nation's tax laws now before Congress marks a reversal of decades of growing Government and special-interest influence over how people and businesses use their money.
