The tax law changes, in particular those that the Senate Finance Committee adopted unanimously last week and that President Reagan has endorsed, mean that the tax system would play less of a role in shaping society and its economic foundations.   This is in part because the changes would diminish the tax code's incentives to steer income to certain activities, and in part because it would let individuals keep more of their income, which they could then feed into the economy as they wished.   Just about all economists maintain that this would produce a sounder and healthier economy and, eventually, higher wages and lower unemployment. It leaves open the questions about prospects for the individuals, charitable organizations and businesses that the tax system helps protect and that an efficient economy tends to overlook.

headline: Jersey Certificates Total $144 Million
abstract: New Jersey is offering $144 million of certificates of participation through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

headline: PANHANDLE STOCK JUMPS ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
abstract: Shares in the Panhandle Eastern Corporation rose sharply yesterday amid rumors that Wagner & Brown, independent Texas oil operators and close associates of T. Boone Pickens, might attempt to take over the big natural gas pipeline company.   At present market prices, Panhandle's stock is already worth nearly $2 billion.   Panhandle owns the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, which holds a major stake in the rich Hugoton gas field of southwestern Kansas. The Hugoton field, which extends into Texas and Oklahoma, is the biggest natural gas field in the country, with reserves of some 10 trillion cubic feet.

headline: ATHENS AIRPORT SPINS A HIGH-TECH SECURITY WEB
abstract: From the cafe deck of Hellenikon Airport, Greece's top security official was pointing out some of the Government's latest antiterrorism measures when a visitor noticed that the roof, a public area, freely overlooked a restricted zone. Could not some weapon or other contraband be dropped to a confederate below? the guest asked.   The official, Kostas D. Tsimas, considered the question for a moment, then with a snap of his fingers summoned a cluster of hovering assistants. ''Put in a glass or a grate here,'' he ordered. ''Anything could be dropped down to someone below.''

headline: 'STAR WARS' PACT DISCLOSURE UPSETS BONN
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government has been embarrassed by the disclosure to the press of a secret accord governing West Germany's industrial role in the Reagan Administration's research program on antimissile defenses.   On Friday, the Cologne tabloid Express published the text of the accord, which was signed in Washington on March 27 by West Germany's Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. The newspaper and an energy newsletter also plan to publish copies of accompanying letters to the agreements on research on the program commonly known as ''Star Wars.''   As with a similar memorandum of understanding reached with Britain in December, the Pentagon had requested that the text be kept secret. Well-placed American officials said this was because the Pentagon will be negotiating such understandings with several countries and did not want to weaken its bargaining leverage by disclosures of what had been conceded to other countries.

headline: U.S. to Give Information To Mexico on Trafficking
abstract: The United States Customs Commissioner has agreed to give Mexican authorities intelligence information about the purported involvement of Mexican police officers and public officials in narcotics trafficking, delegates to a conference of legislators from the two countries were told here today.

headline: ITT IS NEGOTIATING TO SELL FRENCH ITS TELECOMMUNITATIONS BUSINESS
abstract: The ITT Corporation is negotiating to sell the cornerstone of its business, its telecommunications operations, to Compagnie Generale d'Electricite of France for more than $2 billion, according to sources on Wall Street. The sale would be ITT's most dramatic reshaping in its 66-year-old history.   The sources said that the two companies had expected the French Government, which owns C.G.E., to approve the sale yesterday but that the approval was delayed for undetermined reasons. ''They're close,'' one source said, commenting on the progress of the talks.

headline: CASUALTIES IN SOVIET COULD KEEP RISING, U.S. EXPERTS ASSERT
abstract: American experts said yesterday that deaths and injuries from the reactor accident in the Soviet Union may continue to mount for several weeks in the vicinity of the disaster if severe radiation has been released.   These experts on health and radiation said there appeared to be no danger for the Western Hemisphere and probably little in the Scandinavian countries, on the basis of what has been reported thus far.   When the Soviet Union announced that two people had been killed in the accident at the Chernobyl power plant in the Ukraine, there was no indication if the cause of death was radiation, fire or other nonnuclear effects.   There was an unconfirmed report from the area that many more may have died. If that report is confirmed, said Dr. Kenneth Mossman of Georgetown University Medical School, it would suggest extremely high levels of gamma radiation.

headline: Telecom to Sell Commercial Paper
abstract: British Telecom Inc. plans to offer up to $500 million of commercial paper in the American market through Goldman, Sachs & Company.   The commercial paper, which carries the highest ratings of Prime-1 by Moody's and A-1+ by S.&P., is British Telecom's second major financing in the American market. In late 1984, the British Government disposed of slightly more than half of its holdings in the communications company, with about $360 million of the $4.7 billion stock financing being sold in North America.

headline: South Asians Reach Accord to Fight Terror
abstract: Officials from seven South Asian countries ended a three-day meeting here today by agreeing to cooperate more closely to combat terrorism in the region.

headline: Book Assails Reaganomics
abstract: David Stockman, the former White House budget director who left his post last summer to join Salomon Brothers, the investment bankers, called President Reagan a ''terminal optimist'' in his new book ''The Triumph of Politics,'' U.S. News & World Report said in its April 14 issue.   In the 430-page book, to be published April 23 by Harper & Row, Mr. Stockman said of President Reagan, ''There was not a thing you could tell him to shake his absolute faith that these massive deficits were simply going to vanish,'' the magazine reported.

headline: REAL POLISH JOKES THRIVE ON REAL POLISH SOCIALISM
abstract: Coal production may fluctuate and export earnings may falter, but the output of real Polish jokes remains at a high level.   Real Polish jokes are not the insulting ethnic ones that had a vogue in the United States. Instead, they are ironic and pithy commentaries on life under ''real'' socialism, the prevailing system.   No one truly knows where the jokes come from. They seem to arise from some deep subterranean spring of consciousness, which spurts to the surface and then races through Poland's conspiratorial culture.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Artkraft Strauss Sign Corp., which makes outdoor advertising displays, announced the retirement of Eugene Kornberg, general manager.    * California Biotechnology Inc., Mountain View, Calif., a genetic engineering research concern, announced the appointments of John Shine as president and chief scientific officer and Myron A. Wick 3d as chief operating officer.

headline: Sale of Capitol Life
abstract: Integrated Resources Inc., which last week agreed to buy the 666 Building on Fifth Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, said that it would buy the Capitol Life Insurance Company from the Providence Capitol Corporation for $65 million. Integrated Resources said that with this acquisition, its life insurance companies would have about $17.3 billion worth of insurance in force.

headline: Cavalcade Offers To Acquire Tesoro
abstract: The Cavalcade Asset Corporation, a closely held concern with interests in oil, said yesterday that it was offering to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation for cash and securities estimated by analysts to be worth $20 to $25 a share, or between about $263 million and about $329 million.   Cavalcade said that for each share, Tesoro stockholders would receive $5 in cash; a unit of a master limited partnership formed to own Tesoro's oil refining, marketing and transportation division, and notes issued by the partnership valued at $5.

headline: Saudi Trading Gain by U.S.
abstract: Japan is still Saudi Arabia's top trading partner, with the United States closing the gap, according to 1985 import statistics issued today by the Saudi Ministry of Finance.

headline: INDUSTRIES SEE BOTH WINNERS AND LOSERS IF BILL BECOMES LAW; INTEREST DEDUCTION LIMIT DOESN'T ALARM LENDERS
abstract: While business in general and many consumer groups say they are satisfied with the sweeping tax plan approved this week by the Senate Finance Committee, a number of trade and industry groups are starting to voice alarm over some of the plan's provisions.   Numerous tax deductions and incentives would be abolished or dramatically restricted by the plan, removing in some cases special protections that have benefited the groups for years.   The restaurant industry, for example, is worried that the proposed reduction of the deductibility of business meals and entertaining will hurt their business. And real estate syndicators foresee a sharp decline in investments if restrictions on tax benefits from paper losses go into effect. That, they say, could affect the nation's housing stock.

headline: O'NEILL REFUSES REAGAN REQUEST FOR HOUSE FLOOR
abstract: President Reagan asked today to address the House of Representatives on Tuesday to make a final appeal for $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, and the Speaker of the House turned him down.   As partisan maneuvering over the aid request intensified, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said that Mr. Reagan was welcome to address a joint session of Congress, but that ''having the President appear before only one house to lobby for a legislative proposal would be unprecedented.''   A senior White House official said the President's advisers were ''flabbergasted'' by the refusal. Vote Scheduled for Wednesday    The House is scheduled to vote Wednesday on the latest version of an Administration plan to channel $70 million in military assistance and $30 million in other aid to the forces, known as the contras, which are seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

headline: Bond Prices Slip in 'Thin' Day
abstract: Investment activity in the Treasury bond market subsided yesterday, discouraged by yields of less than 7 1/2 percent in some cases, and befuddled by wide intraday price fluctuations.   When trading stopped in New York, Treasury bond prices were lower by about 1 1/2 points, and the bellwether 9 1/4 percent issue due in 2016 was offered at 121 2/32, down 1 13/32, to yield 7.48 percent. The benchmark issue was as high as 122 3/4 early in the day, but that price could not be sustained in the face of substantial selling by investors and traders.   Besides the heavy selling overnight in Tokyo and London by Japanese accounts, securities dealers said domestic clients were also net sellers.

headline: '84 REACTOR SHUTDOWN CALLED WORST FRENCH NUCLEAR EVENT
abstract: Nuclear safety officials said today that a reactor shutdown at the Bugey power station in 1984 - which was cited in a satirical newspaper - was the most serious in France's extensive nuclear power program, but they insisted it was very far from a serious accident.   In an unrelated incident, the state-owned operator of the nuclear fuel retreatment plant at La Hague in northwestern France reported that five workers were irradiated in an accident at the plant Tuesday.   Francois Cogne, head of the Institute for Nuclear Safety and Protection, said the workers received about two or three times the safe annual dose when pipework being closed down was found to have a much higher radiation content than expected.

headline: BIG MILITARY HIGH-TECH SALE TO CHINA
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it planned to sell $550 million worth of aviation electronics to China.   The transaction, if not blocked by Congress, would be the largest sale of military equipment to Peking since diplomatic contacts were resumed by President Richard M. Nixon in 1972.   The sale would also mark another step in a slowly evolving military relationship between Washington and Peking begun by President Carter and cultivated by President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.   In the past, sales to China have been applauded by advocates of trade with China and those who see China as a counter to the Soviet Union. But they have been criticized by supporters of the Nationalist Government on Taiwan and by conservatives wary of the Communist Government in Peking.

headline: State Official Opens Wine, After 13 Years
abstract: After waiting 13 years, Attorney General Robert Abrams opened a bottle of wine yesterday.

headline: In Changes at U S West
abstract: Few executives encourage competition to the extent of giving up a company's monopoly position, but that is what Jack A. MacAllister has done since the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation led to the formation of U S West in 1982.   Mr. MacAllister, who is 58 and has been president and chief executive officer of the Denver-based telephone holding company since its inception, was named chairman on Friday. A new president was also named and other promotions were announced.

headline: LIBYA'S RAID DID NOT ESCAPE CRETE'S NOTICE
abstract: Missiles fired by Libya last week at American installations on the Italian island of Lampedusa may have missed their intended target, but they have made a strong impact on the minds of many people in Crete. The American bases on Crete are bigger and more important than those on Lampedusa, and, like the Italian island, they are only about 100 miles across the Mediterranean north of Libya.   ''The tension has reached us,'' said Deputy Mayor Kyriakos Skepertzis of Heraklion. And the Mayor of Canea, George Katzanevakis, added, ''It makes us realize that Crete is in the middle of all the areas of tension in the Mediterranean.''

headline: AT THE PALACE, A FEW TRIPPED OVER CHOPSTICKS
abstract: Lunch for the visiting leaders at the economic summit conference today was Japanese-style in an annex to the Akasaka Palace, where most of their meetings have been held. It required them, of course, to use chopsticks.

headline: Minstar to Sell Bowling Unit
abstract: Minstar Inc., controlled by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its AMF bowling operations to Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a private investment concern, for about $225 million. Minstar also said it would keep a stake in C.&B.   Minstar acquired AMF Inc. last year and said it would sell 13 subsidiaries accounting for 53 percent of AMF sales.

headline: ANXIETY IN POLAND
abstract: Here in Poland's second largest city, as well as in other areas of the country, anxieties over the fallout from the Ukrainian nuclear accident tended to overshadow the ritual tug of war between the Government and the opposition over rival May Day celebrations.   In a news conference in Warsaw, Zbigniew Jaworowski, director of the Radiation Control Institute, said radiation measurements were declining after having reached dangerous levels.

headline: MANILA CABINET CONSIDERS SCRAPPING ATOMIC PLANT
abstract: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino is considering halting construction of a $2.1 billion nuclear power plant and taking its American manufacturer to court to scrap the contract.   The contract for the 620-megawatt plant, which has been built at Napot Point on the Bataan Peninsula west of Manila, was signed with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in 1976. Since then, the cost has grown from $1.1 billion to $2.1 billion, and critics have asserted that the project is uneconomical and unsafe.   The project drew attention recently after reports that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had received the bulk of an $80 million payment by Westinghouse 10 years ago to Herminio T. Disini, a close associate who is married to a cousin of Mr. Marcos's wife, Imelda.

headline: Shultz Warns Asian Nations
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned Asian nations today that failure to open their markets wider to American goods would undermine the Reagan Administration's efforts to block protectionist legislation in Congress.   Often in impassioned terms, Mr. Shultz argued that Congress would grow increasingly insistent about curbing imports unless the Administration could show that trading partners are just as interested in fighting protectionism.

headline: HONDURAN SEES PROBLEM IF U.S. ENDS CONTRA AID
abstract: The President of Honduras said today that his country would face ''an extremely serious problem'' if Congress did not renew United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels fighting from Honduran bases.   In an appearance at the National Press Club during a four-day visit to Washington, President Jose Azcona Hoyo said, ''We believe that the contras should be fighting inside Nicaragua, and that they can do so only if they receive assistance.''   Speaking of the rebels' 15,000-member force in Honduras, Mr. Azcona said, ''We are not to blame for the existence of the contras, nor are we to blame for the large number of Nicaraguans who leave Nicaragua every day because they do not like the way of life being imposed upon them.''

headline: BATTLE INTENSIFIES IN BID FOR WALKER
abstract: The bidding for Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. intensified yesterday as the Reichmann family of Canada, operating through the Gulf Canada Corporation, offered to pay $27.40 a share, or $2.3 billion, for the 76 percent of the oil and liquor producer it does not already own or control.   As part of the deal, it offered $24.52 a share for all 13.6 million preferred shares. Neither offer is open to United States residents, but Americans have been trading in the stock through intermediaries.

headline: TAX PLAN COULD ALTER THE PENSION LANDSCAPE
abstract: Changes in the Federal tax system that have been proposed by the Senate Finance Committee would provide pension benefits to millions more American workers, according to some tax experts.   The changes would also increase the costs of pensions to companies that offer pension programs, they said. But executives at several large concerns asserted that they nevertheless supported the proposals.   For pension funds, the key change in the Finance Committee proposal is that the maximum ''vesting'' period - the length of time that a worker must be employed before being entitled to a pension - would be shortened from 10 to 5 years.

headline: China and Taiwan Have 2d Round of Talks
abstract: Officials of Taiwan and China held a second round of talks today to discuss the return of a cargo jet flown to China by a defecting pilot, but the chief Chinese delegate said they again failed to resolve their differences. Another negotiating session was scheduled for Monday.

headline: 3 BRITISH VICTIMS IN LEBANON
abstract: Alec Collett New York-based freelance journalist . . . Seized by gunmen south of Beirut on March 25, 1985, while on a writing assignment for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which works with Palestinian refugees . . . Resident of Tudor City on the East Side of Manhattan with his American wife, Elaine, and 12-year-old son, Karim . . . United Nations correspondent for The Associated Press from 1967 to 1972 . . . A British citizen, born in London . . . 64 years old and a diabetic . . . Elected honorary president of the United Nations Correspondents Association in December . . . Director of the United Nations Information Center in Ghana from 1979 to 1982 . . . Father of two sons from a previous marriage . . . Said in a videotape received from his kidnappers last May that he was ''alive and well, doing some writing and a little gardening.'' Leigh Douglas   Professor of political science on his second one-year assignment at the American University of Beirut . . . Resident of Beirut for eight years . . . 34-year-old native of Stalham, in Norfolk, England . . . Dined on March 28 with Philip Padfield and other members of the ''Daring Diners' Club,'' an informal group that dined after dark in dangerous Beirut neighborhoods as a way to keep up morale . . . Then went with him to Backstreet's, a pub in predominantly Moslem West Beirut . . . Last seen leaving the pub with Mr. Padfield shortly after midnight . . . Students at the university protested his disappearance with a one-day sit-in April 7. Philip Padfield   Resident of Beirut for 13 years . . . Director of the International Language Center, a private language school in West Beirut . . . 40 years old . . . Went to Beirut from Bideford, Devon, England . . . His and Mr. Douglas's disappearance prompted the British Ambassador, John Gray, to warn all Britons to leave West Beirut.

headline: Robins Asks Judge For Extension
abstract: The A. H. Robins Company has asked Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. to extend for three months the company's Monday deadline for filing a bankruptcy reorganization plan.

headline: PANEL LISTS 174 TAX-BILL EXCEPTIONS
abstract: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today released a list of 174 special exceptions contained in the tax-revision bill that benefit particular corporations or community projects.   The list, which still lacked many details, was released after some senators put pressure on the Oregon Republican to fully disclose the more than $5 billion in special favors contained in the bill.   Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, had complained that the identity of the beneficiaries of these special favors were masked in legislative language. A number of senators have been upset that they did not have the opportunity to obtain similar exceptions for corporations or projects in their states.

headline: Thai Aide Dismisses Accusations of Torture
abstract: In the first official response to accusations that Thai troops tortured Cambodian refugees in March, Prasong Soonsiri, the head of this country's National Security Council, said Friday that the charge may have been intended ''to defame Thailand.''   The official told Thai reporters that three Cambodians in question ''were not tortured, not even injured,'' a daily nespaper, The Nation, reported.   He dismissed the accusation of torture, which was made by Amnesty International and confirmed by several international aid organizations, and the charge that refugee officials had been denied access to the prisoners.

headline: Advertising; Y.&R. Joint Venture
abstract: Young & Rubicam, a leader in multinational joint venture activity, has now got involved in a joint venture with its joint venture.

headline: Offer for Kinney
abstract: Kinney System Inc., one of New York's leading parking lot operators, said that it had agreed to be acquired by the Cromwell Group Inc., a closely held concern that manages industrial companies.

headline: Londonderry Bomb Defused
abstract: Army explosives experts today defused a 200-pound bomb inside a hijacked truck that was parked in the center of Londonderry, the police said. It was the first bomb incident in Londonderry, a stronghold of resistance to British rule, since November, when a blast for which the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility damaged a shopping center.

headline: CONTRAS WON'T GET ANTIAIRCRAFT WEAPON
abstract: The United States has decided not to send the Stinger, its most advanced portable antiaircraft weapon, to the Nicaraguan rebels, Administration officials said today.   A senior Administration official said the rebels did not need the weapons. ''Too sophisticated for down there,'' he said. ''They're not needed. Nicaragua does not have the same type of air force that Angola and the Cubans have.''

headline: SEA-LAND OFFERED $28 A SHARE BY CSX
abstract: The Sea-Land Corporation, the container and shipping company that has been the unwilling target of Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, received a friendly takeover proposal yesterday valued at $655.2 million from the CSX Corporation, a leading transportation company.   Joseph F. Abely Jr., Sea-Land's chairman, termed the proposal ''most welcome'' and said it would be recommended to Sea-Land's board this week.

headline: U.S. SAID TO SEEK SOVIET TERROR AID
abstract: Senior Western diplomats said today that the United States had unsuccessfully sought Soviet help in an effort to prevent terrorist attacks in Europe by Libyans based in East Germany.   The diplomats reported that in one of the first such efforts by Washington to enlist Soviet support in fighting terrorism, American officials met with Soviet representatives in Washington, Moscow and East Berlin last month to seek help in dealing with terrorists believed to be operating out of the Libyan Embassy in East Berlin.   The diplomats said Moscow never responded to the requests.

headline: ULSTER'S BITTER POLICE: A BATTERING ON BOTH SIDES
abstract: Like their father and grandfather before them, the Gracey brothers are all members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, a police force that has been toughened and tempered in the flames of unremitting sectarian conflict. Like 90 percent of their fellow officers, they are Protestants.   Gary Gracey, who is 23 years old, has twice been blown off his feet by bomb explosions, which have left him with what may turn out to be a permanent hearing impairment. His brother Nigel, five years older, has been shot at four times by the underground Irish Republican Army. Ronnie, the eldest at 36, has not only been shot at but badly beaten on two occasions in pitched battles between the police and supporters of the nationalist cause in Roman Catholic ghettos.

headline: BIOLOGICS' HISTORIC PRODUCT
abstract: For years, it was widely expected that the first living, custom-designed, gene-altered product would come from Boston or San Francisco, the two main centers of research and spending by companies in biotechnology. So last January, when the Agriculture Department issued the historic first license for a genetically engineered product to a virtually unknown Nebraska animal health-care company called the Biologics Corporation, its executives were exuberant.   ''The big boys - Monsanto, Du Pont - the glamour boys - Cetus, Genentech, Calgene - we beat them all,'' Dr. Michael J. Bartkoski Jr., vice president of operations and head of the company's refurbished plant here, said earlier this month.   The euphoria of those heady days has faded, however. In April, the procedures that Biologics and the Agriculture Department followed to test and license Omnivac-PRV, Biologics' new swine vaccine, came under attack from scientists - who worry about the implications of releasing genetically engineered products into the environment - and under scrutiny by Congress and the National Institutes of Health.

headline: SOVIET PLAN AFFIRMS BIG NUCLEAR POWER ROLE
abstract: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov today affirmed Soviet plans to expand nuclear power production, although he said that the Chernobyl disaster had demonstrated the need for stricter reliability.   Presenting the five-year plan of 1986-90 for approval by the Supreme Soviet, the nominal parliament, Mr. Ryzhkov said that ''satisfying the need for electric power depends to a greater degree on the growth of atomic energy.''   Mr. Ryzhkov gave no indication that the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear station would alter the ambitious Soviet power development program, which lays heavy stress on nuclear power to offset waning supplies of easily accessible oil and coal. He mentioned Chernobyl only in reference to the need for stringent safety controls.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 5, 1986
abstract: Markets    Short-term interest rates rose sharply as comments by Paul A. Volcker about potential problems with inflation injected new anxiety into the already battered credit markets. The Fed chairman, at the International Monetary Conference in Boston, was quoted as saying that the nation's economy cannot always count on a huge decline in oil prices. Prices of long-term and intermediate bonds dropped about a point, as interest rates rose in response to Mr. Volcker's comments.  [ Page D1. ]  Yields on certificates of deposit rose slightly for the week, while yields slipped on bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds.  [ D21. ]    Stock prices fell moderately. Mr. Volcker's remarks on inflation encouraged profit taking in a weak trading session. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 7.14 points, to 1,863.29, led by a 2 3/4-point decline in I.B.M.'s shares, which closed at 150.  [ D8. ]

headline: Soviet Names Ex-Envoy
abstract: Yuli M. Vorontsov, the former Soviet Ambassador to France, has been named one of two First Deputy Foreign Ministers, replacing Georgi M. Korniyenko, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

headline: IN SURPRISING MOVE, SENATE VOTES TO KILL SPECIAL UNOCAL TAX BREAK
abstract: In a surprising challenge to special favors in the tax-revision bill, the Senate voted today to remove a tax break that would apply to only one oil company.   The special preference would have given the Unocal Corporation a $50 million tax break to help offset the debt it took on last year in successfully fighting a takeover by T. Boone Pickens.   It was the first element of the Finance Committee's bill to be rejected by the Senate. The vote was 60 to 33.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 1986
abstract: Companies    ITT may sell its telecommunications operations to Compagnie Generale d'Electricite of France for more than $2 billion, Wall Street sources said. A sale of its cornerstone business would leave ITT with service businesses, largely insurance and hotels. The deal would be the most drastic change in the 66-year history of ITT. Sources in France said the talks were at a ''very hot'' stage. ITT stock jumped $4 a share, to $49.375, on the Big Board.  [ Page A1. ]    Interfirst expects at least a $260 million loss in the second quarter and is eliminating indefinitely its common stock dividend, officials of the Dallas-based bank said. Some of the losses were related to loans to a former director.  [ D1. ]  BancTexas Group of Dallas has found a buyer but the deal is burdened by stringent conditions.  [ D3. ]

headline: Prices of Treasury Issues Fall
abstract: Prices for Government securities continued their slide yesterday, with interest rates higher on both long- and short-term Treasury issues.   Analysts attributed the price slump to a pervasive gloom in the credit markets about prospects for action by the Federal Reserve Board to ease interest rates and fears on the part of some traders that the Fed might even move to tighten monetary policy. They said the general pessimism was being aggravated by a pronounced lack of customer interest in the bond market despite the fall in prices, which might otherwise be expected to generate demand.   ''Right now the market is in a fear cycle where it interprets everything as bad news,'' said F. Ward McCarthy, senior money market economist for Merrill Lynch.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE AMERICAN CAPITAL MANAGEMENT & RESEARCH INC.

headline: Treasury Financing Takes a Break
abstract: Treasury financing is confined this week to the bill market, where today's regular auction of three-month and six-month issues will be followed by a one-year bill sale tomorrow.   Late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at a rate of 6.10 percent, while six-month bills were at 6.07 percent and the one-year issue was at 6.12 percent.   Elsewhere in the Treasury market, securities dealers will continue to distribute the unsold portions of last week's $27 billion of new notes and bonds. The new 7 1/4 percent bonds due 2016 were offered Friday at 98 22/32 to yield 7.36 percent, slightly higher in price from Thursday's auction average of about 98 18/32 to yield 7.37 percent. The new 7 3/8 percent notes due 1996 were offered at 99 11/32 to yield 7.47 percent, unchanged from the auction average. The 6 7/8 percent notes due 1989 were offered at 99 20/32 to yield 7.02 percent, down from about 99 3/4 to yield 6.97 percent at auction.

headline: Rosenfeld and Ally Get Health Care Accounts
abstract: The health care industry came though last week with new-product assignments for both Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey and Ally & Gargano/MCA Advertising.   For the Rosenfeld Raiders the font of new billings was the Thompson Medical Company, which this fall will bring out Ibuprin, an ibuprofen-based analgesic with a bigger introductory ad budget than any other product it has ever brought out.

headline: Europe Sees 3.7% Inflation
abstract: Annual inflation for countries in the European Community fell below 4 percent for the first time, despite a slight monthly increase in April, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today.   Eurostat said prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent from March to April, compared with a two-tenths of 1 percent rise from February to March.

headline: CHIRAC UNDER FIRE FROM SOME ALLIES
abstract: In the two months since he took office, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has moved slowly -too slowly, according to a mounting chorus of criticism among his conservative allies - to begin a a program stressing the free market and law and order.   Despite widespread expectations, Mr. Chirac has not concentrated on reversing the programs put into place by the Socialist Government that he and the conservatives defeated on March 16.   He has proposed the removal of some specific measures put into effect by the Socialists. One proposal, for example, would repeal a special tax on the very wealthy. And Parliamentary passage is expected this week on a Government proposal to permit the sale of some 65 state-owned enterprises to private hands. Denationalization is a major element of the conservatives' program.

headline: Agreement Is Reported On Security for Berlin
abstract: After several days of discussion, the Western powers responsible for West Berlin - Britain, France and the United States - were reported late tonight to have reached a compromise accord to increase the security of the city.   It would reportedly include tightened surveillance of the entry points to West Berlin.

headline: Italy Planning Inquiry Into Links With Libya
abstract: The Italian Defense Minister said today that he had asked for an inquiry into statements by a former Italian intelligence official that Italy, to protect its oil interests in Libya, had helped Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi consolidate his power.   The statements were made by Gen. Ambrogio Viviani, former chief of military intelligence.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: Wake County, N.C., is offering $104 million of general obligation public improvement bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.   The triple-A rated tax-exempt bonds are offered with yields ranging from 4.20 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.20 percent in 1991, 5.90 percent in 1996, 6.35 percent in 2001 and 6.50 percent in 2006.

headline: Croat Becomes Confused At War Crimes Trial
abstract: Andrija Artukovic, the 86-year-old former minister in Croatia's Nazi puppet Government, lapsed into disorientation at his war crimes trial today, saying he did not know where he was or what year it was.   He also said he had been tortured for seven years in an English prison by Milovan Djilas, the Yugoslav dissident writer.

headline: Victim of Berlin Blast Dies
abstract: An American soldier died today of wounds suffered in the bombing of a discotheque here April 5. An announcement by the United States Army's Berlin Command said the soldier, Staff Sgt. James E. Goins, a 26-year-old infantryman from Ellerbee, N.C., died at Steglitz Clinic. Another American soldier and a Turkish woman were killed in the bombing, in which about 230 other people were wounded.

headline: Vice Chairman Resigns At Merrill Lynch Unit
abstract: Samuel E. Hunter, vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the investment banking subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company, resigned his post yesterday after less than two months on the job, the parent company said.   Mr. Hunter's decision was provoked, sources close to the company said, by statements he made in early February, when he was named vice chairman. At the time, Mr. Hunter said his appointment was aimed at boosting merger and acquisition activities at Merrill Lynch, a statement that went far beyond the role that had been intended for him to fill.

headline: NORTHROP'S CRUCIAL BOMBER
abstract: Behind three layers of barbed-wire fence in this desert town north of Los Angeles, the finishing touches are being put on the assembly site of one of the most expensive programs in military history.   In a new tan and white building, 50 feet high and the length of several football fields, workers are expected soon to begin assembling the first of six prototypes of the secrecy-shrouded Stealth bomber. Eventually, if all goes well, at least 132 bombers will be produced here, at a probable cost of more than $50 billion.   That is a potential bonanza for the Northrop Corporation, the prime contractor, and for other major contractors such as the Boeing Company, the LTV Corporation and the General Electric Company. Northrop alone could be paid $30 billion or more, perhaps much more, for its role in the project.

headline: KODAK AND SONY IN 8-MM. VENTURES
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Sony Corporation of America yesterday announced plans to distribute motion pictures and other programs on 8-millimeter video cassettes, actions experts say will bolster the market for that product.   Kodak said it had signed an 18-month agreement with Embassy Home Entertainment of Los Angeles that would enable it to distribute a minimum of 46 film and music videos in the 8-millimeter format. Neither company would disclose financial terms of the agreement.

headline: Thrift Inquiry On Property
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America, the nation's second-largest thrift holding company, says some of its officers bought foreclosed real estate from the company at discount prices.   The chairman and chief executive of Financial Corporation, William Popejoy, declined to identify the officers he said had bought the property at ''less than adequate prices.''

headline: Yen Causing Slow Growth
abstract: Although Japan's economy is still expanding, it has slowed considerably because of the yen's rise in value against the dollar, the Government said today.   Its Economic Planning Agency said the index of leading indicators for February stood at 50, down from 66.7 in January.

headline: JAPAN FRETS ABOUT TOMORROW
abstract: Japan today seems to have it all - economic might, political stability, an increasingly affluent populace and companies moving into new markets around the world.   The question that preoccupies the Japanese, however, is: What could go wrong?   This is a nation obsessed with its own future, endlessly analyzing and anticipating what twists lie ahead. Government agencies churn out reports projecting the future course of the economy, and suggesting what steps Japan should take to adapt in time. Polls abound charting what people think may happen in the next decade or two.

headline: Fed Expected to Ease Policy
abstract: Weaker-than-expected employment statistics published Friday helped revive speculation in the credit markets that the Federal Reserve Board may ease monetary policy another notch and help reduce short-term interest rates.   On Friday, employment data for March were the catalyst for a sharp decline in short-term rates and a chorus of predictions that the Fed might cut the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institutions. By late Friday, rates on Treasury bills were below 6 1/4 percent, with the six-month issue bid at about 6.22 percent, down from 6.37 percent.   ''With the economy looking lackluster overall and the energy sector in the midst of a depression, a cut in the discount rate is all but assured,'' said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist at E. F. Hutton & Company.

headline: Freddie Mac
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent subordinated capital debentures due in 2016 at a price of 97.30, to yield 8.50 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The debentures, which are non-callable before maturity, yield about one percentage point more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

headline: Poll Says Most Think Nuclear Parity Exists
abstract: A majority of Americans now believe that the United States and the Soviet Union are ''about equal in nuclear strength,'' according to the Gallup Poll.   As recently as last October,only 40 percent of the public thought the two countries were equal in nuclear power, with 27 percent thinking the Soviet Union was ahead and 21 percent believing the United States had the advantage.

headline: WHAT SUITORS SAW IN ALAMITO
abstract: Until a few months ago, the Alamito Company was an obscure electricity wholesaler in Tucson, Ariz. But then a frenzied takeover battle suddenly turned it into one of the most sought-after utilities in the country.   Complete with lawsuits, ''lockup'' provisions and golden parachutes, the fight first pitted the top executives of the company against shareholders and then turned into a free-for-all that included numerous bids from four outside groups.   Last Friday, the feverish contest -13 offers were made in all - apparently came to an end when Alamito said it had accepted a bid from one of the groups, Osceola Energy Inc., for $165 a share in cash, or $376.2 million. As part of the deal, it was agreed that Alamito's executives - who had been accused by the shareholders and Osceola of trying to spirit the company away for a fraction of its value -would stay on. Why the Interest?  Why were so many bidders so interested in such a low-profile company?

headline: California Cooler Ads Go Macho
abstract: AT first glance, each of the five new spots for California Cooler might strike you as ''just another bouncy soft drink lifestyle commercial.'' But there is more to them than that.   A bit more macho, with a slight edge of raunchiness, they capture the ambiance of a seaside cafe jammed with off-duty lifeguards on a hot August night. You get the picture?

headline: U.N. IN AGREEMENT ON STEPS TO BRING AFRICAN RECOVERY
abstract: The General Assembly unanimously agreed tonight to commit itself to a ''spirit of genuine and equal partnership'' to revive Africa's devastated economies.   The five-year program, involving policy changes by African countries and increased international support, was spelled out in a final document after a week of negotiations at a special session of the Assembly.   After a draft was completed in an all-night session that ended early today, the document was formally adopted tonight by the General Assembly. Measures to Fight Food Crises    The document details a recovery plan that includes measures to deal with food emergencies, drought and the loss of fertile land to deserts; new resources to increase agricultural productivity; development of transportation and communication networks; improvements in domestic trade and finance, and ''radical changes'' in educational systems at all levels to develop programs that address the continent's needs.

headline: TALK WITH STALIN'S DAUGHTER: WHY SHE LEFT SOVIET AGAIN
abstract: On April 16 Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, returned to the United States after a year and a half back in her Soviet homeland, from which she defected in 1967. Her American-born daughter, Olga Peters, also left the Soviet Union, to return to a private school in Britain.   Miss Alliluyeva, who uses the name Lana Peters in private life, went into seclusion with friends near Spring Green, Wis. She met there and in Madison recently with Raymond H. Anderson, a former Moscow correspondent of The New York Times who is now a professor of journalism at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. Here are excerpts from their conversations.   Q. I'm sure that the No. 1 question about you right now in this country is why did you decide so abruptly, and surprisingly, to leave Britain in 1984 and fly to the Soviet Union with your daughter? After all, you had made some very harsh remarks about the Soviet political system in your books.

headline: Xerox Weighs Pretoria Move
abstract: The Xerox Corporation is considering pulling its operations out of South Africa if tensions there do not ease and pressures in the United States continue to mount, the company's top executive said. ''I am not optimistic about   South Africa,'' David T. Kearns, Xerox's chairman, said.

headline: Revamped Mexican Lineup
abstract: Before leaving the Cabinet last week in a shake-up, Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, was scheduled to be the luncheon speaker tomorrow at the Overseas Development Council's symposium on the World Bank.

headline: ADVERTISING; Doyle Graf Chosen
abstract: Doyle Graf Mabley should be in high spirits, thanks to the assignment by the Kobrand Corporation of several alcoholic beverage brands. Besides some new products that will particularly interest the affluent market, there is Taittinger Champagne, Maison Louis Jadot Burgundy and Bouvet Brut sparkling wine. The last agency that did ads for them was Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath.

headline: SUITCASE BOMB AT EL AL COUNTER IN MADRID HURTS 12
abstract: A suitcase being inspected by El Al security personnel exploded today at the Israeli airline's check-in counter here, wounding 12 people, the police said.   An airport official said the suitcase had already passed an X-ray examination by Spanish security officials and was to have been loaded in the baggage hold of an El Al flight to Tel Aviv.   It was not known what kind of explosive was in the suitcase, or whether it had been designed to detonate aboard the Boeing 767 airliner and had exploded prematurely.   The man who checked in the luggage was arrested at the scene and was being questioned tonight, according to one of the airport's directors, Jose Ignacio Garcia de la Rasilla. The man's name was not released, but the airport director said the man was traveling on a Spanish passport. He said the suspect had offered no resistance.

headline: Drop in Money Funds
abstract: Assets of the nation's 360 money market mutual funds fell $815.7 million, to $224.59 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: SOVIET STILL OPEN TO MEETING U.S.
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for a special meeting in Europe with President Reagan on nuclear arms testing does not preclude a regular meeting in Washington this year, a senior Soviet official said today.   The official, Georgi M. Korniyenko, who is a First Deputy Foreign Minister, said at a news conference:   ''Mikhail Gorbachev did not mean that this meeting, if it took place, would supplant the one that had been agreed on in Geneva and would be a visit by Mr. Gorbachev to Washington. This remains on the agenda.''   Mr. Korniyenko reiterated that the Soviet Union was reluctant to set a date for a Washington meeting until it was clear that there would be progress on arms control. American officials have said the best way to encourage progress is to schedule themeeting.

headline: Real Estate; Abrams's New Office Downtown
abstract: SIX months after a conflict-of-interest issue killed a deal that would have moved the New York State Attorney General's office from the World Trade Center to the former A.T.&T. building on lower Broadway, the agency has signed a lease that will put it in another landmark nearby, at 120 Broadway.   Before the end of summer, the agency will move into 290,000 square feet on six floors in the 40-story building on Broadway, between Pine and Cedar Streets, that is owned by Silverstein Properties.   Mr. Abrams resisted efforts to move his agency from the Trade Center to less expensive space in another part of the city, in part to be closer to the courts. That led him to select first the former A.T.&T. building at 195 Broadway, which had been acquired by Peter Kalikow when the communications company moved to its new headquarters on Madison Avenue at 56th Street.

headline: HONDURAN TELLS OF U.S. PRESSURE
abstract: A senior Honduran official has asserted that the Government never felt its security was threatened by a Nicaraguan border raid last week and sought to resist pressure from the Reagan Administration to treat the episode as a major crisis.   ''The United States interest was that this situation have the connotation of an international incident,'' the official said of the Sandinista drive against Nicaraguan guerrilla bases in Honduras. ''We had no interest in this.''   He added that Honduras wanted to avoid direct military confrontation with Nicaragua and was willing to negotiate with the Sandinistas on the presence of the guerrillas here.

headline: BELZBERG'S BID IGNORED BY ASHLAND
abstract: Ashland Oil Inc. yesterday let pass a deadline for responding to the Belzberg family's offer to negotiate a purchase, indicating to the investment community that the company would not cooperate with the Belzbergs' offer to acquire the company.   Ashland's stock was the fifth-biggest losing issue on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $51.50, down $3.75, in anticipation of the company's failure to respond.   The First City Financial Corporation, the Vancouver (British Columbia) investment company controlled by the Canadian financiers, said last week that it was prepared to enter into an agreement to purchase 100 percent of Ashland's stock for $60 a share, or about $1.8 billion. The Belzbergs stated that they were willing to negotiate a higher price if Ashland's board entered into ''good faith'' negotiations. First City holds 9.2 percent of Ashland's 28.6 million common shares.

headline: 10 Killed in Floods in Chile
abstract: Widespread flooding in central Chile has left ten people dead and almost 35,000 homeless, the Government's National Emergency Office said today. The flood waters began to recede today, but water supplies to half of Santiago's four million residents, cut off since Monday evening, returned slowly and tankers were sent out to take fresh water to poor neighborhoods.

headline: United Jersey Buys Jersey Banks
abstract: United Jersey Banks of Princeton, N.J. said it had reached an agreement to acquire Commercial Bancshares Inc., of Jersey City, N.J., for approximately $285 million.

headline: Advertising; Agency, 19, Simplifies Its Lineup
abstract: THE management of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, one of the survivors of the 1967 bumper crop of new agencies, as it prepared to celebrate its 19th anniversary, paused for a moment to look at the forest and as a result has realigned the trees. That gave it something to bark about.  High up in its pronouncement and of obvious importance to the agency was the promotion to the creative director from a creative director of Kevin O'Neill, a 32-year-old Brooklyn-born Princeton alumnus and creative writer.  He becomes the first person to hold the title who doesn't have his name on the letterhead. His promotion means that Arthur W. Einstein Jr., who had been president and creative director, will now content himself with the single title.

headline: Halcyon Holds 8.7% of John Blair
abstract: A New York-based limited partnership, Halcyon Investments, said that it holds an 8.7 percent stake in John Blair & Company and 6.4 percent of the Fruehauf Corporation.   Earlier this week, Blair's board of directors accepted a sweetened bid from Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Capital Group for $31 a share in cash and notes, or a total of $340 million.

headline: CHINA'S ECONOMIC ILLS ARE MANY, C.I.A. SAYS
abstract: China is suffering ''numerous problems'' as a result of its seven-year-old program to introduce market-oriented economic policies, according to a Central Intelligence Agency report made public today.   Among the economic setbacks are a decline in grain production in 1985 - the first in five years - a deterioration in the country's balance of trade and a tripling of the inflation rate, to 8.8 percent.   In issuing the report, prepared for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, a committee member, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said the C.I.A. study ''provides the basis of a more sober view of Chinas's economic situation.''   ''China is not yet a successful example of market socialism or modified capitalism,'' he said, ''and it remains to be seen whether there will be further significant loosening of economic controls.''

headline: GREECE SENSES A THREAT
abstract: The bombing incident Wednesday is likely to deal a serious blow to the already troubled Greek tourism industry, Greece's largest source of foreign currency earnings, Greek officials and Western diplomats said today.   The authorities said they expected a new wave of cancellations by Americans. One official of the National Tourist Organization of Greece said the most likely result would be the failure of a $3 million advertising campaign begun by Greece in the United States.

headline: FLORIDA INSURERS ASSAIL PREMIUM ROLLBACK BILL
abstract: The insurance industry sharply criticized yesterday a measure enacted by the Florida Legislature mandating a 40 percent rollback in commercial premiums and making future price increases more difficult. Insurers say the law would make underwriting in Florida unprofitable and they feared other states would follow suit.   ''It's a disaster, '' said William M. McCormick, chairman and chief executive of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company. ''And if it spreads from Florida to other states, it would be a catastrophe.'' W. Minor Carter, vice president for government affairs at the USF&G Corporation, a major insurance company, added, ''This is a Draconian, onerous measure and I hope no other legislature would act as irresponsibly as the Florida Legislature.

headline: LIQUOR UNIT SALE IS SET BE WALKER
abstract: In a move to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the Reichmann family of Canada, Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big Canadian oil and liquor producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its distilled spirits business to a ''major international corporation'' for $1.86 billion.   Walker, the fourth-largest liquor company in North America, after Seagram, Heublein and National Distillers, would not identify the buyer, but Wall Street sources said they understood that it was Allied-Lyons P.L.C. of London, the big food and beverage producer.   Walker added that it would also buy up to 50 million shares, or 45 percent, of its own stock at $28.64 a share, or a total of $1.4 billion. Eligibility for Offer    The offer will be made through a company to be called the Fingas Investment Corporation, in which Walker and the buyer of the liquor interests have minority voting interests, and is open only to persons outside the United States. Brokers said that, as a practical matter, however, United States citizens could sell to their brokers, who in turn would sell to Canadian brokers.

headline: E.S.M. Plan For Creditors
abstract: A Federal judge approved a plan today to distribute $35 million to 23 creditors who lost money when E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. failed last year. Federal District Judge Jose   Gonzalez Jr. accepted a plan that would pay 17 municipalities and five savings and loans about 22 cents on the dollar for losses suffered.

headline: Recapitalization Plan at Warnaco
abstract: Warnaco Inc. said it planned to proceed with a recapitalization plan despite a hostile suitor's allegation that the plan violated Connecticut law. The suitor, a California-based investor group called the W Acquisition Corporation, has offered $40 a share, or $410 million, to buy the apparel maker.

headline: LTV Beginning Cost-Saving Plan
abstract: The LTV Corporation, the giant steelmaker and military contractor, said at its shareholder meeting that it was initiating a three-point program aimed at saving its steel segment an additional $200 million this year. The plan, which comes two weeks after the company announced a $550 debt exchange offer, calls for reduced energy use at its steel plants, a lowering of capital spending, and the production of higher-grade steel to improve revenue.

headline: BRAZILIAN MINISTER QUITS IN DISPUTE WITH LEADER
abstract: President Jose Sarney accepted the resignation today of the Minister for Agrarian Reform and Development, Nelson Ribeiro, in what political sources described as a dispute over redistribution of land.   The sources said the resignation, announced by a Government spokesman, resulted from friction between Mr. Ribeiro and Mr. Sarney over Mr. Ribeiro's outspoken remarks on the politically sensitive question of distributing underutilized land to rural workers.

headline: Former Officials Banned From Office by Nigeria
abstract: Nigeria's military ruler, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, announced today that former politicians would be barred from holding office for 10 years and presented a series of sweeping economic revisions.

headline: DOLLAR FALLS SHARPLY IN HECTIC DAY
abstract: The dollar went through one of its most volatile days in months on the foreign exchange markets yesterday, falling sharply to a record low against the Japanese yen and tumbling in value against other currencies before staging a small recovery late in the day.   The decline, which came amid several large swings during the trading day, resulted largely from a heightened expectations that the Federal Reserve would lower its discount rate. Late in the day, the Fed did reduce the rate, which is what it charges financial institutions for overnight loans, to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent.   The dollar's gyrations yesterday were accentuated, foreign exchange traders said, by the fact that trading was quite thin, which is common on Fridays.

headline: OTHERS DETECT NUANCES
abstract: A new Soviet arms proposal may have figured in President Reagan's apparent move Wednesday to shade, but not to alter, his decision to disavow the strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979, according to Administration officials.   The Soviet offer entails dropping the requirement that the United States reduce its so-called forward-based systems, meaning American fighter-bombers based in Western Europe and on aircraft carriers, but would raise the proposed limit on overall strategic nuclear forces to 8,000, from 6,000, the officials said.   The new offer is also said to permit long-range sea-launched cruise missiles rather than banning them as before. These missiles would then be counted in the total of 8,000 nuclear bombs and missile warheads. This contrasts with the proposed American ceiling of 6,000 ballistic missile warheads and air-launched cruise missiles only. Mindful of Soviet Offer Officials said Mr. Reagan was mindful of this offer in his comments Wednesday and wished to avoid fouling the atmosphere created by the new proposal, presented in Geneva earlier in the day. The officials also said Mr. Reagan might have wanted to mollify Western European leaders who expressed disapproval of his decision May 27 to abandon the 1979 treaty.

headline: Scientific American Bids
abstract: At least three well-known publishing companies - Time Inc., the International Thomson Organization Ltd. and The Economist Newspaper Ltd. -are among the bidders for Scientific American Inc., according to sources familiar with the situation.

headline: Ford Picks Manager For Alpha Project
abstract: John A. Manoogian, who started as a drafting apprentice at the Ford Motor Company in 1940, has been named manager of the company's advanced manufacturing program.   The program, known as the Alpha Project, is Ford's attempt to match the Japanese in costs and quality in small cars, much like General Motors' Saturn program.

headline: STOCK TRADING LINK SPANS THE ATLANTIC
abstract: In Columbus, Ohio, Robert Lentz is delighted that the London Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. began a trans-Atlantic link today.   Under the arrangement, the two stock markets will exchange price quotations on more than 550 companies, one of them Huntington Bancshares Inc., a bank-holding company of which Mr. Lentz is assistant treasurer in charge of planning.   Many brokers, investors and company executives see the new link as an important step toward global stock trading.   ''This link will give us more visibility in London and that should help us tap the international capital markets,'' Mr. Lentz said. Huntington's stock price will be displayed on 4,000 computers screens of British brokers and dealers.

headline: PARAGUAY RADIO STATION IS LONELY VOICE OF DISSENT
abstract: What most surprised Humberto Rubin about the mob attack on his radio station last month was not the crash of breaking glass or the crack of shots being fired into the air. Rather, it was the sound of musical accompaniment.   The Government denied any responsibility for the assault near sign-off time on April 29, just as it did for the raid five days later on Radio Nanduti's transmission station 12 miles outside Asuncion, where masked gunmen stole vital pieces of electronic equipment.   Yet a tape recording made by a cool-headed technician of the first cacophonous attack brought an interesting revelation. The band that accompanied the 100 or so attackers could distinctly be heard playing two polkas, ''General Stroessner'' and ''The Colorado,'' familiar tributes to Paraguay's longtime dictator and his party.

headline: I.R.S. Audits
abstract: To the Editor:   One reason why ''the I.R.S. has been forced to cut back on tax audits to the lowest level ever'' (''The I.R.S. Loses Its Muscle,'' April 6) is that it doesn't have the time. In general, under present law the I.R.S. has only three years to audit a return after it has been filed and six years to collect the tax after it has been assessed.

headline: House Backs Mortgage Aid
abstract: The House passed emergency legislation today to extend the credit authorities of two Government agencies that help provide mortgage money to home buyers.   The legislation, which was approved by a voice vote and sent to the Senate, would extend the authority of the Government National Mortgage Association, known as Ginnie Mae, to guarantee mortgage-backed securities, to $100 billion from $65.3 billion, and to $95 billion the Federal Housing Administration's $57.4 billion limit for insuring mortgages.

headline: Cuba to Defer Repayments
abstract: Cuba has told its foreign creditors that it will suspend debt payments for 90 days while seeking more favorable terms and $500 million in cash to make up for a projected shortfall.

headline: Philippine Bus Crash Kills 23
abstract: A bus fell from a 50-foot cliff in the southern Philippines, igniting an explosion that killed 23 people, officials said. Sgt. Rolando Geroche, a military spokesman in Iloilo Province, said the accident occurred Friday near the village of Igbugacay in Antique Province, 260 miles south of Manila. Fifteen passengers were injured, he said.

headline: SRI LANKA TRAIN BLAST KILLS 12
abstract: Twelve people were killed and 40 were wounded today by a bomb that exploded in a passenger train in a Colombo suburb, a military spokesman said.   The spokesman said the authorities suspected that Tamil separatist guerrillas were responsible for the blast at Veyangoda, 20 miles northeast of Colombo.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Anderson, Clayton & Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million of senior subordinated notes due 1998 through Prudential-Bache Securities.    * Envirodyne Industries has filed for $100 million of subordinated notes due 1996 and an offering of 1.2 million common shares through Salomon Brothers Inc.    * Environmental Systems Co. is offering $35 million of 6 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2011 at 100 through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $25.25 a share.

headline: SOVIET DENOUNCES WALDHEIM CRITICS
abstract: The Soviet Union today harshly denounced Washington and ''Zionist circles'' for waging ''a campaign of personal hostile attacks'' against Kurt Waldheim.   The commentary in Tass marked the first mention in the Soviet press of the allegations that Mr. Waldheim, who was elected to the Austrian presidency today, had concealed wartime activities that made him privy to Nazi atrocities in the Balkans. Before today's article, Soviet reports had only given the bare facts of the progress of the Austrian election and had been silent on the revelations about Mr. Waldheim's past.   The commentary, which also gave a positive summary of Mr. Waldheim's record as the United Nations Secretary General, placed Moscow unambivalently behind the new President.

headline: One Killed by Police In New Punjab Unrest
abstract: One person was killed and eight others were wounded today when security forces opened fire to disperse angry crowds in the Punjab, the authorities said.

headline: HOUSE PLANS TO ACT ON ARMS TREATY
abstract: House Democratic leaders have decided to press ahead with a bill that would enact into law the limits on strategic weapons negotiated by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1979.   This approach, which was agreed to at a planning session last week, sets up a potential confrontation with the White House over the unratified arms treaty. The Administration is opposed to the Democrats' move, and an official said today: ''Anything that binds the President's hand in foreign policy, absent a treaty, would be objectionable.''   The Democrats contend that they must put pressure on the President because jettisoning adherence to the terms of the 1979 treaty would be ''a foreign policy blunder of major magnitude,'' as Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the majority leader, put it.

headline: ANGOLANS SAY PRETORIA KILLED 53
abstract: The Angolan Defense Ministry said today that South African troops had taken up positions inside Angola to support rebels fighting the Angolan Government and had killed at least 53 soldiers.   The ministry charged that South Africa was seeking to ''multiply conflicts'' in southern Africa.

headline: THOUSANDS MARCH IN A SOUTH KOREAN PROTEST
abstract: Tens of thousands of people marched peacefully Saturday as the opposition party continued to draw enthusiastic support for constitutional change.   The rally was the fourth in the last few weeks. The crowd shouted its disapproval of the Government on the same day that President Chun Doo Hwan left for a visit to Western Europe. Both the opposition rally and a separate student demonstration remained peaceful, eschewing the violence of a small band of demonstrators last week in Kwangju.

headline: INDIA POLICE IN CONTROL OF SIKH TEMPLE
abstract: A force of nearly 2,000 paramilitary police completed a 12-hour operation this morning to regain control of the Golden Temple at Amritsar from several hundred Sikh radicals. But police officials said almost all the major radical leaders managed to escape.   The police officials who conducted the raid on the Sikh religion's holiest shrine, the second major armed intervention by the Government at the temple in two years, said one civilian was killed and two were wounded. They said most of the 300 radicals who were arrested did not not resist.

headline: SOVIET SAYS FALLOUT IS CUT
abstract: The United States said today that the Soviet Union might have smothered the fire that raged for the last five days at a nuclear reactor in the Ukraine.   In addition, a French communications satellite took pictures today that suggested the fire might have been smothered, a report from Sweden said.   ''We cannot see the smoke which we saw Wednesday,'' said Lars Bjerkesjo of Satellitbild, the company that received the picture at a land station in northern Sweden, according to a report by The Associated Press. ''It appears the fire has decreased.''   The accident at the Chernobyl reactor, 70 miles north of Kiev, spewed radioactive material into the atmosphere that has drifted into many European countries. The accident apparently began last Friday, but it became known outside the Soviet Union only Monday.

headline: BULGARIA JEWS' HOPES, AND NUMBERS, DWINDLE
abstract: In the small prayer hall adjoining the Grand Synagogue, 16 men, 16 women and a small boy chanted the traditional Friday evening prayers to greet the coming of the Sabbath.   An aged cantor, turning his back on the worshippers in the Sephardic tradition, led the aged congregation, those of the remaining 3,000 Jews of Sofia who still keep their faith. On the walls hang the richly embroidered velvet tapestries that until the 1940's adorned the arks in which Torah scrolls were kept in the synagogues of Bulgaria's smaller towns.   The synagogues have vanished, as the Jews of Bulgaria have dwindled from 50,000 to 5,000. There are only some books and cult objects, brought to Sofia, to recall the temples. The tapestry that once hung in the synagogue of Russe, on the Danube, proclaims in golden Hebrew letters that it was a gift of the Canetti family, one of whose offspring, Elias, won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1981. He lives in London and Zurich; his works also do not live in Bulgaria, whose literary canons exclude him.

headline: BANKS PUSH DEAL-MAKER ROLE
abstract: When hundreds of securities analysts showed up last month at Citicorp, they spent several hours learning not about automatic teller machines or corporate lending trends but about the bank's role in investment banking.   Citicorp and a host of other major money center banks these days ranging from Morgan Guaranty Trust to the First Chicago Corporation are flocking to the expanding world of securities trading and deal origination. They are redoubling their efforts in these areas both at home and abroad as a bevy of new securities not forbidden to bank activity come into vogue and as traditional banking activities become less attractive.   The new focus, which pits commercial banks against Wall Street firms in the search for talent, comes despite the continued prohibition under the Glass-Steagall Act against corporate bond and equity underwriting in the United States by commercial banks. Innovations Are Cited    ''We tell our people that success in investment banking is just not dependent on realizing greater liberation of Glass-Steagall,'' said George Vojta, an executive vice president for investment banking at the Bankers Trust Company. ''Many of the financial innovations coming into the market have nothing to do with Glass-Steagall.''

headline: U.N. ARCHIVES: DETAILS 'WORD FOR WORD'
abstract: There are the handwritten notes of Secretary General U Thant from his Havana hotel room during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, the secret investigation into the plane crash that killed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and the working papers, drafts and verbatim minutes of the San Francisco conference at which the United Nations Charter was drafted.   That, and more, can be found in the United Nations Archives, 50 million pages of documents crammed into two floors of an office building in Manhattan. Until a controversy erupted recently over former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's record in World War II, few New Yorkers were aware of the existence of the archives, much less where they are, at 345 Park Avenue South.

headline: A STRATEGY OF AGGRESSIVE INNOVATION
abstract: Innovation, by Richard Foster. Summit Books, New York 316 pages, $19.95. UNLIKE Roy Rowan, Richard   Foster is less concerned with means than with ends. He cares little about what mental process leads to innovation, only that a company keep new products and product refinements flowing at a steady pace. That flow, he insists, is the key to long-term success.

headline: SEARCHING FOR A SAFE HARBOR; WHEN INVESTMENT CAPITAL GOES ON STRIKE
abstract: JAMES MADISON reassured readers of the Federalist Papers that the economic elites had little to fear from democracy. Still, the ''haves'' generally are outnumbered by the ''have nots,'' and the specter of votes counting for more than dollars gives the well-to-do the jitters.  The wealthy have traditionally met the threat through compromise, the recognition of labor unions and the modern welfare state being prime examples. But changing conditions may foster a new hard-line position and curb democratic pretensions. The Reagan Administration has promoted these conditions, adopting a strategy that we call global liberalism for its worldwide application of laissez faire economics.

headline: AD AGENCY MERGERS CHANGING THE BUSINESS
abstract: Madison Avenue, the symbolic if not actual home of the advertising world, is going through its most dramatic change since the business began a century ago.   Agencies are being bought and sold at a pace never before seen. In the process, huge advertising and marketing service companies, dubbed ''mega-agencies,'' are being created that dwarf the size of traditional agencies.   Just yesterday, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company of London announced that it had agreed to acquire Ted Bates Worldwide for $450 million, the biggest merger yet.   The acquisition would make Saatchi & Saatchi the largest agency in the world, wresting that title away from an as-yet unnamed combination of three other major concerns - BBDO International, the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group and Needham Harper Worldwide - that was announced only two weeks ago.

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS SEARCHING FOR THE JAILED AND MISSING
abstract: In ones and twos they come to the dingy offices on second floor of the large gray stone building on De Villiers Street here. They are all black, and someone they know is missing.   In the offices of the Detainees Parents' Support Committee, four harried-looking white women listen to stories of missing relatives, of brothers arrested in the middle of the night, of fathers who failed to return from work, of wives who have not been heard from.   ''My brother was taken,'' a slight young man said slowly. When? he was asked. ''At 2 this morning,'' he replied. Where?  ''In Soweto.''

headline: Bingham Sale To Be Revealed
abstract: Representatives of the Bingham family said today that they would announce the new owner of The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times at a news conference Monday morning.   Barry Bingham Sr., chairman of the Bingham communications companies who controls most of the voting shares, met today with investment bankers and family members to consider offers for the newspapers. Mr. Bingham, 80 years old, had announced Jan. 9 that the papers would be sold after a bitter feud among family members over control of the companies.

headline: Libyan Petroleum Products May Face Embargo in U.S.
abstract: The United States, seeking to step up its sanctions against Libya, is moving toward an embargo against petroleum products made with Libyan crude oil and refined in Europe and other foreign countries, State Department officials said today.   Such a ban could put additional pressure on European countries to limit their purchases of Libyan crude oil at a time when the United States is trying to enlist allied support for specific measures against the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: China Condemns Raid And All Acts of Terror
abstract: China officially condemned the United States attack on Libya today, but the wording of the statement and balanced coverage given the attack in the official press suggested at least some understanding for the American decision to strike.

headline: SPAIN STANDS FIRM ON BAR TO MARCOS
abstract: Spain's Foreign Minister said today that his Government would not grant asylum to Ferdinand E. Marcos despite requests from Washington to do so.   The refusal by the Spanish official, Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez, came after a meeting with President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines. The decision further complicates the personal situation of former President Marcos, who is said to be especially anxious to find a haven from lawsuits against him in the United States.

headline: French Nuclear Test Reported in Pacific
abstract: France exploded an underground nuclear device today at its Mururoa test site, its first test of the year and 73d at the South Pacific atoll since 1975, the New Zealand Government said.   Prime Minister David Lange said the test, which was monitored by New Zealand scientists at the country's Rarotonga seismological station on the Cook Islands, ''highlights the need for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty to be concluded as quickly as possible.''

headline: Technology; Gene Mapping Is Improved
abstract: MOLECULAR biologists, assisted by a new generation of automated gene machines, are moving closer to the day when the entire genetic structures of people, crop plants and farm animals will be mapped and understood.   When this is accomplished, it could be possible to eliminate human diseases and birth defects as well as improve crops and livestock. More important, an understanding of the fundamental structure of genes will disclose one of the secrets of how molecules combine to form living things.   Until recently, mapping gene sequences was a rigorous task. Genetic instructions are encoded in a distinctive pattern of four chemical bases, nucleic acids linked in pairs - adenine to guanine, cytosine to thymine. A typical gene contains about 3,000 bases, linked together like pearls on a necklace. The human genetic code, for instance, is 3.5 billion bases long. Since the discovery of the double-stranded structure of DNA in the early 1950's, scientists have only managed to decode the entire genetic instructions of a few simple viruses.

headline: ISRAELIS SAY SYRIA SEEKS ARMS PARITY
abstract: Syria, strengthened by substantial rearmament from the Soviet Union, is trying to attain ''strategic parity'' with Israel, according to Israeli and some American officials.   But few officials in either country see the Syrian buildup as an outright military threat to Israel.   ''Syria should know that it has not reached military parity with Israel,'' the Israeli Minister of Defense, Yitzhak Rabin, said in Washington this week. ''In the long run Syria alone is not a match for Israel. I have no doubt we will win such a war.''

headline: Boeing Jet Order
abstract: Lufthansa German Airlines says it will buy up to 15 Boeing 747-400 jetliners in an order valued at about $2.1 billion.

headline: Opposition Leader Returns to Pakistan
abstract: Benazir Bhutto, the exiled Pakistani opposition leader, returned home from exile today to the cheers of tens of thousands of supporters.
