Hundreds of heavily armed riot police kept the huge crowd from the Lahore Airport terminal, but after Miss Bhutto left the building, joyous backers carried her in triumph to a large truck to lead a massive procession through the border city.

headline: IN SOUTH AFRICA, FRIENDSHIP BLOOMS IN WIDOWS' GRIEF
abstract: They are two women, two widows, bonded, in South Africa, by grief.   Nyameka Goniwe, widowed a year ago, and Di Bishop, widowed for six months, shopped and talked and went to the theater together this weekend -companionship that might seem usual among those seeking freedom from the insistent caress of great and sudden loss.   But in South Africa's agony, there were differences. For one thing, the women are of different skin color, one black, one white, not supposed to mingle, yet thrust across the racial divide by protest and bereavement.

headline: NAKASONE DEFENDS JAPAN'S RECORD ON TERROR
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today defended Japan's record in opposing terrorism and said his Government had taken a ''most appropriate approach'' against Libya by limiting business ties.   Mr. Nakasone, who will be the host at the gathering of major industrial democracies in Tokyo next week, said he would seek agreement on a declaration opposing terrorism. But in a luncheon interview with Tokyo-based foreign correspondents, he did not say how strong a statement he would accept, or whether he would go along with one that included a reference to Libya.   The Reagan Administration's determination to pursue a hard line on terrorism has troubled some Japanese officials, who worry that it may be too strong for them and may put them in an awkward situation as conference host.

headline: CHERNOBYL CHIEFS OUSTED FOR ERRING DURING ACCIDENT
abstract: The director and chief engineer of the Chernobyl atomic power station have been dismissed for mishandling the disaster at the plant in April, and other top officials have been accused of failings ranging from negligence to desertion, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.   Other top employees, including heads of shifts and senior technicians, are still absent from work after fleeing from Pripyat, the town where the plant is situated, the newspaper said.   The report gave few details of the specific accusations against the top executives. But it was the strongest suggestion to date of extensive confusion and negligence after the explosion that ruptured the Unit 4 reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the early hours of April 26, releasing a cloud of radioactive materials. Twenty-six people have died as a result of the disaster at the plant, near the Ukrainian-Byelorussian border.

headline: New York Air Shifting Flights
abstract: New York Air said yesterday that it would shift some flights from La Guardia to Newark International Airport, creating a shuttle service there that will compete with People Express.

headline: EAST GERMANS ADD BORDER CONTROLS AT THE BERLIN LINE
abstract: East German border guards today turned back West German diplomats trying to cross to West Berlin, and advised diplomats from other NATO countries that measures would be enforced Tuesday to enlarge East Germany's legal authority on its side of the divided city.   Diplomats from the United States, Britain and France denounced the East German move as an attempt to establish an international frontier between East and West Berlin. Under postwar statute, the three NATO powers and the Soviet Union have nominal control over all of Berlin; the three Western allies do not recognize its division.   The East German border guards asked that foreign diplomats passing through Checkpoint Charlie, the main crossing point between East and West Berlin, show their passports and not their red passes accrediting them to the East German Foreign Ministry.

headline: LEBANESE MOSLEM RECEIVES O'CONNOR
abstract: Amid the sound of explosions and machine-gun fire, the Archbishop of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor, went to West Beirut today for a meeting with Sheik Hassan Khaled, the Grand Mufti, who is the spiritual leader of Lebanon's 650,000 Sunni Moslems.   Earlier in the day, seven Christian Lebanese men were kidnapped by unidentified gunmen as they traveled from West Beirut to East Beirut.

headline: The U.N. Today: June 26, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Conference on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 3 In Lebanese Port City
abstract: A car bomb exploded in the southern Lebanese port city of Sidon today, killing 3 people and wounding 34 others, the police said. There was no immediate assertion of responsibility.

headline: Weak Demand Stalls Rally
abstract: The price rally that buoyed the credit markets on Tuesday fizzled yesterday as a weaker than expected demand for the Treasury's new seven-year notes pulled down prices for both long and intermediate Government issues.   The rally had driven yields on the notes down to 7.27 percent in pre-auction trading, a sharp drop from the 7.66 percent at which dealers were offering them last Thursday. Dealers said that Japanese investors, who at one point were thought to be interested in as much as $2 billion of the new notes, proved to have less enthusiasm with the yields so low.

headline: F.H.A. Halts New Lending
abstract: The Federal Housing Administration told lenders today to stop taking applications for Government-insured home mortgages because the agency has reached its $57.4 billion credit ceiling. One analyst said the action would force conventional and Veterans Administration loan rates somewhat higher.

headline: THE CARE AND FEEDING OF A PC
abstract: ONE of the more expected, but nonetheless startling, developments in personal computing has been the evolution of these sophisticated machines into commodity items. Although the personal computer is far more complicated than a toaster, the purchase and maintenance of the two devices have to a certain extent come to parallel one another.   I was reflecting on this state of affairs over a toastless breakfast not long ago. Our old two-slice appliance was about the same age as the faithful, dual-floppy personal computer that had graced my desk for some three years. On that particular morning the toaster had proceeded to send me a series of error messages, repeatedly ejecting slices of rye bread as soft and cold as they had been when first inserted. A new toaster was definitely in order. Having the old one fixed was certainly out of the question, for I knew that even getting someone to look at it would be more expensive than the cost of a brand new toaster.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON SOUTH AFRICA ISSUED BY COMMONWEALTH MISSION
abstract: Following are excerpts from the report on South Africa issued here today by the Commonwealth mission known as the Eminent Persons Group:   During the preliminary visit, General Obasanjo was permitted to see Mr. Mandela. Thereafter, the full group met with him on two occasions, although not with other detainees.   The group approached the meetings with Mr. Mandela with another measure of care. It was impossible not to be aware of the mythology surrounding him, but equally, we were determined that it should not color our impressions or influence our judgment. As far as possible, we resolved to approach these meetings with an open mind.   We were first struck by his physical authority - by his immaculate appearance, his apparent good health, and his commanding presence. In his manner, he exuded authority, and received the respect of all around him, including his jailers. That in part seemed to reflect his own philosophy of separating people from policy.

headline: THATCHER HOLDS FAST IN BATTLE OVER SANCTIONS
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stood up to criticism in the House of Commons today in resisting the adoption of British economic sanctions against South Africa.   ''The purpose is not to hurt those whom we least wish to hurt,'' she said, alluding to possible economic harm to South African blacks. As expected, her majority held, defeating by 331 to 206 an opposition motion.

headline: Sale by Carbide Seen
abstract: Directors of the Union Carbide Corporation met last night to discuss the sale of the rest of its consumer products business. An announcement on a buyer was expected as soon as today.   On April 7, Carbide agreed to sell its battery business - its brands are Eveready and Energizer - to the Ralston Purina Company for $1.42 billion. The rest of its consumer business includes such products as Prestone antifreeze and Glad plastic bags.

headline: Ohio Sewer Bonds
abstract: Columbus, Ohio, is tentatively offering $209 million of sewer system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/8 percent an issue due in 2008 through underwriters led by the Ohio Company. Yields on shorter maturities range from 5.70 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 6.30 percent in 1991 and 7.90 percent in 2000. The bonds, backed by revenues of the city-owned sewer system, are A+ by S. & P., with underwriters expecting an A rating or better by Moody's.

headline: 3 in Sri Lanka Killed By Rebel Land Mine
abstract: Three people were killed today when a rebel land mine blasted a van in a security force convoy in eastern Sri Lanka, the National Security Ministry said.Ministry said.   A spokesman told reporters that the van that a soldier in another vehicle was wounded as the convoy passed Aluthoya in the Trincomalee district, 160 miles northeast of the capital.

headline: Your Money; Retirement Before Age 65
abstract: DECIDING whether to retire before the ''normal'' retirement age of 65 - a step taken by almost two-thirds of all new retirees - has many emotional and family implications that cannot be easily quantified. But the various financial considerations can certainly be weighed in detail.   A person's savings, and company retirement benefits are, of course, a major factor in this calculation and will vary, depending on the individual and his or her pension or profit-sharing plan. Medicare benefits do not begin until 65, even for someone receiving Social Security benefits at an earlier age, so adequate health insurance ought to be assured until then. Furthermore, many people cannot afford to retire before 65 and live comfortably without a regular paycheck.

headline: PAKISTANIS SHOOT DOWN AN AFGHAN MIG
abstract: Two American-made F-16 fighter jets of the Pakistani Air Force shot down an attacking Afghan Air Force MIG-21 in Pakistani airspace today, damaged a second and chased off two others, Government officials here said.   Pakistan's forces along the mountainous border between the two countries were placed on full alert, the officials said.   The Foreign Ministry issued a brief statement on the air clash near the border town of Parachinar and warned Afghanistan's Soviet-backed Communist Government to halt such attacks or face the consequences.

headline: Occidental Net Off 35.9%
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 35.9 percent, chiefly because of smaller gains from asset sales in the period.   The Los Angeles-based company said it earned $74.2 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $115.7 million, or 45 cents a share, a year ago.

headline: OCCIDENTAL AND DREXEL IN JOINT BID
abstract: In a move to bolster its operations outside the troubled oil sector, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had signed a letter of intent to purchase the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company for more than $800 million.   In addition to the unusual joint venture with the investment banking firm, Occidental said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the oil and gas exploration and production subsidiaries that it acquired in its recent purchase of the Midcon Corporation. Those units will be sold for about $500 million in cash to a joint venture of the Davis Oil Company and the Apache Petroleum Company.   The deal for part of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation comes 16 months after a courtship by Occidental of Diamond Shamrock crumbled in Shamrock's board room in January 1985. The two oil and chemical companies had discussed a merger for two years, and twice they had seemed on the verge of a deal.

headline: Marriott in Offer For Saga's Shares
abstract: The Marriott Corporation said that it was initiating a tender offer of $34 a share in cash for the Saga Corporation, or a total of about $435 million. The tender offer follows the expiration last week of Marriott's proposal to Saga management to acquire the company, also at $34.

headline: Borg-Warner Elects President as Chief
abstract: The Borg-Warner Corporation, a diversified manufacturing and service company, announced yesterday that Clarence E. Johnson, its president and chief operating officer, had been elected chief executive.   Mr. Johnson, 59 years old, succeeds James F. Bere (pronounced beret, like the French cap). Mr. Bere, 63, has been chief executive at the Chicago-based company since 1972. He will continue as chairman, a post he has held since 1975.

headline: Stan Merritt to Handle Blistex Lip Products
abstract: Stan Merritt Advertising of New York, a new-products development company that evolved into an agency, has just won the lip care division of Blistex Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill. Earlier this year, Merritt announced that it had landed Blistex's Health Care division.   The new assignment will include Blistex Medicated Ointment, Blistik Lip Balm and Daily Conditioning Treatment.

headline: Tax Returns Bring Surplus
abstract: The Federal Government enjoyed a rare $9.93 billion budget surplus in April as a flood of last-minute tax returns swelled Government coffers, the Treasury Department said today.   The April revenue increase still left the deficit for the year at $126.41 billion, 6.6 percent ahead of the pace set during a similar period last year.

headline: Talks Ended By San Miguel
abstract: The San Miguel Corporation says its subsidiary that runs a brewery in Hong Kong has called off negotiations on selling the brewery to Anheuser-Busch International Inc.   San Miguel said in a statement today that San Miguel Brewery Ltd. had been unable to agree with Anheuser-Busch.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Unemployed and Illegal Last Friday's report that overall unemployment dipped to 7.1 percent in March, a drop of only one-tenth of 1 percent from February, may have surprised economists who predicted the rate would go below 7 percent. But Sam Nakagama of Nakagama & Wallace Inc., says one reason the rate may be stuck is that in January the Government began including millions of illegal immigrants in its jobless calculations.   ''With falling oil prices devasting the Mexican economy,'' said Mr. Nakagama, ''Mexican workers have been pouring into this country.'' Thousands who enter illegally will not be apprehended by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, says Mr. Nakagama. And there will be few jobs for them, with rising unemployment in the auto, mining, manufacturing, oil and farm industries. The result, he says: ''The jobless rate will rise to 7.5 percent or more this spring and possibly stay there.''

headline: S.I. Terminal Sale By Chevron USA
abstract: Chevron USA Inc., which is leaving the Northeast light petroleum products business after the sale of its assets to Cumberland Farms, said it plans to sell its terminal on Staten Island.

headline: Your Money; Collecting Liberty Coins
abstract: ASK Douglas Bowsky, customer service manager of the Sears, Roebuck & Company store in Brooklyn, about United States Liberty Coins and he responds with enthusiasm. ''The coins are doing very well,'' he said. ''The initial shipment came in and we had to go back and order.''   Mr. Bowsky was talking about the special coins minted by the Treasury to commemorate the 1986 Statue of Liberty Centennial. With a portion of the purchase price used for restoring the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, these pieces represent the first time that the statue has appeared on American coinage.

headline: FUGITIVE UNIONIST WARNS PRETORIA OF REPISALS
abstract: The fugitive signaled his presence with a single beep of the horn from an automobile parked in the dimly lit street, and waited for assurance that the house was safe.   Then the owner of the house told him the place was secure, and he came in from the cold of a southern African winter's night to talk.   To a waiting reporter, the man's appearance seemed to have changed radically since a previous meeting, as had his style of dress. The fiery labor leader - in disguise and in hiding from detention under South Africa's newest emergency decree -could have passed for a college student or a clerk. But the message he bore was grave.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Airborne Freight Corp. is offering $25 million of 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2011 at 100, through First Boston Corp. as sole underwriter. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $27.65 a share.    * Citicorp on Tuesday sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.766 percent, up from 6.60 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 6.756 percent, up from 6.519 percent.

headline: AN INVITATION'S INTENT
abstract: Yugoslavia's decision to invite the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to hold its annual summer conference on the sunny Adriatic island of Brioni reflects a desire to underscore the country's political support for the developing world, at the same time increasing the island's market value as a venue for international conferences.   Brioni, the largest of an archipelago of 14 islands, vaguely resembling stretches of the Maine coast, was bitterly contested in centuries of wars and was heavily bombed by Allied planes seeking to drive German forces from the island's shores in World War II.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Champion International Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an additional $500 million of unsecured debt securities.    * Ford Motor Credit Co. is offering $300 million of 8 1/4 percent notes due 1996 at 99.75 to yield 8.29 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The notes, rated A-1/A, are offered to yield 8/10 of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: MORE CUTS IN INTEREST RATES SEEN
abstract: The United States and other countries might be able to reduce their interest rates further, a senior Administration official said here today.   ''We have an improving environment for lower interest rates,'' the official said. ''From time to time we may see further interest rate reductions because conditions are developing in that direction.''

headline: Leverage, a 2-Edged Sword
abstract: THE magic of using leverage - the employing of borrowed funds to make an investment - has nowhere been more apparent than in real estate.   From big time real estate entrepreneurs such as Donald Trump to suburban homeowners, many investors have seen their initial outlays multiply, whether in shopping malls, office complexes or residential property.   To be sure, leverage is powerful. It can provide big profits with relatively small investments. And it can be employed in many areas beyond real estate, in buying stocks and commodities, for example. But leverage also has a dangerous downside, even in real estate, and especially speculative real estate. Leverage can escalate the profits if the value of the investments rises, but it also magnifies the losses if the investment fails. ''This is usually not the case with real estate, which is expected to keep going up,'' said James J. Burke, president of the Long Island Society of the Institute of Certified Financial Planners. ''Stocks don't always have that luxury.''

headline: Peru Says It Detained 38,000 During Curfews
abstract: The Peruvian War Minister said in an interview published today that the military, fighting an upsurge in urban guerrilla violence, had detained 38,111 people and shot dead 4 people in the last three months for curfew violations in Lima.   The War Minister, Jorge Flores Torres, said in the newspaper El Nacional that soldiers had made the arrests for violations of the 1 A.M.-to-5 A.M. curfew since Feb. 10.

headline: SALE OF PEUGEOT STAKE
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would sell its 12.5 percent stake in the French auto maker Peugeot and use the estimated $275 million gain to improve its American plants.

headline: Ally & Gargano Gains
abstract: Ally & Gargano, the newest of the publicly held ad agencies, last week released the financial statement for its fiscal third quarter, ended March 31. Revenues were down slightly to $43.1 million from $43.4 million a year earlier, but net income rose to $655,000, or 30 cents a share, from $400,000, or 18 cents a share.

headline: Tough E.E.C. Trade Stance
abstract: The member countries of the European Economic Community today backed the tough stance of the community's executive commission in its latest trade dispute with Washington, according to diplomatic sources.   The sources said a meeting of representatives of member states had endorsed the commission's calls for the United States to agree that the effect of Spain's and Portugal's entry into the European Economic Community, or Common Market, in January should be analyzed in the world trade body the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Baxter Travenol Laboratories filed up to $500 million of senior unsecured debt securities.    * Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone of Maryland is offering $250 million of 9 1/8 percent debentures, rated Aa-2/ AA and due in 2026, at 99.206 to yield 9.20 percent through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * Crazy Eddie Inc. is offering $72 million of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011 at par through Wertheim & Co.; rated B-1 by Moody's, they are noncallable for two years and may be converted into common at $46.25 a share.    * CSX Corp. is offering $250 million of 9 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures, rated A-2/A and due in 2016, at 98 to yield 9.706 percent through First Boston; the debentures, nonrefundable for 10 years, have a sinking fund beginning in 1997 to retire 4 percent of the issue annually, giving the bonds a maximum life of 22.4 years..    * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. is offering $1.01 billion of 6.60 percent bonds due Jan. 5, 1987, at par though various dealers.

headline: EUROPE BROADENS ANTI-LIBYAN CURBS
abstract: The 12 foreign ministers of the European Community agreed today to a package of measures aimed at limiting Libya's ability to sponsor terrorist attacks.   The steps included immediate reductions in the numbers of Libyan diplomats stationed in Europe.   Overcoming initial objections by Greece, the foreign ministers agreed to move somewhat beyond a set of recommendations made at a similar meeting in The Hague a week ago.   At that time, the ministers announced that they would reduce the size of Libyan diplomatic missions abroad, restrict the movements of Libyans in the European countries, and impose stricter visa requirements on Libyan citizens wanting to travel in Europe.

headline: Soviet-Fijian Trade Talks
abstract: Fiji has agreed to discuss prospects for trade and technical cooperation with the Soviet Union, including a fishing agreement, a senior Government official said today.

headline: Imported Oil Demand Up
abstract: Demand for imported oil rose again last month while domestic production fell, as low world oil prices continued to make their impact felt on the American market, the Amerian Petroleum Institute said today.   The institute, an industry lobby group, said demand for gasoline increased 2.8 percent from last April, well under March's 6 percent rise but still a gain over the growth rate in the last half of 1985.

headline: 5 Dismissed At the S.B.A.
abstract: Charles Heatherly, acting director of the Small Business Administration, dismissed directors of five of the agency's 10 regional offices shortly after taking office today, an S.B.A. spokesman said.   The five regional administrators were asked to vacate their offices by the end of the day and acting directors were named to take their posts, the spokesman said.   Mr. Heatherly, who was named by President Reagan as deputy administrator, became acting director of the S.B.A. today following the departure of James C. Sanders, the administrator. Mr. Heatherly worked for a year at the Heritage Foundation, which has recommended dismantling the S.B.A.

headline: U.S. LISTS IMPORTS FOR RETALIATION
abstract: Americans may soon pay more for white wine from France, Italy and West Germany, Perrier from France, pork and canned hams from Denmark and the Netherlands, Scotch whisky and cookies from Britain, and olives from Spain and Portugal as a result a trade war that is about to break out with the European Common Market.   These and other products appeared on a retaliation list that the Office of the United States Trade Representative released today. It will be published Thursday in the Federal Register.

headline: PROFITS FALL AT CHRYSLER AND G.M.
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation today reported earnings declines for the first quarter that were generally in line with analyst's expectations.   Although the earnings were below the level of early 1984 and 1985, the reports indicated that the companies were entering their fourth consecutive year of robust profits.   G.M. earned $1.06 billion, a drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent from $1.07 billion in the comparable quarter of 1985. Earnings per share of common stock fell to $3.11, from $3.32, because some of G.M.'s earnings are now assigned to the E and H classes of stock issued in connection with the acquisition of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company.

headline: South African Workers Plan Strike on June 16
abstract: South Africa's largest labor federation said today that it would back a one-day strike on June 16 to mark the 10th anniversary of the 1976 Soweto uprising.   The labor group, the Congress of South African Trade Unions, which says it has 500,000 members, issued the strike call in a joint statement with two anti-apartheid organizations, the United Democratic Front and the National Education Crisis Committee. The groups urged whites to support the one-day strike.

headline: COMMERCIALIZING A GENTLE UNGULATE
abstract: TECUMSEH has seen its share of livestock sales over the years, but this farm belt Nebraska community had never witnessed anything like the extravaganza staged two weeks ago. Some 1,500 people, followed by network television crews, flew in for the largest and most lucrative llama auction ever held. Fred Hartman, a veteran with the gavel, put 247 llamas on the block, grossing a cool $1.5 million. The priciest turned out to be Oscar, a 2-year-old stud with ''banana-shaped ears'' who fetched $54,000, toppling the record of $51,000 set a year earlier.   Art Kressly, the proud new owner, says he got value for his money. ''Oscar has good quality wool, a heavier bone structure,'' said the Lynnport, Pa., breeder. ''All in all, his proportions are perfectly structurally pleasing to the eye.''   Prices have been consistently rising for a top-of-the-line llama. Cheryl Dal Porto, editor of Llamas magazine, recalls: ''In our first issue, seven years ago, females were selling for $1,500.'' Now breeding females sell at an average price of $6,000 to $10,000; males start at around $750 for a pet or pack animal.

headline: Advertising; Raytheon's New Push
abstract: ALTHOUGH it had more than $6 billion in sales last year and has been running corporate ads with varying intensity since the 1950's, the Raytheon Company would like to be better known and better thought of among its several important publics.   So with the help of HBM/Creamer, its agency since 1973, it will go the television route starting Sunday, laying some $4 million in advertising spending atop its usual print advertising budget of about $4 million.   Three beautifully crafted 30-second commercials directed by Steve Horn will deliver the message: ''Raytheon. Where quality starts with fundamentals.''

headline: Dominican Chief Cancels Trip Over Vote Violence
abstract: President Salvador Jorge Blanco has canceled a planned trip to the inauguration of the Costa Rican President-elect, Oscar Arias, this week after two people were killed Sunday in pre-election violence in the Dominican Republic, the President's office announced today.

headline: CHERNOBYL 'RADIATION AND BURNS' HAVE KILLED SIX, MOSCOW REPORTS
abstract: The Soviet Government said today that six people had died from ''radiation and burns'' suffered in the wake of the explosion and fire at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor.   The announcement marks the first time anyone is known to have died from radiation emitted by a civilian nuclear power plant.   The deaths were reported on the main evening television news program on the same day as the official Soviet press began to report punishments of local Communist Party members accused of shirking their duties during the evacuation of areas near the Chernobyl plant.

headline: BRITISH PRINT UNIONS REJECT MURDOCK'S 'FINAL OFFER'
abstract: A $75 million ''final offer'' of compensation from the publisher Rupert Murdoch was decisively rejected by 5,500 former employes, whose unions have been picketing and demonstrating at his new plant for more than four months.   When the offer was made 10 days ago, Brenda Dean, the leader of the union with the most members involved in the dispute, said she believed that the Australian-born publisher was not bluffing and that this was their last chance to get compensation for the jobs they had lost.   But members of the Society of Graphical and Allied Trades, Miss Dean's union, voted by a margin of 3 to 2 against accepting the $63 million that would have been their share of the total package.   Two other unions, the National Graphical Association and the Amalgamated Engineering Union, voted down the Murdoch offer by even heavier margins. The union ballots appear to mean that Britain's most violent labor confrontation since the yearlong coal miners' strike of 1984-85 may now continue indefinitely.

headline: U.S. AIDES DIVIDED ON FURTHER RAIDS
abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials say that since the American bombing of Libya on April 15, no consensus has developed within the Government on how far to go in repeating such attacks to counter an expected rise in anti-American terrorism around the world.   Since the raid, President Reagan has warned that the United States is ready to use its military power to retaliate again if there are new attacks.   But in interviews in recent days, White House and State Department officials expressed concern that the public support that developed for the bombing of Libya would not necessarily be repeated if Washington became engaged in a regular pattern of tit-for-tat retaliatory raids. 'Relatively Easy Target'    Such raids might be mounted not only against Libya but also against such nations as Syria and Iran, which are believed by the Administration to support terrorist groups.   ''Libya was a relatively easy target, and we lost one F-111,'' a State Department official said. ''Syria and Iran are more dangerous. We probably won't get away with such minimal losses. I wonder how long the polls will show a high approval rating in this country if the losses begin to mount without any evidence of ending terrorism.''

headline: Carson's Head Resisting Unwanted Suitor's Offer
abstract: Three years ago when Peter S. Willmott became chief executive of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago-based retailer, the company was a ''sleepy'' giant, analysts said.   Carson's, they said, lacked merchandising consistency and customer loyalty, its image was vague, sales were sluggish and its earnings fluctuated.   Today, however, the company has emerged refocused with significant improvement in performance, so much so that it has become the target of a takeover.

headline: AUSTRIA TO INSPECT FILE ON WALDHEIM
abstract: Austria asked the United Nations today for permission to examine a secret file on former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, and the world body agreed.   The Austrian Government formally requested the file today after it received written confirmation from Mr. Waldheim that he would not object, according to Wolfgang Petritsch, a spokesman for the Austrian Mission.   The issue has arisen amid Mr. Waldheim's campaign for the Austrian presidency, which has been marred by accusations that Mr. Waldheim has concealed his war record for 40 years.   The chief United Nations spokesman, Francois Giuliani, said the file would be made available to Austrian authorities, as well as to Israeli authorities who also requested the file, at the United Nations Archives at 345 Park Avenue South in Manhattan on Wednesday morning. Representatives from both Governments will be allowed to photocopy the documents, which, under United Nations rules, are to remain confidential.

headline: 'Legendary' Cowpoke To Sell a New Cigarette
abstract: Marketing people the world over know what the introduction of the cowboy to Philip Morris's Marlboro cigarette ads did for its sales.

headline: MEXICO REBUTS CHARGES BY U.S. ON DRUG FLOW
abstract: Mexican officials have rejected assertions by United States officials that Mexico is doing nothing to combat drug traffic across the border and that Mexico is not cooperating with American efforts to combat the drug flow.   Francisco Fonseca Notario, spokesman for the Mexican Attorney General, said Wednesday, ''Mexico has a permanent campaign against narcotics traffickers, and that campaign is going very well.''

headline: TURKEY ARRESTS 4, FOILING A BOMBING OF AMERICAN CLUB
abstract: Four Libyans were arrested in Turkey in connection with what was apparently a plot to attack a United States officers' club in Ankara, State Department officials said today.   According to officials here, two Libyans were stopped by Turkish policemen Friday night outside the club because they looked suspicious. One of them tried to throw away a bag containing grenades and other explosives as they sought to escape.   After their capture, the Turkish authorities picked up two more Libyans, a student and teacher, officials said.

headline: PRETORIA DIVESTMENT QUICKENS
abstract: The pace of withdrawal from South Africa by American companies has quickened, as some of the biggest corporations in the United States reconsider doing business in the economically and politically troubled country.   Last week, the General Motors Corporation, in a reversal of a stance it held for many years, said it would stop selling vehicles to South African military or police agencies.   In recent months, the leaders of other large corporations with major operations in South Africa, including the International Business Machines Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, have raised the possibility that they might end their operations there if business conditions continue to deteriorate.   At least 48 American companies have pulled out of South Africa since the beginning of last year, according to a study by the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a not-for-profit organization based in Washington that studies issues affecting investors and corporations. The center's report said that 38 United States companies ended their presence in South Africa in 1985 and that 10 have left so far this year. In 1984, seven United States companies left South Africa, the center said.

headline: THE TAKEOVER THREAT AT FAMILY NEWSPAPERS
abstract: Traditionally, the newspaper industry has functioned as a fraternity in which an unwelcome offer to acquire a newspaper was rare. And while that restraint remains the norm within the business, a new breed of buyer has emerged that suggests the old rules no longer apply.   In today's market, no communications company is too big to be swallowed by someone else, newspaper analysts and brokers say. Newspapers have routinely been reaping operating profits of 20 percent or more of revenues. That enviable record has attracted extraordinary interest in newspaper companies.

headline: 10 South Koreans Jailed For Sit-In at U.S. Center
abstract: Ten students were sentenced to jail terms of one year to three years today for occupying the United States Cultural Center in Kwangju in December, court officials said.   During the brief sit-in, the students denounced the United States' trade protectionism and its support for President Chun Doo Hwan.

headline: Avon Shifts Accounts To Ayer
abstract: N. W. AYER, the nation's oldest ad agency, celebrated its 117th anniversary yesterday with a nice increase in billings, thanks to a consolidation move by its client Avon.   Ayer had been playing second domestic agency after Ogilvy & Mather, which had 17 years in service to Avon, with about $7 million in billings compared with Ogilvy's $20 million.

headline: Leo Burnett Looking Internally for Growth
abstract: While all around them mergers and acquisitions are changing the face and the temper of the advertising business, the management of the agency that the late great Leo Burnett founded 51 years ago in Chicago will continue to do it his way.

headline: INDUSTRIES SEE BOTH WINNERS AND LOSERS IF BILL BECOMES LAW; PLANNING FOR RETIREMENT COULD CHANGE DRAMATICALLY
abstract: While business in general and many consumer groups say they are satisfied with the sweeping tax plan approved this week by the Senate Finance Committee, a number of trade and industry groups are starting to voice alarm over some of the plan's provisions.   Numerous tax deductions and incentives would be abolished or dramatically restricted by the plan, removing in some cases special protections that have benefited the groups for years.   The restaurant industry, for example, is worried that the proposed reduction of the deductibility of business meals and entertaining will hurt their business. And real estate syndicators foresee a sharp decline in investments if restrictions on tax benefits from paper losses go into effect. That, they say, could affect the nation's housing stock.

headline: Resorts Appoints President as Chief
abstract: Resorts International Inc., the hotel and gambling concern, has named its president, I.G. (Jack) Davis Jr., to the additional position of chief executive. Mr. Davis, 61 years old, succeeds James M. Crosby, the former chairman and chief executive, who died last week.   The company also said that Henry B. Murphy, Mr. Crosby's brother-in-law, had been elected chairman and that Charles E. Murphy, Mr. Murphy's first cousin, had been appointed to the board.   Henry Murphy is a funeral director in Trenton and Charles Murphy is a partner in Whitman & Ransom, the corporate counsel for Resorts.

headline: 4 More Are Killed In South African Strife
abstract: A policeman killed three black youths in Soweto and a bus driver was burned to death in overnight violence, the authorities said today.

headline: New Orders for Boeing
abstract: The Boeing Company said it had received orders worth $245 million. Sabena, the international airline of Belgium, ordered five 737-300 twinjets, for $125 million, and Martinair Holland ordered a $120 million 747-200-C convertible jumbo jet that can be used for cargo, passengers or a combination of them, Boeing said.

headline: Technical Data Signal Danger
abstract: ARE technical indicators flashing a correction ahead for the stock market?   A chart in a recent issue of the Merrill Lynch Market Letter shows that 85 percent of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange are above their 200-day moving averages of prices. This is up from about 40 percent when the rally began last fall.   Moving averages are statistical techniques used to smooth fluctuations in stock price movements to better show the underlying trend.

headline: European Prices Climb
abstract: Consumer prices in the 12-nation European Community rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March from the month before, its statistics office reported today. March prices were up 4.2 percent from a year earlier.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Stake in Fruehauf
abstract: A group led by the New York investor Asher Edelman said it holds 6.1 percent of the Fruehauf Corporation. Mr. Edelman has offered to buy the remaining Fruehauf common shares for $41 a share, or a total of more than $812 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman said that if the company did not accept his offer by the end of business Tuesday, he ''intends to seek control of the company through a proxy contest.''

headline: DEREGULATION
abstract: To the Editor:   Frederick Thayer's article ''The Emerging Dangers of Deregulation'' (Forum, Feb. 23) is, in important part, a triumph of preconceptions over facts.   Professor Thayer is willing to cite the dismaying statistic of an 18 percent increase in the number of trucking accidents between 1983 and 1984, but when he turns to air travel, he tells us only that ''statistics are virtually meaningless.''   Here are the annual average accident rates, all per 1,000,000 flights, for the five years immediately preceding deregulation and the seven years since, for domestic scheduled service.

headline: MANVILLE NAMES 4 OUTSIDE DIRECTORS TO ITS BOARD
abstract: The Manville Corporation yesterday announced the names of four more outside directors who will serve on its board after it emerges from protection under bankruptcy laws.   The company also identified eight current directors who will remain on the board. Manville had previously announced two other new board members, and in its statement yesterday the company said it would name one final director ''in the near future'' to complete the 15-member board.

headline: Barnett to Acquire Thrift Institution
abstract: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire the United First Federal Savings and Loan Association, a thrift institution based in Sarasota, Fla., for $116 million.

headline: Kalish & Rice Assigned Marcal Paper Business
abstract: Kalish & Rice Advertising of Philadelphia, one of the Earle Palmer Browne Companies, has been tapped by Marcal Paper Mills to do advertising for its institutional paper products, which last year billed close to $1 million.   The parent company got its foot in the door through its Brown Design and Promotion unit, which began working for Marcal last year. Venet Advertising previously had the account.

headline: REAGAN PRESSES HARD FOR CONTRA AID
abstract: President Reagan today renewed his drive for $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, saying that the failure to finance their effort to overthrow the Sandinistas could mean a ''divided war-torn region with Nicaragua as a refuge for terrorism.''   Mr. Reagan, expressing strong doubt about Managua's interest in a negotiated peace settlement with the rebels, suggested that the House of Representatives was ''falling victim'' to a Nicaraguan Government strategy of seeking to delay such a peace agreement while it destroys all internal opposition.   The Administration has argued that the aid is necessary to put pressure on Managua to negotiate with the rebels.   ''The strategy of the Sandinistas should now be clear to everyone,'' Mr. Reagan said to a group of Republican candidates and elected officials at the White House. ''It's a strategy of delay, dragging out negotiations, never taking a serious position so they can wipe out their opposition, while Congress waits to see if a peace treaty is around the corner.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * General Telephone Company of Calif. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $600 million of first mortgage bonds.    * Gillette Co. is issuing 55 million European Currency Units of 7 1/2 percent Eurobonds due 1993 at 100 1/4 through Banque Paribas Capital Markets.

headline: Macy's Buyout Backed by Vote
abstract: Stockholders of R. H. Macy & Company approved a $3.7 billion management buyout proposal yesterday by a vote of 40.4 million shares, or 78.3 percent of the shares outstanding, to 885,800 shares. Two-thirds of the shares outstanding were needed to approve the $68-a-share cash offer.

headline: THE RACE FOR SQUEEZABLE KETCHUP
abstract: PLASTICS had a lot to overcome before they made it into food packaging. They used to leach chemicals into the foods or liquids they contained. And they were associated with cheapness and tackiness, certainly not images food companies wanted to convey for their products.

headline: Bethlehem's Chief Adds Job
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that Walter F. Williams, its president and chief executive, had been elected to the additional post of chairman.   Mr. Williams, 57 years old, replaces Donald H. Trautlein, 59, who plans to retire this Saturday. Mr. Williams has been president of Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest steelmaker, since 1980 and chief executive since March, when he succeeded Mr. Trautlein.   Mr. Trautlein became chief executive in 1980 and led the company during a time of heavy retrenchment. Mr. Williams has spent his entire career at Bethlehem, having joined the company in 1951 in the engineering department.

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF SLIGHTLY IN MONTH
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was off slightly by 325,088 shares, in the month ended April 15, to 318.3 million shares. The record of 318.6 million shares was set the previous month. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 223.5 million shares.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange rose 4.5 million shares, to 29.3 million shares.   A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI TANK BUILDUP
abstract: Israel has sent a large number of tanks into a zone under its control in southern Lebanon, apparently to counter what was described as redeployment of Syrian forces in Lebanon's eastern Bekaa region, Lebanese radio and television reports said today.  [ There was no confirmation of the reported tank deployments from Israeli officials. ]  The Lebanese radio and television reports said as many as 50 Israeli tanks escorted by helicopter gunships had taken up positions in the Arkub region on the slopes of Mount Hermon.

headline: REAGAN REBUFFS MARCOS IN CLAIM TO THE PRESIDENCY
abstract: President Reagan has gently, but firmly, rejected an assertion by Ferdinand E. Marcos that he is still the rightful President of the Philippines, White House officials said today.   The two men spoke by telephone Saturday, soon after Mr. Reagan arrived here on the second day of his 13-day trip to the Far East for a meeting with Southeast Asian foreign ministers in Indonesia and for the annual economic summit meeting in Tokyo starting next Sunday.  [ Mr. Marcos, in a telephone call hours later to his supporters in Manila, said, ''I am ready to fight,'' and told them to keep demonstrating on his behalf but to avoid violence. Mr. Marcos did not refer to his talk with President Reagan. Page A11. ]  Reagan Ready for Assertion The Marcos-Reagan phone conversation was the first direct contact between the two men since Mr. Marcos fled the Philippines on Feb. 25.

headline: Spy's Plan for Prison Escape In Oslo Is Thwarted by Friend
abstract: A plan to whisk a convicted spy out of an Oslo jail to West Africa has led to three arrests, the police said today.   The police said a Gambian imprisoned with the spy, Arne Treholt, on drug smuggling charges and a 17-year-old woman Mr. Treholt met at another prison during his trial were being held by police on suspicion of helping to plan the escape.

headline: RATES RISE SHARPLY ON BILLS, BONDS
abstract: Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as comments by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, about potential problems on the inflation front injected new anxiety into an already battered credit market.   By late afternoon, the rate on three-month Treasury bills was 6.52 percent, up from 6.41 percent at the close of trading on Tuesday, and the rate on six-month bills was 6.55 percent, up from 6.47 percent. The rate for the one-year bill was 6.60 percent, up from 6.54 percent. Interest rates on long-term and intermediate bonds, which had also shot up as prices tumbled well over a point in response to Mr. Volcker's comments, recovered somewhat later in the afternoon.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Arms Talks
abstract: United States-Soviet arms talks continued today, with a regular weekly session between negotiating groups on long-range strategic nuclear weapons.

headline: END THE CHARADE ON THIRD WORLD DEBT
abstract: FIDEL Castro is right. The third world debt should be renounced.   However, it is the United States that should take the initiative and unilaterally forgive the debt.   By realistically acknowledging what is by now inevitable, we could preclude or limit the financial chaos and political grudges that would follow abrupt defaults by one or several of the major debtor nations. In fact, an American initiative could benefit both lenders and borrowers.

headline: ISRAELIS SEEM SPLIT ON INQUIRY INTO COVER-UP
abstract: Major differences appear to be developing between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir over how to deal with the growing scandal in Israel's domestic intelligence service, Government sources said today.   The differences have potentially serious political implications. Under the national unity Government's coalition agreement, Mr. Peres, the leader of the Labor Party, is expected to switch jobs in October with Mr. Shamir, who leads the Likud bloc. However, according to Israeli press reports, there are increasing indications that any commission of inquiry might find Mr. Shamir to have been part of an extensive intelligence cover-up of the slayings of two captured Palestinian terrorists in April 1984.

headline: A TAX ACCOUNTANT'S FINEST HOUR
abstract: YOUR next week will be filled with happiness and mirth,'' a Chinese fortune cookie informed Stuart Kessler a week ago. Mr. Kessler knew better. He is the senior tax partner at the accounting firm of Goldstein Golub Kessler, and what filled his week was something between 100 and 140 individual tax returns.   These are the closing days of the tax season, culminating with a down-to-the-wire finish tomorrow. For some taxpayers it is an anxious time of last-minute calculations, urgent telephone calls to accountants and grudging check-writing to the Internal Revenue Service. But for New York's approximately 5,000 C.P.A.'s, it is the finest hour. ''It's part of the drama of being a C.P.A.,'' said Eli Mason, an accountant who runs the National Conference of C.P.A. Practitioners, a group of medium-sized firms. ''Accountants really psych themselves up for it.''

headline: WHAT MARRIOTT SEES IN SAGA
abstract: The Saga Corporation, a big name in campus dining halls, is inching close to a business recovery, analysts say, but it may not wait around for it.   Directors of the Menlo Park, Calif., company met today to consider the Marriott Corporation's acquisition offer of $34 a share in cash, totaling about $435 million, but the company later said the board had not reached any decision. The directors said they needed extra time ''to consider the Marriott offer as well as other alternatives.''   Securities analysts expect the operator of restaurants and contract food services to hold out for a better price, suggesting that something closer to $40 a share would probably be tempting. Saga shares closed today at $37.625 on the New York Stock Exchange, up $1.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Jesse Helms Proposal On Arms Pact Deferred
abstract: Senate critics and proponents of the 1979 strategic arms treaty today deferred efforts to have the Senate vote on the unratified treaty.   The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided to postpone consideration of a proposal by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, to send the treaty to the floor without recommendation.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Another Discount Drop?   The Federal Reserve Board's recent cut in the discount rate - what it charges on loans to member banks - has economists debating the likelihood of another reduction.   The rate is now 6.5 percent, the lowest since May 1978. But today's sluggish economy needs even more stimulus, says Edward S. Hyman, vice chairman of Cyrus J. Lawrence, and that may force the Fed to lower the discount rate again. ''The rate ought to be 6 percent to be in line with the current environment,'' he said, ''and to stimulate the economy it should be a notch lower, about 5.5 percent.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: NATO FAULTS U.S. ON INTENT TO DROP 1979 ARMS TREATY
abstract: Britain, West Germany, Canada and other NATO allies expressed alarm today over President Reagan's decision to stop adhering to the terms of a 1979 strategic arms accord unless there is a major change in Soviet policy.   According to participants in talks here among the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Secretary of State George P. Shultz found himself isolated in defending the American decision.   In announcing the decision Tuesday, Mr. Reagan said the United States would destroy two old submarines, which would keep it within the treaty limits for the next few months. But he said that when more cruise missiles are deployed on B-52 bombers later in the year, the United States would no longer destroy older missiles to stay within the limits.

headline: POLE CITES SUBVERSION BY WEST
abstract: A general in the Polish secret police charged today that Poles were being trained at bases in the West, including one in New Jersey, for sabotage and terrorist attacks against Poland.   He also asserted that Western intelligence agencies had tried to send explosives and guns that resembled pens and radios to opposition groups in Poland.   The accusations were made by Gen. Wladyslaw Pozoga, the deputy head of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, in an interview published in Rzeczpospolita, the Government daily.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Adam I. Friedman & Associates, Greenwich, Conn., and Kanan, Corbin, Shupak & Aronow, New York, have merged to form KCS&A/Adam I. Friedman Group, a public relations firm.

headline: ROCKETS FIRED AT PALACE, SITE OF SUMMIT WELCOME
abstract: Penetrating the extraordinary security surrounding the economic summit meeting, attackers today fired five homemade rockets at the state guest house during welcoming ceremonies there for the leaders of the industrial nations meeting in Tokyo.   The rockets overshot their mark, the Akasaka Palace, landing on the street and on buildings near the Canadian Embassy, south of the palace grounds.   No one was hurt, but several strollers near the embassy said they had barely missed being struck by falling projectiles. The missiles, which were fired from an apartment house about two miles from the palace, were set off by a timing device, the police said.

headline: Chemical in Deal To Buy Jersey Bank
abstract: In a major push to become an interstate bank, the Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the Horizon Bancorp once interstate banking between New York and New Jersey becomes legal.   The agreement is apparently the first to combine major banks from the two states and could eventually lead to a situation in which Chemical could have more than 100 branches in New Jersey. Horizon is New Jersey's fifth-largest bank-holding company.

headline: A MIDRISE CO-OP PROJECT IS GOING-UP IN BAY RIDGE
abstract: There is a little corner of the Bay Ridge community in Brooklyn on which James C. Gherardi, a builder based in Flushing, Queens, has been putting his own strong stamp in the last few years. He is in the midst of his second project there.   The first was a 225-unit town-house development called Water's View at Verrazano, now complete. The current project has 106 modest-sized apartments in two side-by-side midrise buildings, named Hamilton House, at the corner of Fourth Avenue and 101st Street, across the street from the town houses. Occupancy is scheduled to start in June.

headline: Tanzania Lions Kill 10 in '86
abstract: Lions have killed 10 people in southwestern Tanzania since January, the Government-owned Radio Tanzania reported today. It quoted Boniface Poja, chief of the Ruvuma region, as saying the 10th victim, an unidentified man, was killed this week near the village of Mlingoti.

headline: Natural Gas Pricing Vote
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission voted unanimously in principle today to raise price ceilings on most of the nation's supply of so-called old natural gas.   The four-member commission told its staff to redraft provisions that would govern when pipelines must transport gas covered by the preliminary vote.

headline: JAPANESE CENTRAL BANK TAKING POLITICAL HEAT
abstract: The Bank of Japan is normally not a subject taken up by the Japanese tabloids. But some weeks ago, a magazine known for its tantalizing photos of starlets published a two-page spread on a high-ranking bank official, complete with a fuzzy picture of the official walking his dog.   ''The schemer of the high yen,'' read the headline - an indication of the increasing attention paid to the nation's central bank after its efforts helped to raise the yen's value against the dollar.   While the bank has been accorded respect by officials overseas for intervention efforts that brought the dollar lower against the yen than any other foreign currency, in Japan, it has been the object of political heat generated by the adverse effects of the strong yen - more expensive exports and lower corporate profits.

headline: Programs That Design Chips
abstract: WILL computers be used to design other computers? That is the purpose of computer systems that design computer chips. The systems are known as silicon compilers -programs that act like a trusted assistant. Give the compilers a general idea of what you want them to do and they will take care of the details.   But despite much ballyhoo, silicon compilers have failed to catch on as fast as expected, according to analysts and vendors. One reason, perhaps surprisingly, is that electronics engineers can be as reluctant as anyone else to adapt to computers.

headline: THE U.S. DENIES PUTTING PRESSURE ON HONDURANS
abstract: The Reagan Administration today denied assertions by a senior Honduran official that the United States had deliberately exaggerated the seriousness of Nicaragua's recent border raid, and had pressed Honduras to ask for $20 million in emergency aid.   Both the White House and the State Department said the statements by the unidentified Honduran ''come as a surprise to us, especially in view of their deviation from the facts and from the public and private position of the Honduran Government.''   The Ambassador in Honduras, John Ferch, was instructed to seek ''a clarification'' from President Jose Azcona about the allegations. A State Department official said later that Mr. Azcona had told Mr. Ferch that the statements made by the senior official had not been cleared by him.

headline: FIERY 'NECKLACE' BECOMES EMBLEM OF DEEPENING SOUTH AFRICAN VIOLENCE
abstract: The image is stark in its familiarity.   A person is taken by a crowd and a used automobile tire is placed around his neck. The tire is filled with gasoline and ignited. The person dies, and a statistic is added to the nation's pain.   If South Africa's unrest over the last 21 months has acquired its own harsh emblem, it is the form of fiery execution called ''the necklace'' - the retribution meted out usually by those who call themselves ''comrades'' as part of what the Government calls a revolutionary onslaught against white rule.

headline: Utility Company Head Faces New Challenge
abstract: AZP Group Inc. had not considered acquiring a financial institution when it restructured itself just last year, according to the chairman of the utility holding company, Keith L. Turley.   But a few weeks ago it was approached by Merabank, Arizona's largest savings bank. Merabank thought it was likely to be taken over, and sought AZP as a friendly partner. Before long AZP agreed to buy the thrift unit for $440 million.

headline: COLOMBIAN VICTOR: VIRGILIO BARCO VARGAS
abstract: In the final stages of Virgilio Barco Vargas's successful bid for the Colombian presidency, local wits had it that the candidate was at last relaxing: When he ended speeches with three ''vivas'' to the Liberal Party, they said, he read two of them and improvised the third.   The joke, though, was not out of place. Mr. Barco, a civil engineer by training and a meticulous technocrat by instinct, leaves little to chance.   On Sunday evening, long after Alvaro Gomez Hurtado of the Conservative Party had conceded defeat, aides said Mr. Barco sat crouched over a computer analyzing the latest returns rather than socializing with the political chiefs who had come to congratulate him.   A poor public speaker with little personal flair, he had built his campaign around the methodical strategy of uniting the Liberal Party and then traveling to every corner of Colombia. He made few promises along the way.

headline: ROSTENKOWSKI OFFERS TO TRADE ON TAX RATE
abstract: Presenting the opening bargaining position of the House tax negotiators, Representative Dan Rostenkowski said today that he would agree to stick close to the Senate's top 27 percent rate if senators agreed to a bigger tax cut for the middle class and to higher corporate taxes.   Mr. Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, identified a number of corporate tax benefits retained in the Senate bill that could be scaled back in order to accommodate both the House objective of cutting taxes more for middle-income families and the Senate's desire for lower rates.   The list included special tax benefits for oil and gas drillers and military contractors, the deduction for bad debt reserves at large banks, depeciation write-offs for machinery and equipment, and provisions that now encourage corporate takeovers.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA PLACES CURFEW ON 11 MORE TOWNSHIPS
abstract: The Government announced today that curfews would be imposed in 11 more magisterial districts in the Orange Free State, bringing to at least 600,000 the number of South African blacks living under such formal restrictions.   Shortly after issuing an emergency decree on June 12, the authorities ordered curfews in black townships in 13 magisterial disricts in the restive Eastern Cape, including the city of Port Elizabeth, whose segregated black townships are home to hundreds of thousands of people.   Then, with little publicity, the authorities ordered major curfew restrictions on the movement of blacks in the so-called tribal homeland of KwaNdebele, north of Pretoria. The area has been riven by fighting between rival black groups over an official plan to declare the homeland nominally independent of Pretoria in December.

headline: TAMING THE LATEST INSURANCE 'CRISIS'
abstract: THE latest liability insurance ''crisis,'' like its predecessors, is widely attributed to overly generous juries and court decisions expanding manufacturers' liability. As in the preceding ''crisis,'' in 1975, little is said about the fundamental cause - the sharp ups and downs of the insurance industry's profit cycle.   The gradual expansion of legal liability and the profit cycle are distinct phenomena and should be treated separately. The former has not caused rates to increase dramatically; the profit cycle has. Thus, limiting liability and restricting jury awards will not avert future insurance squeezes, but flattening the insurance cycle will.

headline: OFFICIAL IN ISRAEL FOCUS OF INQUIRY IN '84 COVER-UP
abstract: The Attorney General of Israel has asked the police to examine evidence that the head of the domestic intelligence organization covered up the involvement of his agency in the beating deaths of two Palestinian bus hijackers two years ago, Israeli officials and press reports said today.   The Attorney General's request for an investigation was made two weeks ago. It was said to have been accompanied by evidence collected against Avraham Shalom, the head of the Shin Beth, the domestic security service that is the equivalent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.   Israeli newspapers said the evidence suggested that Mr. Shalom might have tampered with evidence, suborned witnesses and withheld relevant documents from two commissions of inquiry that were convened in 1984 and 1985 to investigate the killings.

headline: FOCUS ON LATIN FLIGHT OF CAPITAL
abstract: The investigation of Antonio Gebauer and his handling of Brazilian accounts at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has focused new attention on the broader question of capital flight from Latin America, an issue that has assumed increasing importance in the context of the region's four-year-old debt crisis.   News of the case, which has involved allegations of the diversion of as much as $6 million in deposits, has shocked the many friends and critics here of the banker, who has had dealings with Brazil over the past 15 years. Mr. Gebauer has indicated he will contest the allegations.   Intense coverage by newspapers, radio and television has treated the case as a major scandal. But the presence of ''undeclared'' Brazilian deposits in New York has not come as a surprise.

headline: Dow Up by 9.50 Points, to 1,885.05
abstract: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday for the second consecutive day on hopes of lower interest rates. They ended within a point of record territory.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which of late has vacillated in concert with stock-index futures and programmed trading, ended 9.50 points higher at 1,885.05, just below the record 1,885.90 set on June 6.

headline: Advertising; Alfa Romeo Focuses On Power
abstract: POWER. That's the name of the game. Power as reflected in an executive behind his desk. Several more watching a presentation. A man firing a pistol. Another leaping in the long jump. A baseball player hitting the long ball. A shot-putter. More big operators on the phone.  Film snippets of all of these events appear in a 45-second strip that the Bloom Agency in New York created to identify the target audience of the cars that its client, Alfa Romeo, wants to sell.   ''I love it when you can take a characteristic of a target audience and marry it with an identical characteristic in a product,'' Penny Hawkey, president and creative director of the agency said, as she disclosed the new advertising theme line, ''Power in the hands of a few.''

headline: CONTROL DATA REPORTS WIDER LOSS IN QUARTER
abstract: The Control Data Corporation, the troubled computer manufacturer, said today that losses for the first quarter more than doubled, to $21.2 million, from $9.2 million, a year earlier.   In its computer segment, Control Data, based in Bloomington, Minn., said losses widened to $42.6 million, from $11.5 million, a year earlier.

headline: Conviction in Treason Case
abstract: A 44-year-old linguist was sentenced to 10 years in prison today on a treason conviction. Helene Passtoors, a Belgian and Dutch citizen, was convicted of helping to set up arms caches for the African National Congress and of trying to arrange an escape from South Africa for a congress member. Klaas De Jonge, who was arrested with her last June, escaped from police custody and has been holed up since then in the Dutch Embassy in Pretoria.

headline: WITH RASKOLNIKOV, RETRACING 730 HEINOUS STEPS
abstract: ''On an exceptionally hot evening early in July a young man came out of the garret in which he lodged in S. Place and walked slowly, as though in hesitation, towards K. Bridge.''   So begins ''Crime and Punishment,'' Fyodor Dostoyevsky's classic novel of murder and guilt. For more than a century readers throughout the world have followed the impoverished, radical student, Raskolnikov, on the twisted route from his hovel to the ax-murder of a wretched pawnbroker, and on to repentance and confession.   It is a trail through the depths of one of the most intriguing psyches ever created by a novelist. And for Leningraders, it is a route that begins at the garret of 9 Stolyarny Place (now Przhevalsky Street) and turns toward Kokushkin Bridge over the Griboyedov Canal, a winding waterway named Yekaterinsky Canal before the Revolution but more commonly known as the ''ditch.''

headline: BRITISH OFFICIAL MEETS SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER
abstract: A senior British Government official met in London yesterday with Oliver Tambo, the acting president of the African National Congress, the most prominent of the groups seeking the overthrow of the South African Government.   Mr. Tambo's meeting with Lynda Chalker, a Minister of State at the Foreign Office, was seen as a turning point in British Government policy toward the group, which is outlawed in South Africa. The Thatcher Government previously had refused to meet with African National Congress leaders unless the group renounced violence.   ''This meeting may lead to further high-level talks,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said, adding: ''It is the first time we have had such a meeting with Mr. Tambo. It is significant and we are glad he accepted the invitation to meet Mrs. Chalker.'' The substance of the discussion was not disclosed.

headline: BEAMED AT THE EAST BLOC: NEWS, COMMENT, THE ARTS
abstract: Operating from a white barrackslike structure not far from the graceful English Garden in Munich, Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe beam news broadcasts, analysis, commentary and entertainment in 22 languages to the Soviet Union and countries under its sway.   Radio Free Europe, which was founded in 1950 at the peak of the cold war, broadcasts to Eastern Europe. Its sister station, Radio Liberty, founded a year later, aims its programs at the Soviet Union, and last October a channel aimed at Afghanistan was added.

headline: STALIN DAUGHTER SET TO LEAVE
abstract: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, said today that she had received permission from the Government to leave the Soviet Union once again and planned to do so before the end of the month.   ''I requested permission to leave and I got it,'' she said.   She added that her daughter, Olga Peters, had also received approval to leave and expected to return to school in England in the near future.   In a brief telephone interview from her Moscow hotel, Miss Alliluyeva said she did not know whether she would ever return to the Soviet Union again.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 14, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The Senate voted to remove from the tax bill an advantage that would apply to only one oil company. The preference would have given Unocal a $50 million tax break to help offset the debt it took on last year in successfully fighting a takeover attempt by T. Boone Pickens. It was the first element of the Finance Committee's bill to be rejected by the Senate. The vote was 60 to 33. Senators agreed that the vote posed no threat to the main elements of the bill, which they expect to pass next week.  [ Page 1. ]    Industrial output fell a substantial 0.6 percent in May, the Federal Reserve said, suggesting a more sluggish economic outlook than previously indicated. The Fed said the decline was ''widespread,'' reflecting the oil and gas downturn as well as lower output of cars and trucks, business equipment and other durable goods.  [ 33. ]  Business sales rose 1.4 percent in April, the first increase since December and the strongest gain in eight months. But total business inventories edged up 0.3 percent. Economists said weak demand was making it hard for businesses to work down stockpiles.  [ 36. ]

headline: U.N. LETS U.S. SEE FILE ON WALDHEIM
abstract: The United Nations today permitted the United States to examine a secret United Nations War Crimes Commission file on former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.   At the same, it gave Israel access to two other secret files today.   The Waldheim file was made available to the deputy American delegate, Herbert S. Okun, at the United Nations archives at 345 Park Avenue South near 25th Street, after a formal request by the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations. The file, which was made available Wednesday to Israeli and Austrian officials, was forwarded to the State Department for examination.

headline: Kodak Staff Cuts
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company told shareholders at its annual meeting that its United States work force had been cut by 6,000 workers as of the beginning of May. It said the move was part of a program to cut the number of employees by 10 percent. The move will reduce Kodak's 1986 earnings by 60 cents a share, but the company said it would save $400 million a year as a result of the staff reduction.

headline: Advertising; Geer, DuBois Wins Jaguar
abstract: Jaguar Cars of Leonia, N.J., has chosen Geer, DuBois as the new agency for the British made, costly autos.   The budget is easily $15 million.

headline: Soviet Economy
abstract: To the Editor:   The experience of the past two decades indicates that the Soviet command economy is not a viable mechanism (''A Threat to Soviet Economic Reform,'' Forum, May 4). Because of technological advance and growth in size, the Soviet economy has become much too complex to be effectively and efficiently run from above.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: ENVOY ADMITS VISITING LIBYA IN 1985
abstract: The American Ambassador to the Vatican, William A. Wilson, said today that he had visited Libya in November. He denied reports from Administration officials that he was in Libya early this year after the terrorist attacks on the Rome and Vienna airports.   Mr. Wilson. a friend of President Reagan who announced his resignation last month after his dealings with Libya were disclosed, said through a spokesman that the November visit had been his ''one and only one trip'' to Libya. He said that he then broke off contacts with Libya at the request of the State Department.

headline: TRAVEL AGENTS PROMOTE 'SAFER' TRIPS
abstract: Airlines, cruise operators and travel agents, responding to cancellations from travelers nervous about visiting Europe and the Middle East, say they are beginning to offer incentives or divert travelers to other destinations rather than lose business altogether.   Trans World Airlines has waived cancellation penalties on tickets for international flights and on ground excursions organized by the airline, through May 5. Pan American World Airways said it might move planes from Europe to the United States and discount fares for flights into southern Europe by 20 to 35 percent if the situation worsens.   Sun Line Cruises restationed its 620-passenger flagship to New York from Athens this week, but the line said it would offer passengers on its two remaining Greek-based vessels free shore tours, which normally cost as much as $350 a person.

headline: Dow Off 7.14; Volcker Remark Cited
abstract: Stock prices dropped moderately on Wall Street yesterday and trading volume remained weak as investors, worried about a statement on inflation made by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, decided that it was time to take profits.   Also damaging the market's chance of extending its one-day advance was severe weakness in the price of I.B.M., whose shares have been climbing steadily since it announced a plan last week to repurchase some of its own stock. I.B.M. fell 2 3/4, to 150, and was the fourth-most-active issue, as 1.4 million of its shares traded.   With I.B.M. in the lead, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.14 points, to 1,863.29.

headline: JAPAN ELECTIONS ARE CALLED LIKELY
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone seems increasingly likely to dissolve the Japanese Parliament soon and hold national elections in late June, members of his ruling Liberal Democratic Party say.   Mr. Nakasone, who returned tonight from Washington after two days of talks with President Reagan, has said several times that he has no such plan. But fellow politicians say they assume an election is imminent, and some have already put up wall posters and returned to home districts to campaign.   They say they believe the Prime Minister, seeking to take advantage of uncommon popular support, will dissolve the decision-making lower chamber of Parliament, the House of Representatives, and call an election. They said this would be done to coincide with a vote that must be held for the less significant upper chamber, the House of Councilors.

headline: Iranian President Calls For Demilitarized Gulf
abstract: Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, said today that he would like to see the Persian Gulf demilitarized, the Teheran radio reported.

headline: Warnaco Gets Improved Bid
abstract: The W Acquisition Corporation, an investor group based in Encino, Calif., yesterday increased its bid for Warnaco Inc. for the second time, by offering offered $44 a share in cash, or about $448.8 million, for the leading apparel maker.   ''Our new offer comes in response to market increases in the company's stock,'' said Andrew G. Galef, chairman of W Acquisition.

headline: Your Money; Retirees Adjust To Rate Drops
abstract: WHEN Emanuel Raices, a New York executive, retired about three years ago, interest rates that could be earned by the small investor and saver were a lot higher than they are today. So he put a large portion of his assets in money market mutual funds and enjoyed the luxury of double-digit rates.   Since then, however, yields in the money markets have dropped well into the single-digit range and Mr. Raices, who now lives in Newtown, Conn., has changed the nature of his investments.   ''I bought Ginnie Mae funds and some Government securities funds,'' he said. ''I'm at the stage of life and time where income is more important to me. If I can keep a little bit ahead of the average, I'm in good shape.''

headline: GIMBELS AT 86th: A BORN LOSER
abstract: After Gimbel Brothers Inc. decided in 1968 to build a store on the upper edge of Manhattan's Upper East Side, officials of the company described the neighborhood as ''the richest suburb in the world.''   But when the store opened four years later on Lexington Avenue at 86th Street, it became evident to the Gimbels management and to other retailers that the new store was just as close to East Harlem, one of the city's poorest communities, as it was to one of Manhattan's wealthiest neighborhoods.   With its L-shaped footprint straddling the line between wealth and poverty, the store never managed to establish its own identity, much less remake the neighborhood around it into a fashionable shopping district as the company had hoped. And its repeated failure to attract shoppers was indicative of the company's irreversible decline, first out of the hands of the Gimbel family and now on its way out of business altogether.
