Real Estate Move    After months of trying to find a buyer who would continue to operate the 86th Street outlet as a retail store, Batus Inc., the owner of Gimbels since 1974, has decided to sell it and the flagship store at 33d Street and the Avenue of the Americas for real estate development.

headline: U.S. Home Sets Restructuring
abstract: The U.S. Home Corporation, one of the nation's largest single-family home builders, said today that it was undertaking a comprehensive restructuring that would result in a ''substantial'' loss for its second quarter.   The company said it would establish a one-time reserve of $120 million to $130 million with an after-tax loss of between $70 million and $80 million as a result of the restructuring. U.S. Home lost $1.8 million on revenues of $185 million in the first quarter of this year, and expects a loss for the year.

headline: VACANT 7 YEARS, A PRIME FIFTH AVE. CORNER IS LEASED
abstract: The three-level retail space at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 52d Street that has stood empty for seven years was leased last week to a New York-based development company that plans to fill it by Christmas.   The lessee is Transworld Equities, whose principals include Richard E. Carroll and Jack Laboz. Transworld is taking the entire 25,000 square feet, which is in 650 Fifth Avenue, a sleek, 36-story granite-and-glass office tower.   Mr. Carroll said the company was considering several options, including the creation of an eclectic mix of shops featuring clothing, jewelry and accessories. Another plan calls for a design that would have men's and women's shops on one level, a restaurant on another and a jewelry market on a third. Under a third plan, the developers said, they might put in a mall in which all of the space would be devoted to the sale of jewelry and precious stones.

headline: Advertising; Del Laboratories Adds TBWA to Its Roster
abstract: Del Laboratories of Farmingdale, L.I., which spends about $10 million a year on advertising, announced yesterday that it was adding TBWA Advertising to its agency roster.

headline: Dow Slips 1.99 Amid Light Trading
abstract: Still wrestling with the outlook for interest rates and oil prices, the stock market continued its downturn yesterday as prices sagged a bit for the second consecutive day of light trading.   The big story, however, was the thrashing given to the stocks of companies that are considered takeover candidates. Traders blamed the insider trading scheme involving Dennis B. Levine for the decline in issues such as American Brands, which dropped 4 3/8, to 88 5/8. Mr. Levine, until Monday, had been a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: The U.N. Today: April 29, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Building Contracts Off
abstract: The value of new construction contracts awarded in May fell 9 percent to a seasonally adjusted rate of $226.25 billion, from April's rate of $248.73 billion, according to the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc.

headline: T.W.A. TRIMS CAIRO RUNS
abstract: Trans World Airlines, troubled by two terrorist incidents in the last year. is planning to close down its connections from Cairo to Athens and Rome.   T.W.A.'s flights to Cairo are to be routed through Paris or Frankfurt beginning later this month.

headline: LUGAR ASKS MORE FOR MANILA
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the United States should show its support for the new Philippine Government by providing $100 million more in aid than the Reagan Administration has sought.   ''More is involved here than simply an infusion of economic resources,'' the committee chairman, Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said as the panel opened hearings on additional aid to the Philippines.

headline: DRUG ISSUE PUBLICIZED BY SOVIET
abstract: After long portraying drug addiction as a curse of the West, the Soviet press has acknowledged a growing problem at home.   ''Drug addiction is a new problem for us,'' wrote the youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda in an article Sunday. The article offered readers a glimpse of a previously concealed world of poppy poaching, white powders hidden in toothpaste tubes, glue-sniffing, pill-popping, agonizing cold turkey and other aspects of drug abuse.   The fact that drugs have found their way into Soviet youth culture, even if on a scale nowhere near approaching the West, is hardly a surprise for most street-wise Russians. The novelty is the decision to make the public aware of its dangers and scope.

headline: L.F. Rothschild Net Up 84%
abstract: L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc., the investment banking firm that went public last month, said yesterday that its net income rose 84 percent in the first quarter, to $13.8 million, or 94 cents a share, from $7.5 million, or 54 cents a share, the year before.   Revenues rose 70 percent, to $129.8 million, from $76.4 million.

headline: WHERE SEARS HAS STUMBLED
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, has pushed hard in recent years to persuade its huge customer base to use its new brokerage and real estate businesses. But in seeking to diversify beyond shirts, stoves and stereos, many analysts say, Sears has paid too little attention to its roots and left the retailing foundation of its empire vulnerable.   Lower-price chains like Wal-Mart and such regional discounters as Crazy Eddie and Highland Superstores have wooed customers away from Sears. Product loyalty has eroded, with many shoppers now shunning the Sears and Kenmore house brands in favor of sexier names, like Sony or Esprit, that are not sold at the company's 800 department stores. And Sears's cumbersome distribution system has become an expensive drag on operations.   The result has been six consecutive quarters of flat retail sales and a steep drop in operating income in the company's merchandising division -it fell to $447 million last year, from $656 million in 1984. Sears's troubles have been dramatic enough to prompt talk that the K Mart Corporation, the nation's No. 2 retailer, might soon take over the top spot.

headline: A VEXING ISSUE IN AD MERGERS
abstract: On Madison Avenue, the gospel has always been that if you help Procter & Gamble sell Ivory soap, you cannot tout Colgate toothpaste - much less Palmolive soap - for Procter's archrival, the Colgate-Palmolive Company.   Rules against conflicts of that sort have long been a part of the symbiotic relationship between advertising agencies and their clients, and a key point of contention.   Advertisers and agencies alike have now been forced to take another look at the issue in light of the continuing consolidation of the major ad agencies and the mergers in recent years of such marketers as Philip Morris and General Foods, R. J. Reynolds and Nabisco, and Procter & Gamble and Richardson-Vicks.   Strict policies on conflicts of interest have been stretched, sometimes to the breaking point, by the wave of combinations. The shift in the rules has yet to reach the point where Hertz and Avis can be found sharing an agency, but clients and agencies agree that policies against conflicts are loosening.

headline: COMMUNIST PARTY RAIDED IN JORDAN
abstract: The Government was reported today to have arrested the leadership of Jordan's Communist Party in a move widely seen here as an effort to fix blame for a recent student protest that was violently put down by the police.   The protest erupted last week in this town 100 miles north of Amman, and official reports say three students were killed and 18 people wounded.   But according to widespread rumors the death toll was much higher. These could not be confirmed by either official or unofficial sources.

headline: OTHERS EXPECTED TO JOIN MERRILL IN RATE INCREASE
abstract: Discount brokers and analysts said yesterday that they expect most major brokers to emulate a move by Merrill Lynch & Company to raise its retail commission rates. Merrill Lynch announced that it would increase its rates by an average of 5 percent on stocks and stock options trades involving less than $10,000 starting June 20.   Other full-service brokerage houses reached yesterday said only that they were studying Merrill Lynch's action. But Wall Street analysts, while surprised that Merrill's increase was limited to smaller transactions, said that pressure on profits would cause other brokers to follow suit.

headline: Advertising; JWT Group Chairman Has Wonderful News
abstract: The JWT Group, parent of J. Walter Thompson, did a strange and wonderful thing at its annual meeting yesterday. It made news, most of which was reported by Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive.

headline: Bolivian Debt Talks
abstract: Bolivia said today that it would open negotiations concerning the $650 million it owes to more than 120 foreign private banks.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $1.75 billion, to $224.67 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Washington Watch; Halliburton's Libyan Taxes
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service charges that the Halliburton Company improperly deducted on its 1979 tax return $5.7 million in taxes the oil-service company paid to Libya. The allegation is part of an I.R.S. notice that the company owes more than $32 million in back taxes for 1977 to 1979.   Halliburton, seeking to overturn the claim in the United States Tax Court, argues that it would have ''no effective and practicable administrative remedies'' to seek a tax refund in Tripoli.

headline: PATENTS; A SECURITY FEATURE IN WRITING CHECKS
abstract: Terrence F. Kehoe, president of the National Financial Automation Corporation of Milford, Conn., has invented a machine-readable check with a security feature that prevents alterations.

headline: MILLIONS IN CONTRA AID MISUSED, G.A.O. SAYS
abstract: Congressional investigators asserted today that millions of dollars in American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels had instead been funneled into offshore banks, paid to the Honduran military or kept in the United States.   The money was said to have been earmarked for non-arms aid to the rebels, known as contras.   The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found that one broker for the rebels had received $3.3 million from the United States Government but had sent only $150,000 to Central America.   Most of the $3.3 million went instead to American companies and individuals, and $380,000 went into offshore accounts in Grand Cayman Island or the Bahamas, which have protective banking laws that offer tight secrecy, said Frank C. Conahan, the G.A.O.'s director for international affairs.

headline: INVESTMENT BANKING'S DIRTY LITTLE SECRET
abstract: LATELY, investment banks have been rushing into one of the most ethically dubious corners of the financial world - the issuance of so-called ''fairness letters.'' These documents are a deceit upon the investing public and upon the marketplace generally, and certainly unworthy of institutions with serious national responsibilities and trust.   A fairness letter works something like this: Suppose management of a publicly held corporation wants to take the company private in a leveraged buyout. Clearly, the transaction is contemplated only because management believes it can pay its stockholders less than the real value of the company. Indeed, why else would management want to buy the company unless it could see a profit on its investment, and where else would the profit come from except from paying the real owners of the company - the stockholders - less than the company was worth?

headline: BIG GAIN IN G.N.P. IS GREETED WARILY
abstract: The 3.2 percent growth rate in the G.N.P. in the first quarter could be misleading, many economists warned,They noted that individual economic indicators show an underlying weakness that is masked by the overall figure. For example, industrial production fell five-tenths of 1 percent in March, business inventories rose and capacity utilization slipped to 79.4 percent in March, all indications of sluggishness. The big picture is distorted, the economists say, by such factors as low oil prices, which help keep inflation down but make the economy seem stronger than it is.   The contribution of low oil prices to economic growth cannot be denied. And with OPEC still unable to control production, analysts say oil will almost certainly stay under $18, and could drop as low as $10 a barrel.

headline: Cyanamid Set To Buy Storz
abstract: The American Cyanamid Company, in a move to expand its new medical devices division, agreed to acquire the Storz Instrument Company for more than $100 million in cash.   Storz, which is based in St. Louis, makes instruments for ear, nose and throat surgeons.

headline: Captain of the Sheffield Jammed Ship Defenses
abstract: Electronic antimissile defenses on the British frigate Sheffield, sunk in the 1982 Falkland War, were jammed during an Argentine attack by a telephone call from the captain to naval headquarters, the Defense Ministry said today.   Twenty crewmen were killed when the Sheffield was sunk on May 4, 1982, by a French-made Exocet missile fired by an Argentine warplane.

headline: Shares Offered By Emhart Corp.
abstract: The Emhart Corporation, a shoe and packaging machinery company in Farmington, Conn., is offering 2.75 million common shares at a price of $37 a share through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.   Proceeds from the sale will be used primarily to reduce short-term debt. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the company's stock closed at $37, unchanged.

headline: Careers; New Focus Urged for Chemists
abstract: THE demand for young chemists and chemical engineers is not as large this year as it was in 1985, but the job outlook is still quite good, according to the American Chemical Society, the chemical industry's professional group. This year, however, there has been a change in focus that those entering the industry need to be aware of.   Just as doctors need to develop a pleasant manner with patients, young chemists are advised to be more knowledgeable and friendly with customers of their company to learn their needs.

headline: PLOT AGAINST AQUINO CHARGED
abstract: Officials charged with protecting President Corazon C. Aquino are investigating a robbery suspect's assertion that he was hired to assassinate her at an outdoor rally early last month but backed out at the last minute.   The 30-year-old man, identified as Romualdo Mercado, was arrested last Saturday after a Filipino-American businessman accused him of stealing $6,000.   During the police investigation of the robbery, Mr. Mercado reportedly said that an army general had offered him the equivalent of $25,000 to kill Mrs. Aquino at a thanksgiving mass held in downtown Rizal Park on March 2. The rally, which celebrated the ouster of the former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, drew hundreds of thousands of Filipinos.

headline: Pennzoil to Cut 600 Positions
abstract: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that, because of the ''complex problems facing the oil and gas industry,'' it would reduce its work force of 7,200 by 8.3 percent, or 600 positions.   The Houston-based company said it expected that a substantial part of the cuts would be achieved through employees taking advantage of its voluntary retirement program.

headline: Economic Scene; Tokyo Meeting And the Dollar
abstract: THE first phase of the dollar's decline, lasting from the beginning of March 1985 until a few weeks ago, was gradual and orderly - the very model of a soft landing. But anxieties are growing, in the financial markets and foreign capitals, that the decline is in danger of turning into a free fall that could mean serious trouble for the American and world economy.   The dollar strengthened yesterday in a mixed performance after falling the day before to 167.35 yen, a postwar low, and to 2.17 marks, a five-year low. The plunges caused the Japanese and West German central banks to intervene in the currency markets in efforts to arrest the dollar's decline.

headline: STOCK MARKET BID IN CHINA
abstract: Stock exchanges should be opened in four cities and a capital market created to finance China's economic growth, an analysis in the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily said today.   Publication of the half-page article appeared to reflect heightened debate about whether stock and capital markets are too capitalistic for China, where stock trading was banned after the Communists took power in 1949.

headline: MEDICAL SHOPPING CENTER
abstract: NOTHING is more crucial to the success of a shopping center than the creation of a tenant mix whose diversity will draw shoppers and minimize competition among retailers.   This time-honored retail concept has been borrowed by the developers of a large medical condominium now being formed in Queens, where the combination of doctors and medical services will be strictly controlled.   ''What we are offering with this plan are the same advantages that shopping centers have provided retailers and consumers,'' said Albert Gottlieb, a vice president of Helmsley-Spear who served as a consultant for the project. ''The difference is that instead of stores there will be physicians and medical services here. The complex will be a medical shopping center.''

headline: Sri Lanka Lowers Toll In Jet Bombing to 15
abstract: The Government today lowered to 15 the death toll in the bomb of an Air Lanka jet Saturday.

headline: Advertising; Four A's Getting Help For Drug-Free America
abstract: The American Association of Advertising Agencies' brave plan to go it alone in a vast public service advertising battle against the drug abuse problem, ran into reality. Apparently under pressure from the rest of the advertising community it has now agreed to make its Drug Free America effort part of the Advertising Council, which joins agencies with advertisers and the media to create and place advertising in the public interest.   Now it will never be as big, grand and single concerted effort as planned because it must now be one of many worthy causes.

headline: Revised Offer For Gypsum
abstract: The National Gypsum Company said yesterday that an investment group led by senior management of the company had sweetened its leveraged buyout proposal.

headline: G.O.P. TACTIC PUTS CONTRA AID ON HOLD
abstract: Using a surprise parliamentary maneuver, House Republicans today ambushed the Democratic leadership and foiled attempts to attach President Reagan's request to aid the Nicaraguan rebels to a supplemental spending bill.   Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader, said the Democrats had been playing a ''con game'' with the rebel aid issue because the $1.7 billion spending bill was headed for a Presidential veto that would also kill the aid package.   Addressing a chamber that was charged with partisan rancor, Mr. Michel drew cheers from Republicans when he asserted, ''We refuse to play the roles assigned to us by the directors of this farce.''   But the day's events left the ultimate fate of the President's aid request in doubt. Republican leaders said they had devised a strategy that could force a floor vote on the President's request as early as May 12, and they predicted that the request would pass.

headline: ABBAS INTERVIEW IN ALGERIA
abstract: United States Government sources said today that Mohammed Abbas, facing murder and kidnapping charges in the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, was on a secret visit to Algeria when he said in an American television interview this month that President Reagan had become ''enemy No. 1.''   The State Department has complained to Algeria for not turning the Palestinian over to Italian or American authorities for prosecution in the hijacking of the cruise ship last October and the death of Leon Klinghoffer, an American passenger, the sources said.   ''We've made no secret of our views,'' a United States official said. He said that Mr. Abbas, head of a faction of the Palestine Liberation Front, had left Algeria since and that his whereabouts were unknown.

headline: 3 Die on a Roller Coaster
abstract: The last car on a triple loop roller coaster at a huge indoor shopping center here derailed Saturday evening, dumping four passengers to the concrete below. The police said three people died and up to 15 were injured.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $4.83 billion, to $221.99 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Gandhi Names Sikh To Top Security Post
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in an unexpected step during a Cabinet shuffle, today promoted a Sikh ostracized by much of the Sikh population to India's top security post.   Mr. Gandhi, who has been challenged by militant Sikh separatists in Punjab State, made Agriculture Minister Buta Singh the Home Minister.

headline: IN ANCIENT ANTIOCH, MODERN HOSTILITIES SMOLDER
abstract: When the people of Antakya turn on Syrian television, which they swear they do not do often, they see a weather map that places their town and its entire region in Syria.   Syria has never recognized that the ancient city of Antioch, capital of the province of Syria under the Roman Empire and one of the splendors of the ancient world, belongs to Turkey.   This has been so since 1939, when a plebiscite under the League of Nations separated Hatay Province from Syria, then a French mandate, and restored it to Turkey, which had ruled it through the centuries of the Ottoman Empire. Now the city is known as Antakya, its Turkish name.  ''It's a problem for Syria, not our problem,'' Gov. Sami Oytun, a former general, said curtly. ''Hatay is one of the 67 provinces of Turkey.''

headline: Sri Lankan Planes Bomb Tamil Rebels
abstract: Government planes bombed Tamil separatist rebels on the Jaffna Peninsula today, guerrillas blew up a factory and six civilians were killed in a brawl with soldiers in Colombo.   In other signs of growing violence, a National Security Ministry spokesman said that guerrillas killed nine civilians from a village of the country's majority Sinhalese and that the rebels killed three soldiers in an attack on a military outpost.   Residents of the peninsula, which has a population of one million, said planes and helicopters bombed and strafed several islands and coastal villages around the city of Jaffna.

headline: Advertising; Good Start For 'Made In the USA'
abstract: ''ADVERTISING to save an industry, that's something I've never worked on,'' said Robert J. Fiore, executive vice president and chief creative officer of Warwick Advertising. ''It goes beyond just selling products.''   He was talking about the advertising campaign on behalf of Crafted With Pride in the U.S.A. Council, the banner under which the American apparel and home furnishings businesses and their unions are fighting imports. And according to early results, the battle is going well for the American producers.

headline: URUGUAYAN VISITS U.S. WITH TRADE AS TOP ISSUE
abstract: On a recent trip to Egypt President Julio Maria Sanguinetti asked the manager of the Hotel Luxor where the hotel bought its beef.   ''He said it was imported from France, at a price that almost made me faint,'' said Mr. Sanguinetti, whose country's No. 1 export is beef. ''It was about a third of what the meat would have cost in Europe.''   At the same time, he said, the United States is offering beef to Brazil, Uruguay's northern neighbor, for half what it would cost in the United States.

headline: HOUSE PANEL BACKS NEW SOUTH AFRICAN SANCTIONS
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved and sent to the floor today a measure that would impose a new range of economic sanctions against South Africa, setting the stage for another legislative confrontation with the White House.   The measure foresees penalties in two steps. Upon enactment, all new private investment in the country from American concerns and imports of South African steel, coal and uranium would be barred and landing rights in the United States for South African Airways would be suspended.   If, in a year's time, South Africa did not take certain steps to end apartheid, among them the release of ''all political prisoners'' including Nelson Mandela, the head of the outlawed African National Congress, the United States computer industry would be forced to cease all operations in South Africa.

headline: GANNETT'S 'TRIPLE CROWN' BIDDING FEAT
abstract: Allen H. Neuharth, chairman of the Gannett Company, said today that acquiring the daily newspapers in this city of the Kentucky Derby was the last step in ''winning the Triple Crown.''   He was delightedly referring to Gannett's success over the last year in outbidding other communications companies for three newspaper prizes: The Des Moines Register, The Detroit News and now The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times.   Under the aggressive direction of Mr. Neuharth, dressed today in his signature colors of black and gray, Gannett has become the nation's largest newspaper group. It owns more daily papers, representing more daily circulation, than any other chain. The new additions bring Gannett's newspaper holdings to 93 dailies, including USA Today. Their circulation totals more than six million.

headline: Shultz Urges Support For Anti-Soviet Forces
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in a speech to be delivered Monday, says it is the duty of the United States to support popular democratic movements challenging the Soviet Union and its allies.   ''Political support and modest U.S. military assistance to those resisting Soviet-supported or Soviet-imposed regimes are certainly a prudent exercise of U.S. power,'' he said in the text of the speech to be delivered at Kansas State University, in Manhattan, Kan.   Mr. Shultz also said intervention by the United States would, in the end, help improve Washington-Moscow relations.

headline: MOSCOW PROPOSES A MEETING IN JULY ON '79 ARMS PACT
abstract: The Soviet Union has proposed that American and Soviet officials meet in Geneva next month to discuss President Reagan's decision not to abide by the strategic arms agreement of 1979, Administration officials said today.   American officials said that no decision had been made on how to respond to the Soviet proposal and that Administration officials disagreed about what it signified. They said it would be discussed this week.   Some senior officials favor a positive response, but Defense Department officials have reportedly criticized the idea of such a meeting.

headline: Muller Jordan Chosen By Sherwood Brands
abstract: Sherwood Brands, a candy importer based in Winston-Salem, N.C., is going to dip its bonbons into advertising for the first time, and for that purpose it has retained Muller Jordan Weiss of New York.

headline: REAGAN SAYS U.S. MUST AID BRITAIN ON EXTRADITIONS
abstract: President Reagan, seeking to prod the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to act on a new extradition treaty with Britain, warned today against allowing ''terrorists'' a ''safe haven'' in the United States.   Mr. Reagan, in his weekly radio address, linked the treaty with Britain to larger efforts at combating international terrorism. He said the refusal of the Senate to ratify the agreement would ''undermine our ability to pressure other countries to extradite terrorists who have murdered our citizens.''   The revised 1972 treaty, which was signed a year ago by the United States and Britain, includes new provisions that end exemptions from extradition for crimes justified as politically motivated. At least four fugitives of the Irish Republican Army have avoided extradition by invoking the political exemption, including one convicted 18 months ago of killing a British soldier in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

headline: Walkout at Airline in France
abstract: A strike by the ground staff at the main French domestic airline, Air Inter, forced the company to cancel about 30 percent of the 320 flights it had scheduled for today, an airline official said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Alco Health Services Corp. is issuing a $100 million convertible Eurobond due 2001 with a 6 to 6 1/2 percent coupon at 100, through Drexel Burnham Lambert International.    * Anchor Hocking Corp. has filed for a $70 million issue of 10-year notes through Kidder, Peabody & Co.

headline: Reliance Alters Its Blair Offer
abstract: Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Capital Group sweetened the cash in its bid for John Blair & Company to $31 a share. But it also reduced the number of shares it is seeking and the face value of notes in a package worth about $340 million.

headline: CONGRESSIONAL CHALLENGE PLANNED ON NEW U.S. CHEMICAL WEAPONS
abstract: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said today that he would lead a fight to revoke funds for new chemical weapons, arguing that the Administration had failed to comply with a Congressional mandate requiring prior approval of NATO's governing political body.   The chairman, Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, joined other members of Congress in charging that the Administration had flouted the mandate by seeking only the backing of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's defense ministers. Deal With Germans Is Assailed   He also said that in order to secure the approval of West Germany, the Administration had struck a secret deal by which it will remove from Europe the existing stockpile of chemical weapons and will not send the new ones to replace it unless there is a crisis and Bonn agrees.   ''That is a farce from a legal standpoint and folly from a foreign policy and national security standpoint,'' Mr. Fascell said in a statement. ''We should not build new chemical weapons under these conditions.''

headline: SUMMIT LEADERS SEEN PRAISING GROWTH, WITH RESERVATIONS
abstract: The leaders of the major non-Communist industrialized nations plan to present a glowing portrait of the world's economic prospects at their 12th annual economic summit meeting opening in Tokyo on Sunday. They will attribute this brightening future to the success of their own policies helped by the sharp fall in the price of oil, according to officials preparing the summit talks who were interviewed in several capitals.   Summit participants, several of whom soon face important elections at home, are already broadly agreed on an upbeat, self-congratulatory declaration on the world's economic outlook, for issuance at the end of the three-day meeting, these officials say.   The communique will stress that the industrial nations are heading into a period of steady, sustainable economic growth of more than 3 percent a year that should last through 1987, coupled with low inflation and declining interest rates. It will urge all countries to persevere with conservative policies and continue efforts to deregulate their economies.

headline: FURNITURE MARKET SET
abstract: Despite a stable economy, furniture makers will not be straying from traditional big sellers such as bedroom suites and family room pieces when the Southern Furniture Market opens Thursday, an industry official said. ''These are not fat enough times to see the major manufacturers introducing new styles,'' said Rick Barentine, the executive director of the Furniture Factories Marketing Association of the South. About 1,500 domestic and foreign manufacturers will display their wares to retail dealers at the market.

headline: Sea-Land Sets Restructuring
abstract: The Sea-Land Corporation has announced a corporate restructuring, In addition, it said three new lawsuits had been filed against it over its $742 million acquisition by the CSX Corporation.   Sea-Land said it had restructured its main unit, Sea-Land Service Inc., to help it operate more effectively in an intensely competitive industry and to prepare for its acquisition by the Richmond-based CSX, a transportation and natural resources company.

headline: Patents; Measuring Reactions Of Solids With Gases
abstract: An accurate analytical technique applicable to such projects as finding better ways to burn coal and prevent acid rain is the subject of patent 4,596,470, granted this week to Jin Y. Park, a chemical engineer and professor at the University of Idaho.

headline: The U.N. Today: June 12, 1986
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BULGING MONEY SUPPLY GIVING THE FED PAUSE
abstract: Sharp increases in the nation's money supply in the last five months are causing a problem for the Federal Reserve Board as it considers a further cut in interest rates.   To determine the cause of the rise, the Fed has been surveying 50 large banks that have reported big increases in demand deposits since February. The Fed conducted a similar survey last year after sharp first-half increases in M-1, the basic measure of the nation's money supply. It ultimately decided to ignore that growth and calculate M-1 increases based on the second quarter.

headline: U.S.-Canada Talks Conclude
abstract: The United States and Canada concluded their opening round of negotiations on free trade today with the chief negotiators emphasizing that both countries should benefit from the elimination of bilateral trade barriers.   ''We're working toward a common objective,'' Peter Murphy, the United States negotiator, said.

headline: Fort Howard Pact To Buy Lily-Tulip
abstract: Fort Howard Paper Company has agreed to acquire Lily-Tulip Inc., a maker of disposable cups, for $326 million, the companies announced yesterday.   Under terms of a definitive agreement approved by directors of both companies, Fort Howard will soon make a cash offer of $18.50 a share for all Lily-Tulip common stock.

headline: KIDNAPPED IRISH WOMAN IS FREED
abstract: After a five-hour siege by the police in Dublin today, kidnappers freed the wife of a banker who is related to the Guinness brewing family. She had been held for eight days.   The hostage, Jennifer Guinness, was unharmed, and the police said her courage and negotiating skill had contributed to her release.

headline: Wall St. Sees Sperry Merger
abstract: Although animosity between the Sperry Corporation and the Burroughs Corporation has intensified, Wall Street apparently still thinks the two concerns could combine.   ''This is a done deal,'' said Jonathan Fram, the computer analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: TIRE BLAMED IN MEXICO CRASH
abstract: A fire caused by the explosion of a tire in the landing gear was the cause of the crash March 31 of a Mexicana Airlines Boeing 727 in central Mexico, which killed all 167 people aboard, the Mexican Government said tonight.   An announcement by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said a seven-week investigation by a team of Mexican aviation experts had ruled out the possibility that explosives had caused the accident.

headline: Dual Tenneco Offering
abstract: Tenneco Inc. is offering $500 million of new debt securities, half in 10-year notes and half in 30-year sinking fund debentures, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.   The 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1996 were offered at 99 3/4 to yield 9.288 percent, or 1.8 percentage points more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

headline: REAGAN LOBBIES PANEL ON CANADA TRADE TALKS
abstract: President Reagan appealed to the Senate Finance Committee today to back trade negotiations with Canada, saying that failure to do so ''would adversely color the tone of our political and economic relationships with Canada for many years to come.''   The Republican-controlled committee has scheduled a vote on the issue Tuesday morning, and the President could manage to win narrowly as a result of intense, last-minute lobbying.   Earlier today Mr. Reagan had been scheduled to meet some committee members at the White House to apply further pressure and seek a reversal of the position against the negotiations signaled last week by 12 of the 20 members. However, the meeting was canceled without explanation. Aides said that the President was making telephone calls instead to the 12 senators who oppose negotiations.

headline: Peugeot Has a Profit
abstract: Peugeot S.A. said today that it had a profit last year of $23.5 million after a loss of $29 million a year earlier.

headline: Officials in Sri Lanka Blame Loose Security in Bombings
abstract: Sri Lankan troops were on alert today after officials blamed lax security by both the public and security forces for two bomb blasts that killed 22 people and wounded 100 in Colombo.   Tamil guerrillas fighting for a separate state blasted a food factory in the capital on Friday and a passenger train Saturday.   In another guerrilla action, 21 soldiers and 5 civilians were killed by a landmine in eastern Trincomalee district on Friday.

headline: PANAMANIAN, DENYING CHARGES, SAYS HE WON'T QUIT
abstract: The commander of the Panamanian Army denied all charges of involvement in criminal activities today and brushed aside calls from the opposition for his resignation.   In an interview, the commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, insisted that he and the army would continue to play a major role, together with the civilian President, in running the country. But General Noriega is widely seen as the true wielder of political power in the country and the army has either imposed or deposed the last five presidents.   ''The role of the defense force in this country is different from any other armed forces,'' General Noriega said. ''Here the President of the republic, who rules and takes decisions, is a friend of ours. We are his subaltern and his support. We've learned to walk together.''

headline: PRETORIA AND THE PRESS
abstract: There are few areas that better demonstrate the South African Government's contradictory desires as its attitude toward the foreign press. South Africa yearns to be accepted as a country of Western democratic values, but to maintain its system and self-image it enforces the information practices of authoritarian regimes.   In recent months South Africa's leaders have become increasingly resentful of foreign reporters, whose reports they blame for the country's woeful international image.   For more than a decade, South Africa has accepted the presence of a large body of foreign correspondents, as if to demonstrate it is part of the larger family of democratic nations. Another reason for permitting their presence is, perhaps, an unshakable belief that people in the United States and Great Britain, among others, will come to sympathize with the situation of white South Africans if their story is told abroad. All journalists heading to South Africa are familiar with some variation of the admonition from South Africans that ''you will see it is more complex than you think.''

headline: TANZANIA'S 'GREEN GOLD' WOES
abstract: Sisal plants, like the tops of pineapples, march down the hillsides here in double files. In the colonial era, these plants were called ''green gold'' for the pale fibers they produced, fibers that were combed and spun into twine that bound newspaper bundles, rope that secured ships to their moorings and threads that were woven into burlap sacks for potatoes and onions.   From immense estates on the edges of the Usambara Mountains here, Tanzania once produced the sisal that virtually dominated the world market. But in the last 15 years, that dominance has evaporated as prices for sisal have plummeted - in great measure because of the increased use of plastic fibers -and as the sisal estates deteriorated following nationalization by a determined Socialist government.

headline: Advertising; Howard, Merrell Lands A $12 Million Account
abstract: For an agency with $23 million in billings, winning a $12 million account is a real windfall. And such a bonanza has befallen Howard, Merrell & Partners of Raleigh, N.C.   Its new big client is Union Carbide's Agricultural Products Company in Research Triangle Park, N.C. It previously had its chemical brands split between the Atlanta offices of Ogilvy & Mather and Fletcher/Mayo.   Now, in addition to being in charge of promoting such products as Temik, Amiben, Ethrel and more, Howard, Merrell has been asked to develop new products, along with their packaging and advertising, for consumer lawn and garden care.

headline: A FORESTER'S TOUGH REGIMEN
abstract: The language of Ray Smith, president and chief executive of Canada's biggest lumber company, is often as tough as the rocky coastal terrain where his company, MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., usually cuts most of its timber.   ''We were determined to get a return out of life the way it was,'' he said, ''not the way we'd like it to be.''   There was not much to like. In 1981, MacMillan Bloedel went into what Mr. Smith calls ''a survival mode.'' The company cut its work force to 15,000, from 24,000; ended all capital expenditures except those related to safety, and sold the corporate jet and the company headquarters.

headline: U.S. and Mexico Seek End to Tuna War
abstract: For almost six years now, Mexico and the United States have been locked in a trade war over tuna fish. Mexico is forbidden to market its tuna to the American consumer, and the United States tuna fleet is banned from the tuna-rich Pacific Ocean waters within 200 miles of Mexico.   Both countries are eager to end the conflict, and diplomats from both sides periodically sit down to discuss the matter, most recently within the last few weeks.   But despite such talks, the issue, one of the most nettlesome trade disputes that separates the two countries, is at an impasse because of United States protectionist tendencies, Mexican national pride and complex trade laws.

headline: BHUTTO, ELATED, DEMANDS AN ELECTION
abstract: Benazir Bhutto, elated by the tumultuous turnout at her anti-Government rally Thursday, demanded Friday that new elections be held in Pakistan but pledged not to resort to violence in seeking the ouster of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.   At the same time, Miss Bhutto seemed to warn General Zia to take her cause seriously when she said the hundreds of thousands of supporters who thronged the streets here had it in their power to force him from office.   ''That crowd was so responsive it would have done anything which I or my party directed,'' she said of the rally, the largest anti-Government demonstration in Pakistan since General Zia took power in a military coup and imposed martial law in 1977.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: * William Kurth has been named senior vice president-creative of Doyle Graf Mabley.

headline: Wickes Raises Gypsum Offer
abstract: The Wickes Companies raised its offer today for the National Gypsum Company to $60 a share in cash, or $1.36 billion, countering a leveraged buyout bid of $46 in cash and $28 a share in notes offered by a group of National Gypsum senior managers.   Analysts said that Wickes's latest bid does not top the latest management offer, which they valued at about $61 to $63 a share.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 17, 1986
abstract: The Economy    The Producer Price Index tumbled 0.6 percent in April to its lowest level in nearly two and a half years. The decline in the major inflation gauge, its fourth consecutive monthly drop, was larger than generally expected, but experts predicted that future inflation reports would show increases because of oil price rises.  [ Page 1. ]    A broad coalition is supporting the tax-revision legislation approved by the Senate Finance Committee. It includes some companies that opposed earlier tax revision plans.  [ 37. ]  Senator Dole said any amendment to retain the deductibility of Individual Retirement Accounts would have to recover the lost tax revenue.  [ 49. ]  For taxpayers who want to see how they would fare under the Finance Committee's plan, line-by-line instructions allow them to compare their prospective tax with their tax under the current system.  [ 48. ]  Deferred compensation and stock options may become a thing of the past for executives if the panel's bill is enacted.  [ 48. ]  A big winner under the Senate's approach would be President Reagan, who would see his tax bill drop about 20 percent, and a big loser would be Vice President Bush, who would face a 50 percent increase.  [ 7. ]

headline: HILL & KNOWLTON TO BUY GRAY, THE LOBBYISTS
abstract: Gray & Company, one of the most influential lobbying firms in Washington, has agreed to be acquired for $21 million by Hill & Knowlton, the world's second-largest public relations company, the firms announced yesterday.   Gray was founded only five years ago by Robert Keith Gray, former vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton, but it quickly became the largest public relations and lobbying concern in Washington, in part because of Mr. Gray's access to the Reagan Administration. Mr. Gray was director of communications in the 1980 Reagan campaign and was co-chairman of the President's inaugural committee.   More recently, a public relations firm with even stronger ties to the White House was founded by Michael K. Deaver, former White House deputy chief of staff. Those ties, in fact, caused considerable attention to be focused on lobbying activity in Washington, and last week a special prosecutor was named to investigate whether some of Mr. Deaver's activities violated Federal laws.

headline: GASOLINE LEADS FALL IN PRODUCER PRICES
abstract: Producer prices plunged at an annualized rate of 12.4 percent in the first quarter, the biggest drop ever. March's prices were 1.1 percent below February's, primarily because gasoline prices dropped 21.9 percent, and crude oil overall fell 24.8 percent. Auto sales, meanwhile, were off so much that retail sales as a whole fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the biggest drop in five months.   More interest rate drops are expected, and the stock and bond markets happily anticipated another cut in the discount rate. Short- and medium-term rates are at nine-year lows, and the prospects of low oil prices and a moderately expanding economy are likely to keep them low. Stocks rebounded from a miserable performance a week ago, ending Friday at 1,790.18, up 50.96 for the week.

headline: REFUGEES IN SUDAN FIND WELCOME WEARING THIN
abstract: As the glimmering haze of a steamy afternoon yielded to dusk, the Karkora refugee settlement was overflowing with activity.   Men and women haggled over prices at a small souk, while children congregated at a makeshift juice shop. Other refugees sat attentively at an English lesson, slowly pronouncing the words presented by their American teacher.   People in the settlement near this town in the eastern Sudan say they will go back to their homes in Eritrea, a stretch of land in Ethiopia along the Red Sea, when peace is restored there. But the rebel war has been raging for 26 years and shows no signs of ending. So the 12,000 refugees at Karkora wait and fashion a life in the Sudan.

headline: ADMINISTRATION BACKS RISE IN EXCISE TAXES
abstract: The Reagan Administration today generally endorsed Senator Bob Packwood's plan to raise excise taxes by about $75 billion over the next five years to pay for lower income tax rates and the retention of various tax subsidies.   But representatives of the industries that would have to pay the taxes opposed them strenuously at a day-long hearing before the Senate Finance Committee, and the idea seemed to have little support among the committee members.   The excise tax proposal is a central feature of the tax-revision plan, which appears to be in serious trouble, that was put forward by Senator Packwood, the Finance Committee chairman and an Oregon Republican. It was the best way he could find, the Senator said, to generate enough revenue so that the top income tax rate could be cut to 35 percent from 50 percent, business investment incentives improved and other tax preferences maintained, without lowering total Government receipts.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt    * Atalanta-Sosnoff Capital Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $30 million of convertible senior debentures due 2001 and for an initial public offering of 1.8 million common shares through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.    * Chrysler Financial Corp. is issuing $100 million of 7 1/2 percent Eurobonds due 1991 at a price of par through Banque Paribas Capital Markets. Bond holders may put, or redeem, the bonds after two, three and four years.

headline: Iowa Plans Yield Of 4.55% on Notes
abstract: Iowa, which has no outstanding long-term bonds, is offering short-term tax and revenue anticipation notes for the second consecutive year.

headline: MANILA POLICE AND MARCOS BACKERS CLASH
abstract: The police clashed today with supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, hours before members of his party met in an unofficial session of the National Assembly, which has been abolished by President Corazon C. Aquino.   Hospitals reported 60 people hurt in the clash this morning, including nine with gunshot wounds, after the police moved to disperse a group of Marcos loyalists who had been protesting the removal of a Marcos supporter as mayor of a Manila district.   The police said there was gunfire from the demonstrators, and some of those who were injured said the police had fired on them. Firebombs and rocks were reportedly thrown as the police moved in on the crowd, which had been holding a sit-in at the city hall for the San Juan district.

headline: Patents; A Machine for First Aid
abstract: A LIGHT, battery-powered machine that helps a rescue worker provide first aid to a heart attack victim or someone suffering from a lung ailment was patented this week by a Massachusetts engineer.  The machine, using electronic synthetic speech and liquid crystal displays, answers questions the rescue worker poses by pressing buttons.

headline: Economic Scene; New Optimism In Tax Battle
abstract: SUDDENLY after being down for the nine-count - and indeed after having been counted out by many sophisticates at ringside - a proposal to overhaul and simplify the United States tax system is back on its feet, swinging and with a good chance of winning.   The Senate Finance Committee has given its unanimous approval to a plan, introduced by its chairman, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, to chop personal income tax rates to two brackets, 27 percent and 15 percent; to lower the corporate rate from 46 percent to 33 percent, and to pay for these cuts by eliminating scores of deductions.   The concept of radically changing the tax system by cutting rates and broadening the tax base has long been supported by many economists, both liberal and conservative, who contend that a more neutral tax system would encourage more rational allocation of resources and hence promote economic efficiency and growth.   The major theoretical criticism of that argument, as noted by Roger Brinner and his associates at Data Resources Inc., an economic-analysis concern, comes from those economists who argue that income taxation is less pro-growth than consumption taxation. Hence, if a Federal tax system is based on income, a more balanced program of incentives to investment would be preferable to a neutral tax system, they say.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: * Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corp. to Romann S. Tannenholz for Tavist, a line of antihistamine products.    * Mighty-Mac Inc., subsidiary of Haddad & Sons, to Kaprielian O'Leary Advertising, for its men's and boys' outerwear.

headline: INDUSTRIAL CONDOMINIUMS AT THE OLD BUSH TERMINAL
abstract: For more than 60 years a cluster of industrial buildings on the Brooklyn waterfront once known as Bush Terminal has provided millions of square feet of space for the city's manufacturers.   Now the new owners of the sprawling complex on Gowanus Bay will offer manufacturers the opportunity to purchase their space through a condominium arrangement.   ''Industrial space users in this city are in a bind; they are being squeezed out,'' said Morris Bailey, one of the new owners and head of Industrial City Associates, which bought the complex situated between 32d and 41st Streets in the Sunset Park section of the borough. ''We are offering flexibility through a variety of options which have not existed in the past. But the complex will be a dual operation and we will continue to sign long-term leases. There will be no pressure to buy.''

headline: INVESTING; DYNALECTRON'S NERVOUS RESTRUCTURING
abstract: For years the Dynalectron Corporation has disappointed those who hoped its huge revenue flow could be translated into earnings of a couple of dollars a share. The diversified technical services company, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, reported revenues last year of $640 million, equivalent to about $67 for each of its 9.5 million shares.

headline: Belgium Cuts Key Rate
abstract: Belgium's central bank is lowering its key lending rate by half a point, to 8 percent. This is the fourth cut since the April 16 European Monetary System realignment, which raised the value of the Belgian currency.

headline: THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT; LIVELY JOUSTS FOR POWER FLAVORED BY PERSONALITY
abstract: It is called a summit conference because it is a meeting of the mighty. But on economic issues, what is going on here is a jousting for power over the world economy. And because it is a human process, it sometimes turns on the chemistry of powerful personalities in conflict and on such questions as which nations to let in on which discussions.   One lively conflict involves James A. Baker 3d, the Treasury Secretary, who has made a name for himself as a pragmatic negotiator who usually ends up with much of what he wants, and Gerhard Stoltenberg, the Finance Minister of West Germany. Mr. Stoltenberg welcomes Mr. Baker's collaborative style but has set limits to how far Germany will go in accommodating him.

headline: South Korean Coal Plan
abstract: South Korea plans to import anthracite coal from Canada and Peru this year on a trial basis, officials at the Energy and Resources Ministry said today. The plans were intended to secure a stable supply by diversifying import sources, they added.

headline: Washington Watch; Argentine Soybean Dispute
abstract: The Government's stepped-up agricultural trade offensive has spread to South America. While still fighting the European Community's efforts to curb imports of American soybeans to Portugal, the Reagan Administration is now aiming salvos at Argentina for maintaining a differential export tax on sales of soybean oil and meal.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: ''Protectionist sentiment is in full bloom again, with legislation in both houses of Congress.'' James A. Baker 3d   Treasury Secretary

headline: U.S. Steel to Refinance $2.9 Billion of Debt
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it would begin a ''major financial restructuring'' this year that would include a refinancing of about $2.9 billion of debt that it incurred when it acquired the Marathon Oil Company in 1982.   The company, whose presence is larger in energy than in steel, said the refinancing would require a one-time after-tax charge against earnings of about $325 million, to be taken in some quarter before next year. However, it said the move would reduce costs by more than $125 million annually for the next seven years.

headline: Puerto Rican Offering Priced
abstract: A $160 million issue of Commonwealth of Puerto Rico general obligation bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company with a maximum yield of about 8 percent for 7 7/8 percent bonds due in 2011 at a price of 98.50.   Among shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6.20 percent for bonds due in 1990 to 7.40 percent in 1996 and 7 3/4 percent in 2000.

headline: Bankers Stress Accord
abstract: Bankers in New York said yesterday that it was crucial that Mexico quickly reach a lending agreement with the I.M.F. to keep from falling behind on its interest payments. A team of top Mexican officials is expected to travel to Washington this week to try to reach such an accord.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: A POLICE OFFICER IS SHOT IN NEW ATTACKS IN ULSTER
abstract: A Northern Ireland police officer was shot and the homes of three other officers were firebombed in attacks by Protestant militants who roamed Ulster today.

headline: THE GRIM TOLL OF CHERNOBYL; A THREAT TO SOVIET ECONOMIC REFORM
abstract: WHILE there obviously is never a good time for a nuclear meltdown, the Chernobyl disaster comes at a particularly awkward moment for the Soviet economy. It may well abort Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ambitious effort to turn the Soviet economy around.  Before Chernobyl, Mr. Gorbachev's efforts to discipline and motivate the Soviet work force were beginning to bear fruit. According to official Soviet data, in the first three months of 1986, industrial production rose 6.7 percent and labor productivity 6.3 percent over the comparable period in 1985.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA UNCOVERS BIG ARMS CACHE
abstract: The South African police said today that they had uncovered the biggest cache of arms ever found in the country's 25-year-old war between the white Government and black nationalist guerrillas.   Violence and protest erupted in other parts of South Africa in what seemed to be a deepening of the conflict between radical and conservative blacks.   In Alexandra township north of Johannesburg, by contrast, about 250 liberal whites laid flowers at the graves of eight blacks killed in township protests, saying their wreaths represented ''a symbol of our shared future together.''

headline: STALIN'S DAUGHTER FLYING TO U.S.
abstract: Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Josef Stalin, left the Soviet Union Wednesday for Chicago via Zurich, Heinz Lanz, manager of the Swissair office in Moscow, said today.   Miss Alliluyeva returned to the Soviet Union in November 1984 after 17 years in the West.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 20, 1986
abstract: Markets     Crude oil prices closed above $17 for the first time in more than three months after an increase of about $1 a barrel. Some analysts predicted crude prices would rise by at least another dollar. However, others said that the large worldwide surplus of oil would result in another price drop before prices stabilize. Many analysts and industry executives predict that crude prices will average $15 to $22 a barrel over the course of the year. Demand for crude oil also pushed prices up for futures contracts of petroleum products.  [ Page D1. ]    Trading slowed dramatically on Wall Street, with only 85.8 million shares traded, as speculators apparently feared the repercussions of the insider trading inquiry involving Dennis B. Levine, a former mergers executive. Stocks were mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 1.62 points, to 1,758.18.  [ D10. ]  Thirteen oil companies - all former takeover targets - are reportedly on a list of 102 stocks being circulated by the S.E.C. to find anyone who has evidence to link Mr. Levine or others to insider trading.  [ D5. ]

headline: IN AUSTRIA, SILENCE LOUDER THAN OOM-PAH-PAH
abstract: ''Through her political scandals Austria has managed to draw the big world's attention to herself and at last is no longer confused with Australia.''   Austria is marking the 50th anniversary of the death of the polemicist Karl Kraus, but his one-liner remains unhappily contemporary for an Alpine republic that wants to be associated with downhill skiing and ''The Sound of Music,'' not war crimes.   It was with a sense of public lassitude that the most divisive electoral campaign of Austria's Second Republic ended today. If the opinion polls are accurate, Kurt Waldheim - ''the great Austrian,'' say posters showing him seated behind a desk of Hapsburg proportions - will be elected President on Sunday by a slight majority.

headline: JAPANESE DEMAND WATCHED
abstract: As the credit markets prepare for a record Treasury financing next week, attention is focused on the willingness of Japanese investors to keep buying American notes and bonds.   Last week concern that the decline of the dollar would cause Japanese investors to shun Treasury auctions helped reduce Treasury bond prices by nearly 6 points. This price plunge, one of the steepest in any week, raised the yield of 30-year bellwether Treasury bonds to 7.56 percent from 7.15 percent a week earlier.   While the fickle attitude of American investors is familiar to dealers in government securities, they are not accustomed to sharp swings in Japanese demand. ''The pattern has been for Japanese investors to regard each drop in the dollar as an opportunity to buy because it meant that the risk of additional weakness in the dollar was reduced,'' said William Coleman, head of government securities trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: U.N. OPENS SESSION ON AID FOR AFRICA
abstract: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal opened a special General Assembly session on Africa's economic crisis today with a call for African and donor nations to make ''an act of faith'' in developing the world's poorest continent.   The 50-year-old President, who is also chairman of the Organization of African Unity, asked delegates from the 159 member countries to avoid ideological quarrels and ''bear in mind the essentials: the survival of a continent, the recovery of Africa.''   The weeklong session, the first meeting of the Assembly on a regional economic problem in its 40-year history, is considering an O.A.U. report presented today by Mr. Diouf. The report outlines the continent's declining agricultural production, widespread environmental destruction, mounting debt and uncontrolled population growth.

headline: Hiram Walker President
abstract: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big Canadian liquor and energy company taken over last month by the Reichmann family of Toronto, said yesterday that it had named M. A. Cohen president.

headline: REAGAN EXTENDS LOW TARIFF ON IMPORTS FROM RUMANIA
abstract: President Reagan today approved another yearlong extension of trade benefits to Rumania, but said he did so ''with difficulty'' because of its poor record on human rights. In a statement, the President said: ''I am disppointed by the very limited response of the Rumanian Government to numerous expressions of strong U.S. public, Congressional and Administration concern about its performance in areas of human rights and religious issues.''   Members of Congress had urged the President to deprive Rumania of so-called most-favored-nation treatment, which calls for the imposition of lower United States import tariffs granted to most countries.

headline: A CHANCE FOR CHANGE SEEN IN SOUTH KOREAN TALKS
abstract: Politicians, intellectuals and diplomats here say continuing talks on the crucial issue of constitutional revision offer changes that might ease growing political tensions and allow Koreans more say in choosing their Government.   They add that although they do not believe a recent surge of violent protest will spark a broader uprising, failure to forge an acceptable compromise would risk more widespread protest.   ''Right now there isn't one clear issue that can serve as a catalyst like a fraudulent election,'' said a longtime foreign resident of South Korea who witnessed the disturbances that preceded the last two military coups. ''There's still hope that the question of constitutional revision can be worked out through a process of negotiation and compromise.''

headline: U.S. TOBACCO WINS SUIT OVER LIABILITY ON SNUFF
abstract: A Federal court jury ruled in favor of the U.S. Tobacco Company today in a liability suit brought by the mother of a teen-ager who developed oral cancer after dipping snuff for six years.   It was the third recent victory for the tobacco industry in product liability suits.   Betty Ann Marsee, who had sought $147 million from U.S. Tobacco in the death of her son, Sean, told reporters that she feared the verdict would send a message to other teen-agers that snuff dipping is safe.   Mrs. Marsee had filed the suit against U.S. Tobacco because she said the company made Copenhagen brand snuff, the smokeless tobacco that her son used. She said he began using snuff after receiving a free sample.

headline: Washington Watch; Conversions Of Thrift Units
abstract: NOW that the regulators and the Administration have produced what appears to be a workable $25 billion, five-year rescue plan for the troubled Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, they are concerned about another problem, thrift institution defections.   For more than a year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has imposed a special assessment of $1 billion a year on insured savings and loan associations in an attempt to rebuild the insurance fund's depleted resources. The industry has complained loudly about this burden, asserting that the good managers are paying for the sins of the bad ones.

headline: Hiram Walker Lawsuit Altered
abstract: Olympia & York Enterprises Inc. and the Gulf Canada Corporation, which have been seeking to invalidate an agreement that would sell the liquor business of Hiram Walker Resources to Allied-Lyons of Britain, said yesterday that they had simplified their suit.

headline: 2 Issues Offered By Mesa, Ariz.
abstract: Mesa, Ariz., yesterday began offering a total of about $108 million of general obligation and utility system revenue refunding bonds in two issues through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.   A $53.7 million issue of general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6.40 percent in 1991, 7 3/8 percent in 1996 and 7.60 percent in 1998. Because the bonds are backed by the city's full faith and credit, they are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P. Yields on the $54.4 million companion issue of utility system revenue bonds, rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., ranged from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6.50 percent in 1991, 7.60 percent in 1996 and 7.70 percent in 1997.

headline: DATA BANK: April 13, 1986
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: U.S. Calls on Mexico To Halt Drug Trade
abstract: The State Department called on the Government of Mexico today to ''halt the production and trafficking of drugs in its territory.''   Echoing earlier comments by Adminstration officials, a department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said at a briefing here today that there had been a ''sharp increase in the amount of drugs,'' particularly marijuana and heroin, ''entering the U.S. from Mexico.''

headline: MEESE CRITICIZES CUSTOMS CHIEF OVER MEXICO
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d sharply criticized the head of the United States Customs Service today for charging Mexican Government involvement in drug trafficking.   Mr. Meese said statements made by the Customs Commissioner, William Von Raab, and other senior Administration officials before a Congressional panel May 13 were ''reckless'' and did not reflect the thinking of the Administration.

headline: THE 'IRRITANT' THEY CALL PEROT
abstract: H. ROSS PEROT, the quixotic founder of the computer-services company Electronic Data Systems, champion of prisoners of war, crusader against drug abuse, advocate of educational reform, super-patriot, second-richest man in America, is having a frisky time with his new hobby.   On weekends, he pulls on khaki pants, buttons up a smudged shirt and settles his baseball cap on his head. Then he drives out to a General Motors dealership and pokes around. For about 15 minutes, he usually is treated in the blase way reserved for someone who looks like he can't afford a car radio, let alone a car. Then, inevitably, a senior hand will recognize him as a G.M. board member and its most powerful single shareholder, and, in Mr. Perot's words, ''it's a full court press.''   What he would like, he says, ''is for every customer to get the sort of attention I get after the first 15 minutes.''

headline: Duke Power Issue
abstract: The Duke Power Company is offering $175 million of 9 percent first mortgage and refunding bonds due in 2016 at a price of 98.60 to yield 9.136 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P., the issue is not refundable for five years.

headline: Belfast Council Bows To Court and Convenes
abstract: In the first significant break in a united Protestant campaign of opposition to the British-Irish pact on Northern Ireland, the Belfast City Council has voted to obey a High Court order to resume normal activities.

headline: BASES OF PALESTINIANS IN LEBANON ARE AGAIN RAIDED BY ISRAELI JETS
abstract: Israeli planes attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases around Sidon in southern Lebanon today. It was the second such attack on the port city in 12 days.   The police said two people were killed and 20 wounded when six jets bombed targets in two Palestinian districts, Ain Khilwe and Mieh Mieh, as well as a neighboring village, Sirobieh. A number of houses were damaged, the police said.

headline: ACCUSED OF PLOT AGAINST INDIA
abstract: A provincial court in Hamilton, Ontario, ordered today that seven Sikhs charged with conspiring to commit violent crimes in India be held until a bail hearing on Thursday.   The Sikhs were arrested on Saturday and charged with conspiring to commit an indictable offense. The police said the offense is related to plans to bomb Indian Parliament buildings and kidnap a child of a member of the Indian Parliament in order to force him to assist the effort, as well as plans to derail trains and blow up an oil refinery in India.

headline: PARLIAMENT VOTE HURTS ITALY'S COALITION
abstract: Italy's Socialist-led Government lost a crucial vote in Parliament tonight, and politicians predicted that the defeat would probably bring it down.   Prime Minister Bettino Craxi has been presiding over the longest-serving Italian Cabinet since World War II.   The loss in the Chamber of Deputies, by a margin of 293 to 266, came on a secret ballot vote on a local finance law. An exceptionally large number of members from the five governing parties abandoned party discipline to vote against the Government.

headline: 3 WEEKS LATER, 'THE CLOUD' STILL BOTHERS THE POLES
abstract: The Polish authorities, eager to dispel lingering fears about the effects of the Soviet nuclear reactor disaster, are finding that rumor and suspicion have longer half-lives then radioactive iodine.   Three weeks after the Chernobyl accident, ''the cloud'' remains the major topic of casual conversation and streams of unsubstantiated gossip have warned of contaminated water, dangerous eggs, suspicious milk and mysterious yellow powder from the skies.   Meantime, the underground Solidarity movement has called for protests against the building of Poland's first nuclear power plant. And as so often has been the case in this country, impotent anger is being vented through bitter jokes.

headline: AFRICANS UNHAPPY ON REPLIES AT U.N. AID SESSION
abstract: Many African delegates expressed disappointment today at the failure of the industrialized donor countries to commit themselves to specific financial targets requested by African nations at the General Assembly special session on the African economic crisis.   ''I am still waiting for a commitment, and I am not yet satisfied,'' said Foreign Minister William Eteki Mboumoua of the Cameroons. Another African official called positions outlined by the United States and Japan ''totally reactionary.''   In the first two days of speeches before the five-day session, officials from donor countries, including the United States, Japan, Britain, France and West Germany, praised Africa's willingness to develop free markets and encourage individual initiative.

headline: Advertising; Pepsi's Humorous Approach
abstract: BECAUSE Philip B. Dusenberry has gotten to feel very close to the Coca-Cola Company over the years as the leading creative force at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Pepsi-Cola's agency, he is particularly pleased that the agency has not overlooked the older soft drink company's 100th anniversary.   There is in the current pool of Pepsi commercials a spot that Mr. Dusenberry considers a Coca-Cola birthday offering. It is called ''Time Machine.'' Here's the plot. Two scientists in the lab are about to send a third chap - properly garbed for the period -100 years back in time and are cautioning him to take absolutely nothing with him that might alter the course of history.

headline: U.S. OFFERS TO HELP SOVIET IN DEALING WITH ACCIDENT
abstract: The United States formally offered humanitarian and technical assistance to the Soviet Union today to help it deal with the nuclear accident near Kiev.   A State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said the offer was extended by Rozanne L. Ridgway, Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, in a meeting with Oleg M. Sokolov, the charge d'affaires of the Soviet Embassy. Mr. Redman said she also urged the Soviet Union to make available more information about the incident.   The meeting preceded a Soviet Government statement that said two people had died and that the ''radiation situation'' had been ''stabilized.''   The White House decided overnight to set up an interagency task force headed by the Environmental Protection Agency to coordinate the American response to the disaster at the Chernobyl station.

headline: WHAT'S NEW WITH THE YELLOW PAGES
abstract: ''MY fingers have better things to do than to walk through two books,'' says a guitar-strumming B. B. King in radio ads for the yellow-page directory Southwestern Bell will introduce in Manhattan in November.   Another classified phone directory in New York would serve no purposes other than to ''build upper body strength'' for the sales representatives lugging it around, retorts a Schwarzenegger-esque workout instructor in Nynex's local TV ads.   Competition for the $2 billion to $3 billion that yellow pages advertising has historically commanded is growing hot and heavy in the New York area. And the one-tome-versus-two issue is not the only one in hot dispute. There is also a battle of names and slogans.

headline: PARAGUAYAN POLICE BEAT EXILE
abstract: The police today beat up an exiled opposition leader and a former United States Ambassador who was escorting him off a plane here, witnesses said.   The opposition leader, Domingo Laino, was making his fifth attempt to return.

headline: Report Urges Increase In Natural Gas Supplies
abstract: Western industrial countries must develop new natural gas supplies to match increasing demand, the International Energy Agency said in a report scheduled to be released Monday.   Gas demand was expected to rise at a rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent to 1.3 percent a year from 1984 to 2010, the report said, an estimate based on the assumption that oil prices would fall from 1985 levels but then pick up again in the 1990's.   The report predicted that this increase would be slightly less than the rise in total energy demand.
